title: NO THREE-WHEELER FARE REDUCTION
author: Author not found
Content: The National Joint Three-Wheeler Drivers’ and Industrial Workers’ Association said a three-wheeler fare reduction cannot be considered even after the fuel price revision at midnight on Sunday (30 April). Association Secretary of the association Rohana Perera said reducing the Octane 92 price by seven rupees per litre would not affect taxi fares. “A three-wheeler runs 25 km per litre. With this seven-rupee revision, the cost of a kilometre will be 28 cents. Therefore, the petrol price revision cannot be used to make a fare revision at this time. It is true that the cost of living is decreasing and the prices of three-wheeler spare parts and oil have also come down,” he added. Perera claimed that they are still getting eight litres of petrol in the weekly quota and on the remaining days the drivers have to get fuel through various illegal methods. “We are facing a critical situation when getting petrol,” he said. Therefore, it is not possible to reduce the three-wheeler fares at this time, Perera said.  He also advised his fellow drivers to get registered with the Western Provincial Council and the Ministry of Power and Energy, so they get 15 litres of diesel per week, legally. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: James Taylor envisioned the potential of tea as a plantation crop
author: Author not found
Content: The vision of James Taylor regarding the enormous potential of tea as a plantation crop, the difficult conditions under which he worked, the manner in the perfected the art of the manufacture and the dedication of his entire life to the plantation tea industry to the extent of staying a bachelor all his life are legendary among tea planters of Sri Lanka. The commemoration of 131st death anniversary of James Taylor is therefore of a great significance to the plantation industry. Even after 131 years there are many lessons to be learnt from the life and deeds of this pioneer tea planter not only for planters but for all professed entrepreneurs. In the colossal and economically crucial period of time, for the tea industry, which we see today, I hope this message will give those who are associated with tea industry an insight of James Taylor’s dedication to his assignment and will remind us that it is up us to improve and consolidate the tea industry established over 155 years ago, as an industrial beacon to be reckoned with among, tea producing countries. It is therefore, not only a duty but an obligation on our part as the beneficiaries of Taylor to remember this great pioneer at least when his 131st death anniversary is commemorated. According to the record of burials available at Mahaiyawa Cemetery, Kandy, James Taylor of Loolecondera Estate, Ceylon the pioneer of the tea and Cinchona Enterprises in this Island, died on 2 May 1892 at the age of 57 years. All concerned with the wellbeing of the industry, hope and pray that the management companies will show the intrepidness and foresight of the Founding Father in managing the estates, which is under their purview ensure the stability and growth of the industry. In this account of the late James Taylor, I may have omitted other important factors in relation to this great man but the fact remains that as a Nation we should be grateful to the pioneer who brought the great tea industry to Ceylon on a commercial basis and we largely depend on this for employment and foreign exchange to the present day. We pray that he may be rewarded suitably in his place of rest. Lalin I De Silva, former Senior Planter, Agricultural Adviser / Consultant, former Secretary General of Ceylon Planters Society and Editor of CPS Bulleting and free lance juornelist. By. Lalin I De Silva.

title: Navy arrest two with Kendu leaves
author: Author not found
Content: Navy takes hold of over 836kg of smuggled Kendu leaves in Kalpitiya on 30 April and, yesterday (1) during separate operations carried out off Paramunai and Kudawa beach. The search operations also led to the seizing of a dinghy and the arrest of two suspects. Initially, as a result of these efforts, SLNS Vijaya, belonging to the Northwestern Naval Command, intercepted a suspicious dinghy, during a search conducted off Paramunai in the night of 30 April.  When searched, the Navy recovered 17 sacks of Kendu leaves weighing about 550.75kg and took them into custody along with the dinghy and two suspects involved in the racket. Meanwhile, SLNS Vijaya also recovered about 286.2 kg of smuggled Kendu leaves, in nine sacks, from the Kudawa beach, during a search carried out in the area, yesterday (1) morning.  The suspects held are residents of Anawasala in Kalpitiya, aged 18 and 23. The accused along with the total consignment of Kendu leaves and the dinghy were handed over to the Customs Preventive Office in Katunayake for legal action. (SS)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Govt should bring in lawsto curb Uni teachers’ strikes
author: Author not found
Content: The Government should introduce necessary Parliamentary Acts to ensure that the University Teachers’ strike which has also affected the marking of GCE Advanced Level Papers, does not continue to hamper the lives of students who have completed that exam, the Government Medical Officers’ Forum (GMOF) said. GMOF President Dr. Rukshan Bellana yesterday (1) urged the government to ensure that the freedom given to University dons to cause an upheaval in the lives of students who had sat their A/L s and those who are to sit the GCE Ordinary Level Examination and their parents with their behavior is curbed. “These parents have suffered with their children for the past 13 years spending colossal sums of money on their education only to have University teachers with vested interests holding their entire future to ransom,” he lashed out. These lecturers have not learnt to correct GCE A/L papers overnight but have gone through workshops conducted to specially train them on A/L paper marking and have not been endowed with the capability with their doctorates. He urged the government to have those workshops for doctors as they were prepared to take up the task and put the innocent children and their parents out of the agony of having their lives disrupted and delayed from moving ahead. There are 25,000 doctors who have obtained best A/L results. Of them at least 500 to 600 had their masters in ‘information technology (IT),’ another 700 or so have qualified in ‘management’, another 700 have qualified in ‘law’ while another 700 or more have doctorates in Health Economics and there are another 2,500 who have doctorates in their own field. He observed that there were another 1,000 non specialists who also had the proficiency in languages and Arts subjects. “Unfortunately, the university academics tasked with the duty have taken on more of a political agenda, like they did in 2014, when they resorted to a similar campaign demanding a six per cent budgetary allocation for education in order to bring former President Maithripala Sirisena to power. However, they seemed to have forgotten this demand after the election. Once more they are on a mission. Therefore, something should be done about replacing them,” the GMOF President said. “A country like Russia, Cuba or even China would not have tolerated such acts of sabotage, where persons engaged in them would have been executed. In countries like China and North Korea such behavior, which infringes on the freedom of others would be a punishable offence. We have seen how corruption has been dealt with in those countries,” the GMOF President said adding that being a democratic country, Sri Lanka was far more tolerant. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: NP’s PTEA holds a low key May Day rally
author: Author not found
Content: A vehicle parade marking May Day was held in Jaffna yesterday (1). It was organised by the Northern Province Private Trade Employees’ Association. Workers on motorcycles and in three-wheelers, carrying red flags, paraded from the Jaffna District Secretariat at 8.30 a.m. to Kasthuriyar Road in Jaffna. But it was a low-key event with few workers on the road. Many commercial establishments in Jaffna were closed. Despite the fact that there were a large number of Police officers on the streets, only a few people joined the procession. By T. Pratheepan – Jaffna

title: Value-added rubber export makesUSD 20M loss
author: Author not found
Content: The value-added rubber export sector saw a 10% revenue decline in the first three months of 2023, falling from USD 251 million to USD 231 million, according to the Sri Lanka Association of Manufacturers and Exporters of Rubber Products (SLAMERP). The downward trend started in 2022, when revenue dropped by almost 20% from USD 1.2 billion in 2021 to USD 1 billion by the end of the year. Due to the sharp decline in both domestic and international demand, many factories have reduced production capacity or are temporarily closing. The forward order books have also decreased significantly. Although input costs have decreased as well, buyers continue to request price cuts in order to place new orders, according to SLAMERP Director General Rohan Masakorala. He added that while the US experienced a stagnant first quarter of 2023, Europe had a sharp decline in orders. On the global front, the demand is coming down due to high inventory with buyers and also the recessionary pressures linked to inflation and interest rate hikes which are affecting the total global supply chain.  SLAMERP also expressed concern that the only positive factor they had was the global freight which peaked in the last two years, was coming down due to market forces, but locally the shipping ministry has taken decisions to artificially inflate freight rates by allowing un-bundling of the freight, to avoid market forces, by removing a competition gazette that was originally introduced in 2013. SLAMERP said that they are confident that President Ranil Wickremesinghe, whom they have spoken to, will fix this issue. The industry also said that the government must focus on supporting the export industry to grow, encourage new export diversification and ensure that the national export strategy is implemented along with the rubber master plan, which had been neglected. The country’s economic problems have to be resolved by strengthening the export sector with every possible support extended by all line ministries, the Director General emphasised. (SRM)

title: India’s Air Force CAS here
author: Author not found
Content: Chief of Air Staff (CAS), Indian Air Force Air Chief Marshal V.R .Chaudhari, PVSM, AVSM, VM, ADC, arrived at Bandaranaike International Airport on 1 May 2023 on a four-day official visit to Sri Lanka at the invitation of Air Marshal Sudarshana Pathirana, Commander of Sri Lanka Air Force. Chief of Staff, Sri Lanka Air Force Air Vice Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa and Deputy High Commissioner of India, Vinod K. Jacob warmly welcomed Air Chief Marshal Chaudhari on his arrival. During the visit, Air Chief Marshal Chaudhari is scheduled to make courtesy calls on President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena and have meetings with State Minister of Defence, Defence Secretary, Chief of Defence Staff and Service Commanders. The visit symbolises strong relations and close cooperation between the two friendly neighbours, with Sri Lanka being accorded the status of ‘Priority One’ partner by India. Underlining the strong bonds of friendship between the two services,  Air Chief Marshal Chaudhari would be laying the foundation stone for India- Sri Lanka Friendship Auditorium at Sri Lanka Air Force Academy, Trincomalee under Rs 250 Million grant assistance by the Government of India (GOI), in line with India’s ‘Neighbourhood First’ policy, the Indian High Commission in Colombo announced. As part of GOI’s commitment towards capacity building of Sri Lanka Armed Forces, Chief of Air Staff of the Indian Air Force would be presenting AN-32 propellers to ensure high operational readiness of the aircraft held with Sri Lanka Air Force. He would also be interacting with students at the prestigious National Defence College, Sri Lanka and the Air Force Academy, China Bay, wherein training aids for the students would be gifted. In February 2021, at the invitation of SLAF Commander, a 22 Aircraft contingent of the Indian Air Force participated in the 70th Anniversary celebrations of Sri Lanka Air Force. In addition, the Indian Air Force has been the first responder by deploying its assets expeditiously for providing 12T medical supplies in May 2020 and 100T Nano Fertilisers in November 2021.The visit of Chief of Air Staff, Indian Air Force would strengthen the existing relations between the two countries and facilitate discussions on common security challenges and enhancing capacity and capability building initiatives towards ensuring Security And Growth for All in the Region (SAGAR), as propounded by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, it was further stated.

title: Vadivel demands apology from Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Jathika Estate Workers’ Union General Secretary Vadivel Suresh yesterday (1) demanded that Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa apologise to the residents of Madulsima, in the Badulla District, for not attending a recent meeting and warned he would no longer be a part of Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) if Premadasa failed to do so. Addressing a May Day rally in the upcountry, Suresh said he was cautioning SJB Leader Premadasa to not take the people of the upcountry for granted. “He skipped the meeting in Madulsima recently. If he doesn’t come here and apologise to the people who expected him, I won’t be a part of the SJB,” he stressed. Furthermore, he said there is constant discussion about a national policy, and that in such discussions, the upcountry plantation sector should not be left out because they are also citizens of Sri Lanka. Also, if a national plan is formed, they should be included without any discrimination, he insisted adding that the plantation workers also deserve all the rights enjoyed by Sri Lankans. “Our people are not terrorists or those involved in terrorist activities. They have not been involved in any violence in the country. Why should those who have worked to make the country a better place, be overlooked? They are still landless. Our people have no food to eat and no safe place to live. When people are suffering like this, the party and its symbol are irrelevant to me,” he stated. He also stated that during the economic current crisis, each worker in the plantation sector should be paid at least Rs 3,250 per day. “This is assessed by University of Peradeniya. The President of the country should ensure that all regional Plantation companies pay that sum,” he said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SL, B’desh and Maldives sign Trilateral MoU on Maritime Cooperation
author: Author not found
Content: Factum Sri Lanka, an Asia-Pacific focused think-tank on foreign policy, in partnership with The Bangladesh Institute of Peace and Security Studies (BIPSS) and The Baani Centre for International Policy, Maldives, held a Trilateral Dialogue, on Maritime Cooperation in the Indian Ocean, in Colombo on 30 April 2023. The Dialogue was held in the backdrop of the Indian Ocean – The Ocean of the 21st Century’s significant big power contestations and focused on how small, island, and littoral states in South Asia can position themselves as hubs for cooperation in several areas, such maritime infrastructure, dealing with maritime disasters, climate resilience, and economy and trade. A panel discussion chaired by Ambassador Pamela Jayasekera Deen featured the President of BIPSS Major General Muniruzzaman, Rear Admiral (Retd) Y. N. Jayarathna and Co-Founder of The Baani Centre Thoriq Hamid. ‘’The biggest problem for South Asia is the absence of maritime security architecture for the region,” noted Major General Muniruzzaman of BIPSS. ‘’The Indian Ocean region is a center of gravity in international politics. 70% of energy resources and 80% of global oil supplies are transported through the Indian Ocean,’’ he added.  There is a need to build capacity around marine spatial planning, observed former Chief Hydrographer Rear Admiral (Retd) Y.N. Jayarathna. ‘’Maritime security infrastructure and surveillance must be improved,’’ he explained, noting that ‘’in the last five years maritime tracking systems have improved significantly in Sri Lanka.’’ ‘’Potential oil spills, illegal fishing, narcotics trafficking, and terrorism are key concerns for the Maldives,’’ noted Thoriq Hamid. ‘’Climate threats for a country like the Maldives, which is home to 99% ocean and 1% land, is something we cannot afford not to worry about,’’ he added. The Dialogue which resulted in a 6-point Declaration was attended by defence officials, diplomats, foreign policy analysts, academics, civil society, and youth, who urged transforming the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace and denuclearisation. Factum, BIPSS, and Baani also signed a Trilateral Memorandum of Understanding to sustain thematic cooperation and pursue measures of mutual benefit for the Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, and the Maldives. By Uditha Devapriya

title: A Leader’s Connect, A Nation’s Voice – 100th Episodeof Mann Ki Baat in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: On the milestone occasion of the 100th episode of Mann Ki Baat, High Commission of India, Colombo hosted the live broadcast of the radio programme as it was aired worldwide on 30 April  2023 at the Swami Vivekananda Cultural Centre in Colombo. The 100th episode of Mann Ki Baat saw the Prime Minister recollecting the journey of the radio broadcast in its celebration of people’s participation and positivity. Prime Minister shared the transformative impact the programme has had by inspiring mass movements aimed at societal changes. The milestone episode revisited some of the popular stories on the themes of women empowerment, promotion of local handicrafts and nature preservation. It also featured a conversation between DG UNESCO and Prime Minister on the ways in which India is attempting to put culture and education at the top of the international agenda, especially in the context of holding the Presidency of G20. The live broadcast was followed by a Special Panel Discussion on the theme of ‘Mann Ki Baat: A Leader’s Connect, A Nation’s Voice’. The distinguished panelists comprised High Commissioner of India, Gopal Baglay, Chairman, Liberty Publishers (Pvt) Ltd & Derana Macro Entertainment (Pvt) Ltd  Dilith Jayaweera, Director of International Affairs at the Presidential Secretariat, Dinouk Colombage and Chairman of FCBkl.lk, Santosh Menon. The panelists discussed the platform’s ability to integrate the power of the individual for collective good. They underscored the value of emotional connect for effective communication. High Commissioner emphasised that the participatory approach of Mann Ki Baat brings people at the centre of India’s growth story. It provides a platform for sharing, learning and creating people’s movements to achieve national goals. The programme was attended by members of the Indian community, local dignitaries and friends of India in Sri Lanka. Mann Ki Baat is a monthly radio programme hosted by the Prime Minister of India, Shri Narendra Modi, where he interacts with citizens of India on various contemporary themes and issues. These include government policies and reforms, India’s cultural legacy and diversity, extraordinary achievements of citizens as well as global events of relevance, among others.

Factum, BIPSS, and Baani also signed a Trilateral Memorandum of Understanding to sustain thematic cooperation and pursue measures of mutual benefit for the Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, and the Maldives. By Uditha Devapriya

title: 14 Lankan evacuees arrive at BIA from Sudan
author: Author not found
Content: Fourteen Sri Lankans, residing in the Republic of the Sudan, who were evacuated due to the prevailing crisis, arrived at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) on Saturday (29). They were received by Director General of the Consular Division of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Sisira Senavirathne. Their evacuation was facilitated with the coordination of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the generous assistance of the Government of Saudi Arabia. The Embassies of Sri Lanka in Riyadh and Cairo and the Consulate General of Sri Lanka in Jeddah have been working with the authorities of the Royal Government of Saudi Arabia and the Government of India to evacuate the Sri Lankans living in Khartoum who had requested to be rescued. The High Commission of Sri Lanka in Nairobi and the Sri Lanka Embassy in Muscat also extended assistance in the evacuation process. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said it continues to monitor the situation in the Republic of the Sudan and remains ready to assist the Sri Lankan nationals who are still in the Republic of the Sudan if and when a request is made for repatriation.

title: SL on verge of devastating dengue epidemic
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka is on the verge of a devastating dengue epidemic with nearly 2,000 patients being reported weekly islandwide, the Health Entomologists’ Association (HEA) warns. According to HEA National Organiser Disnaka Dissanayake, immediate steps should be taken to control this situation. Dissanayake said State hospitals can only accommodate less than 600 patients at present, putting them under severe strain. According to the data received by the National Dengue Control Unit, nearly 28,500 dengue patients have been reported with 15 deaths by the end of April this year while 25 per cent of the patients are schoolchildren. About 62 per cent of total patients are aged 18-55, Dissanayake said. Speaking further, he said the Health Ministry is more focused on destroying mosquito breeding grounds and has overlooked fogging. More attention should be paid to fogging as a control method at present, he pointed out. Meanwhile, about 300 rat fever patients have been reported in the Ratnapura District since January this year. Consultant Community Physician in Galle District Dr. Amila Chandrasiri said rat fever is spreading rapidly in the district. By Mithun Jayawardena, Savani Sheashadhi and Farhan Nizaamdeen – Galle

title: ‘Ratmalane Kudu Anju’ to be repatriated soon
author: Author not found
Content: Steps are underway to bring notorious criminal Sinharage Saminda Silva alias ‘Ratmalane Kudu Anju’, who was arrested in France, to Sri Lanka within a month, a CID official said. Meanwhile, Public Security Minister Tiran Alles said ‘Kudu Anju’ will be repatriated to Sri Lanka like in the case of ‘Harak Kata’ and ‘Kudu Salindu’ who were repatriated from Madagascar.  ‘Kudu Anju’ was wanted for his involvement in multiple crimes including the murder of Dehiwala-Mount Lavinia Municipal Council member Ranjan de Silva, as well as large-scale drug trafficking. INTERPOL too had issued a Red Notice for the arrest of ‘Kudu Anju’. He was taken into custody by the French law enforcement authorities following a complaint filed by his wife over a personal dispute. BY Keerthi Mendis

title: Presidential Task Force to promote AI
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe instructed the Ministry of Technology to form a Presidential Task Force comprising Artificial Intelligence (AI) experts and prepare a concept paper to promote AI usage in the country. During a recent discussion at President’s Office, the President highlighted the potential of AI in various fields, including agriculture, education, health, fisheries, and industry. President said the annual contribution to Sri Lanka’s Gross National Income through computer and information technology is around USD 1.9 billion but, the financial contribution from AI technology is unknown. The President instructed officials to develop a system to track AI contributions and stressed the importance of taking prompt action to increase AI contribution to the Gross Domestic Product in the coming years. The President further said, “We have identified the modernisation of agriculture and fisheries, tourism, and improvement of supply centres as urgent areas for development in our economic reforms. Additionally, we have placed a greater focus on the technology industry. “As we see the world progressing with AI, it is crucial for Sri Lanka to focus on this technology and invest in it. The private sector needs to be involved in this initiative. “I called for this discussion today to seek your opinions on how we can proceed with this. How can we kick-start these programmes? What are the advantages and disadvantages of investing in AI? These are some of the issues I want to discuss with you. The Government plans to allocate Rs one billion for AI technology next year. To develop this technology in the country, we need to create an appropriate environment, which requires an institution and data. So, I am eager to hear your suggestions on how we can develop these programmes.” Speaking further, the President said the Government is aiming to create a digital economy and that it will require a lot of effort in the coming months. “Fortunately, the Government has already prepared the necessary plans. However, it is important to note that only 2,500 engineers are produced in our country annually. I have suggested that we should aim to produce at least 10,000 engineers to meet the demands of the digital age. When it comes to AI, we should take Singapore and India as role models. It is true that East Asia, South Korea, Japan, and China are making progress in AI but no country in West Asia has reached that stage yet. This presents a clear opportunity for us, and we must have strategies in place to implement this programme promptly. In order to achieve this, we should start by improving university research departments,” he added. During the discussion to integrate AI technology into the wider model of digitisation in Sri Lanka, the Minister of State for Technology Kanaka Herath and Secretary of the Ministry, Niranjan Gunawardena shared their views. The participants focused on the development of infrastructure necessary for related research activities and the latest trends in the field. Scholars who attended the discussion also expressed their views on future steps that are needed to be taken for the advancement of the field. Chandani Wijewardena, Senior Additional Secretary to the President for Strategic Affairs, along with representatives from the Sri Lanka Artificial Intelligence Association, universities, national innovation institutes, and experts in IT were among those who participated in the discussion.

title: 3,500 Police deployed for May Day rallies
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly 3,500 Police personnel would be deployed in Colombo today (1) for duty on May Day, Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said.  The Police media spokesman yesterday (30) said many political parties and trade unions were organising the May Day rallies today in several locations in Colombo. These parties were communicating with the Police on holding rallies in a peaceful manner without inconveniencing the public, he said.  SSP Thalduwa said May Day rally organisers agreed to use a single lane for the parades so that roads would not be blocked for normal vehicular movement. BY Amra Liyakath

title: SJB to take disciplinary action against Fowzie
author: Author not found
Content: Disciplinary actions will be taken against Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP A.H.M. Fowzie, who voted in favour of the International Monetary Fund’s (IMF) Extended Fund Facility (EFF) agreement in Parliament, SJB General Secretary Ranjith Maddumabandara said. He said the SJB took a collective decision not to vote in favour of the agreement, but Fowzie violated that decision. The debate on the IMF agreement was held in Parliament for three days, from 26 to 28 April. None of the SJB MPs, except Fowzie was in the Chamber when the vote took place. Fowzie was sworn in as an MP to fill the seat left vacant by SJB’s Colombo Mayoral candidate Mujibur Rahuman. BY Mithun Jayawardena

title: UGC to introduce two new degrees
author: Author not found
Content: Two new degree programmes will be introduced for students who enrol in the Faculty of Arts in State universities next year, University Grants Commission (UGC) Chairman Prof. Sampath Amaratunga said. In addition, to the Arts degree, students would also have the opportunity to obtain a degree in Technology and in Computer Science, Prof. Amaratunga said. The UGC Chairman said all investment needed for laboratories and providing relevant technology to complete the requirements relating to degrees in Technology and in Computer Science have been fulfilled at the moment. He said the Government had spent Rs 400 million last year for these facilities. He said presently, the unemployment situation is on the rise due to the passing out of a large number of students from a single stream. The world is moving with the latest technology and the university system should also follow accordingly. Consequently, the UGC had decided to offer two degrees, including Technology and Computer Science, along with the Arts degree, Prof. Amaratunga said.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: CAA seizes date-expired food flavouring
author: Author not found
Content: A stock of date-expired artificial flavours, used for flavouring food, was seized by the Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) from a shop at Technical Junction, Maradana. According to B.S.U.P. Perera, the CAA official in charge of the raid, both  date-expired and non-expired food have been distributed at this shop. A case will be filed against the shop owner this week. The raid has been carried out by the CAA’s investigations officers following a complaint over storage of  date-expired food items. The CAA observed that this stock of artificial flavours had passed their shelf life in the years 2020 and 2021. These date-expired flavours were used only in flavouring the food items but not to be sold in the shops, Perera said.

title: Govt should stepin to protect womenand children- CBK
author: Author not found
Content: Civil rights activists and NGOs cannot prevent the continuously increasing child and women abuse on their own. The Government should step in and assist those already involved in combating this menace, said former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga. She was speaking at the launch of ‘Chronicles of Melancholy’ true life stories of child abuse survivors, organised by Stop Child Cruelty Trust (SCC) and Child Protection Alliance recently. She alleged that responsible State institutions were not responding during some cases of child abuse and shared a firsthand experience where the relevant authorities had been very indolent. “I even made personal requests to the authorities requesting action to be taken  regarding the issue, but they did not accede to the request. Even a former President of the country cannot get support in a case of child abuse to save ordinary people. The Government should look into these issues and ensure the efficiency of these institutions,” she said. On a further note, she claimed that women are also victimised in society and  records of abuse and harassment on women have escalated during recent times. “Our society has become a very unsafe place for women. Numerous friends and relatives who visit Sri Lanka from foreign lands, claim our public transportation to be unsafe. They are intimidated by the behaviour of Sri Lankan men. Not only foreigners, evena local woman can’t travel alone these days. And domestic violence is on a high.” The former President expressed her displeasure over the way the Police were dealing with cases of sexual abuse. “Women are unsure of seeking help from the Police, because most Police Officers would end up embarrassing the victim  and sometimes even try to put the blame on the woman’s dress or find something else to blame it on” “There are several individuals and organisations like SCC and Child Protection Alliance that work against child and women abuse, and I personally work with most of them. I am ready to give any support to them in the future as well. But all our work is just a small drop in the ocean. We can’t progress further, unless the Government gives its fullest support,” she said. By Induwara Athapattu

title: Workers under undue pressure – JJB
author: Author not found
Content: The elite ruling class of Sri Lanka, under the guise of finding a solution to the economic crisis they created, declared bankruptcy through the Governor of the Central Bank, and now the elite rulers are resorting to State terror against the people, especially the working people, Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) in its May Day message said. “This year the working people of Sri Lanka are celebrating May Day at a time when many changes are taking place not only at national level but also at international level. The neo-liberal capitalist social economic system that dominated the world for forty-five years globally is eroding from its base. On the other hand, the challenge to that socio-economic agenda is emerging from the global South with Asia at its centre. Meanwhile, the elite ruling class of our country, under the guise of finding a solution to the economic crisis they created, declared bankruptcy through the Governor of the Central Bank. As a result, Sri Lanka has now been placed under the International Monetary Fund’s ‘Stabilisation’ and the World Bank’s ‘Structural Reforms’ programmes. According to the conditions of the IMF, State-owned properties are being sold, while oppressing the people’s voice. In order to suppress the rising protests of the people against implementation of these conditions, the elite rulers are resorting to State terror against the people, especially the working people. Right now, the Government is continuing to oppress the people curtailing social security programmes, cutting public facilities such as health and education. Working women and especially, workers in the informal sector are being burdened with high cost of living. Therefore, on May Day this year, all those who are suffering due to these evil acts of the Government, should endeavour to get organised to oppose these anti-people measures. Apart from this, the working community of Sri Lanka are celebrating this May Day, at a time when the common man is rallying round the JJB to find a solution to their problems after 75 years. The elite rulers, who are anxious about this, are postponing elections and showing the true colours of so-called neoliberal democracy. Therefore, at this time, the responsibility of establishing democracy too lies with the common people. It is imperative that allpro- democratic factions unite to oust the corrupt rulers and to establish a peoples’ government. Under these circumstances, the JJB is ready to celebrate International May Day with the working community and we extend our wishes to the people on this day,” the JJB said.

title: SEVERE SHORTAGE OF BLOODIN JAFFNABLOOD BANK
author: Author not found
Content: There is a severe shortage of blood at the Blood Bank of the Teaching Hospital, in Jaffna and the daily collection of blood through donations is not sufficient to meet the demand at the moment, hospital sources said. Speaking to Ceylon Today, a hospital spokesman said the blood bank should have at least 330 pints of blood in the blood bank but unfortunately there is just a 181 pints of blood in the blood bank right now. On a daily basis, the blood bank distributes 50 pints of blood for surgeries and to patients in need of blood. When compared with the daily blood requirement the daily blood collection is abysmally low, according to the official. He said even though the hospital is collecting blood conducting blood donation camps, however the daily collection is not sufficient to meet the demand.  As a result, the hospital made an open request to the public to donate blood. The hospital also requested organisations in the district to organise blood donation camps in their region. Those willing to donate blood could contact  the hospital on 0772105375. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: FSP May Day rally starts at Delkanda
author: Author not found
Content: May Day rally organised by Frontline Socialist Party (FSP) will kick off at 1.00 p.m. today (1) near the Delkanda fair This year’s FSP May Day celebration will be held under the theme of ‘Working force against IMF trap and Indian, American invasions’. The main event of the celebration will be held at the Ananda Samarakoon open air theatre at 3.00 p.m. “Last year the people were able to chase away a President who failed them miserably and led the country into an abyss. It was a wonderful moment in the entire Sri Lankan history. People needed a system change through ‘Aragalaya.’ There are many unfulfilled wishes of the people, specially working class, for a better country, a true system change. We are focusing on these aspects in our May Day celebrations,” Kumar Gunaratnam, Leader of FSP said. (MD)

title: 24-year-old nabbed with hashish worth Rs 800,000
author: Author not found
Content: A suspect with a parcel of hashish was arrested in Silawathura during a coordinated search operation conducted by the Sri Lanka Navy and Mannar Police recently. The suspect was arrested with 893g of hashish. The street value of the seized narcotics is believed to be aroundRs 800,000, according to the Navy. Through its constant vigilance and persistent efforts, the Sri Lanka Navy is making significant strides in eradicating the scourge of drugs from the country, a spokesman said. Based on information received by the Northwestern Naval Command, the combined operation was mounted by SLNS Therapuththa and Mannar Police in the Silawathura area on the evening of 27 April. Accordingly, a person in the area was interrogated on suspicion and a hashish parcel ready for sale was found in his possession. The suspect is a 24-year-old resident of the Silawathura area and was handed over to the Mannar Police. (NV)

title: FSP May Day rally starts at Delkanda
author: Author not found
Content: May Day rally organised by Frontline Socialist Party (FSP) will kick off at 1.00 p.m. today (1) near the Delkanda fair This year’s FSP May Day celebration will be held under the theme of ‘Working force against IMF trap and Indian, American invasions’. The main event of the celebration will be held at the Ananda Samarakoon open air theatre at 3.00 p.m. “Last year the people were able to chase away a President who failed them miserably and led the country into an abyss. It was a wonderful moment in the entire Sri Lankan history. People needed a system change through ‘Aragalaya.’ There are many unfulfilled wishes of the people, specially working class, for a better country, a true system change. We are focusing on these aspects in our May Day celebrations,” Kumar Gunaratnam, Leader of FSP said. (MD)

title: 24-year-old nabbed with hashish worth Rs 800,000
author: Author not found
Content: A suspect with a parcel of hashish was arrested in Silawathura during a coordinated search operation conducted by the Sri Lanka Navy and Mannar Police recently. The suspect was arrested with 893g of hashish. The street value of the seized narcotics is believed to be aroundRs 800,000, according to the Navy. Through its constant vigilance and persistent efforts, the Sri Lanka Navy is making significant strides in eradicating the scourge of drugs from the country, a spokesman said. Based on information received by the Northwestern Naval Command, the combined operation was mounted by SLNS Therapuththa and Mannar Police in the Silawathura area on the evening of 27 April. Accordingly, a person in the area was interrogated on suspicion and a hashish parcel ready for sale was found in his possession. The suspect is a 24-year-old resident of the Silawathura area and was handed over to the Mannar Police. (NV)

title: Game ends inno result due to rain
author: Author not found
Content: The first ODI between Sri Lanka and the visiting Bangladesh women’s team resulted in a no result due to rain at the P. Sara Oval stadium in Colombo on Saturday. Batting first, Sri Lanka were 152 for 6 in 36.4 overs at close with opener Chamari Atapattu unbeaten on 47 and Kavisha Dilhari unbeaten on 30 runs. Imesha Dulani and Kavya Kavindi, both from Devapathiraja College Rathgama, made their debut in the match. The two sides will meet today in the second ODI.   Sri Lanka: 152/6 (36.4 overs) (Chamari Atapattu 47*, Prasadani Weerakkody 24, Kavisha Dilhari 30*; Nahida Akter 3/24) vs Bangladesh

title: Exports shrink for sixthconsecutive month to March 2023
author: Author not found
Content: Exports contracted for the sixth consecutive month to last month (March 2023), Year-on-Year (YoY) due to import restrictions and/or ‘long’ procedural approvals for raw material imports needed to be processed for exports, Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) data from Friday (28 April) showed. Consequently, export earnings, YoY have been shrinking since October 2022. Due to the above malaise, exports last month shrank by two per cent Year-on-Year (YoY) to USD 1,037 million last month and export earnings in the first three months (first quarter) of the year contracted by 7.9 per cent YoY to USD 2,998 million. Garments, Sri Lanka’s single largest foreign exchange earner last year, saw export earnings YoY to last month decline by USD 10.7 per cent to USD 379.50 million and its fall in the first quarter of the year by USD 1,273 million. However, due to import restrictions, imports declined by 20.3 per cent YoY to USD 1,450 million last month and in the first quarter of the year (2023) by 31.7 per cent YoY to USD 3,859 million, resulting in the country suffering from trade deficits of USD 413 million and USD 861 million, last month and in the first quarter of this year, respectively. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Govt revenue up Rs 549B in 2022
author: Author not found
Content: Total Government revenue and grants aided by high taxes increased by 37.49 per cent (Rs 548.8 billion) to Rs 2,012.6 billion last year (2022), Year-on-Year (YoY), Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) data from Friday (28 April) showed. This increase was aided by tax revenue in the review period increasing by 34.91 per cent(Rs 453.1 billion) to Rs 1,751.1 billion. Tax revenue comprised 87.01 per cent of total Government revenue last year. In like developments, grant aid, 2022 over 2021, increased by 398.51 per cent (Rs 26.7 billion) to Rs 33.4 billion, data also showed. Further, non-tax revenue in the review period increased by 43.37 per cent (Rs 69 billion) to Rs 228.1 billion in 2022. In related developments, Government expenditure in the review period increased by 27.1 per cent (Rs 950.9 billion) to Rs 4,472.6 billion, CBSL statistics further showed. In this connection, the Government’s recurrent expenditure in the review period increased by 28.11 per cent (Rs 772.1 billion) to Rs 3,519.6 billion and the Government’s ‘capital expenditure minus repayments’ was up by 23.08 per cent (Rs 178.7 billion) to Rs 952.9 billion in the period under review, CBSL data also showed. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: COLOMBO HOUSEHOLD’S ELECTRICITY BILL UP BYRS 10,192 YOY IN APRIL-CSD
author: Author not found
Content: The electricity bill of a household in Colombo increased by Rs 10,192.10 year on year (YoY) this month (April 2023), Census and Statistics Department (CSD) data, released on Friday (28 April) showed. Subsequently a Colombo household’s living expenses rose by Rs46,169.37 YoYthis month, nonetheless decelerating for the first time after 24 months, CSD data further showed. Of this month’s Rs 46,169.37 YoY increase, the price of such a household’s food commodities bill increased by Rs12,929.09 YoY to this month and the increase in their non-food commodity bill accelerated to a record Rs 46,169.37 in absolute terms, compared to their previous month’s (March 2023) YoY increase of42,247.62, statistics further showed.  The main, YoY increase in such a family’s food bill this month was led by their milk powder bill increasing by Rs 1,887.34, fresh fruit led by plantains increasing by Rs 1,370.82 YoY to this month, sea fish by Rs 1,367.21, chicken (Rs 1,058.02), bread by Rs 568.96 and rice by (Rs 557.02).  Some of the main YoY non- food drivers of inflation this month were such a household’s electricity bill by increasing by  Rs 10,192.10 YoY, transport costs by Rs 6,445.47 YoYthis month,  clothing and footwear(Rs 1,940.19), furnishing, household equipment and routine household maintenance (Rs 1,759.78),  health(Rs 1,677.17), education (Rs 1,197.64),‘recreation and culture(Rs 999.62), communication expenses (Rs 823.08), ‘alcohol, tobacco and narcotics’ (Rs 746.41) and water bills (Rs 695.33). In related developments, vis-à-vis the Rs 6,445.47 YoY increase in transport costs of a household in Colombo, ncluded their petrol bill increasing by Rs 1,361.51 and   bus fare other than bus fare to go to school(Rs 678.66). Meanwhile,  Colombo inflation decelerated for the seventh consecutive month to last month after a 166-month hiatus to 35.3 per cent YoY aided by food inflation decelerating 30.6 per cent for the seventh consecutive month to this month and non-food inflationdecelerating to37.6per cent. Prior tothis month, the last time Colombo inflation decelerated for at least seven consecutive months was 166 months ago, where for a total of 12 consecutive months, ie from July 2008 to June 2009, YoY inflation decelerated from 26.6 per cent to 0.9 per cent, aided by the Global Financial Crisis and followed by the Great Recession, resulting in commodity prices, led by oil falling to near historic lows. Meanwhile, inflation in June 2008 was 28.2 per cent. Nonetheless, Colombo inflation has been in double digits for 17 consecutive months tothis month. Prior to this month, the last time Colombo inflation was  in double digits for at least 17 consecutive months was more than 14 years ago, where it was in double digits for 32 consecutive months, from June 2006 to January 2009. However, the current record high inflationary levels are due to multiple causes led by excessive money printing and record high rupee depreciation in the context that Sri Lanka is an import dependent economy, made worse by Sri Lanka stopping repaying its external debt in April 2022, due to a US dollar shortage, thereby closing the access to international markets for the country. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Severalfactions to vote against IMF’s EFF agreement
author: Author not found
Content: Several factions in Parliament will vote against the agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) on the Extended Fund Facility (EFF), granted to Sri Lanka, today (28), Ceylon Today learns. After a parliamentary debate of three days, the agreement will be taken for a vote today (28). The MPs who represent the recently formed Uththara Lanka Sabhagaya, Freedom People’s Alliance, will vote against the agreement. The Tamil National Alliance (TNA) and Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) too will vote against the agreement. However, the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) was unable to reach a decision regarding the vote as of yesterday (27) evening. SJB General Secretary Ranjith Maddumabandara said a final decision with regard to the matter will be taken today (28). Meanwhile, Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) Chairman Maithripala Sirisena said he would not be able to attend the vote as he has to leave Colombo due to unavoidable reason. In a statement, Sirisena said if there are unhealthy conditions for Sri Lanka in the agreement, such things can be resolved through discussions with relevant parties. However, the SLFP will also take a decision on voting today (28), SLFP General Secretary Dayasiri Jayasekara said. Sri Lanka Muslim Congress (SLMC) too will take a decision on voting today (28). BY Bingun Menaka Gamage, Lakshmi Jayakody, Savani Sheashadhi, Krishan Jayasuriya and Mithun Jayawardena

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Seven Covid-19 cases detected
author: Author not found
Content: Amidst the increase observed in the number of influenza and dengue cases being reported, the Covid-19 statistics, given by the Government Information Department (GID), show that on Wednesday (26) a total of seven cases have been diagnosed with the corona virus.    The GID, in its latest update has shown that with the seven cases, the total number of Covid -19 patients detected from Sri Lanka, had increased to 67,2150. The Department also noted that on Tuesday (25), four new cases of Covid-19 had been detected in the country. Medical teams have continuously urged the public to maintain safe health practices when moving in crowded areas and travelling in public transport. Although a large number of the public have let their guard down it would be advisable to wear a mask, maintain hand hygiene and sneezing etiquette by using ones elbow to cover the nose and mouth when sneezing. According to health sources from Jaffna, a total six cases with the viral infection had been detected from the Jaffna District on 18 April 2023. They said the patients had been oxygen dependent. However, Director of Teaching Hospital Jaffna Dr. T. Sathiyamoorthy, when contacted, said three patients had been diagnosed with the virus. Patients were tested for Covid only if the physician suspected them to be infected with the virus. There are several other infections which have similar symptoms that were also doing their round in Jaffna, he noted.  Acting Epidemiology Chief Dr. Samitha Ginige said however that there was no evidence to prove that there was an increase in the viral infection, when the numbers were fluctuating. There have been days when only two fresh cases have been diagnosed with the disease. Covid -19 has claimed the lives of 16,808 in Sri Lanka up to now. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Navy presents three CATVs to President
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy Marine Corps presented three special Combat All-Terrain Vehicles (CATVs) to President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (27). The CATVs were produced locally by Ideal Motor Company and are a part of the new concept of the Sri Lanka Navy Marine Corps to combat illegal activities, terrorist activities, and various smuggling activities along the coast of Sri Lanka. The CATVs will be used to combat various illegal activities and drug trafficking in Colombo and Mannar areas. They are currently in the custody of the Sri Lanka Navy, and their operation was demonstrated for the President during the presentation. The event was attended by Senior Advisor to the President on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayake, Navy Commander Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, Navy Deputy Chief of Staff and Director General Operations Rear Admiral Pradeep Ratnayake, Director of the Marine Corps Commodore Sanath Pitigala and other senior officers. Chairman of Ideal Motors Ceylon Private Ltd Naleen J. Welgama and several others were also in attendance.

title: Paper shortage hits State hospitals
author: Author not found
Content: Several hospitals, including some of the specialised large hospitals, were having difficulties due to a shortage of paper even to document the details of patients, Ceylon Today reliably learns. Informed sources yesterday (27) said all State hospitals, including large hospitals like Apeksha Hospital in Maharagama, too, were feeling the pangs of not just the issues related to medicinal drugs but writing paper as well. Currently, old stocks were available but some ward doctors have to utilise available rough and any other available paper to write case details of each patient owing to the paper shortage and not the paper meant for the purpose. They also called for an investigation into the death of the seven-year-old child in Gampola, as a result of an overdose of paracetamol, adding one cannot think of what the situation might be in the peripheries if even the large State hospitals were facing such issues. The death occurred at Gampola Kurunduwatte Divisional Hospital. It was revealed that owing to a shortage of prescription envelopes, medicines are dispensed in old electricity bills or paper chits. Owing to an influx of patients, certain generic medications such as paracetamol have already been wrapped and kept, with the recommended dose written on the inside of the paper. As a result, paracetamol issued for the child had also been given from one such pre-prepared stock, in which the dosage usually prescribed for adults was written on the inside. Despite the recommended dosage for the seven-year-old having been written on the outside of the relevant packaging, the parents of the child had failed to see this and they had administered the drug at a dosage much higher than that usually prescribed for children, resulting in the child’s death. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Unique mobile phone ringtone as tsunami warning
author: Author not found
Content: A unique mobile ringtone will be introduced to alert the public of possible tsunami threats, Assistant Director of Media and Public Relations of DMC Janaka Handunpathiraja said yesterday (27). He said that as more than 90 per cent of people in the country have mobile phones, alerting them of possible tsunami threats through a ringtone would be an easy task and it would help to reach more people simultaneously, without incurring any expense and wasting the resources or time. Director General (DG) of DMC Retired Major General Sudantha Ranasinghe is currently working jointly with the telecommunication service providers to introduce this system as soon as possible, according to the Assistant Director. “As many people will be asleep between 1.00 a.m. and 4.00 a.m. a system will be set up to ring all mobile phones if a tsunami warning is received,” he said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: SL regretsU.S. blacklisting Karannagoda
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka regrets the decision by the US to designate Admiral of the Fleet Wasantha Karannagoda, the present Governor of the North Western Province, on 26 April 2023, Foreign Minister Ali Sabry said. Ali Sabry expressed Sri Lanka’s grave concerns associated with this decision to the US Ambassador Julie Chung yesterday (27). “As a longstanding bilateral partner of Sri Lanka, such unilateral action by the US, without following due process, is counter-productive to the holistic approach that Sri Lanka has taken on addressing national unity and reconciliation. It is also unfortunate that the announcement emanates against the backdrop of tangible progress made by the Government in strengthening the country’s democratic governance and reconciliation structures. Despite these challenges, Sri Lanka will continue in its on-going efforts to achieve reconciliation, economic recovery and socio-economic development,” the Minister said. The US designated Karannagoda, pursuant to Section 7031(c) of the Department of State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 2023, due to his alleged involvement in a gross violation of human rights during his tenure as a Naval Commander, the US State Department said, in a statement posted on its website on Wednesday (26). The statement quoting US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken said, “As a result of today’s action, Karannagoda and his wife, Srimathi Ashoka Karannagoda, are ineligible for entry into the United States. “The allegation that Wasantha Karannagoda committed a gross human rights violation, documented by NGOs and independent investigations, is serious and credible.  By designating Wasantha Karannagoda, the United States reaffirms its commitment to upholding human rights, ending impunity for human rights violators, acknowledging the suffering of victims and survivors, and romoting accountability for perpetrators in Sri Lanka.”

title: IGP tells COPA 2,419 WPC vacancies remain
author: Author not found
Content: There are 2,419 vacancies for Woman Police Constable (WPC) and although it was proposed to complete the said vacancies in 2023, it could not be done due to the current economic situation, IGP Chandana Wickramaratne told the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA). The IGP made this revelation when the Sri Lanka Police was summoned before the COPA recently. The IGP said the conventional context within the Police Department has been changed and the necessary reform programme has been initiated to provide opportunities for women to higher positions, including the post of IGP, in the future. He said as a result, an opportunity will be provided for the emergence of a future female Inspector General of Police. Special attention was also paid to the need to improve the language skills of Police Officers. Senior Police Officers pointed out that many programmes have been started to impart Tamil and English language skills to Police Officers. The Committee emphasised the need to streamline those activities. Issues related to Police promotions, Police reward fund management, road accident control, crime control and other problems and their solutions were also discussed here. The IGP also told the committee that a new pilot project is currently being implemented in Hatton and Nuwara Eliya Police Stations, where details can be obtained from the filing of a complaint to the status of its Court proceedings. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: BASL to challenge ATB
author: Author not found
Content: The Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) warned that they would take legal action to challenge the Anti-Terrorism Bill (ATB), if it is placed in the Order Paper of Parliament in its current form. This follows the observations made by a special committee, appointed by BASL to review the Bill, according to which the Bill violates Fundamental Rights enshrined in the Constitution. The committee noted that clauses 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 16, 28, 30, 31, 36, 82, 83, 84, 85 and 86 of the Bill infringe upon the principles of the criminal justice system and contravene the legal rights of the citizens. The BASL will also be making representations to the Ministry of Justice and all other stakeholders, requesting for amendments to be made to the Bill in compliance with law. (FT)

title: Anti-Corruption Bill tabledin Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: The Anti-Corruption Bill was tabled in Parliament by Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe yesterday (27). The Bill was proposed as a part of the Government’s commitments to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) agreements to resolve the economic crisis in the country. According to the Government the new legislation is to give effect to certain provisions of the United Nations Convention against Corruption and other internationally recognised norms, standards and best practice. According to the Bill the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) is given powers, as stated above, when it comes to matters falling under agreements or arrangements to Sri Lanka and other foreign countries. The commission therefore is given the power to enter into agreements or arrangements with an institution of a foreign nation or with an international organisation or body of persons established by an overseas Government or a State or with a foreign law enforcement agency. CIABOC members are appointed by the President on the recommendations of the Constitutional Council Also, as per the Bill the President, Prime Minister, Cabinet of Ministers, MPs, Provincial Council members, members of local bodies, State officials, including the senior officers of the Central Bank and even the members of Constitutional Council, are made liable to declare their assets and liabilities and the assets and liabilities of their wives and children. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Expat workers’duty-free allowance increased
author: Author not found
Content: The duty-free allowance given to Sri Lankan expatriate workers at the airport will be increased from 1 May and the circular in this connection has been issued, Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara said yesterday (27). Nanayakkara, addressing a media briefing, said his Cabinet proposal to increase the duty-free allowance given to expatriate workers at the airport, was approved and the circular was issued after that. As per the circular, expatriate workers who legally send money to Sri Lanka, through the banking system, are eligible to receive an increased duty-free allowance. The amount of money sent through the banking system, since the first of May last year, will be taken into account and this concession will be given under five categories. Accordingly, the workers who have sent between USD 2,400 and 4,799 will get an additional duty-free allowance of USD 600 and workers who have remitted between USD 4,800 and 7,199 will get an additional allowance of USD 960.  Workers who have sent between USD 7,200 and USD 11,999 will receive an additional duty-free allowance of USD 1,440. Expatriate workers who have remitted between USD 12,000 – USD 23,999 can get USD 2,400 and workers who have sent USD 24,000 or more can get an additional USD 4,800 duty-free allowance. Nanayakkara said, “It is very important to direct the workers for foreign jobs and it is equally important to bring the money they earn to the country through legal channels. We have worked hard for that in the past. At a time when the amount of remittances received from expatriate workers had dropped to 190 million dollars, when some went to other countries and told workers not to send money to the country, and while some chose illegal methods such as undiyal to send money, we implemented several measures to rectify these issues. After understanding how the people of our country were suffering, our expatriate workers once again started sending money to the country through the banking system. Several programmes were implemented to bring money to the country through safe and legal channels.” According to the minister, an import license was introduced for migrant workers to import electric vehicles. We have also arranged to provide duty concessions to expatriate workers. Accordingly, the circular was issued to increase the duty-free allowance for expatriate workers at the airport. “As per the circular, the increase in the duty-free allowance for expatriate workers at the airport will be implemented from the first of May. The facility is available through an App operated by the Central Bank. By registering through this App, it is possible to get an additional duty-free allowance based on the amount of dollars sent to the country. Last week, Cabinet approval was obtained to introduce a low-interest loan system for expatriate workers. Accordingly, expatriate workers can get loan facilities up to two million rupees. Also, the President presented his observations to the Cabinet and informed the Cabinet that a programme should be implemented for the workers who have returned to this country after working abroad,” he said. Furthermore, Nanayakkara said some time back, expatriate workers were called heroes of the country. “Then during the Corona period, they were treated as human bombs. False information was circulated that expatriate workers returning to the country will put the country in peril during the covid pandemic. They were mistreated and embezzled during quarantine. Against this backdrop, the initiatives taken by the new government gave the expatriate workers new hope and the foreign remittances started flowing again through legal channels,” he said.

title: Expressway fares upped
author: Author not found
Content: A Gazette Notification was issued yesterday (27), by the Ministry of Transportation, revising the fares of all expressways. As per the Gazette Notification, expressway tolls will be increased by 25 per cent and fares will be increased from Rs 50 onwards.  Accordingly, from Kottawa to Katunayake the toll will be Rs 400 while from Katunayake to Hambantota Rs 1,300 and Kottawa to Galle Rs 500. (NV)

title: New Electronic Broadcasting Authority Bill soon
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Mass Media Bandula Gunawardena said yesterday (27) that a new Electronic Broadcasting Authority Bill will be introduced soon to prepare a standard procedure in granting licences. A Cabinet sub-committee has already been formed to prepare the draft legislation, he said. Gunawardena said there are serious questions with regard to the procedure to grant licences for TV and radio channels. Speaking in Parliament, the Minister said there have been serious discrepancies in granting licences to all 25 TV channels and 51 radio channels as a result of the absence of a standard procedure in granting licences. In response to a question raised by Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Gayantha Karunatileka, the Minister said after preparing the draft Bill, the Government will hold discussions with the media institutions before preparing the final draft. BY Methmalie Dissanayake
