title: CBSL Annual Report 2022 handed over to the President
author: Author not found
Content: The Annual Report of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) 2022 was presented by Central Bank Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe to President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the Ministry of Finance yesterday (27). Presented as the 73rd Annual Report of the CBSL, this report consists of four main parts. Accordingly, the first part consists of eight chapters and 30 sub-chapters explaining the state of the economic affairs of the year, while the second part consists of a collection of gazettes and circulars related to various policy measures taken by the Government and the CBSL. The third part of this report explains the departments of the CBSL and their related roles and the fourth part includes a list of laws and ordinances related to the banking system connected to the Government and the CBSL. In accordance with Section 35 of the Monetary Law Act, the Monetary Board of the CBSL is required to produce an annual report on the economic conditions and the policies taken for that year and submit it to the Minister of Finance within four months after the end of the relevant year. Secretary of the Ministry of Finance Mahinda Siriwardana, Director of the Economic Research Department of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka Dr. P.K.G. Harishchandra, Additional Directors of Economic Research Dr. S. Jegajeevan and Dr. L. R. C. Pathberiya participated in this event. The 2022 annual report of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka can be accessed through the CBSL website.

title: PHIs seize date expired drinks
author: Author not found
Content: Over 1,800 bottles of soft drinks, which had been released to the market with altered expiry dates, were seized by PHIs in Jaffna on Wednesday (26). The alteration of expiry dates on certain popular soft drinks, has been carried out at a warehouse in Jaffna prior to releasing it to the market. These were discovered following an inspection, after a customer in Jaffna noticed something unusual in a bottle of drink and notified the public health inspectors of the Jaffna Municipality about it. Public Health Inspectors of the Jaffna Municipality have taken steps to take legal action against the owner of the warehouse. By Rasadi Chathurangi Gamage- Vavuniya

title: Motorcyclist dies in mishap
author: Author not found
Content: A 22-year-old died in a road accident on Wednesday (26) when he lost control of the motorbike he was riding and crashed into the boundary stones along the Pottuvil-Panama road. The biker who sustained severe injuries was admitted to the Pottuvil Hospital, however was pronounced dead upon admission. The deceased was a resident of Pottuvil. The Pottuvil Police are conducting investigations. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: All liquor sales outlets closed for three days
author: Author not found
Content: All licenced wine stores and liquor sales outlets across Sri Lanka will be closed for three days next week in view of the Vesak festival, the Department of Excise announced.Accordingly, all licenced liquor outlets or retail outlets will be closed from 4 – 6 May.  The Department warned that stringent action will be taken against those failing to close down during the said period.

title: Dengue on the rise in Batticaloa
author: Author not found
Content: Dengue cases are on the rise in the Manmunai North, Kattankudy and Valaichchenai Central Medical Officer of Health (MOH) Divisions, in the Batticaloa District, Regional Director of Health Services (RDHS) Batticaloa District Dr. G. Sugunan said on Wednesday (26). Dr. Sugunan said between the period beginning 1 January to 25 April this year, 700 Dengue cases and one death had been reported from these MOH divisions. A special Dengue eradication programme is currently underway across the District, he added. Stringent legal action will be taken against those not supportive and who are keeping their residences and surroundings unclean, thus encouraging the breeding of the aedes aegypti mosquito responsible for the Dengue menace, Dr. Sugunan said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Parents protest teacher’s transfer
author: Author not found
Content: A group of parents protested in front of the Semmannodai Al Hamra School against the transfer of a teacher. Those who gathered in front of the school last morning (27), held placards with slogans and protested against such transfer. The teacher who was teaching students appearing for the grade five scholarship examination has been transferred to another school. The protesting parents observed that the said teacher was teaching for the past four months and that such transfer with six months remaining for the examination could affect the students and called for her to be returned. While grade five students did not attend school yesterday, they handed over a letter containing the request to the Vice Principal M.H.M. Hakeem and the latter said the issue will be brought to the attention of the Regional Director of Education BY T.L. Jaffarkhan  – Batticaloa

title: UAE – SL Business Forum and Trade Fair kicks offin october
author: Author not found
Content: A preliminary discussion was held at the President’s Office on Wednesday (26), under the patronage of President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, regarding the UAE – Sri Lanka Business Forum and Trade Fair. The event is scheduled to take place from 20 to 29 October at the RAK Exhibition Centre in the United Arab Emirates. The Federation of Sri Lanka Chambers of Commerce and Industry and the Sri Lanka Tourism Industry Board are jointly organising this trade fair under the theme of ‘Strengthening economic relations between Sri Lanka and the United Arab Emirates in the post-pandemic world.’ The primary objective of the exhibition is to explore new opportunities for Sri Lankan business entities in the economic contexts of the United Arab Emirates, the Gulf Straits, and the Middle East, and to strengthen business relationships between companies from the United Arab Emirates, the Gulf and the Middle East and Sri Lankan companies. Additionally, the event aims to promote Sri Lankan exports such as products and services, improve bilateral trade, investment, employment opportunities, tourism, and financial cooperation between Sri Lanka and the United Arab Emirates. During the discussion, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake advised the relevant ministries and related line agency officials to provide necessary support to the Federation of Sri Lanka Chambers of Commerce and Industry and the Sri Lanka Tourism Industry Board to ensure the success of the conference. Senior Additional Secretary to the President for Strategic Affairs, Chandani Wijewardana, senior officials of ministries and government institutions, and officials of the United Arab Emirates, Federation of Sri Lanka Chambers of Commerce and Industry and the Sri Lanka Tourism Industry Board were present at the meeting.

title: Ten-hour water cut on Saturday
author: Author not found
Content: A 10-hour water cut will be imposed in several areas, including the Kolonnawa Municipal and Rajagiriya areas from 11.00 a.m. on Saturday (29), owing to essential maintenance work on the main panel of the Kolonnawa Pumping Station. In a statement, the National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) said the water cut will affect the Kolonnawa Municipal area, Moragasmulla, Rajagiriya, Obeysekarapura, Bandaranayakepura, Ethul Kotte, Nawala, Koswatta. The water supply line extending along with the main road from Koswatta and Rajagiriya to Nawala Open University and all connected byroads will be shut off.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: SL cannot getcompensation as ship was released against AG’s orders –Wijeyadasa
author: Author not found
Content: Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe revealed in Parliament yesterday (27) that Sri Lanka is unable to obtain compensation with regard to the September 2020 MT New Diamond ship fire, due to the vessel being released against the orders of the Attorney General. The Minister alleged although the Attorney General instructed not to grant permission for the ship to be released from Sri Lankan waters, until the compensation is obtained, then Foreign Ministry Secretary Jayanath Colombage had instructed the Sri Lanka Navy to release the ship, disregarding the Attorney General’s instructions. Rajapakshe said after the release of ship, its owners did not even respond to Sri Lanka’s demands for compensations. Then State Minister of Coast Conservation Dr. Nalaka Godahewa, who spoke after Rajapakshe’s statement, said even though he was the subject Minister the order to release the vessel was not issued by him. He also said it was Colombage who instructed the Navy to release the ship. On 3 September 2020, the MT New Diamond, a very large crude carrier, caught fire off the western coast of Sri Lanka. After burning intermittently for almost a week, the fire was reported to be extinguished by 11 September and the vessel was later released. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Woman dies after being hit by motorbike
author: Author not found
Content: A 73-year-old woman died on Wednesday (26) after being hit by a motorbike in Warakapola, while crossing the road. The victim succumbed to injuries while receiving treatment at the Warakapola Hospital. The deceased was a resident of Tholangamuwa. Police arrested the biker. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Political influencehampering development – Rasamanickam
author: Author not found
Content: Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi (ITAK) Batticaloa District MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam claimed on Wednesday (26) that the development mechanism of the country must be freed from political interferences and, if not the ultimate goal cannot be achieved. MP Rasamanickam said many issues had arisen in the Batticaloa District, due to political interference, while implementing infrastructure as well as livelihood development projects in the past. Due to political interference many malpractices have occurred in the construction work of an ice factory at Mansivantivu in Batticaloa, he alleged. The ITAK MP also alleged that there is a doubt whether a proper permit or approval was obtained to construct the said ice factory. However it is very clear that political influence is being applied heavily in this construction, he claimed. “I learned from reliable sources that the construction site has come under the control of the nephew of a politician in the region,” he alleged. “It needs to be probed how the responsible departments acted in connection with this matter. Permissions cannot be granted for such constructions without obtaining proper approvals. Development works must take place without causing any damage to the natural structure or resources in a particular area,” Rasamanickam said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Arrested with cannabis
author: Author not found
Content: A 23-year-old man was arrested, in possession of 10 kilograms of Cannabis, during a raid conducted by the Karuwalagaswewa Police, in Puttalam on Wednesday (26). The suspect is a resident of Nagawilluwa. The suspect is scheduled to be produced before the Puttalam Magistrate’s Court today (28). Meanwhile, the Karuwalagaswewa Police are conducting investigations. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Drought affects more than 6,000 families
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly 21,042 persons, from 6,343 families, have been affected as a result of prevailing drought in seven Divisional Secretariat (DS) Divisions in the Ampara and Trincomalee Districts, the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) said on Wednesday (26). Among the affected DS divisions were Muttur, Kinniya, Seruwila and Luchchaveli, Maha Oya, Pottuvil and Lahugala DS Divisions, the DMC said. Assistant Director of Ampara District DMC Office M. A. C. M. Riyas said a total number of 649 families, comprising 2,192 members, 2,639 families comprising 8,926 members and 143 families comprising 510 members have been affected in Maha Oya, Pottuvil and Lahugala DS divisions, respectively in the Ampara District. Furthermore, a total number of 1,283 families, comprising 4,323 persons, in the Seruwila DS Division, 1,038 families comprising 3,364 persons in the Kuchchaveli DS Division, 344 families comprising 893 persons in the Kinniya DS Division and 237 families comprising 779 persons in the Muttur DS Division had been affected in the Trincomalee District, according to Assistant Director of Trincomalee District DMC Office K. Sugunathas. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  A 42-year-old man was stabbed to death on Wednesday (26) in Ambalangoda. According to Police, an argument had arisen between the victim and another, while they were drinking alcohol with few others. The argument then gone out of hand resulting in the stabbing. The victim was admitted to the Balapitiya Hospital but was pronounced dead on admission. The deceased was a resident of Ambalangoda. Ambalangoda Police are conducting investigations. By Dinithi Wijesundara Popular

title: Four arrested over abduction, assault
author: Author not found
Content: Sapugaskanda Police arrested four persons who had abducted and assaulted a 22-year-old and left him near the Pamunuwila public cemetery. The twenty-two-year-old, who was seriously injured, is currently being treated in the Intensive Care Unit of the Colombo National Hospital. He was abducted near the Fort railway station in Colombo on 19 April, afternoon and taken to the Pamunuwila public cemetery in a vehicle. The vehicle used for the abduction is in Police custody, whilst investigations are underway to arrest four others involved in the crime.  The two women arrested are 22 and 48 years old and the two men are 22 and 23 years old. The accused are residents of Colombo, Grandpass, Kiribathgoda, Wellampitiya and Sapugaskanda and they were produced before the Mahara Magistrate’s Court for an identification parade, following which they were remanded. By K. Duminda- Biyagama and Bihadu Vinuwara- Delgoda

title: Injunctionissued against Handungoda and hisYouTube channel
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief District Judge Purnima Paranagama yesterday (26) issued an injunction against social media activist Darshana Handungoda and his YouTube channel, preventing the publishing of defamatory content against two officers of the Attorney General’s Department, on the basis that they deliberately delayed action with regard to the MV X-Press Pearl ship fire. Accordingly, the injunction will be in effect until 10 May and Hadungoda was ordered to appear before Court on the same day.  The Judge issued the Order after taking into consideration a request made by President’s Counsel Kuwera de Soyza. Soyza filed this complaint before Court on the basis that his clients have been insulted and prejudiced by the news published by Hadungoda stating that they have deliberately delayed instituting action. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Doctors ready to assist in A/L paper marking – Dr. Bellana
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors are ready to assist in marking answer scripts of G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination 2022 if the Government makes a request, Deputy Director of National Hospital Colombo, Dr. Rukshan Bellana said. Speaking to the media yesterday (26),Dr. Bellana accused university lecturers of working against the interests of the country. “These people should be sacked like in 1983. They never cared about the development of the country. The university lecturers are a group that accept contracts to topple the Government from time to time,” he alleged. “It is a tragedy that A/L paper marking is delayed. If the Government makes a request, doctors are ready to lend a helping hand,” he said. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Price reduction announcement on schoolbags, shoes on 23 May
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said the official announcement with regard to the price reduction of schoolbags and shoes will be made on 23 May. The State Minister said manufacturers have agreed to the request of the Ministry. “A discussion was held in this regard on Tuesday (25). During the discussion it was requested to provide consumers the benefit of the lower prices of raw materials compared to the devaluation of the USD. It is true that the price of products that increased with the depreciation of LKR against USD remain same when LKR appreciated,” he said. Siyambalapitiya said due to the current economic situation, parents find it extremely difficult to afford school equipment for children. Therefore, he requested manufacturers to provide products to the market at the lowest possible prices. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Stocks fall for eighth day after four years
author: Author not found
Content: The stock market fell for the eighth consecutive market day to yesterday (26) after four years due to sustained uncertainty and a high interest rate regime aided by high, double digit inflation. A similar fall was last witnessed in the immediate aftermath of ‘Easter Sunday terror attacks 2019’ that took place on 21 April 2019, where the stock market fell for 10 consecutive market days, then. Subsequently, the benchmark ASPI, yesterday over the previous day Tuesday (25) fell by 0.37 per cent to 9,091.72 points and the more sensitive S&P SL 20 Index by 0.39 per cent to 2,646.48 points on a low Rs 740.53 million turnover. Prior to yesterday, the  stock market last fell for at least eight consecutive market days was from 2 May 2019 to 15 May 2019, where it declined for 10 consecutive market days then, buffeted by ‘Bloody Easter Sunday’ which took place on 21 April 2019. Meanwhile, market indices last registered lower figures than the above was 65 calendar days ago on 20 February with the ASPI registering value of 9,082.33 points and the S&P SL 20 Index, 2,644.27 points, respectively. A high interest rate regime is inimical to the growth of the bourse as then; investors are attracted to the fixed income market, rather than to the latter. Nonetheless, the stock market enjoyed net foreign inflows (NFIs), albeit nominal, for the fifth consecutive market day to yesterday (26), with yesterday’s NFIs amounting to Rs 70.98 million, thereby increasing NFIs in the calendar year to date to Rs 1.64 billion.  The number of shares that changed hands yesterday fell to a 22 calendar day low of 34.09 million. A lower share volume than this was last registered on 4 April with a figure of 25.03 million. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: 25 Sri Lankans evacuated from Sudan capital – MFA
author: Author not found
Content: In light of the escalating hostilities between Sudanese forces and militia, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs reported yesterday (26) that 13 Sri Lankans who were evacuated with the assistance of the Saudi Government, have been met in Jeddah by Sri Lanka’s Acting Consul General, and 12 other Sri Lankans are currently in Port Sudan awaiting evacuation. Sri Lanka is carefully collaborating with its international partners, particularly the governments of India and Saudi Arabia, to evacuate the trapped Sri Lankans from Sudan. Around 50 people live in Sudan, according to sources. As a result of intense fighting between the two military squads, hundreds of Sudanese have been killed, and people of many different nationalities, including Chinese, Indians, Americans, and Australians are being evacuated.  Ensuring the safety and security of Sri Lankans stranded in the Republic of Sudan is the primary concern of the Government of Sri Lanka, the MFA said yesterday (26) in their official statement. Sri Lanka continues to monitor the evolving security situation in Sudan and is closely working with its international partners, including the Government of India and the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, to evacuate the stranded Sri Lankans. The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Cairo and Sri Lanka’s Honorary Consul in Khartoum are in regular contact with the relevant parties in Khartoum, including the Sudanese authorities and the Indian Embassy in Khartoum, to secure safe evacuation. The Government of Sri Lanka is making every effort to evacuate the remaining Sri Lankans in Khartoum, taking into account the need for safe passage in a volatile security situation. The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Cairo can be reached via e-mail : [email protected] and telephone +201272813000. The Secretary of the Honorary Consulate of Sri Lanka in Khartoum Sayed Abdel can be contacted via telephone +249912394035 for any immediate assistance, the MFA informed. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Revised indictment served on Rajitha, two others
author: Author not found
Content: The revised indictments on three suspects, including former Fisheries Minister Rajitha Seneratne, for causing unlawful loss to the Government, when leasing out the Modara Fisheries Harbour to a private company in 2014, was served before Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (26). Accordingly, the Judge ordered the pre-trial hearing of the case to be held on 16 June. Earlier, the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) had informed Court that since there are no documents to prove some of the charges in the indictment filed by the Bribery Commission against these defendants, they will amend the indictment and hand it over against defendants. Accordingly, yesterday, the revised indictment was handed over to the defendants by the Commission. Former Chairman of the Ceylon Fisheries Harbour Corporation, Upali Liyanage and former Managing Director, Neil Ravindra Munasinghe and Seneratne were named defendants in the case for causing unlawful loss to the Government between 1 August and 1 November 2014. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Sri Lankare-emerging as a success story – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe who said some Banks have raised concerns that the Colombo Stock Exchange (CSE) will collapse due to certain measures taken with regard to the banking system, stressed if that is the case and the CSE collapses he will shut it down. In a special statement during the debate on agreeing with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in Parliament yesterday (26), the President said various sectors cannot put conditions at a time when the country is gradually moving forward. “However, this matter will be discussed in Parliament and a decision will be taken in Parliament as well.” The relevant sectors will be informed following that,” he said. President Wickremesinghe announced that Sri Lanka is on the path of renaissance and is re-emerging as a success story, with the expectation of support from the entire nation to carry it forward. The President highlighted the progress made in the Sri Lankan economy, which had previously collapsed due to riots, arson, and state bankruptcy. In just eight months, the country has turned its fortunes around and is now known as the ‘Sri Lanka comeback story’. The President also spoke about the IMF agreement, which he presented to Parliament. He acknowledged that the country had failed to implement previous agreements with the IMF despite entering into 16 such agreements. However, the President said there is no other active option for Sri Lanka but to sign an agreement with the IMF at present. He reassured the public that the restructuring of local debt would not harm members of the Employees Provident Fund (EPF). Furthermore, he stated that a social safety net has been implemented to protect low-income earners and create financial stability in the country. With these measures in place, the President is optimistic about Sri Lanka’s future and urged the nation to work together towards a brighter future. “As soon as I took over the Government, I began negotiations with the IMF, the World Bank, and the Asian Development Bank. As a result, in September, we reached an agreement with the IMF regarding extended credit facilities. The comprehensive credit facility consists of six major reforms; Revenue-based Fiscal Consolidation, Restructuring of Public Debt, implementation of multiple strategies to ensure the restoration of financial stability, including the formation of foreign reserves under a flexible foreign exchange rate regime, implementation of relevant policies and reforms to ensure the stability of the financial sector, implementation of structural reforms necessary to control corruption–In this regard, the Minister will present the relevant draft and taking necessary measures to enhance economic growth” Today, we received the financing assurance from foreign creditors, with the Paris Club and India working together to grant it. India was the first to publish it, and we are grateful for that. China is expected to deal with it separately, so we will discuss with the Paris Club and India on one hand and negotiate with China on the other. After these discussions, we will have talks with private creditors. This agreement will enable us to receive approximately USD3 billion from the International Monetary Fund over the next four years, with the potential to obtain about USD7 billion from other institutions. This money is crucial for us, the President said. “Additionally, we have regained the trust of foreign banks and financial institutions, with economic stability already being established in the country. Social Security is receiving more funding, and investors are showing a keen interest in Sri Lanka. We have entered into agreements with the IMF 16 times in the past, but we have not fully implemented them. On the 17th occasion, when we achieve stability, we must address our long-term weaknesses and move forward with a new programme” The President said Sri Lanka must first negotiate with foreign creditors. “We hope to initiate these discussions soon, with domestic debt restructuring also being considered. A final decision has not yet been made, but it is important to discuss this issue. Negotiations cannot be held with terms and conditions already in place. It is easier for us to join negotiations without conditions. Some Banks may express their inability to cope with the programme, but it is important for them to accept it in order to move the economy forward. There are concerns that the stock market may collapse, and some may not be able to offer different conditions. However, decisions will be made in Parliament, and appropriate measures will be taken to ensure that no harm is done to anyone, such as the members of the EPF.” “We have initiated necessary programmes to support the poor, and the World Bank has provided funding for this. We are currently implementing a programme to give aid to those who truly deserve it and remove those who do not. Our aim is to create financial stability and protect the low-income people. To achieve these objectives, we are holding joint discussions with the Paris Club and India on one platform, while separate negotiations with China are also underway. We have nothing to hide, and several steps need to be taken in this regard. The Central government tax revenue flow  in 2022 was Rs 1 Trillion  751,000,   end March it was   Rs 650 billion. I must say we have fallen short in some areas such as the Customs because imports have been reduced, but on the other hand we have increased direct taxation. The tax revenue final target for the end of the year is Rs 2.9 billion.” “Parliamentary approval of the new Central Bank Act will be tabled in Parliament next month .Completion of the asset quality review component of bank diagnostic exercise for the two largest State-owned banks and the three largest private sector banks will be done. Parliamentary approval of the welfare benefit payment scheme and the application of the new eligibility criteria to identify low-income families will be obtained for receiving welfare benefit payments by end of May. Cabinet approval would be obtained for a comprehensive strategy to restructure the balance sheets of the CEB, CPC, SriLankan Airlines, and the Road Development Authority by end of June, Cabinet approval also will be obtained for a full revision of the Banking Act by end of June. Also new anti-competition legislation will be enacted to harmonise it with the United Nations Convention against Corruption, pending comprehensive asset recovery provisions by end of June,” the President said. Appropriation Bill 2024 will be presented to Parliament by end of October, he said. “Under staff baseline scenario, USD 17 billion in debt service reduction is required, including the arrears accumulated in 2022.So we are trying to get a USD 17 billion debt reduction on that side. Do you want it or not. Are we going in for debt restricting? We can’t manage without debt restructuring. That is what I want to make it clear to all the members.” “Various restrictions have been imposed for 25 to 30 years, depending on the preferences of each ministry. Let us now look at the economy and decide which limits will be retained and which will be lifted.  A highly competitive social fair market system is required. We require a green economy. The economy must be digitalised. There are several activities available for this. Agriculture is being modernized, and new industries are being introduced. That is something I will address separately,” “Now we have to build the country for 2048. If we do not accomplish this, we would be betraying the country’s youth. Their future has been destroyed. Think about the youth of the country. Don’t just think about grabbing power only. If this program is not done, none of us will be able to survive in another two or three years. So I urge everyone to come together to approve this. After that we will come together and prepare the set of policies required until 2048. I also, urge you to provide support to implement the programme during the next five years,” he said.

title: President to attend King Charles III’s coronation
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe will attend the coronation of King Charles III, Ceylon Today reliably learns. According to highly placed sources, the President will begin a three-day official visit to London in the first week of May to represent Sri Lanka at the coronation, which will be held on 6 May at Westminster Abbey. Camilla, Queen Consort, will also be crowned alongside the King in the historic ceremony. Many world leaders including the French President, Prime Ministers of Australia, Pakistan and Bangladesh have already confirmed their participation in the ceremony. This will be Wickremesinghe’s fourth foreign visit after he was elected as President by Parliament in July 2022. The President visited Egypt to attend the 2022 UN Climate Change Conference (COP27) in November last year. Further, this will be Wickremesinghe’s second visit to London after he was elected. The President attended the funeral of Queen Elizabeth II in September 2022. His parents Esmond Wickremesinghe and Nalini Wickremesinghe participated in the coronation ceremony of Queen Elizabeth II in 1953 along with then Prime Minister Dudley Senanayake. By Rifthi Ali in London

title: Files go missing from President’s House
author: Author not found
Content: The Police Special Investigation Division yesterday (26) revealed to Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage that a file regarding the transfer of three elephants under the custody of the Wildlife Department to another party that was kept at President’s House had gone missing. This was when the case filed stating that such transfer on the orders of former President Maithripala Sirisena is illegal, was taken up before Court. The Magistrate ordered the Police Investigation Division to take necessary measures and conduct proper investigations, obtain statements from the relevant persons and report facts to Court. The Police Special Investigation Division informed Court that the original file is not in the Presidential Secretariat and the Additional Secretary to the President has informed police that it is missing. When the case was taken up yesterday (26), Police said they obtained a statement from former President Sirisena and his Additional Secretary Kingsley Fernando and they stated that they could not give details without checking the original file. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Payment delays halt mid-day meal to school children
author: Author not found
Content: The programme to provide mid-day meals to schoolchildren was forced to be halted due to delays in payment to suppliers in February and March this year, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said yesterday (26). Accordingly, the programme has been halted islandwide, except in the Western Province. There is an outstanding payment of Rs 875 million for these two months due to suppliers. The Minister was responding to a question raised by Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake. Although, Rs 16.6 billion was allocated for this programme in Budget 2023, payments have been delayed due to the economic crisis. Dissanayake queried as to what the reason was to halt the programme, Island wide. Premajayantha responding said steps would be taken to settle the dues within the next two to three weeks, utilising World Bank funds. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Revised indictment served on Rajitha, two others
author: Author not found
Content: The revised indictments on three suspects, including former Fisheries Minister Rajitha Seneratne, for causing unlawful loss to the Government, when leasing out the Modara Fisheries Harbour to a private company in 2014, was served before Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (26). Accordingly, the Judge ordered the pre-trial hearing of the case to be held on 16 June. Earlier, the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) had informed Court that since there are no documents to prove some of the charges in the indictment filed by the Bribery Commission against these defendants, they will amend the indictment and hand it over against defendants. Accordingly, yesterday, the revised indictment was handed over to the defendants by the Commission. Former Chairman of the Ceylon Fisheries Harbour Corporation, Upali Liyanage and former Managing Director, Neil Ravindra Munasinghe and Seneratne were named defendants in the case for causing unlawful loss to the Government between 1 August and 1 November 2014. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Sri Lankare-emerging as a success story – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe who said some Banks have raised concerns that the Colombo Stock Exchange (CSE) will collapse due to certain measures taken with regard to the banking system, stressed if that is the case and the CSE collapses he will shut it down. In a special statement during the debate on agreeing with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in Parliament yesterday (26), the President said various sectors cannot put conditions at a time when the country is gradually moving forward. “However, this matter will be discussed in Parliament and a decision will be taken in Parliament as well.” The relevant sectors will be informed following that,” he said. President Wickremesinghe announced that Sri Lanka is on the path of renaissance and is re-emerging as a success story, with the expectation of support from the entire nation to carry it forward. The President highlighted the progress made in the Sri Lankan economy, which had previously collapsed due to riots, arson, and state bankruptcy. In just eight months, the country has turned its fortunes around and is now known as the ‘Sri Lanka comeback story’. The President also spoke about the IMF agreement, which he presented to Parliament. He acknowledged that the country had failed to implement previous agreements with the IMF despite entering into 16 such agreements. However, the President said there is no other active option for Sri Lanka but to sign an agreement with the IMF at present. He reassured the public that the restructuring of local debt would not harm members of the Employees Provident Fund (EPF). Furthermore, he stated that a social safety net has been implemented to protect low-income earners and create financial stability in the country. With these measures in place, the President is optimistic about Sri Lanka’s future and urged the nation to work together towards a brighter future. “As soon as I took over the Government, I began negotiations with the IMF, the World Bank, and the Asian Development Bank. As a result, in September, we reached an agreement with the IMF regarding extended credit facilities. The comprehensive credit facility consists of six major reforms; Revenue-based Fiscal Consolidation, Restructuring of Public Debt, implementation of multiple strategies to ensure the restoration of financial stability, including the formation of foreign reserves under a flexible foreign exchange rate regime, implementation of relevant policies and reforms to ensure the stability of the financial sector, implementation of structural reforms necessary to control corruption–In this regard, the Minister will present the relevant draft and taking necessary measures to enhance economic growth” Today, we received the financing assurance from foreign creditors, with the Paris Club and India working together to grant it. India was the first to publish it, and we are grateful for that. China is expected to deal with it separately, so we will discuss with the Paris Club and India on one hand and negotiate with China on the other. After these discussions, we will have talks with private creditors. This agreement will enable us to receive approximately USD3 billion from the International Monetary Fund over the next four years, with the potential to obtain about USD7 billion from other institutions. This money is crucial for us, the President said. “Additionally, we have regained the trust of foreign banks and financial institutions, with economic stability already being established in the country. Social Security is receiving more funding, and investors are showing a keen interest in Sri Lanka. We have entered into agreements with the IMF 16 times in the past, but we have not fully implemented them. On the 17th occasion, when we achieve stability, we must address our long-term weaknesses and move forward with a new programme” The President said Sri Lanka must first negotiate with foreign creditors. “We hope to initiate these discussions soon, with domestic debt restructuring also being considered. A final decision has not yet been made, but it is important to discuss this issue. Negotiations cannot be held with terms and conditions already in place. It is easier for us to join negotiations without conditions. Some Banks may express their inability to cope with the programme, but it is important for them to accept it in order to move the economy forward. There are concerns that the stock market may collapse, and some may not be able to offer different conditions. However, decisions will be made in Parliament, and appropriate measures will be taken to ensure that no harm is done to anyone, such as the members of the EPF.” “We have initiated necessary programmes to support the poor, and the World Bank has provided funding for this. We are currently implementing a programme to give aid to those who truly deserve it and remove those who do not. Our aim is to create financial stability and protect the low-income people. To achieve these objectives, we are holding joint discussions with the Paris Club and India on one platform, while separate negotiations with China are also underway. We have nothing to hide, and several steps need to be taken in this regard. The Central government tax revenue flow  in 2022 was Rs 1 Trillion  751,000,   end March it was   Rs 650 billion. I must say we have fallen short in some areas such as the Customs because imports have been reduced, but on the other hand we have increased direct taxation. The tax revenue final target for the end of the year is Rs 2.9 billion.” “Parliamentary approval of the new Central Bank Act will be tabled in Parliament next month .Completion of the asset quality review component of bank diagnostic exercise for the two largest State-owned banks and the three largest private sector banks will be done. Parliamentary approval of the welfare benefit payment scheme and the application of the new eligibility criteria to identify low-income families will be obtained for receiving welfare benefit payments by end of May. Cabinet approval would be obtained for a comprehensive strategy to restructure the balance sheets of the CEB, CPC, SriLankan Airlines, and the Road Development Authority by end of June, Cabinet approval also will be obtained for a full revision of the Banking Act by end of June. Also new anti-competition legislation will be enacted to harmonise it with the United Nations Convention against Corruption, pending comprehensive asset recovery provisions by end of June,” the President said. Appropriation Bill 2024 will be presented to Parliament by end of October, he said. “Under staff baseline scenario, USD 17 billion in debt service reduction is required, including the arrears accumulated in 2022.So we are trying to get a USD 17 billion debt reduction on that side. Do you want it or not. Are we going in for debt restricting? We can’t manage without debt restructuring. That is what I want to make it clear to all the members.” “Various restrictions have been imposed for 25 to 30 years, depending on the preferences of each ministry. Let us now look at the economy and decide which limits will be retained and which will be lifted.  A highly competitive social fair market system is required. We require a green economy. The economy must be digitalised. There are several activities available for this. Agriculture is being modernized, and new industries are being introduced. That is something I will address separately,” “Now we have to build the country for 2048. If we do not accomplish this, we would be betraying the country’s youth. Their future has been destroyed. Think about the youth of the country. Don’t just think about grabbing power only. If this program is not done, none of us will be able to survive in another two or three years. So I urge everyone to come together to approve this. After that we will come together and prepare the set of policies required until 2048. I also, urge you to provide support to implement the programme during the next five years,” he said.

title: Korea agrees to provide 8,000 jobs for Lankans
author: Author not found
Content: The Director of the Korean Human Resources Department based in Sri Lanka, during a discussion, agreed to provide 8,000 job opportunities for Sri Lankans in Korea this year, exceeding the job quota of 6,500 offered earlier, the Ministry of Labour and Foreign Employment said. He said this during a discussion with Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara yesterday morning (26). This agreement was reached during the discussion held last morning between the Director of the Korean Human Resources Department and the Minister. It had also been agreed to refer 600 people who are presently registered on the Korean job website after passing the Korean language proficiency test under the production sector category for jobs in the shipbuilding sector. Priority will be given to job seekers registered on the website, whose period for securing a job will expire by 31 December this year. Accordingly, these jobs are to be provided by shifting the job category from the production sector of the website to the shipbuilding sector. Therefore, candidates who are willing to change their job category from production to the shipbuilding industry should apply for it as soon as possible. The Korean Human Resources Department has also agreed to conduct examinations and recruit 900 welders and painters for jobs in the shipbuilding industry under the E9 visa category from next year. The Director of the Korean Human Resources Department has also informed the Minister that from next year, the Korean Language Proficiency Test will be conducted using the UBT system instead of the present computer-based CBT system.

title: Govt aiming to silence citizens via ATB – SJB
author: Author not found
Content: If the Anti-Terrorism Bill (ATB) is passed in its current state, the people of the country will only be able to open their mouths to eat and yawn, because the Government has decided to restrict the people’s freedom of expression through this Bill, the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) claimed. Addressing a media briefing on Tuesday (25) SJB MP Ashok Abeysinghe said, under the leadership of the Opposition Leader, a large number of parties in the country have decided to jointly protest against the Anti-Terrorism Bill. “There is a big question about the definition of a terrorist in this Bill. We, as citizens, believe that media organisations are not speaking out enough about this,” he added. Abeysinghe claimed that if the Opposition holds a press conference and the government decides that something anti-government has been said in it, they can prosecute the Opposition under the provisions of the Bill.  “Therefore, especially, the freedom of press has been restricted through this Bill. They will be barred from speaking on behalf of the citizens of the country,” he claimed. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: UNP’s May Day rally ‘Jayagamu’ at Sugathadasa Indoor Stadium
author: Author not found
Content: The May Day commemoration organised by the UNP’s Jathika Sevaka Sangamaya and Youth Task Force will be held under the title ‘Jayagamu’ (Let’s Win) at the Sugathadasa Indoor Stadium on 1 May, Assistant Leader and President of the Jathika Sevaka Sangamaya, Akila Viraj Kariyawasam said yesterday (26). He was speaking at a a media briefing at Sirikotha. Kariyawasam said the title was selected because there are signs of many burning issues which could be resolved before the end of this year under the leadership of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Kariyawasam said it is an undeniable truth that education has collapsed to some extent, adding however;issues in the education sector are being gradually resolved. “Therefore, leading political forces including the Opposition must unite to support the progress of this difficult journey. However, objective criticism was acceptable. The JVP supported President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga to abolish the Executive Presidency.However, they agreed to form a Government in 2004 and worked with them even when their promises were not fulfilled. Why can’t they reach an agreement at this time when there are many problems that need to be addressed?” Kariyawasam queried. “Furthermore, MPs who worked with us in Parliament and those who held ministerial positions have the responsibility of helping us at this difficult time.Even amidst severe criticism President Wickremesinghe is doing everything in his capacity to resolve the economic crisis”, he said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: PresidentialEnvironment Awards 2021-2022
author: Author not found
Content: The Presidential Environment Awards 2021-2022, organised by the Central Environmental Authority, will be held on 28 April at 9:00 a.m. under the patronage of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Arrangements have been made to hold the 9th Awards Ceremony at the Lotus Hall of the BMICH with the participation of Minister of Environment Naseer Ahamed, Environmental Secretary Dr. Anil Jasinghe, Chairman of the Central Environmental Authority Supun S. Pathirage and Director General, Central Environmental Authority P.B. Hemantha Jayasinghe and other officials and award winners. Awarding State honours to industries, business organisations and individuals who have made an excellent contribution towards environmental conservation; building an environmentally-friendly industry, business and service culture, encouraging society to engage in environmentally-friendly activities, etc. is the prime objective of the Awards Programme. Under the guidance of the Ministry of Environment, the Central Environmental Authority organises the award ceremony annually, also keeping in mind the objectives of promoting people’s participation in sustainable development. Considering the conditions that prevailed in the country in the past years, arrangements have been made to present the awards for both the years 2021 and 2022 at this year’s ceremony. Having given the opportunity to the relevant personnel representing the two main sectors as Industries, businesses and project category; and Institutions, social and mass media category to apply for this award ceremony, those contestants are formally evaluated by a panel of expert scholars to select the award winners for the Presidential Environment Awards 2021- 2022. Under the Industries, businesses and project category: solid waste recovery/recycling/disposal or processing plants, chemical industries, vehicle servicing centres, food and beverages industries, hotels, textile and textile processing industries, pharmaceutical products and personal care products industries, hospitals, rubber based products industries, animal farms, apparel industries, tea factories, packaging industries with printing, waste management projects of Local Authorities, industry initiatives in promoting the 3R concept and renewable energy generating projects (small scale mini hydropower projects/ solar power projects/ wind power generating projects) were evaluated for 16 sectors. Under the Institutions, social and mass media category: evaluations have been made under seven sections, namely: schools, environmentally-friendly government institutions, environmentally-friendly private institutions, individuals who are committed to environmental conservation, the best NGO that is committed to environmental conservation and promotion, eco-friendly innovations (School/ Universities and Tertiary Educational Institutions/ Open section) and media field. In evaluating the media field entries, the following categories were considered; exploratory environmental reporting – Print Media (Sinhala, Tamil, English), exploratory environmental programme production – Radio Media (Sinhala, Tamil, English), and exploratory environmental programme production – Television Media (Sinhala, Tamil, English). A total of 90 individuals and entities will be awarded Gold, Silver, Bronze and Merit awards at the Presidential Environment Awards 2021-2022.

title: Rs 927,000 squanderedon Iranawila children’s park
author: Author not found
Content: A report compiled by the Auditor General’s Department stated that public funds have been squandered to build a children’s park at Iranawila West in the Mahawewa Divisional Secretariat Division. According to the Department, the amount spent to build the park has been estimated at Rs 927,000. The Department pointed out that the park in question had been built by the previous Good Governance Government four years ago as part of its ‘Gamperaliya’ concept. The said park had been inaugurated on 14 January three years ago, but since then it has not been used by children as it is prone to coastal erosion. Thus, the Auditor General’s Department has mentioned in its report that the amount incurred to build the park is a wanton waste of public funds as it has been built sans any environmental evaluation and the impact on the people hasn’t been considered. By Jude Samantha

title: Past pupils invited to get-together
author: Author not found
Content: A get-together of the past pupils of C.W.W. Kannangara Central College in Matugama will be held on 30 April from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. The event will be held at Munasinghe Mahagedara Hall, Mahagedara Road, Matugama. The organisers cordially invite the batches of ‘89 (scholarship), ‘95 (O/L) and ‘98 (A/L) to grace the occasion.

title: Maximum compensation only USD 27M – Eran
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya MP Eran Wickramaratne claimed in Parliament on Tuesday (25) that the maximum compensation that can be obtained by transferring the MV X-Press Pearl case to the Singaporean legal system is USD 27 million. He said, the Government should take proper steps to seek compensation for the environmental damage caused to Sri Lanka by the X-Press Pearl disaster, which was one of the worst maritime disasters in history. “After an accident, the damage to the marine environment may increase in the future, so it is natural for the companies concerned to try to limit compensation,” he stressed. The SJB MP alleged that although the affected country should calculate the compensation scientifically and seek compensation, it doesn’t seem to have been done properly by this Government. “It is reported that the Marine Environmental Pollution Committee that was appointed to assess the damage of this ship was the same committee that was appointed for the MT New Diamond ship fire. There was also no transparency about the compensation received for the damage caused by the MT New Diamond ship accident. Why is it not possible to declare the amount of compensation received so far?” Wickramaratne queried. The MP questioned whether it is possible to believe that the authorities would maintain transparency in the assessment of the X-Press Pearl ship disaster, in which the compensation to be received could be much more than in the previous ship disaster.

title: Rajarata Uni Rotaractors hold medical camp
author: Author not found
Content: The Rotaract Club of University of Rajarata and the Leo Club of Athugalpura collaborated to organise a medical camp and awareness programme on 21 April. This programme aimed at addressing non-communicable diseases in the local community of Kurunegala. The event was held at the Kudakoowanawalasgala Raja Maha Viharaya. The medical camp offered free checkups and consultations to the attendees, and over 100 people benefited. The organisers emphasised the importance of early detection and prevention of chronic illnesses, which contribute to a high mortality rate in Sri Lanka. The event demonstrated the effectiveness of community-based initiatives in promoting health and well-being.
