title: Nigerian Defence delegation meets Navy Chief
author: Author not found
Content: A Nigerian National Defence College (NDC) delegation, comprising student officers and directing staff, visited the Navy Headquarters in Colombo on 24 April. The delegation from NDC Abuja- Nigeria was headed by Air Commodore Osichinaka Chedu UBADIKE and comprised 24 members, including 13 student officers and directing staff from the Course No. 31.  As part of the visit, Air Commodore Osichinaka Chedu UBADIKE, Acting Defence Adviser in New Delhi and accredited to Sri Lanka, Colonel AO Salami and directing staff members called on Commander of the Navy, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera. Subsequently, the student officers of the Nigerian NDC were briefed on the role and task of the Sri Lanka Navy. Meanwhile, mementoes were also exchanged between Commander of the Navy and head of the Nigerian NDC delegation, marking the importance of the occasion.  During the stay in the country, the Nigerian NDC delegation will visit some of the tourist attractions in Sri Lanka. (NV)

title: Renowned Battle ofthe Saints – Josephian Perspective
author: Author not found
Content: The 89th Joe-Pete Two-Day Cricket Encounter and 49th One-Day Encounter will take place on the 28 and 29 April and 30 April respectively at the SSC grounds. The Joe-Pete cricket encounter, more popularly known as the ‘Battle of the Saints’, is a much- awaited event in the College calendar due to the quality of cricket and spirit in which the game has been played and its rich traditions. The Battle of the Saints is renowned for its exciting and competitive brand of cricket. The Joe-Pete Encounter is going to be an interesting one as the players have undergone rigorous training and will showcase their prowess. It is not going to be a cakewalk for either of the teams as every player is brilliant and unique in his own capacity and every one of them is in a class of his own. Needless to say, sports make us healthy and strong and not only teaches us to celebrate victory, but also accept defeat with grace and magnanimity. Such lessons lay a firm foundation for success in later life. The organisation of matches is improving every year and we are glad that we are providing the opportunity to many budding players to hone their skills so that they could one day showcase their talent nationally and internationally. We wish to record that the Josephian-Peterite Limited Overs cricket version is the oldest encounter in the Island. St Joseph’s College, Colombo is a premier Catholic School in Sri Lanka and has a history for excellence in Education, Sports, Extra Curricular activities and spiritual uplift over 127 years. We should reflect on the past and always ask ourselves what have we done or achieved recently. In this context, I am delighted to state that currently Josephians are the Under-19 Inter School Division One Tier A, 2-Day Joint Champions. We are now endeavouring to maintain the high standards to secure many more victories in the future, as well. At St. Joseph’s College in keeping with our vision, we aim to nurture innate talent, abilities and capabilities and develop multi-talent and skills to bring out the best from the Josephian fraternity in order to produce resolute leaders to our College, the Motherland and the universe. Our College has produced a galaxy of multi-talented exemplary leaders in all walks of life including professional cricketers to the nation and overseas. In this context, we have produced many national caps and legendary cricketers. With their dynamic leadership, knowledge, skills, talents, expertise, versatile experience besides sportsmanship, these cricketers have maintained the high standards of our College, thus brought glory and honour to our Alma Mater and our Motherland. I am glad to state that these great cricketers have helped our Nation to secure many noteworthy achievements in cricket thus making our Country victorious on many occasions in spite of facing their strong opponents in the game of cricket. They were the cream of the Sri Lankan Cricket team which played with devotion and diligence. It is my duty to mention the names of those cricketers at this juncture and thank them for keeping the College and National flags flying high and for their valuable contribution to our College and Sri Lankan cricket. The elite panel includes our current skipper Dimuthu Karunaratne, former skipper Angelo Mathews, legendary paceman Chaminda Vaas, Dunith Wellalage, who was the National Under -19 Captain and present promising national all-rounder, Ashley de Silva, the CEO of Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC), Thisara Perera, Michael Van Dort, Roshen Silva, Priyamal Perera and Sadeera Samarawickrama. I am sure that both teams will play exciting cricket to entertain both the young and old Peterites and Josephians. Finally, let me wish the captains and both teams the very best to deliver two days of exhilarating cricket besides success in their future endeavours to become tomorrow’s national cricketers. By Maruthai Ravindhiran

title: Tree planting campaignkicks off from BMICH
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Association of Airline Representatives in association with the BMICH, launched a tree planting campaign at the BMICH premises. The objective of the project is to support global environmental issues such as global warming, air pollution, lack of echo-friendly environments and sustainability, etc. The BMICH was selected because it is centrally located and it is an urban forest in the heart of the city which expands to 42 acres. In addition, the historical value of the location, the in-house resources, the environment surrounded by lush greenery, etc. was considered for selection of BMICH to launch the ‘Tree Planting’ project. “It is needless to say that the world needs more trees to overcome most of the environmental issues in order to save our planet. Hence, in the time to come, we intend  to expand this project islandwide in stages”, a spokesman said. The Association is in existence for nearly 30 years and has earned a reputation for being a vibrant entity that safeguards the interest of the Airline industry and its members representing online and offline passenger/cargo GSAs. “The objective of the Association is to support the industry, stakeholders, and regulatory authorities in solving many challenges related to the industry in an efficient and effective manner. Our efforts will pave the way for all foreign airlines to continue their operations and increase their frequencies to Sri Lanka and bring the much-needed tourists to the country” the spokesman added and said in addition, the association continues to provide training and development to staff members of the industry and support various CSR  projects for the benefit of the community.

title: 1,674 Saudis evacuated from Sudan – Saudi Envoy
author: Author not found
Content: Khalid Hamoud Alkahtani, Ambassador of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia said continuing the efforts made by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, under the directives of the Kingdom’s leadership, to evacuate its citizens and nationals of brotherly and friendly countries from the Republic of Sudan to the Kingdom, 13 Saudi citizens arrived in Jeddah this morning, and the number of nationals of brotherly and friendly countries who were evacuated reached 1,674  from the following countries: Oman, Syria, Libya, Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia, Lebanon, Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Palestine, Mauritania, Yemen, USA, Canada, Germany, United Kingdom, Switzerland, Ireland, France, Netherlands, Armenia, Hungary Sweden, Turkey, Ethiopia, Sierra Leone, Nigeria, Senegal, Tanzania, Djibouti, Cape Verde, Congo, Madagascar, Ivory Coast, Somalia, South Africa, Botswana, Malawi, Croatia, Nicaragua, Liberia, South Sudan, Kenya, Uganda, Philippines , Afghanistan, India, Indonesia, Zimbabwe, Pakistan, Chad, Bangladesh, Niger, Sri Lanka and Thailand. They were transported by ship and the Kingdom was keen to provide the basic needs of foreign nationals to facilitate their departure to their countries. The total number evacuated from Sudan reach around 2,148 people since the start of the evacuation (114 Saudi citizens and 2,034 people of 62 countries). The Kingdom’s leadership, always works for the comfort of Saudi citizens in and out of the Kingdom, the Envoy said.

title: Current fuel quota system to continue
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has decided to continue with the recently increased weekly fuel quotas, for vehicles, under the National Fuel Pass QR system, until further notice. Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said the decision was taken following a progress review meeting. He said during the meeting with officials attached to the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation, fuel quotas, fuel import plans, fuel distribution and the National Fuel Pass QR system were discussed. (NV)

title: ITN to probe sexual harassment allegations
author: Author not found
Content: Following a viral social media post of a former female news presenter at Independent Television Network (ITN) on sexual bribery at the workplace, Minister of Mass Media Bandula Gunawardana said yesterday (25) that he informed Ministry Secretary Anusha Palpita to obtain a formal complaint from the aggrieved party. In response to a question of Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Rohini Kaviratne in Parliament, Gunawardana said Palipita has informed the aggravated party to make a formal complaint with regard to the matter. “ITN Chairman Sudarshana Gunawardana informed that an external committee headed by a female lawyer has been appointed to look into the matter as well,” Gunawardana said, adding that according to the ITN Chairman, the Attorney General’s Department has also been informed in this connection and the Principal of Sri Lanka Law College has agreed to provide consultative support in the investigation. The employee, in a recent Facebook post, said she decided to leave the company because she did not want to fall victim to the sexual bribery demands from some senior male employees. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Indian Rupee as designated currency will help trade– CBSL Governor
author: Author not found
Content: Making the Indian Rupee (INR) a designated currency by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) will enable trade settlements between the two countries, CBSL Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said. He added that it will also enable Indian tourists visiting Sri Lanka to use INR for transactions. Weerasinghe also expressed support for the linking of digital payment interfaces between the two countries. He made these remarks following the launch of a Special Cover commemorating Seetha Amman Kovil in Seetha Eliya. The Kovil is believed to mark the place of Ashok Vatika, in the epic Ramayana and is a great hit with Indian tourists, as part of Ramayana circle which the Sri Lankan Government is seeking to promote.  Tourists from India traditionally constitute the largest segment of international tourists coming to Sri Lanka. Further, delivering a special address in the Webinar on ‘Economic Scenario of Sri Lanka: Current Status and Way Ahead’, organised by Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FICCI), the High Commissioner of India highlighted the areas of prospective economic cooperation between India and Sri Lanka. He particularly focused on connectivity, IT, renewable energy and tourism.  (FT)

title: Herath queries transfer of USD 5M to overseas bank
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) MP Vijitha Herath yesterday (25) questioned in Parliament how the compensation of USD 5 million, which was credited to a local bank account of GAC Shipping Ltd., over the MT New Diamond disaster, was transferred to a bank account overseas. Herath demanded an investigation into the transfer. He said, “USD 5 million had been credited, by the German Deutsche Bank, to the account of the GAC Shipping Ltd., with the Union Bank in Sri Lanka, on behalf of the Singaporean Company called Smith, between January and May 2022, as a part of compensation for MT New Diamond disaster. However, this same sum had been transferred to an overseas bank account. How did this happen and what did happen to this money? There should be an immediate investigation to find answers to these questions.” He also said a report should be tabled in Parliament over the matter. Crude carrier MT New Diamond caught fire off the western coast of Sri Lanka on 3 September 2020, resulting in the death of a Filipino crew member. After burning intermittently for almost a week, the fire was reported extinguished by 11 September 2020. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Hartal brings North and East to a standstill
author: Author not found
Content: A hartal in the North and East, yesterday (25), brought public services to a complete standstill in several towns, while only Sri Lanka Transport Board bus services operated as usual. Private bus services came to a standstill in Northern cities. However, some restaurants and pharmacies remained open to the public in the North. The call for a hartal by the TNA, was accepted by all Tamil political parties operating in the North and East, to express their strong opposition to the Government’s gazetted Anti-Terrorism Bill (ATB) and alleged “Sinhala-Buddhisization” in the North and East. During the one-day hartal, activities of schools and universities came to a standstill. Also, many State-run banks and private banks were shut in several towns in those two provinces. In the Jaffna District, most of the commercial centres and markets were closed, but pockets of activity was observed. All commercial activities ceased and Jaffna, Mullaitivu, Vavuniya, Batticaloa, Mannar and several other locations were deserted. However, some essential services including a few restaurants and pharmacies remained open to the public. In the Jaffna District, all commercial centres and markets were closed and traders wholeheartedly endorsed the shutdown called for by the Tamil parties. Also, Batticaloa town was deserted yesterday, with all schools and banks and State institutions shut. The Trincomalee District too remained sombre in support of the hartal called for by Tamil political parties, although some shops remained open to the public. Business establishments and schools in Trincomalee town and suburban areas were closed in support of the hartal. There weren’t many vehicles on the road. At the Magistrate Court – Trincomalee, some lawyers wore black sarees in support of the protest. Many Muslim shops and Tamil shops along the NC Road, Central Road, and Third Cross Road in Trincomalee had been closed in support of the hartal. However, the success of the hartal was relatively low despite scant activity spotted in the vicinity. Despite the hartal, everyday activities continued as usual in the Ampara District too. Banks, restaurants, markets, business establishments and textile shops remained open yesterday (25). Kalmunai, Sainthamaruthu, Periya Neelavanai, Sammanthurai, Ninthavur, Addalaichenai, Akkaraipattu, Central Camp and some other busy cities in the Ampara District functioned as usual. Many people were seen purchasing goods in Ampara. Daily activities were normal in Onthachimadam, Periya Neelavanai, Karaitivu, Sainthamaruthu, Maligaikadu, Ninthavur, Attapallam, Sainthamaruthu, Mavadipalli, Central Camp and Savalakadai areas in the Ampara District. Police and military presence was observed at large gathering venues. Markets, banks, supermarkets, fuel stations, pharmacies and other business establishments in the Kalmunai town were unaffected. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan, T. Pratheepan and Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Tax relief not possible due to agreements signed– Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: It is not possible, at the moment, to grant the tax relief demanded by the professionals, as the Government doesn’t have the capacity to do that, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said. Responding to a question raised by a journalist, Gunawardena said it would be a serious situation if the country cannot come to a common ground with regard to increasing income and cutting expenditure, in a backdrop where Sri Lanka has signed an agreement aimed at recovering from the economic crisis. To gain the trust of international community, we have to adhere to such agreements. Otherwise, it would be difficult to recover from the current situation, he said. Speaking further, Gunawardena said Sri Lanka has already neglected the conditions imposed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) 16 times. “If we continue to do that, the country will be placed in a difficult situation in the international arena. It will be a disgrace to the country as well. The Government is making every effort to increase income in order to rescue the country,” Gunawardena added. BY Mithun Jayawardena

title: Dullas proposes scrapping this year’s GCE O/L exam
author: Author not found
Content: MP Dullas Alahapperuma yesterday (25) proposed in Parliament that the G.C.E. O/L Examination not be conducted this year but that the students be provided with a certificate stating that they are qualified to enrol in A/L classes. Alahapperuma said that there is a situation at the moment where nearly 600,000 students are unable to move beyond the O/L stage. “So, why can’t we hold the exam this year? Instead Department of Examinations can issue certificates to students who have fulfilled the requirements to enrol in  A/L classes?” he queried.  Alahapperuma said during the Covid-19 pandemic, a similar decision was taken pertaining to the London O/L examinations. Education Minister Susil Premajayantha responded saying that the latter’s proposal is impractical in the current context. “The testing and evaluation process followed in the London syllabus is different from the local exams. In the London syllabus, the students are being evaluated in classroom continuously and those results are added to the final marks. We still have an exam-centric syllabus,” the Minister pointed out. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Child (7) dies of paracetamol overdose
author: Author not found
Content: In a tragic turn of events, a seven-year-old child died of an overdose of paracetamol. The Grade 2 student of the Uduwella Primary school, developed a fever and was given the paracetamol by the Gampola Kurunduwatte hospital. The post-mortem revealed that the child had died of paracetamol overdose. The child had been taken to the hospital twice, as she developed a fever. Whilst the doctor had specified a certain dosage of paracetamol for the child, the hospital pharmacist had written a dosage generally prescribed for adults, resulting in the overdose. Whilst the hospital has over 600 patients daily, there is only one pharmacist at the hospital pharmacy. Further, as the hospital is short of packets to provide medicine, they wrap medicine in paper or old electricity bills. Due to a high number of patients at the hospital, paracetamol and several other medicine have been already been wrapped in paper with a prescribed dosage for adults written in it. However, the dosage for children is usually written at the back of the packet. The parents of the seven-year old have given the child the dosage prescribed inside of the packet, which is for adults. The child has then developed a stomach pain and she was taken to the hospital on 22 April in a critical state. Whilst the child was directed to be admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU), the beds in the ICU of the Gampola, Peradeniya, Nawalapitiya and Kandy hospitalsd had been full, due to which the child was taken to the Teaching Hospital, Ragama. Due to the increased pain suffered by the child, she was anesthetised, following which she died the same evening. The post mortem revealed that the overdose had severally affected the child’s lung. BY Suranga Dilhan – Gampola

title: Who is Chamara Gunasekera?
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe made a shocking revelation yesterday (25) in Parliament that a whopping USD 250 million has been credited to the bank account of a person named Chamara Gunasekera, as a bribe from the operator of the MV X-Press Pearl, to prevent the Sri Lanka Government from receiving compensation for the damages caused by the ship fire.  Minister Rajapakshe, in response to questions raised by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, however, said that he cannot vouch for this information. “I received this information and I cannot be responsible for this. Also, I don’t know whether this can be used as evidence in the case too. The Ministry of Defence and the Police should conduct investigations to find the truth,” the minister said. Speaking further, Rajapakshe said a limitation procedure has been filed in the UK to limit the damages which the Sri Lankan Government could claim. Meanwhile, the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) queried as to why the case pertaining to obtaining compensation, for the damages caused by the X-Press Pearl fire, was filed in a Singapore Court when, according to the experts, it could have been filed in a local Court. Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella alleged that this move of the Government indicates that it does not trust Sri Lanka’s judicial system. Rajapakshe who responded said it is wrong and unfair to make such statements. “According to the normal procedure, these types of cases are filed in judicial zones where the complainant party had the best advantage. The Committee of experts, which was appointed to look into securing damages, including Ronald Perera, PC and Chandaka Jayasundera, PC also wanted to file the case in a local Court. However, after a discussion with the Attorney General, they agreed to file the case in a Singapore Court. It is the Attorney General who takes decisions on legal matters on behalf of the State,” the minister pointed out. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Minister Alles hands over complete PCoI Report to Catholic Bishops
author: Author not found
Content: The complete Report of the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) which probed the 21 April 2019, Easter Sunday terror attacks, was handed over to the Catholic Bishops’ Conference of Sri Lanka (CBCSL) by Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles. The report was handed over to CBCSL President, Bishop of Kurunegala, Harold Anthony Perera. It was handed over to the Catholic Bishops’ Conference with the President’s approval. A CBCSL spokesperson yesterday (25) said Rev. Perera had received six CDs comprising volumes of the report. He said the six CDs that were handed over to the Bishop’s Conference also contained the volumes that had “allegedly been left out earlier.” In 2021, Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith rejected the PCoI report, claiming that the person responsible for the attacks and those who funded the perpetrators had not been identified by the commission. “The report is incomplete and therefore unacceptable to the Catholic Bishops,” he said at the time.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Tsunami warning towers not in proper condition– Prof. Senaratne
author: Author not found
Content: If the tsunami warning towers erected along the country’s coastal belt are not in proper condition, it could lead to a catastrophic situation in Sri Lanka in the future, Professor of Geology of the University of Peradeniya, Athula Senaratne claimed. Prof. Senaratne made this remark in a backdrop of nine tremors reported in Sri Lanka from 1 January until Monday (24). Addressing the media in Kandy, he said currently an alarming trend for tremors had begun to take place globally. He is of the view that out of close to 10,000 tremors which occur worldwide what matters to Sri Lanka are those taking place encompassing the Sumatra Islands and the Indian Ocean. Prof. Senaratne however noted that Sri Lankans should not be unduly concerned of minor tremors that had been reported from various parts of the country. But, he insisted that officials would need to ensure that tsunami warning systems are operative 24/7, in case, a tremor exceeding 4.4 on the Richter Scale were to be detected close to the shores here. Meanwhile, magnitude 7.3 earthquake has struck west of Indonesia’s Sumatra Island, triggering a tsunami warning yesterday (24). The tsunami warning which was in place for around two hours, asked local authorities to immediately instruct residents of the affected area to move away from shores, but it has since been lifted. Meanwhile, Sri Lanka’s Department of Meteorology announced that there is no tsunami threat to Sri Lanka at present from the effect of above earthquake and that therefore, the coastal areas of Sri Lanka are declared safe.  “Public is further informed that this message is announced in consultation with relevant national and international agencies,” the National Tsunami Early Warning Centre said. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Women’s Orgs want foreign employment sector digitised
author: Author not found
Content: Several women’s organisations on Monday (24) urged Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara to digitise the foreign employment sector, to deter human smugglers and ensure the safety of women migrant workers. While pointing out that the foreign employment sector brings much needed foreign revenue to the country and a large number of Sri Lankan women are employed abroad, the organisations pointed out that digitising the sector was imperative to root out corruption and malpractices and ensure the safety of women migrant workers. Nanayakkara responded positively to the request made by the three organisations. The Village Women’s Front, Jasmine Women’s Organization and Galle Business Women’s Forum jointly handed over a memorandum to Nanayakkara on Monday (24) making a written request to digitise the field of foreign employment. It is stated in the letter, addressed to Nanayakkara, that their organisations have been dealing with expatriate women workers for a long time and that they are making this request to ensure the safety of Sri Lankan female migrant workers. The women’s organisations informed the minister that through digitisation, it will be possible to further develop the field of foreign employment, and ensure the protection of migrant workers. They said it will also help in providing speedy resolutions to the problems faced by the migrant workers. The organisations pointed out that by digitising the field of foreign employment, it will be possible to monitor online the process from applying for a foreign job until securing employment and going abroad for work, which will be transparent and fast. Such a mechanism they pointed out can put a stop to the activities of fraudsters and human smugglers who prey on innocent job seekers looking for greener pastures abroad. After accepting the organisation’s request, the minister told the media that he received a request to digitise the sector to ensure the safety of women going abroad from Sri Lanka, to prevent deficiencies, errors, corruption and malpractices in the field of foreign employment. “These people demanded to digitise the foreign employment sector and change the existing system to ensure holistic development. These people are a group that has always raised their voice highlighting the difficulties faced by migrant workers including the incident involving Rizana Nafeeq. They urged us to embrace new technology and a more transparent method of recruitment like other countries of the world to prevent such incidents from happening again,” he added. (NV)

title: Customs seizes Rs 84M worth ‘Canadian Kush’
author: Author not found
Content: Customs officers seized around Rs 84 million worth of ‘Kush’ cannabis at the Laksiri Cargo Terminal in Peliyagoda, on 24 April. An authorised wharf clerk had arrived to release the goods from Customs and he was arrested along with the stock of drugs. The stock of narcotics, concealed in two wooden crates, was couriered to the country by a person living in Canada. Customs officers found 24 parcels of ‘Kush’ weighing around 12 kg concealed in false bottoms in the two wooden crates. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: UL 120 diverts to MRIA
author: Author not found
Content: UL 120, flying from Gan Island to Colombo, diverted to Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport (MRIA) yesterday (25), for what appeared to be bad weather. The Airbus A320-200, registered 4R-ABO, climbed to 4,000 feet and went into a holding pattern near Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) at 5:15 p.m. yesterday, before diverting to MRIA 20 minutes later. Following a quick turnaround, the aircraft departed MRIA at 7:31 p.m. and landed at BIA around 7:50 p.m. By Adnan Ali Cassim

title: Novice monk aged eight assaulted
author: Author not found
Content: An eight-year-old novice Buddhist monk, who had allegedly been assaulted by three other monks, had initially been admitted to the Gampola Hospital, but was transferred to the Peradeniya Teaching Hospital, as his injuries were severe. According to Police, the novice monk who had been ordained only 45 days ago, had been set upon by the elder monks due to having fluffed his lines when reciting the sermons during the offering of flowers to the Buddha. The injured novice monk had resided at a temple situated at Pussellawa in Gampola. The relatives of the novice monk allege that despite a complaint lodged with regard   to the assault of the novice monk, the                     three elder monks are yet to be arrested and that no statement had been recorded either from them or from the Chief Incumbent of the Temple. (To report child   abuses call 1929: the hotline of National Child Protection Authority (NCPA) BY Suranga Dilhan – Gampola

title: 28-year-old cyclist killed in school bus crash
author: Author not found
Content: A 28-year-old Bemmulla cyclist died on the Kirindiwela-Gampaha Road on Monday (24) when his bicycle collided with a school bus. According to Police, the victim had succumbed to his injuries on admission to the Malwathuhiripitiya Hospital. Kirindiwela Police are conducting investigations. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: 18-year-old dies of lightning
author: Author not found
Content: An 18-year-old Balangoda resident died of lightning on Monday (24). The victim was pronounced dead on admission to the Balangoda Hospital. The body was kept at the Balangoda Hospital morgue. Balangoda Police are conducting investigations. By Dinithi Wijesundara and Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Eye Hospital resumes routine surgeries
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Health temporarily suspended the use of 20,000 vials of Prednisolone Acetate, following post-surgical infections in patients,after cataract surgeries at the National Eye Hospital, Colombo. While temporarily suspending the use and importation of a drug which caused post-surgical infections in patients following cataract surgery, the National Eye Hospital recommenced its routine operations on Monday (24), Consultant Vitreoretinal Surgeon at National Eye Hospital Colombo Kapila Bandutilake said.  Fielding questions during a media briefing held at the Health Ministry on Monday (24) Dr. Bandutilake said that Sri Lanka had received 50,000 vials of the Prednisolone Acetate one per cent while measures had been taken to temporarily suspend the use of 20,000 of them. The drug is registered with the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA). He said that the particular stock had been manufactured in December 2022, while the Date of Expiry was in November 2024. He said the Hospital performed an average 60 to 70 cataract surgeries daily and that those whose operations had been temporarily halted, due to the infection, would be rescheduled.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Quack doctor busted
author: Author not found
Content: A person masquerading as a doctor and prescribing medicines to patients at Upuldeniya, in Galenbindunuwewa, was arrested by the Galenbindunuwewa Police. Police arrested the suspected following a tip-off from the Anuradhapura Regional Director of Health Services. The suspect is 35-year-old Thusitha Naramwala. He had run a dispensary in Upuldeniya, Anuradhapura on the pretext of being a doctor. The suspect was enlarged on surety bail and ordered to appear before the Kahatagasdigiliya Chief Magistrate on 19 May. By Balasooriya – Galenbindunuwewa

title: Uni student’s killer further remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis on Monday (24) further remanded, till 8 May, the suspect, who has been charged with the stabbing to death of a 24-year-old university student. The suspect, identified as Pasindu Chathuranga, was a student of the University of Colombo. Cinnamon Gardens Police had arrested the suspect and produced him in Court, after which he had been ordered to be remanded, on charges of stabbing to death a female student of the University of Colombo. Her body was discovered lying near the scoreboard at the Race Course on 17 January. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: KPC organises protest against ATB
author: Author not found
Content: The Kilinochchi Press Club (KPC) has organised a protest against the Anti-Terrorism Bill (ATB). The protest, in Kilinochchi,  involving media personnel  is scheduled for Saturday, 29 April. The KPC said that if this anti-terrorism law, proposed by the Sri Lankan Government is passed, the media, which is considered to be the fourth pillar of democracy, will be at great risk and the media personnel won’t be able to carry out their duties independently. The media clubs in the Northern Province, social service activists and other organisations engaging in social service and willing to raise voice against the ATB have been asked to gather opposite the Kilinochchi Public Market on 29 April at 9.00 a.m. (NJ)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: UL 120 diverts to MRIA
author: Author not found
Content: UL 120, flying from Gan Island to Colombo, diverted to Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport (MRIA) yesterday (25), for what appeared to be bad weather. The Airbus A320-200, registered 4R-ABO, climbed to 4,000 feet and went into a holding pattern near Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) at 5:15 p.m. yesterday, before diverting to MRIA 20 minutes later. Following a quick turnaround, the aircraft departed MRIA at 7:31 p.m. and landed at BIA around 7:50 p.m. By Adnan Ali Cassim

title: Novice monk aged eight assaulted
author: Author not found
Content: An eight-year-old novice Buddhist monk, who had allegedly been assaulted by three other monks, had initially been admitted to the Gampola Hospital, but was transferred to the Peradeniya Teaching Hospital, as his injuries were severe. According to Police, the novice monk who had been ordained only 45 days ago, had been set upon by the elder monks due to having fluffed his lines when reciting the sermons during the offering of flowers to the Buddha. The injured novice monk had resided at a temple situated at Pussellawa in Gampola. The relatives of the novice monk allege that despite a complaint lodged with regard   to the assault of the novice monk, the                     three elder monks are yet to be arrested and that no statement had been recorded either from them or from the Chief Incumbent of the Temple. (To report child   abuses call 1929: the hotline of National Child Protection Authority (NCPA) BY Suranga Dilhan – Gampola

title: 28-year-old cyclist killed in school bus crash
author: Author not found
Content: A 28-year-old Bemmulla cyclist died on the Kirindiwela-Gampaha Road on Monday (24) when his bicycle collided with a school bus. According to Police, the victim had succumbed to his injuries on admission to the Malwathuhiripitiya Hospital. Kirindiwela Police are conducting investigations. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: CIABOC says they don’t have original copies of cheques
author: Author not found
Content: The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), yesterday (24) informed Colombo High Court Judge Damith Thotawatta, that they were currently not in possession of the original copies of the cheques, pertaining to the case filed against Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella and former Chairman of SPC Jayampathy Heenkenda. The Attorney General has charged the duo before the High Court, with causing a loss of revenue to the State, through the payment of the Ministers private telephone’s bill of Rs 230,984.45 from SPC funds, while Rambukwella had been serving as the Minister of Mass Media, from 15 March to 14 April 11 years ago. The Bribery Commission made the aforementioned revelation, when the Pre-Trial Conference of the case was convened. They however told Judge Thotawatta, that though they are not in possession of the original copies of the cheques, they could still furnish Photostat copies, if the need arose. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Court concluded the Pre-Trial Conference and deferred further proceedings of the case to 21 July. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Court approvescomparing DNA evidence
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya yesterday (24) granted approval to the CID to compare the DNA evidence collected from former Director of Janashakthi Insurance PLC Dinesh Schaffter, with that of veteran cricket commentator Brian Thomas. The Additional Magistrate ruled thus, having perused a request made to this effect by the CID. The CID informed the Court, that though previously DNA evidence had been collected from four persons, including the security officers at the Borella Cemetery and from a few Police officers, it had not matched with the DNA obtained from the late businessman. Furthermore, Dr. Asela Mendis Senior Lecturer in the Department of Forensic Medicine Toxicology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Colombo, told the Court that in order to compile a final report into the cause of death of Schaffter, the five-member Committee of Specialist Doctors, still needed to peruse a few more documents. He maintained that a few crucial reports were yet to be received, by his Committee, from the Government Analyst. Accordingly, Additional Magistrate Jayasuriya instructed the Court Registrar, to re-inspect the relevant documents and submit them to the five-member Committee of Specialists. Further proceedings were deferred to 8 May. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Send applications for Intermediate Grades directly to schools– Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: School enrolment applications for Grade 2 to Grade 11, except Grade 6, should only be sent to respective schools via registered post, the Education Ministry announced through a circular. As per the circular, schools will take the necessary steps to select students to fill the vacancies available within. The ministry will no longer issue letters to admit students to intermediate grades in national schools hereafter.

title: MSD short of 119 essential drugs
author: Author not found
Content: With Sri Lanka having used close to 99 per cent of the loans and credit, which had been given to purchase medicinal drugs, the Medical Supplies Division (MSD) was short of 119 essential drugs. Additional Secretary of the Health Ministry, Dr. Saman Ratnayake yesterday (24) said that of the 14 lifesaving drugs, two are produced locally. Hospitals were short of 25 of the 383 Essential drugs required by State hospitals.  Every hospital uses about 1,347 while 14 of them were lifesaving drugs, of which, two were produced locally. “However we can safely say that by May this year the dug shortage would reduce to about 60 drug types,” Dr. Ratnayake said adding that there had been reluctance on the part of medicinal drug suppliers to cater to Sri Lanka’s requirement with the country Health Ministry owing them a whopping Rs 230 million.  He said that the funds provided by the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank had been repurposed. “We did not have the required dollars to open letters of credit.  He said the Health Ministry had decided to open several more medicine manufacturing plants locally  as a result of this monetary crisis. There would be a pharmaceutical manufacturing zone in Oyamaduwa and Maloya.” He said the country faced an issue as many of laboratory equipment used required machine specific reagents. The Director General Health Services (DGHS), having discussed with medical specialists, has come up with a new model, so that only low cost lab equipment would be utilised to perform tests in order to face the economic crisis.  Citing an example, he said that there were machines which required over Rs 130 to perform a blood sugar test while the same test could be performed at Rs 30 per test on another. There are about 125 reagents in shortage, he added. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: HRCSL probes GCE A/L script marking delay
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) has commenced an investigation into the delay of conducting the G.C.E. Advanced Level examination 2022 answer script marking. The investigation has been launched following a complaint lodged by a group of parents of the students of Sri Rajasinghe College, Kotikawatta. The complaint said the delay of conducting paper marking is a violation of human rights of the students who sat for the examination. Accordingly, the HRCSL expects to summon all the relevant parties to the commission for an inquiry. BY Amith Madhuranga Gamage

title: Use water sparingly– NWSDB
author: Author not found
Content: The National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) requested the public not to use drinking water to wash vehicles and water plants during this dry weather period. According to the NWSDB, the use of water has increased by three per cent amidst the extreme hot weather conditions these days. A spokesperson of the NWSDB, said if this situation continues they would have no other option but to limit the water supply. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Petition seeking Diana’s arrest set aside
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (24) said there was no necessity for the Court to issue an order for State Minister Diana Gamage’s arrest, in connection with offence committed under the Provisions of the Immigration and Emigration Act. The Chief Magistrate observed that if the State Minister has flouted any Provisions contained in the said Act, the CID has been empowered by law, to take necessary measures against her. Accordingly, the Court, while setting aside the petition seeking Gamage’s arrest, instructed the CID to take necessary action against the State Minister concerned. Elaborating further, Chief Magistrate Alwis, opined that the CID sleuths, have been empowered by the Provisions contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure Act, to institute action against Gamage and maintained there was no need to seek an order from the Court. The petitioner had prayed the Court, to issue a warrant for the State Minister’s arrest, as the latter had violated Provisions contained in Section 32 of the Code of Criminal Procedure Act. The CID had produced submissions to Court two years ago, in connection with the case, stating that Gamage, through her conduct, had infringed Provisions contained in Section 175 of the Penal Code, as well as Section 45 (1) of the Immigration and Emigration Act No. 20 of 1948. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: TID restrained from recording statement or arresting Dappula
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (24) issued an Interim Order preventing the Terrorism Investigation Division (TID) from recording a statement from the former Attorney General, Dappula de Livera, pertaining to a statement made by him regarding the Easter Sunday attacks. Court also issued an interim order preventing the arrest of the former AG pending the hearing and determination of the Writ Application filed in this connection. This was when the said Writ Application, filed by de Livera, seeking an order preventing him from being so summoned or arrested was taken up before Courts. The former Attorney General was previously summoned by the TID on 19 April to record a statement pertaining to an alleged statement made by him, during his tenure as AG, that there was a certain conspiracy regarding the Easter Sunday attacks. However, he did not appear before the TID but a seven-page objection was filed on his behalf. Whilst the former Attorney General was summoned before the TID for the second time yesterday (24), the relevant Writ Application was filed by him seeking an order preventing the recording of a statement from him. It was noted in the Writ Application that statement in question was made by him in his capacity as the Attorney General in the public interest. It was also noted that as per the documentation made available to him at the time, there appeared to be a conspiracy in respect of the 2019 Easter Sunday attacks. However, the identities of relevant perpetrators were not revealed. Further it was stated that the Petitioner gave detailed instructions to the Inspector General of Police to carry out further investigations into the matter. The Petitioner expressly stated that except for the documentation made available to him at the time, in his capacity as the Attorney General, he has no further knowledge with regard to the relevant facts or circumstances. It was also observed that since he had retired as Attorney General, he does not possess any documentation in relation to this matter or any other matter pertaining to the discharge of his duties. The Petitioner pleaded that there cannot be any rational reason to question him at this stage, with regard to an interview made by him in his official capacity as Attorney General more than two years ago. The Petitioner further went on to observe that to question him in connection with the interview given by him in his official capacity as Attorney General to the media or to record a statement  is patently unlawful. It was also stated that the former Attorney General fears that there is a serious and imminent likelihood of him being arrested and that in the event he is arrested, there is a grave likelihood he would be detained without having access to bail. The former Attorney General also observed that on 21 April, a group of persons, said to be Police officers, had rung the bell at his residence, while banging on the door and calling out for him, thereafter persons at his residence had informed the said persons at the door that the Petitioner was not at home. It was observed that notwithstanding the same, the said persons remained outside the gate of the Petitioner’s residence and when the Petitioner’s son returned from work, the said persons had tried to follow him into the residence by force, wrongfully and/or unlawfully and/or without any authority whatsoever. Having been unable to enter the premises, the Petitioner stated that the said persons remained outside the premises for a long period of time while continuing to ring the bell and bang on the gate.  Thereby, following consideration of the Writ Application, Court issued an interim order preventing his arrest pending the hearing and determination of the Application. Court also issued an interim order preventing the questioning of the Petitioner, with regards to anything done by him in the course of discharging his duties in the capacity of Attorney General, pending the hearing and determination of the Application. Further, Court also issued an interim order preventing respondents from recording a statement from the Petitioner in regard to the interview/statement given by him in his capacity as Attorney General, pending the hearing and determination of this matter. By Faadhila Thassim

title: Court prevents SDIG Tennakoon being namedas suspect
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (24) issued a Stay Order, preventing the implementation of the instructions given by the Attorney General, to name Western Province SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon as a suspect in the 9 May 2022 attack on anti-Government protesters by SLPP supporters. The order was issued when the Petition filed by Tennakoon, against naming him as a suspect, was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and M.A.R. Marikkar. Further, Court also issued notice on the respondents, including the Attorney General and the Inspector General of Police (IGP). The Attorney General previously, in a letter to the IGP on 19 April, instructed to name Tennakoon as a suspect in the 9 May mayhem and to submit an amended list of suspects to Court. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Five remanded over destruction of restaurant
author: Author not found
Content: The Jaffna Magistrate remanded five suspects, till 3 May, including Arun Siddharthan, who functioned as a civil society activist in the Jaffna District. Jaffna Police had apprehended seven suspects, including Siddharthan, on charges of damaging a restaurant and its property in Jaffna and assaulting the restaurant owner. Of the seven suspects initially arrested two were women and as they were breastfeeding they were enlarged on Police bail, while the rest had been produced before Court. Police added that Arun Suddarthan had reportedly claimed to the media that he is the leader of the Ava Group in the Jaffna District. There are a spate of charges ranging from manslaughter, theft, causing of damage to property etc. pending in Court against him. BY Rasadi Chathurangi Gamage – Vavuniya

title: Doctor finds grenade
author: Author not found
Content: Chavakachcheri Police said a live hand grenade was recovered from a garden belonging to a doctor, near the Meenatchchi Amman Kovil in Sangattanai,  Chavakachcheri yesterday (24) morning. The doctor had found the grenade while he was cleaning the garden and subsequently handed it over to the Thambattai Army Camp in Chavakachcheri. The Chavakachcheri Police are conducting investigations. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Archaeological Reservation destroyed
author: Author not found
Content: Residents say that the historic Madugalla Archaeological Reservation, attached to Thrikonamaduwa, Welikanda in Polonnaruwa, had been completely destroyed by an organised group using a bulldozer. Residents said the archaeological reservation concerned had contained invaluable evidence related to the Anuradhapura period. They alleged that the reservation had been destroyed using backhoes and bulldozers and this destruction had taken place despite an order issued against it by the Supreme Court. BY Nimal Jayaratne – Manampitiya

title: Navy nab youth with Kerala cannabis
author: Author not found
Content: A 21-year-old individual, who was in possession of over 26 kg of Kerala cannabis, was arrested by the Sri Lanka Navy on Sunday (23), in the coastal area of Anthonypuram in Palali, Jaffna. The suspect is a resident of Anthonypuram. The Navy recovered about 26.17 kg of Kerala cannabis in 13 packages from a traditional boat used by the suspect. The suspect along with seized Kerala cannabis was handed over to the Palali Police for legal action. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: One dies in road mishap
author: Author not found
Content: A 65-year-old man died when the three -wheeler, he was travelling in,collided with a car on the Thanamalwila road, in Angunukolapelessa, on Sunday (23). The accident had resulted in four people including the three-wheeler driver being rushed to the Thanamalwila Hospital. However, one passenger, who was in the three-wheeler, was pronounced dead upon admission. Police are conducting investigations. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Police probe suspicious death
author: Author not found
Content: The Weerawila Police have initiated an investigation into a suspicious death reported from Tissamaharama, on Sunday (23). According to Police, the victim was hospitalised by family members after they had found him lying in front of his house the following day, having attended a party at a friend’s place. The victim was a 34-year-old resident of Tissamaharama. The body lies at the Hambantota Hospital morgue following the post-mortem. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Sgt Maj nabbed filming school girls on bus
author: Author not found
Content: A Sergeant Major, attached to the Galle Disaster Management Centre, had been set upon by a group of commuters on a bus, after he allegedly secretly filmed two female school students using his mobile phone. He was then handed over to the Habaraduwa Police. According to the commuters on the bus, the two students were standing near the seat occupied by the suspect when had started to videotape them. After the incident had been witnessed by a few passengers they had begun to assault the suspect before handeing him over to the Police. When contacted, Habaraduwa Police said the two students had not lodged a complaint against the suspect and as such, after recording a statement from him, he had been released on Police bail. BY Siri Gardiyage – Koggala

title: ‘Welcome Back to Sri Lanka’ tourism promotion workshop hosted in Brussels
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Brussels hosted a workshop, titled ‘Welcome Back to Sri Lanka’, for tourism promotion in the Belgian travel market, at the Press Club in Brussels on 20 April 2023, with the participation of over 80 guests, comprising tour operators, travel agents, travel bloggers, social media influencers, travel journalists, media professionals, and TV professionals. Sri Lanka’s Ambassador to Belgium, Grace Asirwatham, addressing the travel professionals, said Sri Lanka was beaming once again as a magnificent holiday destination after an unprecedented economic crisis, due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. While expounding on the measures taken in Sri Lanka to address the economic crisis, the Ambassador said that the year 2023 was a boom year for tourism, with a large number of tourists visiting Sri Lanka to experience a holiday of a lifetime to cherish, and requested that the travel professionals in Belgium promote Sri Lanka amongst their clients. Ambassador Asirwatham explained, in detail, the important reasons why Sri Lanka should be on their priority list of tourism destinations and summed up that, with its vivid diversity, Sri Lanka was a magical dreamland for any tourist who wanted to have a perfect holiday.  Honorary Consul of Sri Lanka in Antwerp Monique de Decker, and Managing Director of Andrews Travels in Sri Lanka Mahen Kariyawasan described what’s unique to Sri Lanka, mainly nature and landscape, historic and ancient sites, including eight UNESCO heritage sites, beaches, adventure and sports, wildlife, wellness and ayurveda, Sri Lankan cuisine, festivals, and shopping, as well as the quality tourism infrastructure facilities, including types of accommodation facilities, transport connectivity, advanced communication, and technology. Belgian travel industry professional Johan Six shared his experiences in Sri Lanka as a tourism destination and emphasised that Sri Lanka was an authentic and natural holiday land to be explored by all. Representatives of Emirates, Qatar Airways, Etihad, and Turkish Airlines, which operate connecting flights to Sri Lanka from Belgium, also attended the workshop. The workshop provided a splendid opportunity for participants to network while enjoying a Sri Lankan dinner.

title: Five remanded over destruction of restaurant
author: Author not found
Content: The Jaffna Magistrate remanded five suspects, till 3 May, including Arun Siddharthan, who functioned as a civil society activist in the Jaffna District. Jaffna Police had apprehended seven suspects, including Siddharthan, on charges of damaging a restaurant and its property in Jaffna and assaulting the restaurant owner. Of the seven suspects initially arrested two were women and as they were breastfeeding they were enlarged on Police bail, while the rest had been produced before Court. Police added that Arun Suddarthan had reportedly claimed to the media that he is the leader of the Ava Group in the Jaffna District. There are a spate of charges ranging from manslaughter, theft, causing of damage to property etc. pending in Court against him. BY Rasadi Chathurangi Gamage – Vavuniya

title: Doctor finds grenade
author: Author not found
Content: Chavakachcheri Police said a live hand grenade was recovered from a garden belonging to a doctor, near the Meenatchchi Amman Kovil in Sangattanai,  Chavakachcheri yesterday (24) morning. The doctor had found the grenade while he was cleaning the garden and subsequently handed it over to the Thambattai Army Camp in Chavakachcheri. The Chavakachcheri Police are conducting investigations. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Archaeological Reservation destroyed
author: Author not found
Content: Residents say that the historic Madugalla Archaeological Reservation, attached to Thrikonamaduwa, Welikanda in Polonnaruwa, had been completely destroyed by an organised group using a bulldozer. Residents said the archaeological reservation concerned had contained invaluable evidence related to the Anuradhapura period. They alleged that the reservation had been destroyed using backhoes and bulldozers and this destruction had taken place despite an order issued against it by the Supreme Court. BY Nimal Jayaratne – Manampitiya

title: Demo over cattle rustling
author: Author not found
Content: With cattle rustling on the rise, cattle breeders held a demonstration at Mallakam Junction in Jaffna yesterday (24) morning demanding, the arrest of the rustlers to ensure the safety of their animals. The protest was organised in response to the ongoing theft of cows being raised for food in the northern areas of Valigamam. The demonstrators also tied a cow at the location. They visited the office of Kankesanthurai SSP and submitted a petition. BY T. Pratheepan

title: Stray dogs at BIA a nuisance
author: Author not found
Content: Many stray dogs are roaming in and around the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) premises these days.  Most of these dogs cause inconveniences to passengers who had arrive at the BIA by sniffing their bags and parcels. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.
