title: Eye surgeries resume today
author: Author not found
Content: Surgeries at National Eye Hospital, Colombo will resume today (24), the Ministry of Health announced yesterday (23). Routine surgeries at the National Eye Hospital, Colombo came to a halt on 19 April following the detection of post-surgical infections in several cases. The use of ‘Prednisolone’, an eye drop imported from India, was found to have caused the complications. The Health Ministry said an investigation has commenced with regard to the matter.

title: Tourist arrivals in first 20 days of April, surpass April 2022 numbers
author: Author not found
Content: Tourist arrivals to the island in the first 20 days of this month (April), surpassed the totality of tourist arrivals for the whole of April 2022 by 10.83 per cent (6,819), Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA) statistics of Friday 21 April showed. Whereas the total number of tourist arrivals for the totality of April 2022 was a miserly 62,980, the corresponding number in only the first 20 days of this month (April 2023) amounted to 69,799, statistics further showed. Meanwhile, Sri Lanka, in the calendar year to 20 April 2023 has entertained a total of 405,478 tourists, whereas the figure for the totality of last year (2022) was a mere 719,978. This number of 405,478 is equivalent to 56.32 per cent of the total tourist arrival figure of last year. According to latest Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) data, tourism earnings in the first three months (first quarter) of the year was USD 529.8 million, a year on year (YoY) increase of 9.8 per cent (USD 47.4 million). Further, tourist arrivals in the first quarter of the year (2023), YoY increased by 17.64 per cent (50,345) to 335,679, latest SLTDA data further showed.  Tourism was Sri Lanka’s fifth largest foreign exchange earner last year (2022), behind garments, remittances, IT and IT enabled services exports and tea in that descending order, respectively, according to latest CBSL and Export Development Board data. Tourism earnings for the whole of last year (2022), totalled USD 1,136.3 million, a YoY increase of 124.2 per cent, while arrivals in the same period increased by 270.2 per cent YoY to 719,978, CBSL data also showed. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Govt mulling making SL air, sea hub inthe region – President
author: Author not found
Content: Addressing the 30- year development plan of the Colombo North Port workshop, on Friday (21) in Colombo, President Ranil Wickremesinghe emphasised that the Government’s intention is to make Sri Lanka an air and sea hub in the region. The country has to focus on its future in the next 25 years on how to make Sri Lanka a developed country, he added. The President also said the attention should be drawn to the development in India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Iran, and the entire Makran coast, in assessing the role that Sri Lanka. President Wickremesinghe also highlighted the adjustments to be taken in making Sri Lanka the hub of the Indian Ocean when the whole logistics and transportation in the region changes with the Chinese involvement in the East to West Railways in the African nation. The President also revealed that by 2050, India will be the most populous country in the world from 1.4 billion increasing to 1.7 billion people. The industrialisation of India is on a fast track, especially in some areas such as Gujarat, Maharashtra and especially Tamil Nadu. Highlighting the importance of probing the development in India to find the connectivity that’s going to take place between India and Sri Lanka, President Wickremesinghe pointed out the opportunities that Sri Lanka would receive. The event was attended by Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva, Chief of Staff to the President and Senior Adviser on National Security Sagala Ratnayake, Secretary of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K. D. S. Ruwanchandra, Chairman of the Sri Lanka Port Authority Keith D. Bernard, Directors of AECOM Infrastructure and Environment UK Ltd, Past Chairmen of the Ports Authority and other senior officials.

title: Delft Island shaken by multiple murders
author: Author not found
Content: Fear shook the Delft Island, 38 years after the Kumudini boat massacre of 1985, when five senior citizens were found hacked to death in a house at dawn on Saturday 22 April 2023. A 51-year-old deportee from Germany was arrested by Police on Saturday night in Punguduthivu over the murders. Three women and two men had succumbed to injuries by the time the incident was reported while another 100- year-old woman, who sustained injuries is being treated at Jaffna Hospital. According to Police the murders have taken place at around 4.00 a.m. on Saturday. The house owner Karthikesu Nagasundari (74), Naganathy Balasingham (75), his wife Balasingham Kanmanipillai (72), Velayutham Pillai Nagaratnam (76) and Subramaniam Mahadevan (78), who were closely related to each other were killed. Of the five murdered, two were expatriate Tamils from the United Kingdom. When a dog had barked to alert the neighbourhood, the suspect is alleged to have attempted to kill the dog but the animal had escaped with a cut injuries.  The owner of the house, who was living close to the Navy Camp in Nedundivu Mavali Jetty had been providing accommodation and food to people visiting the Delft Island. Her husband was also one of the Kumudini massacre victim and ever since then she had been living alone renting her house to earn a living. One was found dead outside the house and others inside the house on the bed and floor. The 8 km-long Deflt Island,  with its unique landscape of corals, white sandy beaches, and horses, had a population of over 25, 000 families before the civil war, but it has now been reduced to about 2,500 families. Those who have lived overseas have begun to arrive in their villages in the Northern Province. The five elderly people had come to Nedunthivu for their ancestral Hindu temple festival, travelling all the way from the United Kingdom.  The suspect was identified as Sabaratnam Raghu, in his early 50s, who was deported from Germany following the prosecution of an attempted murder case against him there. He is also suspected to be a drug addict but it is yet to be confirmed. He was apprehended while hiding in the neighbouring island, Punguduthivu on Saturday night. Apparently after the murder the suspect had boarded the first bus to Karikkatuwan and from there ferried to Pungudutivu. Also Minister of Fisheries, Douglas Devananda, who arrived at the Delft Island, said all those involved in the brutal murders should be brought to justice after impartial inquiry. He also stressed on the security of the people who are living in a fear psychosis over the shocking murders.  Magistrate Gajanithibalan visited Nedundivu and conducted investigations. Meanwhile, the Jaffna Forensic Police Team and the Judicial Medical Officer went to the spot and conducted investigations. The people in the area staged a protest when the Magistrate had arrived at the house where the incident took place. They protested demanding that the criminals should be identified immediately and given the maximum punishment and the safety of the people of Nedundivu should be ensured. The suspect had said that he had been visiting the elderly often and also stayed couple of days with the elderly people in that house, which is at close proximity to the Sri Lanka Navy checkpoint. “I was staying at their house. I decided to steal the jewellery they were wearing because I needed money. If I stole the jewellery alone, I would get caught so I killed them all to divert suspicion,” the suspect in his early 50s had revealed to the Police. Police said that 26 sovereign of gold jewellery, clothes and mobile phones were seized from the suspect. Those five murdered with brutal cuts were recovered from a house near the Sri Lanka Naval camp in the 12th division of Delft Island, near the Mavili jetty. A 100-year-old woman who was rescued in critical condition and admitted to Jaffna Teaching Hospital for treatment has been recounting her ordeal. In relation to the event, a Police team led by Inspector Sai Menon and advised by Jaffna Regional Senior Superintendent of Police Vishanth launched an expedited inquiry on the orders of Jaffna District Deputy Inspector General of Police Manjula Senarath. According to the information gathered by the Police, the suspect who had roamed in Nendutivu left Delft Island early Saturday morning. A 51-year-old man was arrested and deported to Sri Lanka after being found guilty of attempted murder in Germany. He was arrested with a large amount of gold jewellery. During the investigation, the suspect confessed., “If I come to Nedundivu, I used to stay at the home of the elderly people. I stayed there  a few days ago. These expats were wearing gold jewellery. I planned to go back to Germany and for that purpose I had to make my passport and needed money to go back to Germany, he had confessed. Further he had said, “So, on Saturday morning at about 4.30 am I planned to kill everyone who was sleeping and take the jewellery and escape. I killed them all to divert the police investigation,” the suspect told Police. He also said that he dropped the knife he used in the killings in a well in Neduntivu. The suspect was taken to the Delft Island to collect evidences related to the murder. Pix by T. Pratheepan – Jaffna Correspondent By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan and T. Pratheepan

title: Moulavi arrested over bogusattack warning
author: Author not found
Content: The CID arrested a Moulavi, who allegedly made a phone call to the Police emergency hotline 118, that attacks could be carried out in mosques in Akurana and several Muslim-majority areas in the country. Following this phone call, security was beefed up in Akurana, Kandy on Wednesday (19), following the phone call received by the Police emergency hotline, on the previous night, about a possible attack on mosques during prayers in the holy month of Ramadan. The residents in the town also started checking devotees who came to the mosques. The suspect had given these phone calls on 18 and 19 April. Special Police teams were sent to Akurana following the warning. Those teams will remain in the town until the situation is resolved. The Police after a thorough investigation found out that the phone call was a bogus and the person, a Moulavi in Harispattuwa was arrested. Police Spokesperson SSP Nihal Thalduwa said owing to these bogus phone calls, a large sum of State funds was wasted and the Police and other security forces were severely inconvenienced. SSP Thalduwa warned that although people can make such bogus phone calls, the Police can find out who they are within a short period. BY Keerthi Mendis

title: X-Press Pearl case to be filed today in Singaporean Court
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General’s Department will file a case today (24) in the Commercial Court in Singapore against the owners of MV X-Press Pearl, demanding compensation for the massive environmental damage caused by the shipwreck. The X-Press Pearl incident was the worst maritime disaster to have struck Sri Lanka. It has had a significant impact on the country’s sensitive coastal environment, local communities and the economy. Moreover, the event continues to unfold, and its active pollution generation phase will only come to a  with the elimination of the risks from the wreck and containers lost at sea. The Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) warned on 4 April that if legal action is not instituted in connection with the MV X-Press Pearl ship fire before 29 May, Sri Lanka will have to forfeit its right to compensation worth an estimated USD 10 billion. The Marine Environment Protection Authority (MEPA) said it has provided all necessary documents to the Attorney General’s Department to prosecute the ship owner or the operator or the ship’s agents in Sri Lanka under the Criminal Law, in terms of Section 26 of the Prevention of Maritime Corruption Act. Meanwhile, environmentalists say that going to Singapore has its disadvantages for Sri Lanka as there are many International Conventions that apply in Singapore, as opposed to Sri Lanka. Attorney -at-Law/Legal Counsel, an expert in Law of the Sea and Maritime Law Dr. Dan Malika Gunasekera, in a recent interview with Ceylon Today, said  the Sri Lankan Marine Pollution Prevention Act and other laws cannot be used in Singapore and further emphasised that Sri Lanka is under no obligation to travel to Singapore and that the Cabinet and Parliament could revert the decision in doing so, in order to bring a lawsuit against the X-press Pearl vessel, which had polluted the country’s ecosystem, in Sri Lanka.

title: FUTA challenges President to carry out threat
author: Author not found
Content: Condemning the President’s ultimatum that properties of teachers and university lecturers who do not come to mark the G.C.E. Advanced Level examination 2022 answer scripts, would be confiscated, the Federation of University Teachers’ Associations (FUTA) said it might decide to voluntarily return to paper marking, once the President’s threat fails and are confident that they would not be bullied or threatened by anyone. It is only out of consideration for students’ and parents’ concerns, FUTA said in a statement. “We will never give up our struggle until the people of this country triumph, but we may change the focus and direction of our trade union action so as to ease the public burden as we continue to fight for justice and fairness, both for our members and the country at large,” the statement said. Challenging the President, FUTA said it wishes to call the President’s bluff and challenge him to implement his threat against university academics in the country. “He has stated that he will declare Education as an Essential Service and prosecute all academics who do not comply with his draconian regulations. He has gone on record threatening all of us that at the end of this week he will begin arresting us and confiscating our property,” FUTA added. “Yet, he is deafeningly silent about the ill-gotten gains of politicians who destroyed and bankrupted this country! Mr. President, this threat is both illegal and unjust, so we challenge you to do your worst. GCE Advanced Level marking is an additional activity that university academics perform as a national service. It is not part of our regular duties, nor, it should be noted, are we even paid properly for this work. Many of us have not even been remunerated the pittance due to us for work done in 2022.  “We wish to clarify that the President’s hypocritical concern for AL students is not matched by his Government withholding even basic resources from the university and school systems. The universities are now expected to run without recruiting staff even for existing vacancies, basic supplies are being withheld, student grants and loans are not being paid and hostel and canteen facilities are woefully inadequate. Hundreds of students cannot follow courses due to financial and other constraints. Teachers cannot teach due to lack of space and materials. If the Government was really concerned about students and their education, surely, much more would have been done to alleviate this crisis, instead of pretending that AL marking is the only deadlock,” FUTA said.

title: Agreement signed to build S Asia’s largest Commercial and Logistics Centre
author: Author not found
Content: The Construction Agreement, for South Asia’s largest Commercial and Logistics Centre, was signed recently under the patronage of Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva. The total construction cost of the facility is estimated to be USD 400 million and will be implemented as a Public Private Partnership (PPP) Project. Accordingly, 70 per cent of total shareholding will be owned by China Merchant Company, 15 per cent by Sri Lanka Ports Authority, and 15 per cent by Access Company. “The ownership of the centre will be vested upon Sri Lanka Ports Authority in 50 years time,” the Minister said. He said economic progress of the country would be greatly strengthened with the construction of the South Asia’s largest Commercial and Logistics Centre in Sri Lanka. The signing of the agreement took place on 21 April 2023 at the Ministry between Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva and Miao Jianmin, Chairman of the China Merchants Port Holdings Company Limited. Expressing his views, the Minister said that the investment opportunity received from the Chinese Government was highly appreciated at a time the country was facing an economic crisis. “The construction of this Logistics Centre will increase the number of vessels calling the Port of Colombo thereby further strengthening credibility placed on the port,” he said. The Centre will generate the ground rent as fixed by the Government Assessor and the State Royalty of 15 per cent out of profit as government revenue. This eight-storey building with a height of 92m will consist of state of the art technology. The total warehouse capacity will be 530,000 Cubic Metres. The construction of the Logistics Centre inside the Colombo port will expedite container and cargo transportation between the port and Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) using the Port Access Elevated Highway (PAEH). The time constraint will be reduced to 30 minutes. The Minister said that the port community, including stakeholders of port and commercial maritime industry have expressed confidence that construction of the Logistics Centre in the Port of Colombo would make the port the strongest maritime Centre in South Asia. The Secretary to the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, the Chairman of Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA)  Keith D. Bernard, several officials of SLPA and the investment company were also present at the occasion.

title: PM, Indian HC issue special cover for Seethai Amman Temple
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, accompanied by High Commissioner of India and other dignitaries, issued a Special Commemorative Cover for the Seethai Amman Temple in Seetha Eliya, Nuwara Eliya yesterday (23). They also laid the foundation stone for a Meditation Centre at the Temple, which is believed to signify the place of Ashok Vatika in the epic Ramayana. Furthermore, the Meditation Centre will add to the facilities at the Temple and help attract more tourists from India and other places to Nuwara Eliya.

When a dog had barked to alert the neighbourhood, the suspect is alleged to have attempted to kill the dog but the animal had escaped with a cut injuries.  The owner of the house, who was living close to the Navy Camp in Nedundivu Mavali Jetty had been providing accommodation and food to people visiting the Delft Island. Her husband was also one of the Kumudini massacre victim and ever since then she had been living alone renting her house to earn a living. One was found dead outside the house and others inside the house on the bed and floor. The 8 km-long Deflt Island,  with its unique landscape of corals, white sandy beaches, and horses, had a population of over 25, 000 families before the civil war, but it has now been reduced to about 2,500 families. Those who have lived overseas have begun to arrive in their villages in the Northern Province. The five elderly people had come to Nedunthivu for their ancestral Hindu temple festival, travelling all the way from the United Kingdom.  The suspect was identified as Sabaratnam Raghu, in his early 50s, who was deported from Germany following the prosecution of an attempted murder case against him there. He is also suspected to be a drug addict but it is yet to be confirmed. He was apprehended while hiding in the neighbouring island, Punguduthivu on Saturday night. Apparently after the murder the suspect had boarded the first bus to Karikkatuwan and from there ferried to Pungudutivu. Also Minister of Fisheries, Douglas Devananda, who arrived at the Delft Island, said all those involved in the brutal murders should be brought to justice after impartial inquiry. He also stressed on the security of the people who are living in a fear psychosis over the shocking murders.  Magistrate Gajanithibalan visited Nedundivu and conducted investigations. Meanwhile, the Jaffna Forensic Police Team and the Judicial Medical Officer went to the spot and conducted investigations. The people in the area staged a protest when the Magistrate had arrived at the house where the incident took place. They protested demanding that the criminals should be identified immediately and given the maximum punishment and the safety of the people of Nedundivu should be ensured. The suspect had said that he had been visiting the elderly often and also stayed couple of days with the elderly people in that house, which is at close proximity to the Sri Lanka Navy checkpoint. “I was staying at their house. I decided to steal the jewellery they were wearing because I needed money. If I stole the jewellery alone, I would get caught so I killed them all to divert suspicion,” the suspect in his early 50s had revealed to the Police. Police said that 26 sovereign of gold jewellery, clothes and mobile phones were seized from the suspect. Those five murdered with brutal cuts were recovered from a house near the Sri Lanka Naval camp in the 12th division of Delft Island, near the Mavili jetty. A 100-year-old woman who was rescued in critical condition and admitted to Jaffna Teaching Hospital for treatment has been recounting her ordeal. In relation to the event, a Police team led by Inspector Sai Menon and advised by Jaffna Regional Senior Superintendent of Police Vishanth launched an expedited inquiry on the orders of Jaffna District Deputy Inspector General of Police Manjula Senarath. According to the information gathered by the Police, the suspect who had roamed in Nendutivu left Delft Island early Saturday morning. A 51-year-old man was arrested and deported to Sri Lanka after being found guilty of attempted murder in Germany. He was arrested with a large amount of gold jewellery. During the investigation, the suspect confessed., “If I come to Nedundivu, I used to stay at the home of the elderly people. I stayed there  a few days ago. These expats were wearing gold jewellery. I planned to go back to Germany and for that purpose I had to make my passport and needed money to go back to Germany, he had confessed. Further he had said, “So, on Saturday morning at about 4.30 am I planned to kill everyone who was sleeping and take the jewellery and escape. I killed them all to divert the police investigation,” the suspect told Police. He also said that he dropped the knife he used in the killings in a well in Neduntivu. The suspect was taken to the Delft Island to collect evidences related to the murder. Pix by T. Pratheepan – Jaffna Correspondent By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan and T. Pratheepan

title: Minister Alles advises new SIs to be honest in their duties
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles, addressing a group of Sub Inspectors, who were recently deployed for duty, advised them not to fall prey to rotten eggs within the Police Department, as such individuals could be found in any State institution. The Minister made this remark addressing 189 Sub Inspectors, who were deployed for duty after following an initial training course at the Police College, Kalutara. Speaking further, Minister Alles said, “When you are assigned to your respective Police Stations you could become one of the rotten eggs, but you should exhibit foresight not to fall into that trap. If you could avoid that trap you will make your parents proud. If you are serving at the Police Department, you will need to be honest, steadfast and act according to the law, while striving to maintain peace in the country. “From today you will be compelled to face different kinds of challenges. When you are assigned to different areas, those involved in the illegal drug peddling racket and those from the underworld will flock around you. But, you should remember not to become a pawn in their game. If you do your job honestly and without fear or favour, I will support you to the hilt,” the Minister added. BY Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: 73rd ‘Battle of the Golds’ Sebs take major honours in drawn game
author: Author not found
Content: Sebastianites Sanesh Fernando (1st inning) and Vimath Dinsara (2nd inning) scored centuries in Moratuwa’s big match between St. Sebastian’s and Prince of Wales which ended in a draw at De Soysa Stadium Moratuwa on Saturday. Sandeesh Fernando claimed 6 wickets for 67 runs. St. Sebastian’s had scored 207 runs for 2 wickets in 58 overs at close. Vimath Dinsara scored an unbeaten 101 runs in 150 balls with 7 boundaries. Vimath and Adesh Almeida (79) were involved in 166 runs stand for the 2nd wicket. title: Bogus PHIs make a killing
author: Author not found
Content: A complaint has been lodged with the Kuliyapitiya Police that a group had been obtaining money from shops and large scale canteens, in the Kuliyapitiya town, pretending to be PHIs. The complaint was lodged by PHIs at the office of Medical Officer of Health (MOH), Kuliyapitiya. PHIs urge the public not to deposit any money following any such phone calls and to inform the MOH office. BY Shakya Induwara – Kuliyapitiya

title: FAO, EU to boost paddy cultivation
author: Author not found
Content: The Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) and the European Union (EU) launched a new programme to strengthen food security in Sri Lanka by boosting productivity and sustainability of paddy cultivation. The 4 million Euro (approximately  Rs 1.5 billion) initiative funded by the EU was initiated at an event held at the Bataatha Agro Technology park in Hambanthota under the auspices of Minister of Agriculture, Mahinda Amaraweera, EU Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Denis Chaibi and FAO Representative in Sri Lanka, Vimlendra Sharan. Implemented by FAO with the support of the Ministry of Agriculture and the Mahaweli Authority, the programme targets 71,000 smallholder paddy farmers and 1,200 paddy seed farmers across seven districts including Polonnaruwa, Badulla, Ampara, Matale, Puttalam, Kurunegala and Hambantota Districts who were severely impacted by the recent-economic crisis. Speaking at the event, which saw the official start of the farmer field schools, EU Ambassador Chaibi said, “With this new action, we want to help farmers not only to grow more, but most importantly to grow better so that they can increase their production and incomes, but also protect the environment around them. We hope that together with FAO and the Government of Sri Lanka we can gradually promote a transition towards greener and climate-smart agriculture. Transition  that produces sufficient amount of food, while protecting the planet and its people.” The recipient farmers will receive material and technical support to transition from traditional cultivation methods into climate-smart, modern farming techniques. The eligible paddy farmers cultivating up to 0.5 ha of land will receive 50 kg urea fertiliser and necessary tools to enhance efficiency of fertiliser use. 3,820 tonnes of urea fertiliser procured by the programme were already handed over to the Ministry of Agriculture to be distributed among selected smallholder paddy farmers and paddy seed farmers. Paddy seed farmers supported through the programme will also receive locally produced, high quality paddy seeds alongside material support such as parachute trays to improve efficiency and profitability of cultivation methods. Furthermore, all recipients will be enrolled in farmer-field schools to improve knowledge sharing on modern techniques such as the Integrated Plant Nutrient Management (IPNM) strategy to boost efficiency and reduce dependency on the use of chemical fertiliser. Minister Amaraweera expressed his appreciation to the FAO and the EU for the implementation of a holistic programme to improvie sustainability of Sri Lanka’s paddy sector and said, “Our paddy farmers underwent significant challenges over the past few years. This support we received from FAO and the EU is a testament to their perseverance during the tough times, for which we are thankful. These inputs and knowledge sharing will no doubt elevate the quality of rice production and the livelihoods of Sri Lankan paddy farmers.” “This programme marks an important milestone in FAO’s work in Sri Lanka over the past year – the shift back into development from the emergency response. We are grateful for the support we have received from the EU to implement this programme, which aims to address some of the longstanding concerns in the local paddy sector, to reach better production, leading to better nutrition, a better environment and improve food security for all Sri Lankans,” FAO Representative in Sri Lanka, Sharan said.  The EU and FAO will continue to work closely with the Government of Sri Lanka and key partners to support the recovery of the agriculture sector while building resilience and sustainability into the sector to increase yield and profit for smallholder farmers as the sector recovers.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Kuwait – SL Unity donates to Apeksha Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: Kuwait – Sri Lankan Unity, an association of Sri Lankans working in Kuwait, recently donated a consignment of vaccines and drugs used for treatment of cancer patients and milk packs worth more than Rs 2.5 million to the Apeksha Hospital, Maharagama. title: Fmr MEPA Chair was against X-Press Pearl case being heard in Singapore
author: Author not found
Content: Former Marine Environmental Protection Authority (MEPA) Chairman Dharshani Lahandapura claimed she went against the decision taking the X-Press Pearl disaster matter to the Courts in Singapore. She claimed, however, Minister of Justice Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe submitted the Cabinet Paper requesting to file the case in Singapore to obtain the compensation claims. “The proposal to file a case in Singapore was submitted by Minister of Justice, and I and the other stakeholders were completely opposed to it,” she said. She added that after receiving the first two payments, for cleaning the beach, in US dollars, she rejected the P&I Club’s offer to pay the third instalment for Beach Cleaning Compensation in LKR at the height of the nation’s economic crisis. She argued that the P&I club had attempted to take advantage by having the beach cleaning compensation settled in LKR, and she presented Minister Prasanna Ranatunga with a Cabinet memo demanding that the payment be made in US dollars, to which the Minister consented. She continued, “But that assertion is currently on hold.” She said she was forced to accept the LKR settlement despite the Cabinet’s approval to take the settlement in USD, but that decision has since been put on hold because if legal action is taken again on this matter the compensation for Beach Cleaning would further delay. She added that it would take only two to three days to identify the person or people, who took a USD 250 million bribe on the X-Pearl disaster compensation, as mentioned by the Minister of Justice. She advised against delaying as it would set a poor example for all the organisations working to obtain compensation from the vessel owner and the P&I club insurer, including the NARA, MEPA, expert committee Merchant Shipping, etc. She claimed that many had questioned whether MEPA was at fault, because the lawsuit, which was supposed to be filed before 23 September 2022, was actually filed on 23 January 2023. According to Lahandapura, MEPA and she fought against some of the judgments that interfered with their mission. Lahandapura claimed that MEPA and she had fought against some of the rulings that had prevented them from securing compensation for the X-Press Pearl disaster, but that the bribe allegations could cast a negative light on those institutions, who worked for the compensation and cause their operations to collapse if the claims were not proven but kept going. The declaration by the Minister of Justice, stated that he obtained information regarding the transfer of USD 250 million to a Sri Lankan’s foreign account as a bribe to obstruct the legal process related to the X-Press Pearl disaster. He then ordered the Police to begin an investigation into the matter. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Police fail to arrest teacher over assault on student
author: Author not found
Content: A teacher who thrashed a Grade 13 biology stream female student, of a leading Tamil medium school in Hatton, has not been arrested as yet, eventhough a complaint has been lodged with the Hatton Police, the parents of student alleged. According to the parents, the teacher thrashed their daughter bundling five canes together on 21 April because she did not attend a private biology class. The student, who sustained injuries due to the beating, was admitted to Dickoya Base Hospital. The parents alleged that this teacher in question has beaten other students on several occasions as well. When queried from the Police as to why he has not been arrested yet, the Police said the teacher had also got admitted to Dickoya Base Hospital claiming to have had a heart attack. Actions will be taken against him following advices of the doctors, the Hatton Police said. BY Neeta PathmaKumari – Norwood

title: Kenya cult deaths: 21 bodiesfound in investigationinto ‘starvation cult’
author: Author not found
Content: Kenyan police exhumed 21 bodies near the coastal town of Malindi, as they investigate a preacher said to have told followers to starve to death. Dead children were among those exhumed, and police said they expected to find even more bodies. The shallow graves are in Shakahola forest, where 15 members of the Good News International Church were rescued last week. Preacher Paul Mackenzie Nthenge is in custody, pending a court appearance. State broadcaster KBC described him as a ‘cult leader’, and reported that 58 graves have so far been identified. One of the graves is believed to contain the bodies of five members of the same family – three children and their parents. Mackenzie has denied wrongdoing, but has been refused bail. He insists that he shut down his church in 2019. He allegedly told followers to starve themselves in order to ‘meet Jesus’. The Kenyan daily The Standard said pathologists will take DNA samples and conduct tests to determine whether the victims died of starvation. Police arrested Mackenzie on 15 April after finding the bodies of four people suspected of having starved themselves to death. Victor Kaudo of the Malindi Social Justice Centre told Citizen TV “when we are in this forest and come to an area where we see a big and tall cross, we know that means more than five people are buried there”. The preacher allegedly named three villages Nazareth, Bethlehem and Judea and baptised followers in ponds before telling them to fast, The Standard reports. Kenya is a religious country and there have been previous cases of people being lured into dangerous, unregulated churches or cults. (BBC)

title: March for Justice for Easter Attacks Victims
author: Author not found
Content: The march, demanding Justice for the Easter Sunday terror attack victims, started from St. Sebastian’s Church, Katuwapitiya yesterday (20) evening. The march will conclude at the St. Anthony’s Church, Kochchikade today (21) morning. A human chain along the roads will be formed today (21) in protest against the Government’s failure to deliver justice to the victims of the Easter Sunday terror attacks. The Catholic Church in Sri Lanka recently requested the public to silently line up on the road from 8.00 a.m. – 9.00 a.m. on the day, along the Colombo-Negombo Main Road, Galle Road from Dehiwala to Moratuwa or from Kalutara to Beruwala. Pix by Janindu de Zoysa

title: MRP of eggs by weight gazetted
author: Author not found
Content: A Gazette notification was issued by the Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) imposing a maximum retail price (MRP) for eggs by weight. The Gazette notification came into effect yesterday (20). Accordingly, the MRP of a kilo of white eggs is Rs 880, while the MRP of a single white egg is Rs 44.  The MRP of a kilo of brown eggs is Rs 920 and the MRP of a single brown egg is Rs 46. The CAA has also ordered that no Manufacturer, Producer, Supplier, Distributor or Trader shall sell, supply, expose or offer for sale, or display for sale the item listed below, exceeding the Maximum Retail Price. Earlier this week, the All Ceylon Egg Producers’ Association (ACEPA) Chairman Sarath Ratnayake said it would be difficult to reduce the price of local eggs this week, but had come to a decision to sell a local egg below Rs 50. He said when striving to reduce the price of eggs in the domestic market several factors would need to be considered at length and insisted that they cannot opt for ad-hoc decisions which could worsen the plight of local traders who make a living through the industry. “As a result of extreme hot weather these days, the hens are dying. Some farmers have sold their hens for meat as well,” he said.  Ratnayake noted that most traders have taken the decision to opt out of the trade due to the recent decision taken by the Government to import eggs from India. He added that if the CAA does not arbitrarily interfere with the egg manufacturers, his Association would be able to reduce the local egg price by a sizeable amount by 1 May. However, the All Ceylon Egg Producers’ Association (ACEPA) stressed that it is impossible to sell eggs according to prices gazette by the CAA,  ACEPA Chairman Sarath Ratnayake said if an egg is 38g, 1kg of eggs will contain 28 eggs. So, the egg producers will receive only Rs 31 per egg, if 1kg of eggs is priced at Rs 880. If an egg is 50g, there would be 20 eggs per 1kg. If that happens, we have to wait for five months to earn profits, he said. Therefore, a kilo of eggs should be priced at least Rs 900, he said. Meanwhile, the shortage of eggs in the market still prevails, even ifthough the CAA sets a MRP for a kilo of eggs. Many super markets and shops said due to the confusion following the Gazette they did not order eggs. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: IMF programmea ruse to carry out undemocratic actions – SJB
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is stifling democracy, taking away the rights of the people to speak and protest, under the guise of implementing the IMF programme, the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) alleged. Addressing a media briefing, on Wednesday (19) MP Dr. Harsha de Silva said the Government is struggling to put forward the Anti-Terrorism Bill and create a situation where anyone who attempts to protest against its agenda and expresses their opinion through social media could be interpreted as an act of terrorism and placed in detention for months. “We strongly condemn what they are trying to do under the disguise of the IMF. Compared to last year, this year’s New Year festive season has changed. Even though the difficulties faced by the common people in the country have been reduced to some extent, it does not mean that the situation has been restored. However, the situation has improved a little bit,” he said. Dr. de Silva further said everyone knows that the Government is engaged in  undemocratic actions under the guise of the IMF. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Child trafficking ring exposed
author: Author not found
Content: A human trafficking ring was exposed after an eagle-eyed Malaysian Immigration Department officer noticed discrepancies during an appointment for a new passport. Immigration Director-General Datuk Ruslin Jusoh said the modus operandi of a group that trafficked Sri Lankan children to Europe was uncovered following the arrest of a local husband and wife couple, aged 37 and 26, respectively, on April 12 in Kuala Lumpur. “The syndicate would convince parents to bring the birth certificates of their children aged 12 to the Immigration Department office in the guise of making a passport. “However, the child brought to the counter would instead be one of a similar age from Sri Lanka and that child will be sent to get their photo taken and fingerprints recorded,” he said in a statement yesterday. He said the suspects, who led the syndicate, were also the “transporters” who would take the Sri Lankan children, who have successfully obtained their passports, to Europe. “Investigations are underway to trace and determine how many children have been involved and how long the syndicate had been in operation. “Based on preliminary investigations, the syndicate was paid between €30,000 and €50,000 (RM145,906 to RM243,177) for each child who got a passport and escorted to Europe,” Ruslin said The couple was busted after going to the Kuala Lumpur Immigration Department branch when they were attempting to get a passport. They were stopped after discrepancies were found during the application process and an officer proceeded to interview the child. The child failed to communicate in Bahasa Malaysia and had distinct facial differences from the suspects. The suspects were brought to the Kuala Lumpur Courthouse yesterday and would be held at the Kajang prison until May 11 for their case to be mentioned (The Star)

title: Public opinion being sought – Agri Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: In the light of controversies surrounding the proposal to send Toque monkeys to China, Secretary to the Ministry of Agriculture Gunadasa Samarasinghe noted that over 100,000 monkeys had been requested by a Chinese animal breeding company for breeding purposes. He said however that it is yet at the request stage and the relevant stakeholders have been informed of the same and no decision has been taken in this connection. Samarasinghe added that the Ministry is seeking public opinion and the opinion of several parties including environmentalists and experts in the field, prior to taking any decision. He emphasised that several factors will also be taken into consideration, prior to taking any decision in this regard, including the legitimacy of the company, the wildlife laws in China and wildlife laws in Sri Lanka. Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera however previously observed that the request for Toque monkeys from Sri Lanka was for Chinese zoos. He said a Chinese company, that handles several private zoological gardens, made a request to provide monkeys from Sri Lanka for their zoos, adding however that a committee comprising representatives from the Department of Wildlife Conservation, Department of Zoological Gardens, Attorney General’s Department, Ministry of Agriculture and Department of Agriculture will be appointed to inspect the request. Amaraweera also observed that a Cabinet Paper for the appointment of a committee to look into the request is to be submitted. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: CBSL tightens central controls
author: Author not found
Content: Following the incident in which Rs 5 million in cash went missing from a safe at Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) recently, the CBSL has strengthened the internal controls and processes. In a statement the CBSL said investigations are underway into the Rs 5 million that was reported missing from a safe of the CBSL. The CBSL said a shortage of a cash bundle worth Rs 5 million (Rs 5,000 denomination) was discovered in a vault of the Central Bank during the currency operations on 11 April 2023.  “An internal probe into the matter was commenced immediately, while a complaint was also lodged at the Fort Police Station. The Police investigation is in progress,” the bank said.  The Central Bank further stated that it is taking necessary measures to thoroughly investigate the incident and strengthen the internal controls, processes, etc.  The CBSL added that it will also continue assisting the Police to carry out the investigations BY Methmalie Dissanayake.

title: Magistrate rejects Police request to ban protest
author: Author not found
Content: Negombo Acting Magistrate Indika de Silva yesterday (20) rejected a request from the Negombo Police to issue an injunction banning a demonstration, scheduled to be held today (21), demanding justice for those who died and those who sustained long-lasting injuries, following the Easter Sunday terror blasts, four years ago. The Acting Magistrate said the fundamental rights of citizens could be violated, via the issuance of injunctions by the Judiciary, willy-nilly, as sought by the Police and based on their imaginations. The Acting Magistrate made this remark, while dismissing a request made to him by the Chief Inspector of Negombo Police. Acting Magistrate de Silva opined that the Judiciary has no right whatsoever to infringe upon the fundamental rights enshrined in the Articles of the country’s Constitution. He said Constitution guarantees its citizens convene peacefully at rallies and air their views, either in support of the incumbent Government or to even express dissent. He pointed out that if injunctions were to be issued at the drop of a hat, to accommodate such frivolous requests by the Police, it would be a violation of fundamental rights of the people, guaranteed in the Constitution. He then mentioned that if anyone were to indulge in any activity that hinders public peace, then the Police could always act, according to Provisions contained in the Police Ordinance. Negombo Police submitted a detailed report to Court, stating that if the protest is allowed to be held today, it could disturb public peace and even lead to acts of violence afterwards, as it coincides with the fourth year since the Easter Sunday carnage took place. They added that the intended demonstration was planned to be organizsed by a religious organisation and that from information available to them, certain political parties and trade unions, were also set to support it, which could lead to a violent situation. The Police afterwards prayed the Court, to issue an injunction, based on Provisions contained in Section 106 of the Code of Criminal Procedure Act. Taking the submissions into perusal, the Negombo Acting Magistrate, rejected the request by the Police. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Extensive discussion on Anti-Terrorism Bill needed – Chung
author: Author not found
Content: There should be ‘extensive’ public and Parliamentary discussions on the proposed Anti-Terrorism Bill, US Ambassador to Sri Lanka Julie Chung said. The controversial Anti-Terrorism Bill was gazetted to repeal the draconian Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). The US Ambassador, in a tweet said during a meeting with Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe yesterday (20) afternoon, discussed her concerns with regard to certain aspects of the proposed Bill which fall outside of international standards. Chung said, during the meeting, she shared their ‘strong desire’ to see extensive discussions, both public and parliamentary, on the matter. “It is important that all voices – including civil society, academia, and lawmakers – are considered to ensure the legislation serves as an effective tool for combating terrorism without restricting freedom of expression or assembly,” she pointed out.

title: Parliament to debate IMF’s EFF from 26 to 28 April
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Parliamentary Business decided to take up the Resolution, for the implementation of the arrangement under the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for Sri Lanka, into debate on the three consecutive days falling on 26, 27 and 28 April. This was decided at the meeting of the Committee on Parliamentary Business held yesterday (20) under the Chairmanship of Deputy Speaker of Parliament Ajith Rajapakse. The Government of Sri Lanka and the International Monetary Fund have entered into an agreement for the rapid progress in the economy of Sri Lanka and for sustainable economic growth that will benefit the present and future generations. The arrangement for the 48-month Extended Fund Facility of about USD 3 billion was tabled on 22 March. Whilst the proposal submits that the Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies should provide all necessary approvals for the implementation of the said setup, a vote is to be followed post the three-day debate if necessary. Parliament is scheduled to convene from 25 to 28 April and 9.30 a.m. to 10.30 a.m. has been allocated for Questions for Oral Answers. Accordingly, on 25 April , Order under the Code of Criminal Procedure (Special Provisions) Act, published in the Gazette Notification 2317/28 dated 30 January, is scheduled to be taken up for debate from 10.30 a.m. to 5.00 p.m. Thereafter, the Motion at the Adjournment Time by the Government will be taken up from 5.00 p.m. to 5.30 p.m. Following Questions for Oral Answers, on 26 April 26, it has been agreed to approve, without debate, the Resolution under the Essential Public Services Act published in the Gazette Notification 2328/02 dated 17 April 2023 by the President. Thereafter, the Resolution for the implementation of the arrangement under the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) of the IMF for Sri Lanka will be taken up for debate until 5.00 p.m. It was also decided to present for approval 13 motions regarding the Annual Reports of various Statutory Institutions. Furthermore, it was also agreed to present the Private Member Bills, Kelaniya Buddhist Women’s Charitable Society (Incorporation) Bill and Sri Lanka Institute of Taxation (Incorporation) (Amendment) Bill for its second reading. Thereafter, time has been allotted from. 5.00 p.m. to 5.30 p.m. for Questions at the Adjournment Time. On 27 and 28 April the Resolution for the implementation of the arrangement under the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) of the IMF for Sri Lanka is scheduled be debated for the second and third consecutive days from 10.30 a.m. to 5.00 p.m. On 27 April the Motion at the Adjournment Time by the Opposition will be held from 5.00 p.m. to 5.30 p.m. Following the debate on 28 April, it has been agreed to approve the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill without debate. Thereafter, time has been allotted from. 5.00 pm to 5.30 pm for Questions at the Adjournment Time.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Acting Anaesthetists appointed toState hospitals
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Ministry has appointed Anaesthetists, in an acting capacity, to several hospitals in the island, including the Embilipitiya District General Hospital, with immediate effect. A senior Spokesman for the Health Ministry yesterday (20) said that eight such medical practitioners had been appointed on the advice of Health Minister, Keheliya Rambukwella. He said that these appointments would enable State hospitals to which they were appointed to be normalised as these acting Anaesthetists would fill in the vacancies. According to the Director General of Health Services (DGHS) Dr. Asela Gunawardena the acting Anaesthesiologists had been appointed to the Embilipitiya District General Hospital, Base Hospitals in Udugama and  Kamburupitiya, Kilinochchi District General Hospital, Dickoya General Hospital, and Mannar District General Hospital,. Emergency surgeries were halted at the Embilipitiya District General Hospital, for over two weeks, due to the shortage of anesthetists. The situation arose as the result of the Anesthetists serving at the hospitals vacating their posts to go in search of greener pastures. The anesthesiologist who was appointed temporarily to replace the vacated post also is said to have left for overseas training. (DJ)

title: Govt to reduce MOP fertiliser price
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has focused on reducing the price of MOP by Rs 4,500 for paddy cultivation this Yala season, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. “The Government has drawn attention to this matter at the recently convened Cabinet meeting and since a 50 kg bundle of MOP is currently sold at Rs.18,500 in the market, it is difficult for farmers to bear such a sum,” he said. He added however that the final decision will be taken at the Cabinet meeting due to be held next week.  “As the two government-owned fertiliser companies are working to provide fertiliser at the lowest price, competition has arisen in the market regarding the sale of chemical fertiliser. The price of a bundle of urea, which was Rs 42,000 last Yala season, in 2022, has been reduced toRs. 11,000,” he said. He added that the said companies have observed that the prices of TSP and MOP will also decrease further. “In the past, there were only six private companies that imported and distributed fertiliser, whereas currently, the number of fertiliser companies, importing and distributing it has increased to 12 and the advantage of this competition should be provided to farmers,” he said. (FT)

title: Wild elephantsravage Mailankulama cultivation
author: Author not found
Content: A private cultivation being maintained on 300 acres in Mailankulama in Puttalam District was destroyed by wild elephants recently. Crops such as coconuts, plantains, and mangoes had been grown at the cultivation while some 70 people from nearby villages such as Mailankulama, Thenuwara and Thabbowa had been permanently employed for the past 10 years. The residents and villagers said villages such as Mailankulama, Thabbowa and Thenuwara which are situated close to Thabbowa Wildlife Park come under wild elephant attacks regularly. They alleged that despite the construction of electric fences across the villages, such fences had proved to be ineffective in warding off wild elephants. The Manager of the cultivation, destroyed by wild elephants, estimated the loss at Rs 200 million and he urged the Government to provide relief to the workers who are facing unemployment and to take concrete measures to thwart wild elephant attacks. By Balasuriya – Galenbindunuwewa

title: SI dies in head on collision
author: Author not found
Content: A 54-year-old Police Sub-inspector died when his motorcycle collided head-on with a lorry and a bus in Chavakachceri, on Wednesday (19).According to Police, the Policeman, who was travelling from Jaffna to Kodikamam when the accident occurred, was rushed to the Chavakachcheri Hospital where he was pronounced dead on admission.The body lies at the Chavakachcheri Hospital morgue following the postmortem. Further investigations are being conducted by Chavakachcheri Police. BY Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Indonesian Naval ship here
author: Author not found
Content: The Indonesian Naval Ship KRI Bima Suci arrived at the port of Colombo on an official visit yesterday (20). The visiting ship was welcomed by the Sri Lanka Navy (SLN) in compliance with naval tradition. KRI Bima Suci is a 112.2m long platform manned by a crew of 95 and she is commanded by Commander M. Sati Lubis. ‘Meanwhile, Commander M. Sati Lubis called on Commander Western Naval Area Rear Admiral Suresh De Silva at the Western Naval Command Headquarters today and the cordial interaction between them came to an end with an exchange of mementoes. The crew of KRI Bima Suci is expected to visit tourist attractions in Sri Lanka during their stay. In addition, Officer under Trainees of SLN will also visit the ship in Colombo. The ship is scheduled to depart the island on 22 April and on her departure she will host a training visit for two SLN Officer Trainees as well. (NV)

title: Two bodies found on beaches
author: Author not found
Content: Two bodies were found by Police, at different locations, on Wednesday (19). Both were still unidentified and the causes of death were being probed. One body was found on the Medakatiya beach, and the Tangalle Police have initiated investigations. The body lies at the Tangalle Hospital morgue. Meanwhile, another body was discovered by the Udappuwa Police on the Periyapadu beach following a tip-off. Further investigations are underway. BY Dinithi Wijesundara

title: NAVY COMMANDER CALLS ON INDIAN HC
author: Author not found
Content: Commander of the Navy, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera called on the Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Gopal Baglay at his official residence in Colombo, yesterday (20). During the cordial discussion they exchanged views on several matters of bilateral importance. The Naval Assistant to the Commander of the Navy, Commodore Kosala Warnakulasooriya and Defense Adviser to the High Commission of India, Captain Vikas Sood were also present on this occasion. At the end of the official interaction, the Navy Commander presented a memento to the Indian High Commissioner, symbolizing cooperation and goodwill. (NV)

title: Navy recover explosives
author: Author not found
Content: A search operation conducted by the Navy in Udayapuram Beach area in Jaffna led to the recovery of 25 Water Gel Sticks – a type of commercial explosive on 19 April. The Navy conducts regular search operations in coastal areas to prevent destructive fishing practices using explosives, as it is an illegal practice that not only causes harm to marine life but also poses a significant threat to the sustainability of the fishing industry. On receipt of information, SLNS Kanchadewa and SLNS Welusumana in the Northern Naval Command conducted the search operation in Udayapuram Beach area and recovered a suspicious sack concealed in shrubs. During further search, naval personnel recovered 25 Water Gel Sticks from the sack which were subsequently taken into naval custody. It is believed that these explosive items have been hidden at the beach, to be used for illegal fishing. Meanwhile, the 25 Water Gel Sticks have been kept in the custody of the Navy until they are handed over to authorities for onward legal action.

title: Two nabbed with artifacts
author: Author not found
Content: Kegalle Police on 18 April arrested two persons on charges of unlawful possession of artifacts. One is a resident of Hemmathagama in Elpitiya while the other is from Mawanella. According to the Police, among the artifacts in the suspects’ possession were a gold-plated Buddha Statue and a few other items of archaeological value. The Police said the artifacts had been concealed in a house belonging to the suspect from Elpitiya. Further inquiries are being conducted by the Kegalle Police. BY K.V. Bandara – Mawanella
