title: All 15 accused allowed bail
author: Author not found
Content: Kebithigollewa District Judge Kasun Dissanayake recently enlarged on bail a Buddhist monk and 14 others, who were incarcerated for over a year on charges of murdering a Sub Inspector of the Kebithigollewa Police Station, and assaulting a Chief Inspector who had gone to probe an incident where an individual had died in a wild elephant attack. The Judge released each of the suspects, including the main suspect W. Madusanka Pushpakumara and monk Ven. Nawela Dhamma Vibachi Thera, on two sureties of Rs. 500,000 each. The 15 suspects had been charged with violation of Provisions contained in Sections 32, 102, 140, 322, 317, 183, 344, 296 and 414 of the Penal Code and on charges of preventing the Police from performing their duty, while being members of an unlawful assembly, causing both grievous and minor injuries to Police officers while on duty, exertion of criminal intimidation on Police officers, severe assault of a Police officer and causing his death while continuing to burn tyres on the Anuradhapura-Kebithigollewa main road and hindering its traffic flow at the Rambakapuwewa Junction. Sub Inspector Maithri appeared on behalf of the prosecution on the instructions from Medawachchiya OIC, Chief Inspector R.M.I.G. Ratnayake, while Senior Counsel Ranga Sujeewa appeared for the suspects. BY Upali Karunadasa – Anuradhapura

title: Mystery surrounds fish deaths in Kotmale Oya
author: Author not found
Content: Following the mysterious deaths of fish, since Sunday (16), in the Kotmale Oya, which flows from Ambewela to Talawakelle, the residents and villagers living near the Kotmale Reservoir are advised not to consume those dead fish, Nuwara Eliya District Health Services Director Nissanka Wijewardena said. He said that following inquiries, conducted thus far, it has come to light that on a 12km stretch of the Kotmale River from Ambewela to Meraya and from Algin up to Agarakanda the fish had begun to die under mysterious circumstances. The people, especially the estate workers who resided near these areas are taking those dead fish for consumption and they are advised not to consume the fish until the reason behind mysterious deaths are discovered. Wijewardena added that Medical Officer of Health (MOH) Lindula and a group of PHIs have been sent to Kotmale Oya to conduct a detailed investigation into the sudden deaths of fish. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: FPA MPs won’t support IMF agreement – GL
author: Author not found
Content: Not a single Freedom Peoples’ Alliance (FPA) MP will support the IMF Agreement, which is to be debated in Parliament, Prof. G.L. Peiris said. He said this when addressing a media briefing, convened by the FPA in Colombo, yesterday (17). “The next Presidential Poll is due between 18 September and 18 October next year. A President who has been elected by the House, to cover the term of his predecessor, cannot call for a Presidential Poll after a lapse of four years. To do so, he or she would need to obtain a two-thirds majority vote in the Legislature. But, we have regularly been clamouring for the indefinitely put off LG Polls. It is clear that this President is running a dictatorial regime,” he stressed. Speaking further, Prof. Peiris alleged that there has been no transparency in any of the talks held to date with the IMF. “The country is groping in the dark with regard to conditions put forth by the global money lender to Sri Lanka, ahead of approving its bailout package. The Government has also failed to distribute either Sinhala or English Language copies of the IMF Agreement to MPs and in light of these developments the MPs of the FPA will refrain from voting for it,” he said.   By Krishan Pathirath Jayasuriya

title: Gammanpila to raise privilege issue against Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader MP Udaya Gammanpila said he expects to raise a privilege matter in Parliament, on 25 April, against Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena and his Media Secretary Indunil Abeywardena, over the Speaker’s announcement on the Supreme Court Determination with regard to Central Bank (Amendment) Bill. The Speaker on 4 April announced to the House that the Supreme Court has determined that none of the provisions in the Bill are inconsistent with the Constitution. He said the Court has determined that the Bill can be passed by a simple majority in Parliament, subject to the amendments mentioned in the determination. The Speaker’s announcement sparked controversy as several including Gammanpila, alleged that the Speaker failed to announce the Supreme Court determination on the Bill correctly to the House. In this backdrop, Gammanpila, in a letter to the Speaker, said the determination, which is 54-pages-long, clearly said certain provisions of the Bill have to be passed with two-third-majority/referendum. The Supreme Court has proposed 80 amendments to the Bill. According to my point of view this Bill is the most erroneous one among the laws presented to Parliament in recent history, he stressed. The Speaker not communicating this determination clearly to Parliament has caused a huge damage to the goodwill of the Supreme Court. Not only that, it is a violation of Parliamentary Privileges of the MPs who challenged the Bill in Supreme Court as well, he alleged. “After you (the Speaker) made the announcement on 4 April, I, as an MP who petitioned against the Bill, tried several times to contact you to request it be corrected. Since you were abroad I contacted your Coordinating Secretary Dr. Chameera Abeywardena. However, later your Media Secretary Indunil Abeywardena had issued a press release alleging that I am trying to deceive the country for narrow political gains. This is an insult to me as well as a violation of my Parliamentary Privileges,” he said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: CEJ to take legal action against export of toque monkeys
author: Author not found
Content: Legal actions will be instituted if a decision is taken to unlawfully export toque monkeys to China, Senior adviser to the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) Hemantha Withanage said. He said there is a high possibility that toque monkeys are likely to be exported to China for testing laboratories, adding that in the recent past, there has been a shortage of test animals for laboratories in certain countries including China. “The proposal is to export monkeys for zoos but there are only approximately 18 such facilities in China and if Sri Lanka is to export 100,000 toque monkeys, that amounts to  at least over 5,000 monkeys per facility,” he said adding thereby that it sounds illogical. Withanage emphasised that a huge sum of money will have to be incurred to capture 100,000 monkeys, while questioning as to why such sum of money cannot be used to compensate for crop damage by animals. “The issue of crop damage requires a long-term solution, especially in terms of putting an end to clearing of forests, resulting in destruction of food sources for animals, including monkeys due to which they tend to go to villages in search of food, often resulting in such damage,” he said. Withanage further noted that there has also been misinformation as to the population of monkeys in Sri Lanka, adding that although it is stated that there are over three million monkeys, no assessment has been done in this regard. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Navy arrests six with 179 kg of heroin
author: Author not found
Content: The six men who were arrested along with 179 kg of heroin worth of over Rs 3.5 billion during a special search operation were brought ashore at the Galle Harbour yesterday (17). Sri Lanka Navy intercepted a fishing trawler carrying over 179 kg of heroin, with street value of over Rs 3.5 billion, along with six suspects in southern seas on 15 April.  The Navy revealed that they had seized drugs with a gross street value of over Rs 4.9 billion, during operations mounted in 2023, along with the latest haul. The operation was carried out by the Sri Lanka Coast Guard Ship ‘Samudraraksha’ and the Commander of the Navy Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera was present when the suspects and the narcotics were brought to the Galle Harbour. Based on information received from a combined intelligence operation led by the Naval Intelligence, the State Intelligence Service, and the Police Narcotic Bureau, the Sri Lanka Coast Guard Ship ‘Samudraraksha’ was deployed for this special operation off the Little Basses, south of Sri Lanka. In this operation, a local multi-day fishing trawler in the sea area, about 132 nautical miles (about 244km) off the Little Basses, was searched on suspicion and a consignment of heroin was recovered from the trawler. Accordingly, about 179.6 kg (including packages) of heroin were found in 160 packs which were in eight sacks. The suspects held in the operation have been identified as residents of Nakulugamuwa, Kudawella, Netolpitiya, and Trincomalee, aged from 25 to 32. They were to be handed over to the Police Narcotic Bureau for onward legal action.  (NV)

title: Cardinal invites all to form human chain
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lankan Catholic Church called upon all citizens,  irrespective of racial, religious and political differences to commemorate the 2019 Easter attack victims on Friday (21), by forming a ‘human chain’ along the Colombo-Negombo main road starting from St. Anthony’s Church, Kochchikade up to St. Sebastian’s Church, Katuwapitiya. Addressing the media, at the Bishop’s House in Colombo yesterday (17), Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith said this would call upon the leaders of the country to render justice to the victims of the Easter attack and strengthen the hands of freedom and justice in the island. He said the Sri Lankan Catholic Community would continue to pressure the government and authorities until such time that the leaders understood and gave justice for 2019 Easter Sunday victims. Cardinal Ranjith invited all to gather on both sides along Colombo-Negombo main road starting from St. Anthony’s Kochchikade to Katuwapitiya, St Sebastian’s peacefully at 8.30 a.m. without disturbing the traffic. He also called upon those gathered to maintain two minutes of silence at 8:45 a.m. and continue to remain in that line till 9.00 a.m.  Those in offices and factories could also pay their respects to the bomb victims by maintaining the two minutes silence at 8.45 a.m.  Fielding questions Cardinal Ranjith said there were over 300 cases filed in Colombo and Negombo Courts by victims and their relatives demanding compensation.  “None of the governments has paid attention to the Catholic Church’s call for justice for the victims who died in the Churches and the five star hotels. Whatever action has been taken has been on its own volition and those of the organisations and institutions which collaborate with the Church of Sri Lanka,” he said noting that several persons had been given punishment through Court for several fundamental rights cases filed by individuals and organisations collaborating with the Church.  Delaying of justice also prompted the local Catholic community to take its woe to the international community.  He said that Pope Francis was also aware of endeavours made by the Sri Lankan Catholic community to seek justice. “We have not given up our efforts to find the truth behind the attacks and would continue to be committed to that cause,” the head of Sri Lanka’s Catholic Church said. Recalling the statement made by former Attorney General who had called it the most cruel and inhuman attacks to have taken place in the most recent times, he said that the former Attorney General had noted that the attacks had been a part of a “grand conspiracy”. It is clear to us and many others that these attacks were a plot organised in order to gain political power. Presidents as well as politicians who ruled this country since 2019 as well as the incumbent President and some corrupt State officials have been and are a part of an attempt to hide the truth behind the attacks in order to protect the perpetrators.  The country is fast going towards an unacceptable state where the impression is that all decisions and actions are taken by one person. As the Prime Minister the incumbent President took action to clip the wings of the President of the ‘good governance government.’ However, now after becoming the President he is now introducing laws to give him that power, he alleged. Claiming that this was highly unacceptable in a democratic country, Cardinal Ranjith said that there needs to be an election to ensure that the voice of the people was heard. “We obtain power to serve the people and to give justice and not to merely retain that power and quash their voices,” he said. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Difficult to reduce local egg price this week – ACEPA
author: Author not found
Content: Owing to certain reasons, it will be difficult to reduce the price of local eggs this week, All Ceylon Egg Producers’ Association (ACEPA) Chairman Sarath Ratnayake said. However, they decided to sell a local egg at below Rs 50, he said. Ratnayake said this during a media briefing on Sunday (16). He said when striving to reduce the price of eggs in the domestic market several factors would need to be considered at length and insisted that they cannot opt for ad-hoc decisions which could worsen the plight of local traders who make a living through the industry. “As a result of extreme hot weather these days, the hens are dying. Some farmers have sold their hens for meat as well,” he said.  Ratnayake noted that most traders have taken the decision to opt out of the trade due to the recent decision taken by the Government to import eggs from India. He added that if the Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) does not arbitrarily interfere with the egg manufacturers, his Association would be able to reduce the local egg price by a sizeable amount by 1 May. BY Shakya Induwara – Kuliyapitiya

title: Amaraweera to seek Cabinet nod to appoint committee
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera is to submit a Cabinet Paper for the appointment of a committee, to look into the request made by China, for toque monkeys from Sri Lanka, for their zoos. Amaraweera noted that although a request has been made from China for toque monkeys from Sri Lanka, no final decision has been taken in this connection. He said a Chinese company that handles several private zoological gardens had made a request to provide monkeys from Sri Lanka for their zoos, adding however that a committee comprising representatives from the Department of Wildlife Conservation, Department of Zoological Gardens, Attorney General’s Department, Ministry of Agriculture and Department of Agriculture will be appointed to inspect the relevant request.  “Toque monkeys will only be exported to China based on the the recommendation of the sub committee appointed by the Cabinet. If the committee decides otherwise, then this matter will be put to an end,” he said. While stating that there has been certain misunderstandings in this regard, he noted  that those who oppose this proposal have not provided alternatives to tackle crop damage caused by Toque monkeys and thereby that it has to be looked at with an open mind. (FT)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Disaster warning
author: Author not found
Content: The Disaster Management Centre at the Balangoda Divisional Secretariat has warned residents to be vigilant for earthslips and landslides that could occur due to the torrential downpours being experienced in the afternoons over the past few days. This warning was issued by Balangoda Divisional Secretary Hemantha Bandara.  Accordingly, if the rainfall received is above 150 mm or 75 mm the public living in villages such as Egoda Waleboda, Pettigala, Rassagala, Kabaragala, Gawaranhena should be vigilant for these natural disasters due to the ongoing inclement weather. BY Nalinda Waleboda – Balangoda

title: Two arrested over attempt to sexually abuse foreigner
author: Author not found
Content: The owner and an employee of an unregistered massage parlour, in Thalwila, Marawila, were arrested on charges of attempting to sexually abuse a French woman within the premises recently, Thoduwawa Police said. According to the Police, the unregistered massage parlour had been operated at Thalwila in Marawila and its owner is a resident of Thalwila while the employee is a resident of Rambukkana. The two suspects were arrested by the Police following a complaint lodged by the French woman. The Police said that as per the complaint the foreigner arrived in the country on 15 April after which she resided at a tourist hotel in Thalwila, Marawila. They added, on the following day, in the afternoon, she went to the massage parlour in question and an employee had attempted to sexually abuse her under the pretext of servicing. The Police acting on the complaint swiftly arrested the owner and the employee of the massage parlour. By Jude Samantha

title: Motorcyclist killedin road mishap
author: Author not found
Content: A 19-year-old motorcyclist died on the spot, when his machine crashed into a tractor in Oyamaduwa on Sunday (16) afternoon. According to Police, the victim was a resident of Pemaduwa. Initial investigations revealed that the youth had lost control of the machine’s speed resulting in its colliding with the tractor on the Mahawilachchiya Road. The pillion rider sustained injuries and was admitted to Anuradhapura Teaching Hospital. The tractor driver was arrested by Oyamaduwa Police. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Body found in tobacco chena
author: Author not found
Content: The body of a man, who died under suspicious circumstances, was recovered in a tobacco chena in Hasakala on Sunday (16).  The deceased was a 35-year-old resident of Batumulla, Police said. The initial investigations revealed the deceased left his house a few days earlier saying that he was going to visit a cousin. His body was discovered by his sibling in the tobacco chena that belonged to the deceased. The cause for the death was not yet revealed at the time of going to press and Batumulla Police are conducting investigations. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Three Indians nabbed with Kerala cannabis
author: Author not found
Content: The Delft Police arrested three Indian nationals who were in possession of nearly 62 Kg of Kerala Ganja on Sunday (16). The suspects were aged 16, 23 and 38. According to the Police, the trio was arrested during a raid conducted by the Coast Guard west of the Delft Coastal line. Delft Police are conducting investigations. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: President cannot escape responsibility
author: Author not found
Content: Former Kinniya Pradeshiya Sabha member M. M. Mahadhi yesterday (17) claimed that President Ranil Wickremesinghe cannot escape from his responsibility to the Muslim community that was subjected to various forms of discrimination during the ‘good governance’ government. Addressing the media in Kinniya, Mahadhi said that the Muslim community had trusted Wickremesinghe and made an enormous contribution to form the good governance government. “Because of that, a certain faction fuelled racism and fundamentalism and carried out various attacks on Muslims and their properties. As a result millions of rupees worth of properties belonging to Muslims were destroyed in Ampara, Kandy, Digana, Aluthgama and Minuwangoda. In these attacks severe destruction was caused to mosques,” he alleged. Those victims should be given justice and provided with reasonable compensations. The culprits involved in these crimes should be dealt with  by law. Wickremesinghe cannot escape from that responsibility, he said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Court orders removal of statue
author: Author not found
Content: The Jaffna Chief Magistrate’s Court issued an order to remove a Nagapooshani Amman Statue, which had been constructed on the Jaffna-Pannai road, thereby obstructing the flow of traffic. The Jaffna Police announcing the Court order to the people said if anyone was laying claim to the statue in question, they should do so through Court immediately or else the Police will remove it from its present location. According to the Police, no official approval had been sought from any State institution towards the construction of the statue, while it continued to impede the flow of traffic on the said route. In the aftermath of the order issued by the Court the Police have decided to provide round the clock protection to the Statue till it is removed. BY Rasadi Chathurangi Gamage – Vavuniya

title: Son arrested over father’s death
author: Author not found
Content: Kahataruppa Police, in the Badulla District arrested a 30-year-old individual, in the evening of Sunday (16), over the killing of his father The victim, a 57-year-old, died while undergoing treatment at the Kandy Teaching Hospital, Police said. According to the Police, an argument between the father and son had turned into a brawl and subsequently the father was assaulted by the son. The victim, who was initially admitted to the Provincial General Hospital in Badulla, was later transferred to the Kandy Hospital. Kahataruppa Police are conducting further investigations.  By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Open side ofbridge a death trap
author: Author not found
Content: Residents of the Hasalaka town have urged the relevant officials to fix the veritable death trap, near the entrance to the Hasalaka National School, before a serious tragedy takes place and results in the loss of lives. The Hasalaka Ranasinghe Premadasa National School and the Model Primary School are situated close to the Minipe River, while close to 1,000 students are attending the two schools. A bridge has been built over the Minipe River on the Kandy-Mahiyangana main road, while a part of the bridge connecting to a school has been left uncovered and residents describe it as a veritable death trap for the public including students. Hence, they urge the authorities to construct a security fence to cover the uncovered part of the bridge before a serious calamity takes place. BY Sunil Ihalagedera – Hasalaka

title: No truth in SJB MPs joining Govt ranks – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Only an Election could save the country from the current unfortunate destiny the country is heading for, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said yesterday (16). In a statement, Premadasa rejected speculation that several SJB MPs would join government ranks and take ministerial portfolios. “These reports are completely false. This is a disgusting attempt of pro-government camps. The current Government which is an extension of the  Rajapaksa regime and is pushing the country towards a grave disaster. Its programmes to rebuild the country are a complete failure. The people will soon know about all the gimmicks of the Government. They are afraid of that and to deceive the public they create fake news about us,” he said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: RDA earns Rs 35M as expresswaytoll tariff
author: Author not found
Content: The Road Development Authority (RDA)  earned Rs 35 million as expressway tolls in the 24-hour period ending 12 a.m. on 15 April. According to RDA Director General L.V.S. Weerakoon, 126,760 vehicles had used expressways in the 24-hour period ending 12 a.m. on 15 April. As a result, he said the income earned during this time period is Rs 34.9 million. On an average day, approximately 90,000 vehicles use the expressways, with a daily income of approximately Rs 25 million.Meanwhile, compared to previous New Year seasons, there is a decrease in road accidents on expressways this year, according to Weerakoon. (TR)

title: Six youths arrested for assaulting cop
author: Author not found
Content: Six youths were arrested by the Kandy Police for assaulting a Police Officer during an outdoor musical show held at a hotel. The suspects include the sons of a professor, a doctor, a local politician, and a prominent Kandy businessman, according to Police. The Police Officer was assaulted while attempting to control a conflict between two groups during the musical show and underwent emergency surgery at the Teaching Hospital Peradeniya following the assault. The Police were able to track down the suspects by reviewing CCTV footage at the location. The suspects were remanded till 27 April and will face an identification parade on being produced in Court. By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Certain factions fear mongering about Anti-Terrorism Bill – Keheliya
author: Author not found
Content: Certain factions are creating false fear with regard to the proposed Anti-Terrorism Bill, but the majority of the public support President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s programme to stabilise the crisis-hit economy of Sri Lanka, Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella said. Speaking at a media briefing in Kandy yesterday (16), the minister said while there are a few political hypocrites who undermine the country’s stabilisation process, the majority of people support the country’s economic revival. He added that the Government has given trade unions complete freedom. “However, any Government is responsible for defeating conspiracies to overthrow it by promoting certain political agendas through trade unions. These persons are now creating false fear with regard to the Anti-Terrorism Bill. Every group in this country is divided when various Constitutional amendments are proposed. There was widespread fear when the 13th Amendment was presented. We cannot see the same fear when there are discussions about enacting the 13th Amendment. That is because everyone wants a stable country above all,” he said. Speaking further, he said now that there is some semblance of hope; everyone must decide whether they want to move forward or dwell on the past based on political hypocrisy. “The Paris Club, China, and other countries have expressed their enthusiastic support for the debt restructuring programme. This is a victory for us as well. Groups with hypocritical and rigid beliefs are attempting to squish that opportunity. We must shed our differences and work together to defeat these hypocrites,” he added. By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Toddler drowns in canal
author: Author not found
Content: The body of a two and half-year-old child who was reported missing was found yesterday (16) in a canal near his maternal grandparents’ home, in Neluwa. The child was reported missing since Saturday (15) evening. He had travelled from Aluthgama with his parents to his grandmother’s house for the New Year. The child’s father reported the child missing to Neluwa Police on 15 April. The body was found during an operation conducted by the Police, the Army, and the villagers, following suspicions that the child had fallen into the canal near the house. The body was taken to the Teaching Hospital Karapitiya for the post-mortem. Neluwa Police are conducting further investigations into the death. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Anti-Terrorism Act must be overhauled or scrapped – AI Director
author: Author not found
Content: In response to the publication of the draft text of the proposed Anti-Terrorism Act, by the Sri Lankan Government, Amnesty International (AI) Asia Advocacy Director Carolyn Nash said that the USA’s Biden- administration needs to send a clear message to President Ranil Wickremesinghe that this law must be overhauled entirely or scrapped altogether. The draft Anti-Terrorism Act categorically fails on every human rights benchmark. If the Biden administration values the rights of the Sri Lankan people, they need to send a clear message to the President, Nash said in a statement. The Sri Lankan Government has been using the draconian Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) to detain and torture critics and minorities for over four decades. International condemnation of the PTA led the government of Sri Lanka to commit to repealing the law. The ATA, published on March 22 is the replacement legislation the government has proposed after another Bill brought in 2018 was shelved after widespread condemnation.  “If the administration and Congress are silent as this draft law advances, they will allow the Sri Lankan government to further cement its ability to suppress dissent,” said Nash.  “The proposed legislation is an insult to civil society in Sri Lanka, who have advocated for decades for legal reforms to protect human rights. This is far from a good faith effort on the part of the Sri Lankan authorities to improve or replace a bad law – it is an effort to shore up the government’s ability to target and silence their critics,” she added. The AI South Asia Researcher Thyagi Ruwanpathirana said, “The drafters of the ATA have not taken into account the benchmarks laid out by UN experts in order to come up with a counter-terror law that would start to bring the legislation in line with international law. The offences in the anti-terror Bill remain broad, vague, and subjective. They are ripe for abuse. Even offences under Sri Lanka’s ICCPR Act are now made terror offences.”  “It’s clear after the mass protests last year, the State has become even more willing to misuse counter terrorism offences in order to target activists. This is reflected in new offences created that seek to classify acts of civil disobedience as terror offences.” The new Bill also retains PTA provisions to enable prolonged detention (up to one year without charge). The High Court can extend this period at the request of the Attorney General. It provides the Police with access to those who are already indicted and in judicial remand and enables suspects to be removed from remand custody for the purpose of conducting further investigations under the authority of an order made by a Magistrate.  “This provision is dangerous and facilitates torture, especially in a context that is already rife with allegations of torture in custody,” added Ruwanpathirana.  The Bill empowers the military to carry out arrests without warrants. It retains unchecked powers of the executive, including proscribing persons and organisations without judicial oversight. Penalties include the death penalty, which AI strongly opposes, Ruwanpathirana said.

title: Chadian, Yemeni nationals nabbed with fake passports
author: Author not found
Content: A Chadian and a Yemeni national, who tried to enter the country using forged passports, were arrested and deported by immigration officials at the (BIA) arrivals terminal yesterday (16). The 39-year-old Yemeni and the 36-year-old Chadian arrived at BIA on 16 April at 9.45 a.m. from Dubai, on UAE FZ 547 of Fly Dubai Airlines. They then made it to the to the immigration counter at the arrival’s terminal to obtain on-arrival tourist visas, presenting the passports. However, officials had suspicions about their passports and informed the airport border control unit. Immigration officials then inspected their luggage and found two passports issued by Yemen and Chad that belonged to them. In addition, a ticket to Belgium was also found inside the mobile phone of the Yemeni national.Meanwhile, it was confirmed that the UAE passports the suspects gave immigration officials were false. It was later found the two passports were made through a broker. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Engine driver shortage leads to 34 train cancellations
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 34 trains were cancelled yesterday (16) owing to the shortage of operators, the Department of Railways said. The department said, the locomotive engineers who had gone on leave for the New Year, had not reported for duty yesterday (16). As a result, 34 trains had to be cancelled until last evening. The actual number of train cancellations during the day could be more than 34, the department said. The Kandy-Badulla train was also reportedly cancelled due to engine drivers failing to report for duty. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: President will make SL a lender nation – Vajira
author: Author not found
Content: The President expects to pay off the loans that Sri Lanka has obtained from foreign countries, within the next few years, and then make Sri Lanka a country that lends to other countries, UNP Chairman MP Vajira Abeywardana said. Addressing a New Year event at the UNP office in Galle on Saturday (15), Abeywardana said when the President’s programme succeeds; foreigners will take up employment opportunities in Sri Lanka as well. “The public should not have any reservations about this. President Wickremesinghe made the country self-sufficient in rice at a time when many people were suffering. As a result, people were able to celebrate the New Year joyfully,” he added. “It is the President who made celebrating national festivals a reality amidst severe economic difficulties. We would not have been able to celebrate these festivals if he had not taken over the country without any fear or hesitation. When the country collapsed, the others did not come forward to accept the responsibility. However, at that time, the President stepped forward and took over the reins of government,” Abeywardana said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: ‘Wasath Siriya 2023’ to be held on 22 April
author: Author not found
Content: ‘Wasath Siriya 2023’ celebration for the Sinhala and Tamil New Year will take place on 22 April at Galle Face Green, Colombo. This event is organised by the President’s Office, the Prime Minister’s Office, and the Ministry of Public Administration, and is open to staff members of various ministries and public sector institutions, as well as to all Sri Lankans and foreigners who wish to participate in the competitions. The festivities will commence with New Year games and competitions starting at 7:00 a.m. and concluding at 5:00 p.m. Thereafter, a musical concert has also been planned from 6:00 pm to 12:00 p.m. The competitions have been divided into three sections, namely State Section, Open Section, and Guest Section, and feature a total of 18 competitions for both men and women. These competitions are open to the staff members of ministries and government institutions, their family members, friends, and children. The line-up of events include finding the hidden guest, placing the eye on the elephant, breaking the pot blindfolded, counting the seeds of a papaw, weaving coconut branches, scraping coconut, pillow fighting, bun eating contest, drinking milk with a soother, threading a needle, 100 M race, feeding yoghurt blindfolded, obstacle race, bursting the balloon, lighting the candle, lime and spoon race, musical chairs, passing the hat game, best laugh competition, selecting the biggest belly, Avurudu prince and princess contest, and climbing the grease pole. The event will also feature an open section for foreigners, embassies, foreign institutions, and staff from nearby hotels. This section includes ten competitions to engage and entertain international guests. The event also showcases a recreated model of a village house, which portrays the relationship between the village and the village house during the bygone era. Visitors can enjoy sweets, costumes, New Year rituals, and many village games and demonstrations, including drumming, panchakeliya, olindakeliya, chakgudu, folk music, wrestling, Angkeliya, swings, bamboo fireworks shows, a bazaar, and more. The festivities will continue with the ‘Miyasi’ musical concert, which will commence at 7:00 p.m. at the venue. The concert will feature Ranwala Band, followed by the Mead Land Band. The event will also include performances by renowned singers such as Rookantha Gunathilake, Sanuka Wickramasinghe, Windy Goonatillake, Tashni Perera, Dulmina Perera, Hijas Taleesh, and Ashanya Premadasa.

title: SLPI deeply concerned over the proposed ATA
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Press Institute (SLPI), its constituents and affiliated organisations said they are deeply concerned over the proposed ‘Anti–Terrorism Act’ (ATA), published on 22 March 2023, drafted to replace the Prevention of Terrorism Act (Temporary Provisions) Act No. 48 of 1979 (PTA). In a statement, the SLPI said it is of the opinion that the Anti-Terrorism Bill has several controversial elements that are not conducive for the media community. The proposed Bill consists of an overbroad and vague definition of ‘acts of terrorism’ that can be interpreted in a manner which curtails the freedom of expression. “The broad powers vested within the proposed Bill enables the criminalisation of speech that is likely to be understood as an encouragement or inducement to commit or prepare for terrorism, with the burden of proof on the defendant to show that was not their intention,” the statement said. These offences also apply to those who publish, distribute, sell, or transmit publications that could be interpreted as materials supporting acts of terrorism.  According to the Bill, confidential information could be any information having an ‘adverse impact’ on ‘national security/defence’ which includes ‘any information not in the public domain’. “Therefore, the broad and vague classification of ‘confidential information’ could place media personnel in a precarious position in the due course of executing their duties, as many offences which fall under the criminal law could now be reframed as ‘terrorist offences’. It is evident that the constitutionally guaranteed fundamental rights of citizens, in terms of freedom of speech and expression, freedom of assembly and association, and freedom to dissent are threatened through the proposed ATA. While the SLPI understands the need to amend the PTA, it also endorses caution in making amendments that could undermine democracy and good governance.”

title: SL’s debt restructure talks begin sans China
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s lenders have begun debt restructuring talks without China, an international news agency said last Friday (14). US based Bloomberg’s correspondent in Beijing speaking at a Chinese Foreign Ministry press briefing alleged, “Sri Lanka and its major creditors have formally launched talks to restructure that nation’s debt without China, which is Sri Lanka’s biggest bilateral lender. This appears to be a sign of current frustration with Beijing’s approach to debt woes in the developing world. How does the foreign ministry respond to these talks going forward without Beijing?” the Chinese Foreign Ministry website in an upload said. On the previous day (13 April) at another briefing of the Chinese Foreign Ministry, the Reuters Correspondent to Beijing asked, “Japan, France and India will announce a new platform for creditors to coordinate restructuring of Sri Lanka’s foreign debt. Japan said it would be very welcome if China joins the platform. Will China join and what is China’s response?” In reply, China’s Foreign Ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin is quoted to have had said, “I would like to reiterate that China calls on commercial and multilateral creditors (such as  sovereign bond holders and the IMF) to jointly participate in Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring under the principle of fair burden-sharing. We have been in close communication with Sri Lanka and supported Chinese financial institutions in actively discussing debt treatment arrangements with Sri Lanka.” Meanwhile, the Japanese Embassy in Sri Lanka in a twitter message on Friday said, “On13 April Japan, India and France announced a common platform to coordinate restructuring of Sri Lanka’s debt. We highly value this milestone as it demonstrates our commitment to help Sri Lanka & paves the way for solving the debt issue of middle-income economies like Sri Lanka.” (PA)

title: ARRESTED FOR PAYING EXPRESSWAY TOLL WITHFAKE CURRENCY
author: Author not found
Content: A motorist, who attempted to pay the expressway toll at the Kadawatha exit point, was arrested by Police officers on duty last morning (16). The money he tendered is suspected to be counterfeit. The suspect was later handed over to the Kadawatha Police for further interrogation and is reported to be a resident of Haputale. Kadawatha Police are carrying out further investigations to ascertain if he was involved in the counterfeit mafia.

title: Significant decline in fireworks related injuries
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly 175 people sustained injuries in various accidents and were admitted to the National Hospital of Sri Lanka (NHSL) in the past 48 hours. Of 175 patients, 145 were found to be men. According to available statistics, as of 15 April, 35 people were injured in road accidents, while another 48 were injured in falls. In addition, seven were admitted after being injured while working at home and another five were injured while being involved in their occupation. The Accident Service of NHSL however reported a significant decrease in the number of firework injuries at the dawn of the Sinhala and Tamil New Year. According to a spokesman of the NHSL Accident Service, there was only one injury reported by midnight of 14 April. Six were injured while participating in New Year sports, while 44 were injured in violent incidents. Meanwhile, two people were injured in attempted suicides while 15 were injured while being inebriated and involved in fights.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Indian dhow with 62 kg Ganja valued at Rs20M seized, 3 arrested
author: Author not found
Content: The Navy intercepted an Indian dhow carrying over 62 Kg of Kerala cannabis and apprehended three suspects, during a special operation conducted in the Sri Lankan waters west of the Delft Island, Jaffna on 15 April. Sri Lanka Navy conducts regular patrols and search operations in the coastal and sea areas around the island, with a view to preventing the influx of drugs into the island. As an extension of these efforts, the Fast Attack Craft P 411 of the 4th Fast Attack Flotilla, attached to the Northern Naval Command conducted this search operation. The Navy recovered two sacks of Kerala cannabis which were in 23 packages weighing about 62.4kg. The operation also led to the apprehension of three suspects in connection to the incident. The gross street value of the seized stock of Kerala cannabis is believed to be over Rs 20 million. Three suspects along with the stock of Kerala cannabis and the Indian dhow were handed over to the Delft Police for legal action to be taken.

title: ‘A Custom for the New Year – A Plant for the Environment’ launched
author: Author not found
Content: The launching ceremony of the ‘A Custom for the New Year – A Plant for the Environment’ was held in conjunction with the auspicious start of the New Year on 14 April, 2023 at the Central Environmental Authority(CEA) premises under the patronage of Environment Minister Engineer Naseer Ahamed.  Secretary of the Ministry of Environment, Dr. Anil Jasinghe, Central Environmental Authority Chairman Supun S. Pathirage and CEA Director General P. B. Hemantha Jayasinghe and other officers also attended. Signifying the launch of the national programme, Minister of Environment, Secretary of the Ministry of Environment, the Chairman of the Central Environmental Authority and Director General of the Central Environmental Authority planted four saplings in the CEA premises. With the commencement of the programme on 14 April anyone could join the programme by planting a sapling within the one-week period till April 20. Children, youth and adults can join the programme. A medicinal plant, a plant with timber value, a fruit plant or a plant that fulfils the food requirement could be planted.  It is important that the sapling planted should be sustainable. Participants could register by sending a photograph taken at the time of planting, along with the name, age, address, district, Gramaseva Niladhari division, telephone number, name of the sapling planted, height of the sapling at the time of planting to the e-mail address [email protected] After three months of planting, a photo of the growth and maintenance of the planted sapling could be sent to the relevant email address fulfilling a performance milestone in the evaluation process and those who complete it, will be awarded an electronic certificate in recognition of their environmental contribution. Further, a survey will be conducted after one year and a panel of judges will select the best plants in each district and award prizes and certificates to those who have planted and maintained the plants. ‘A Custom for the New Year – A Plant for the Environment’ programme is jointly organised by the Ministry of Environment and the CEA.

title: State Minister commends students who excelled at shooting championship
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Defence Premitha Bandara Tennakoon commended the schoolchildren who excelled at the 7th Navy National Shooting Championship. The National Shooting Championship, organised by the Sri Lanka Navy for the 7th consecutive time, was held from 28 March to 4 April at the Welisara Navy Shooting Range. Students representing several schools, who had won laurels at the championship, called on the State Minister at the Ministry in Colombo on Monday (10). While talking to the young sports achievers, the State Minister recalled that the development of sports shooting was one of the main concerns that he had focused on when he took up his portfolio. The students and their coach, Nandana Weerasinghe said that bringing home an Olympic medal is their ultimate goal and stressed the need for a 10 metre air gun shooting range of international standard to make it a reality. Tennakoon stated that sports shooting is a sport that has a high potential to bring international fame for Sri Lanka in terms of physical fitness and existing performance levels of marksmen. While extending his heartiest congratulations to them over their achievements, Tennakoon said that he would personally intervene to construct an international shooting range in consultation with the relevant authorities. Nehasha Weerasinghe of Sirimavo Bandaranaike Vidyalaya, who won the championship in both the junior and open categories of the 10m air pistol women's event, Randhir Senaratne of Nalanda College who won the 10m air rifle youth championship and third place in the open category, Pavith Rodrigo of Nalanda College who took third place in 10m air rifle open category, MM Abhilash Indisa of Ananda College who won the 10m air rifle junior category, UKD Tisangi Geethma of Visakha Vidyalaya and Ravin M Premarathne of Nalanda College who represented the country at the World junior Championship 2022, WHAJ Dhanara Weerasinghe of Sirimavo Bandaranaike Vidyalaya who finished second in the youth category of the 10m air rifle event in 2022 and got selected to the youth pool, and Movidu Shyamantha Wijenayake of D.S. Senanayake College who finished third in the 10m air pistol junior category along with their coach Nandana Weerasinghe, were present on the occasion.

title: India to spearhead delayed debt restructuring for SL
author: Author not found
Content: India took another step forward yesterday (12), to assist Sri Lanka, in its debt restructuring process, a condition laid out by the IMF in order to receive the USD 2.9 billion bailout package for Sri Lanka, which was approved by the IMF on 20 March 2023. The launch of Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring negotiation process will take place today (13) in Washington, DC. India’s Finance Minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, who is currently in Washington DC, informed the IMF that she will today (13), together with a senior official from the French Finance Ministry, announce the beginning of Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring negotiations. Despite the IMF agreement to approve the bailout package, the debt restructuring with Sri Lanka’s international creditors has not yet taken place. China, India and Japan, the main creditors, had to agree to a process of debt restructuring that would assist in receiving the bailout loan. While State Minister Shehan Semansinghe and CBSL Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe will represent Sri Lanka, Japan will be represented by Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki,  and Vice Minister of Finance Masato Kanda along with India’s Sitharaman. France’s Director General of the Treasury, Emmanuel Moulin will also be present. Japan, India, and France will hold a press briefing on the sidelines of the IMF – World Bank Spring Meetings to announce the launch and the three crediter countries have been closely working toward a coordinated debt restructuring plan for Sri Lanka. China, which was delaying its consent to debt restructuring finally agreed to the process. IMF Managing Directer Kristalina Georgieva on 7 April said that China had been helpful in reaching a debt relief deal for Chad and also Sri Lanka, a middle-income country that was not eligible for help under the G20 framework, and she encouraged China to show progress in other cases. Semasinghe tweeted yesterday (12) about this new initiative, stating, “In my meeting with IMF Managing Director Krisalina Georgieva, have expressed our gratitude for giving leadership to support Sri Lanka in overcoming the difficulties faced during the economic crisis.” We reiterated our commitment to finishing the IMF programme while continuing to implement it. He also emphasised Sri Lanka’s ambitious reform plan to achieve debt sustainability and economic stability and reaffirmed its commitment to rebuild it as a thriving country with the help and trust of its foreign partners, drawing on the lessons learned from the crisis. When Sri Lanka defaulted its payment to its creditors it was India that informed the IMF that Sri Lanka should receive an IMF bailout. She and the US Ambassador of Sri Lanka Julie Chung  said they would back the process for Sri Lanka, as it is in desperate need of financial assistance. Georgieva also tweeted that she had met the Central Bank Governor Weerasinghe and the Sri Lanka delegation and that the  IMF will to support at this difficult time. “Now it is important for everyone to come together to do their part to overcome the crisis,” she tweeted. Also, the World Bank, too, reiterated its support for Sri Lanka to stabilise its economy, step up social protection and revive growth.    The bailout package for Sri Lanka was agreed to as a 48-month extended arrangement under the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) programme. The EFF programme will allow Sri Lanka to access financing of up to USD 7 billion from the IMF, international financial institutions and multilateral organisations.  By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: FUTA suspends continuous strike
author: Author not found
Content: The Federation of University Teachers’ Associations (FUTA) has decided to suspend the continuous strike from 17 April. Issuing a special statement yesterday (12), FUTA said the decision was made after the Minister of Education promised to address FUTA’s concerns. The FUTA also emphasised that the Government’s progress will be continuously monitored and the strike will resume if the promises are not fulfilled within a reasonable time frame. At the meeting, the FUTA discussed recent correspondence with the Chairman of the University Grants Commission and the Minister of Education and decided that according to these documents, sufficient action has not been taken to address FUTA’s primary concerns. It was decided that until a satisfactory conclusion is reached, the decision on the participation of university academics in the G.C.E. Advanced Level evaluation will be deferred. FUTA recognises the Minister of Education’s initial dedication, but believes that the support of other government officials is needed to successfully implement the proposed changes, FUTA said. Without a concrete plan outlining when the Government plans to fulfil its promises, FUTA is hesitant to place its faith in the Government. The failure of the Government to meet the demands of FUTA has had far-reaching effects on the quality of education, and FUTA holds the Government solely responsible, the statement said.  “The Government’s response to the demands of FUTA and PTUA, as well as the Government’s treatment of unions, is both undemocratic. To find a better solution, FUTA wants the Government to speak to both FUTA and PTUA. Workers should be allowed to organise into unions and bargain collectively, and the Government should honour these rights. The Government should address the concerns of FUTA and PTUA and find a solution that benefits society as a whole. As FUTA, we have informed the Government that we will no longer tolerate its failure to address the legitimate demands of the university academics, which has led to concerns including life threats to FUTA leaders. We, at FUTA, strongly disapprove of such conduct and pledge to take any and all measures necessary to stop it in the future. We condemn the threatening behaviour. We advocate for a space where all people can feel comfortable sharing their ideas without fear of retaliation. We call on every Sri Lankan to stand with us in defending these ideals and fostering an atmosphere of mutual regard and tolerance,” the statement said.

title: More buses to take people home
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB) said additional buses will be deployed for passengers to go back to their villages for the Sinhala and Tamil New Year holidays starting from 12 April. SLTB Deputy General Manager Panduka Swarnahansa said the schedule of the arrangements for the bus services had been made since 8 April. Swarnahansa said that a number (011 232 80 81) has been announced for people to get information about buses. “It was reported that more people have been arriving at the Colombo Central Bus Stand yesterday (12). So, we have assigned additional buses to provide transport facilities for them,” he said. “We expect more people to use the central bus stand for their travels this afternoon and evening. Therefore, the SLTB has decided to assign more than 250 additional buses for long-distance services,” Swarnahansa said. He added that certain buses have been recalled from remote depots to be assigned for the long-distance services. Meanwhile, the Lanka Private Bus Owners’ Association (LPBOA) also said additional private buses will be assigned during the New Year season following the requirements of the National Transport Commission (NTC) and the Road Passenger Transport Authority (RPTA). Addressing the media, yesterday (12) LPBOA Chairman Gemunu Wijerathne said limited additional bus services were operated on 11 April and more additional buses will be deployed to operate this afternoon and tonight. “Fifty per cent of the buses will operate, today (13), including short and long-distance services. There will be fewer bus services scheduled to operate on 14 April as the conductors and drivers too need to celebrate the New Year. The bus conductors and drivers who do not celebrate the New Year can carry on with their duties,” he said. Another 25% of buses are scheduled to operate on 15 April. However, long-distance bus services will resume only on 16 April. Wijeratne noted that LPBOA will provide additional buses following the request of the NTC and RPTA and have decided to charge an additional half of the fare as the buses have to return without passengers. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Sovereign lenders yet to outline debt talk plans
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s sovereign lenders have yet to inform the Government how they will engage with the country to restructure its USD 7.1 billion of debt and whether they will form an official committee or engage in bilateral talks, the Central Bank Governor told Reuters in an interview on Tuesday. The island nation aims to formally engage in debt negotiations with overseas creditors that include China, India and the Paris Club group of nations in May, after concluding a debt rework with holders of its domestic debt. “It’s up to the creditors to decide. We are happy if there is one platform, as it would be easier to discuss and share information,” Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe told Reuters. “Whether they are coming together or on a separate bilateral basis, we will have comparable debt treatment,” Weerasinghe said on the sidelines of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund Spring Meetings in Washington. As a middle-income country, Sri Lanka is not able to apply for relief under the Group of 20 common framework for debt treatments, so how the Government can engage with creditors is not formally outlined. But is unclear whether a formal committee could secure a swift overhaul, as the platform has failed to speed up debt restructuring talks for common framework countries such as Zambia. Sri Lanka, caught in the worst financial crisis since independence from Britain in 1948 triggered by a severe shortage of dollars, has seen steep inflation, a currency plunge and its economy slide into recession. It recently secured a USD 2.9 billion loan from the IMF, and also aims to get debt relief from over USD 12 billion owed to holders of sovereign bonds. When asked if the country would consider debt-for-nature swaps for all its overseas creditors, Weerasinghe said “those are useful and relevant financial instruments,” though the country’s main goal is to complete the debt rework process “as soon as possible.” “If creditors say that they would like to have those instruments, that it can be done within the timeline and do it fast, we are open,” the Central Bank Chief said. Sri Lanka’s foreign private creditors are considering swapping the country’s defaulted bonds for new securities where cash flow is linked to future economic growth. “Everyone can come and offer those kinds of solutions, and as we engage with them, we can see whether to include them or not.” The Central Bank Governor said additional financing through the IMF’s Resilience and Sustainability Trust (RST) to address climate change’s impact on the economy could be available, but only after the country recovers its debt sustainability under the Washington-based lender programme. (Reuters)

title: Govt to obtain support from all parties – Ali Sabry
author: Author not found
Content: The Government aims to obtain support from all the parties in Parliament to implement the 13th Amendment to the Constitution as the first area to establish national reconciliation, Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry said. The minister said this during a discussion with Ambassadors and High Commissioners of Foreign Missions recently. Ali Sabry said, “The first area is to implement the 13th Amendment to obtain support from other parties in Parliament and reach a broad consensus to give all Sri Lankans the dignity and respect they deserve. The second area involves some executive actions, including speaking to all parties before amending the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) to meet international standards.” The Minister thanked the Ambassadors and High Commissioners for attending the discussion “Thank you for your continuous support in staying informed about Sri Lanka’s progress and developments. I also make use of this opportunity to thank all Sri Lankan creditors and especially the international community represented by your beautiful countries, for supporting Sri Lanka during this very difficult period,” he further said. The Minister said President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s vision is to achieve stability and economic reforms to prioritise the ethnic reconciliation process and provide a long-lasting solution to problems. The Government formed a Cabinet Sub-Committee on National Reconciliation to consolidate three areas for the final push towards reconciliation, he added.

title: India to spearhead delayed debt restructuring for SL
author: Author not found
Content: India took another step forward yesterday (12), to assist Sri Lanka, in its debt restructuring process, a condition laid out by the IMF in order to receive the USD 2.9 billion bailout package for Sri Lanka, which was approved by the IMF on 20 March 2023. The launch of Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring negotiation process will take place today (13) in Washington, DC. India’s Finance Minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, who is currently in Washington DC, informed the IMF that she will today (13), together with a senior official from the French Finance Ministry, announce the beginning of Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring negotiations. Despite the IMF agreement to approve the bailout package, the debt restructuring with Sri Lanka’s international creditors has not yet taken place. China, India and Japan, the main creditors, had to agree to a process of debt restructuring that would assist in receiving the bailout loan. While State Minister Shehan Semansinghe and CBSL Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe will represent Sri Lanka, Japan will be represented by Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki,  and Vice Minister of Finance Masato Kanda along with India’s Sitharaman. France’s Director General of the Treasury, Emmanuel Moulin will also be present. Japan, India, and France will hold a press briefing on the sidelines of the IMF – World Bank Spring Meetings to announce the launch and the three crediter countries have been closely working toward a coordinated debt restructuring plan for Sri Lanka. China, which was delaying its consent to debt restructuring finally agreed to the process. IMF Managing Directer Kristalina Georgieva on 7 April said that China had been helpful in reaching a debt relief deal for Chad and also Sri Lanka, a middle-income country that was not eligible for help under the G20 framework, and she encouraged China to show progress in other cases. Semasinghe tweeted yesterday (12) about this new initiative, stating, “In my meeting with IMF Managing Director Krisalina Georgieva, have expressed our gratitude for giving leadership to support Sri Lanka in overcoming the difficulties faced during the economic crisis.” We reiterated our commitment to finishing the IMF programme while continuing to implement it. He also emphasised Sri Lanka’s ambitious reform plan to achieve debt sustainability and economic stability and reaffirmed its commitment to rebuild it as a thriving country with the help and trust of its foreign partners, drawing on the lessons learned from the crisis. When Sri Lanka defaulted its payment to its creditors it was India that informed the IMF that Sri Lanka should receive an IMF bailout. She and the US Ambassador of Sri Lanka Julie Chung  said they would back the process for Sri Lanka, as it is in desperate need of financial assistance. Georgieva also tweeted that she had met the Central Bank Governor Weerasinghe and the Sri Lanka delegation and that the  IMF will to support at this difficult time. “Now it is important for everyone to come together to do their part to overcome the crisis,” she tweeted. Also, the World Bank, too, reiterated its support for Sri Lanka to stabilise its economy, step up social protection and revive growth.    The bailout package for Sri Lanka was agreed to as a 48-month extended arrangement under the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) programme. The EFF programme will allow Sri Lanka to access financing of up to USD 7 billion from the IMF, international financial institutions and multilateral organisations.  By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Rupee strengthens by 4.48% YoY
author: Author not found
Content: The benchmark ‘spot’ has gained by between 1.85 per cent to 4.48 per cent (six- 10 rupees)) to Rs 319/320 to the US dollar in two-way quotes, year on year (YoY) to yesterday, thereby defraying cost-push inflationary pressure, data showed. A year ago the ‘spot’ was trading at Rs 325/335 to the dollar in two-way quotes, statistics further showed. Meanwhile, the ‘spot’ remained unchanged at Rs 319/320 to the dollar in two-way quotes for the second consecutive market day to yesterday as buying pressure from the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) to strengthen the country’s parlous foreign reserves continued to far outweigh sustained ‘avurudu’ inflows and exporter conversions, despite import pressure being negated by import controls and bans, market sources who didn’t want to be named told ‘Ceylon Today.’  In related developments, CBSL strengthened the official ‘spot’ for the fourth consecutive market day to yesterday, this time mildly, by 0.04 per cent (Rs 0.14) to Rs 319.83 to the dollar. However, a year ago, CBSL, then under the purview of Basil Rajapaksa, who was the Finance Minister at that time, weakened the official ‘spot’, by 4.24 per cent (Rs 12.68) to Rs 311.68 to the dollar, thereby  resulting in a YoY weakening of the official ‘spot’ by 2.55 per cent (Rs 8.15) to the dollar. In like developments, a year ago the market ‘spot’ weakened by from 1.56 per cent to 1.52 per cent (Rs 5) to Rs 325/335 to the dollar in two-way quotes data further showed. ‘Spot’ trades are settled after two market days from the date of trading. CBSL the steward of GoSL debt and of its foreign reserves deals in the official ‘spot.’ The official ‘spot’ is usually artificially propped up to minimise the cost of GoSL’s foreign debt in rupee terms and also to minimise GoSL’s foreign debt servicing costs in rupee terms. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Seven arrested for selling unhygienic food
author: By Nandana Kelegama – Polpithigama
Content: Kotawehera MOH M.S.M. Shakeer said seven suspects were arrested on charges of selling kottu and fried rice prepared using eggs unfit for human consumption. He said the raids were conducted by officers based on a lead on 11 April. He added that during the inspection, 800 eggs unfit for human consumption had been seized from eateries while arresting six owners of eateries in Kotawehera. A 35-year-old woman alleged to have supplied the eggs to the eateries had also been arrested, Shakeer said. The seized stock of eggs had been destroyed.

title: WBB verifies 3.2M households for benefits
author: Author not found
Content: The Welfare Benefits Board (WBB) announced that after verifying the applications of nearly 3.2 million households, welfare benefit payments will be made to the eligible individuals beginning in June of this year. According to WBB chairman, B. Wijayaratne, nearly 3.2 million household applications have been verified so far. Meanwhile, the information survey, aimed at identifying eligible individuals for the welfare benefits programme, concluded on 10 April. The census work was originally scheduled to be completed by 31 March, but the deadline was later pushed back by 10 days. The survey was launched to confirm the information of individuals who had applied for the programme titled ‘Let’s Be Honest – Help the True Needy.’ Wijayaratne added that once the data census work is finished, a list of eligible candidates for welfare benefits will be prepared and displayed at all Divisional Secretariats and Grama Niladhari Offices. Those who are not listed as eligible candidates will be given a 10-days time to file appeals and objections. The appeals and objections will be examined by respective committees, at Pradeshiya Sabhas, appointed by the District Secretaries. The committees will made necessary recommendations to the Board before commencing the welfare benefit payments in June.

title: 42-year old found dead at spa in Kandana
author: Author not found
Content: A man who had come to a spa in Kandana at midnight on Tuesday (12) was found dead in the wee hours of the morning yesterday (12), Police said. Police believe he may have suffered a heart attack. Kandana Police are conducting investigations.

title: Education Ministry urges lecturers to commence AL paper marking
author: Author not found
Content: The Education Ministry urged university lecturers to intervene and commence the G.C.E. Advanced Level examination 2023 answer script evaluation. Teachers have shown a positive response following the Education Ministry’s  reaction to provide solutions to their problems. The Education Minister welcomed the Federation of University Teachers’ Union (FUTA) decision to suspend trade union action. In a statement, the Ministry stated that the Department of Examinations was now ready to begin evaluating A/L answer scripts. The Ministry informed the FUTA that it was ready to discuss any additional issues at any time. The Ministry also praised the decision to resume university lectures on 17 April 2023. The FUTA had decided to temporarily halt their strike action against the Government’s new income tax policy which commenced on 9 March.

title: Excise raid 16 liquor stores in the South
author: Author not found
Content: The Southern Province Special Excise Raids Unit raided wine and liquor stores during a four-day period from 6 to 10 April and instituted legal action against the suspects taken into custody. The raid was conducted following instructions received from the Excise Commissioner. Raids were conducted in Ahangama, Weligama, Akuressa, Morawaka, Okewela, Julampitiya, Thoradeniya, Ambakolawewa, Pannagamuwa and Weerawila. Cases will be filed in Courts in Galle, Matara, Walasmulla, Hanbantota and Morawaka on charges of selling of unlicensed local and foreign liquor brands, possession of illegal spirits and selling moonshine. BY S. Diyagahage – Ahangama

title: N Eliya – Talawakelle bus out of operation
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB) operated a bus between Nuwara Eliya and Talawakelle but now it is out of operation inconveniencing the public, especially schoolchildren. People in the area complain that the bus has been out of operation for more than two weeks. They requested SLTB officials to take note of the issue immediately and commence the bus service once again. BY T. Chandru – Nuwara Eliya

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.
