title: Demand for legalalcohol down, illicit liquor sales up – Sagala
author: Author not found
Content: The demand for legal alcohol has decreased, while the sale of illicit liquor has increased, following the increase by 20 per cent in excise duties in January. This was revealed by the President’s Chief of Staff and Senior Adviser on National Security, Sagala Ratnayake, during a discussion with Foreign Ambassadors and High Commissioners on Monday (10). As a result, the Government could not collect the expected revenue through excise duties. During the meeting, Ratnayake announced that the President has presented the International Monetary Fund’s (IMF) Extended Fund Facility (EFF) programme to Parliament and it will be discussed from 25 April, while political parties will have to decide whether they will support their country or not. He emphasised the importance of a structural reform programme for economic recovery and sustainable growth, which includes not only financial and economic reforms, but also the reconciliation process, which is crucial for Sri Lanka’s progress. Ratnayake further said, “We started this tedious and ambitious programme of structural reform for economic recovery and sustainable growth. We were left with very little option to do that and it was a very committed effort that we started on. This programme is not limited purely to the fiscal and economic reforms; the fiscal reform in particular, also encompasses matters like the reconciliation process, which is the key to recovery for Sri Lankans and sustainable growth. “I won’t go into great detail on the IMF- EFF because it is a public document and I’m sure all of you have been through it. I just touched on the key areas. It is based on advancing revenue-based fiscal consolidation, which includes tax policy measures. Many of them have already been implemented, but there are others, such as the removal of para-tariffs, which I will touch on again later, that will be based on a structured process. There are others that we will have to review in September when we review the IMF programme. “The Budget Office is expected to be up and running by May 2023. There is a mandatory time period that allows for public consumption, after which it will be presented to Parliament and then referred to the Public Finance Committee, which in turn has to come back to Parliament. This is a process they have to follow, and they hope to finish it by the first Parliamentary week of April,” he said. “It is a very tight target. Once Parliament ratifies the decision of the Public Finance Committee, we hope to finish it by the first Parliamentary week of this month, which starts on 25 April. “In the third quarter of 2024, a new public debt management law will be introduced, covering various areas, including ones that are currently not covered by law. This includes processes such as providing Sovereign guarantees and so on,” Ratnayake elaborated.

title: Number of LG members slashed to 4,714
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the National Delimitation Committee Mahinda Deshapriya said the total number of members elected to Local Government bodies has been slashed to 4,714 in the new report on demarcation. The final report of the committee was handed over to Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena yesterday (11) morning. According to the committee report, the plethora of members of Municipal Councils, Urban Councils, Pradeshiya Sabhas and provincial councils which is more than 8,000 has been reduced by nearly half. A five-member National Delimitation Committee was appointed in November 2022 for the demarcation of wards for local authorities, through a Gazette Notification by Premier Gunawardena in his capacity as the Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government. The committee was chaired by Deshapriya and comprised Jayalath R.V. Dissanayake, W.M.M.R. Adikari, K. Thavalingam and I.A. Hameed.

title: Anti-Corruption Bill contains laudableprovisions – TISL
author: Author not found
Content: The proposed Anti-Corruption Bill contains several laudable provisions that seek to improve on the existinganti-corruption legal framework in Sri Lanka, Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL) said. The proposed Anti-Corruption Bill, which seeks to replace the Bribery Act (Chapter 26), the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption Act No. 19 of 1994, and the Declaration of Assets and Liabilities Law No. 1 of 1975, has been gazetted and is expected to be tabled in Parliament soon. This Bill was open for observations from different stakeholders including TISL and other civil society organisations, activists, and the public.    Speaking at a media briefing yesterday (11), TISL Deputy Executive Director Sankhitha Gunaratne said, “Specifically recognising sexual favours as a form of gratification, including private sector corruption, and corruption offences related to sporting events within its ambit, are important changes introduced in this Bill. The Bill also significantly increases fines that can be imposed for offences.” The media briefing was held at the TISL premises in Rajagiriya on 11 April, together with TISL Advocacy and Research Manager Janithrika Jayasundara, TISL Legal Officer – Community Sector Piumi Madushani and TISL Programme Officer – Communication Rifdhi Nawas. According to the proposed asset declaration system in the Bill, there will be a central authority (CIABOC – the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption) with which all the declarations of assets and liabilities will be filed. The asset declarations will be made publicly available through an electronic system, subject to the redaction of certain sensitive information. This electronic system will identify red flags regarding the illicit enrichment of the individuals to whom this law applies. The proposed law also requires the President to file their declaration of assets and liabilities, unlike the present law. However, TISL said there are two serious concerns in the proposed law. It seeks to override all other written law, which includes the Right to Information Act. The proposed law contains sections that require officials of the CIABOC to sign oaths of secrecy and therefore, the disclosure of information by CIABOC under the new law will only be possible with special permission from the Commission. As such, the proposed law promotes a culture of secrecy by making access to information from the CIABOC more difficult and thereby negates the objective to “enhance transparency in governance,” as stated in the Bill.  TISL also noted that Section 119 of the Bill, which refers to false allegations, appears to send a negative signal to citizens willing to come forward as informants and whistleblowers to report corruption. While the similar provision in the present law has not been misused targeting corruption fighters, this particular provision could become seriously counterproductive and dangerous in a context of a politically-influenced public service, or in an adverse environment of stifled civic space, democratic deficits, weak governance or kleptocracy. As an organisation that advocates for citizens’ freedom of expression, TISL believes that the proposed Bill should be more robust and progressive enough to encourage whistleblowers and citizens to come forward and report corruption without fear of repercussions, while discouraging the corrupt.    TISL further emphatically highlights that the law itself, on paper, cannot solve the plague of systemic corruption in Sri Lanka since the effectiveness of the law will entirely depend on its enforcement. For instance, the Bill provides for joint investigations and international cooperation, which will have no impact unless this is practically implemented. Under this Bill, the CIABOC is granted immense police powers, which provides adequate space for CIABOC to carry out its functions. TISL reiterates that the successful implementation of those functions depends on the level of independence the Commission is given, starting with the appointment of the Commission and the Director-General, the creation of an enabling environment where the commission and law enforcement officials are able to act without undue influence and intimidation, availability of resources including human resources, financial independence, and knowledge capacity. The mere passage of this Bill, despite its progressive portions, will not be able to address the issue of corruption in Sri Lanka until there is the political will to lead the country by example, a system change that includes a cultural shift where the people resist corruption even at the petty level, and a context that is conducive to the whistle-blowers.    Therefore, TISL calls on the Government, with the technical assistance of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to rectify these concerns in the law forthwith and further, to continue to engage with citizens, experts, and civil society, in order to adopt a holistic approach to achieve the envisaged goal of eradicating corruption in Sri Lanka.

title: 100,000 TOQUEmonkeys to be airlifted to China – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: About 100,000 toque monkeys will be sent to China to be displayed in zoos, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. This is in an effort to control the monkey population in Sri Lanka and with a view to reducing damage caused by the animals to cultivations. It is reported that a committee will be formed to hold discussions with a group of Chinese representatives, who are due in the island shortly. According to the Minister, as the first phase of this programme, 100,000 monkeys will be flown to Beijing, China. Another committee will be set up comprising officials from the Attorney General’s Department and the Department of Wildlife Conservation to formulate the necessary laws to undertake the proposed task. Following a recent survey conducted by the Hector Kobbekaduwa Agrarian Research and Training Institute, it came to light that monkeys and giant squirrels had damaged 93 million coconuts and various other crops islandwide from January to June 2022. By Savani Sheashadhi

Under this Bill, the CIABOC is granted immense police powers, which provides adequate space for CIABOC to carry out its functions. TISL reiterates that the successful implementation of those functions depends on the level of independence the Commission is given, starting with the appointment of the Commission and the Director-General, the creation of an enabling environment where the commission and law enforcement officials are able to act without undue influence and intimidation, availability of resources including human resources, financial independence, and knowledge capacity. The mere passage of this Bill, despite its progressive portions, will not be able to address the issue of corruption in Sri Lanka until there is the political will to lead the country by example, a system change that includes a cultural shift where the people resist corruption even at the petty level, and a context that is conducive to the whistle-blowers.    Therefore, TISL calls on the Government, with the technical assistance of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to rectify these concerns in the law forthwith and further, to continue to engage with citizens, experts, and civil society, in order to adopt a holistic approach to achieve the envisaged goal of eradicating corruption in Sri Lanka.

title: 100,000 TOQUEmonkeys to be airlifted to China – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: About 100,000 toque monkeys will be sent to China to be displayed in zoos, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. This is in an effort to control the monkey population in Sri Lanka and with a view to reducing damage caused by the animals to cultivations. It is reported that a committee will be formed to hold discussions with a group of Chinese representatives, who are due in the island shortly. According to the Minister, as the first phase of this programme, 100,000 monkeys will be flown to Beijing, China. Another committee will be set up comprising officials from the Attorney General’s Department and the Department of Wildlife Conservation to formulate the necessary laws to undertake the proposed task. Following a recent survey conducted by the Hector Kobbekaduwa Agrarian Research and Training Institute, it came to light that monkeys and giant squirrels had damaged 93 million coconuts and various other crops islandwide from January to June 2022. By Savani Sheashadhi

title: Only Rs 2.5B approved for ‘Suwaseriya’ upkeep – Chairman
author: Author not found
Content: Although it is estimated that nearly Rs 9 billion is needed from the Treasury to operate ‘1990 – Suwaseriya’ emergency ambulance service, only Rs 2.5 billion has been approved, Chairman of ‘1990 – Suwaseriya’ Dumindra Ratnayake said. Thus, they had been compelled to seek donations from the private sector towards its operations as the Government had failed to provide them with requisite funds for its maintenance, Ratnayake said. Following the request for donations, Rs 525 million has been received from the private sector towards the upkeep of the popular ambulance service to date. At present, 297 ambulances are in service as part of its operations and a sum of Rs 5 million has been estimated towards the upkeep of a single ambulance, he added. Ratnayake observed that certain private firms had agreed to maintain 20 ambulances and noted that several Sri Lankan migrant workers had also agreed to donate funds for its operations. During the past five-year period, the much sought-after ambulance service had transported over 1.5 million patients to hospitals, he said. By Bingun Menaka Gamage

title: Highest accident admissions from8 to 16 April – NCDU
author: Author not found
Content: State hospitals receive the highest number of accident victims during the period from 8 to 16 April, Consultant Community Physician Samitha Sirithunga of the Health Ministry’s Non Communicable Disease Unit (NCDU) said. Dr. Sirithunga lamented that the highest number of accident victim deaths, while receiving treatment in hospital, is also reported during this period. Starting from 8 April till about the 16 this a time that hospitals receive the highest number of accident victims and record the highest number that die while receiving treatment for the injuries sustained in them, he explained during a media briefing. A majority of hospital admissions are due to injuries sustained by falling. But the reason for the influx of admissions are road traffic accidents. “Also, there are those who sustain injuries due to animal bites, due to falling objects and assaults during the above -mentioned period,” Dr.Sirithunga said.  With the available data, a majority of deaths that occur during this period are due to road traffic accidents, drowning and poisoning. “Since we did not enjoy the Sinhala and Tamil New Year on a grand scale during the past two years as a result of Covid-19, we have noted that the trend will increase during these few days once more.” The attempt to accomplish a large number of things within a short period, sleepiness may result in increasing the speed of the vehicle that we are travelling in, he said. Drunk driving during the festive season and limited knowledge regarding the environment that they are in during excursions may result in accidents and drowning incidents. The Consultant Community Physician also warned that accidents could occur while preparing food items for the festival. “That too is something that people should be conscious of,” he said. Dr. Sirithunga also urged organisers of ‘Avurudu festivals’ to utilise the morning hours for their marathon events to prevent accidents from occurring due to excessive sweating.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Prices of school bags, shoes to be slashed– Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: Considering the difficulties of parents to provide for children at present, the Ministry of Finance will take steps to reduce the prices of school bags and shoes immediately, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said. Siyambalapitiya said this during a discussion held at the Finance Ministry on the prices of school bags and shoes. He also instructed officials of the Trade and Investment Policy Department of the Ministry to provide a report within a week. The State Minister pointed out that importing these items has been banned completely at present and only importing raw materials to manufacture them is allowed. “We are aware that parents are going through a difficult time providing for children with the beginning of a new school term. Owing to higher prices, they are at a point where they cannot afford these items anymore. Now the LKR has appreciated against the USD as well. Considering this situation, we decided to reduce the prices of school bags and shoes,” he said.

title: LG Pollspostponed once again – EC
author: Author not found
Content: The Local Government Election 2023 was postponed once again owing to the lack of funds. Accordingly, the election scheduled for 25 April has been postponed for the second time, the Election Commission officially announced yesterday (11). In a statement, Commissioner General of Elections Saman Sri Ratnayake said it was decided to postpone the election due to non-availability of funds and other reasons that are beyond the control of the EC. “Holding the election will bank on a Supreme Court decision or being able to obtain necessary funds from the Government,” he said. He added that a fresh election date will be announced by the District Returning Officers after consulting the EC. “However, all measures to hold the election will continue unimpeded,” he said. The LG Election was originally scheduled for 9 March. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: MCPA urges Health Secy to probe Kumudesh’s allegations
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) urged the Health Secretary to investigate accusations made by the Association of Health Professionals (AHP) against officials of the Health Ministry, following the tragic death of a pregnant woman.  AHP President Ravi Kumudesh, on Monday (11), claimed that the Health Ministry distributing an anaesthetic drug, allegedly imported from Myanmar, to replace another anaesthetic drug, which led to the death of a pregnant woman, who was admitted to Teaching Hospital Peradeniya for a caesarean section on 2 April, is highly suspicious. Speaking to the media, Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa, yesterday (11), called for an “impartial investigation into accusations of corruption made against the officials of the Health Ministry by AHP President Ravi Kumudesh.” “If the hospital administrators, assistant secretaries and Deputy Directors’ General of the Health Ministry were involved in corruption, fraud, and irregularities in the past, as he said action should be taken to conduct immediate investigations against those officials and take disciplinary action against them in order to restore the Ministry’s reputation,” Dr. Sanjeewa asserted. Dr. Sanjeewa said, “according to the AHP President, the Ministry of Health has been involved in corruption, fraud, irregularities and the purchase of various medicines, the purchase of laboratory goods during the last two years.” “It is the responsibility of the Health Secretary to conduct disciplinary investigations against the relevant officials, as there was enough and more evidence that Health Ministry officials were involved in corrupt deals when purchasing medicines, consumables, laboratory equipment and other materials,” he added. He also said the Health Secretary’s failure to take action would only result in him having acknowledged Kumudesh’s allegations of corruption. The MCPA President urged the Health Secretary not to hesitate in conducting an investigation against Kumudesh himself if he felt that the latter had only made such accusations out of malice towards Health Ministry officials and hospital authorities.     By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: CID probesbreak-in atformer AG’s office
author: Author not found
Content: The CID informed Colombo Additional Magistrate T.N. Ilangasinghe that they had launched a probe into an incident where a person had unlawfully entered the Colombo 7 office of former Attorney General Dappula de Livera in 2022. The CID, via motion on Monday (10), told the Additional Magistrate that the former AG had lodged a complaint with the Narahenpita Police, alleging that an unauthorised individual had entered his Colombo 7 office on 11 November last year. They added that thereafter, the IGP had instructed them to launch a probe into the incident. The CID further told Additional Magistrate Ilangasinghe, that, accordingly, they had launched an investigation into the incident, having submitted the CCTV footage at the former Attorney General’s office to the Government Analyst. The CID stated that perusal of the CCTV footage had shown that an individual, having entered de Livera’s office, had come out of the office, before stepping into a white van and heading towards Thimbirigasyaya. The Court then instructed the CID to conduct further investigations into the incident and file a progress report at the next hearing. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: No coal shortage at Norochcholai Plant – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: There will be no shortage of coal to operate the Norochcholai Power Plant, despite recent speculation in this regard by both the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) trade unions and certain media outlets, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera assured. In a tweet, Minister Wijesekera provided a detailed breakdown with regard to the coal requirement for the power plant to operate. Assuring that the required stocks have been procured, he said 30 stocks of coal cargo are needed to operate the Norochcholai Power Plant at full capacity as per the generation forecast by the CEB for the upcoming season. “While the 23rd stock of cargo is presently being unloaded, the 24th, 25th and 26th stocks have docked at Puttalam and unloading is pending. Further, the 27th, 28th and 29th cargos have been nominated and are due to arrive before 1 May, while the 30th stock of coal cargo is due to be nominated, and is scheduled to arrive in the first week of May,” he said.

title: Four stowaways remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Four persons who secretly boarded a Panama-flagged cargo ship, anchored at the Colombo Port, in an attempt to illegally migrate were remanded until 18 April by Galle Magistrate’s Court yesterday (11). These suspects, who attempted to leave the country illegally as stowaways on the vessel that was docked at the Colombo Port on 24 March, were found by the Captain of the ship near the security checkpoint at the Suez Canal in Egypt. They were sent back to the Galle Port and taken into custody by the Department of Immigration and Emigration in the afternoon of 10 April. According to sources from the Colombo Port, the vessel had been docked at the Colombo Port in order to load a stock of Sri Lankan manufactured apparels to Europe. The suspects aged 25, 31, 32 and 32 are residents of Jaffna.  BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Legal action against 20 crooked traders in N’ Eliya
author: Author not found
Content: Legal action has been instituted against 20 traders in Nuwara Eliya District for selling eggs at higher prices and hiding egg stocks, Chief of Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) office in Nuwara Eliya Amila Ratnayake said. He said over the last few weeks, 10 traders who sold eggs at higher prices were produced before the Hatton and Nuwara Eliya Magistrates. Also, 2,000 eggs were confiscated from a trader found to be hiding eggs. Ratnayake said such raids will be conducted until the end of the festive season in the public interest. He added that the law will be strictly enforced against crooked businessmen who try to take undue advantage of customers. By Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Arrested with Kerala ganja
author: Author not found
Content: A 59-year-old man was arrested, by Okkampitiya Police, for being in possession of nearly six kilograms of Kerala Ganja. Police said the suspect is a resident of Maligawila. Further investigations are being conducted by the Okkampitiya Police. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Ton up Pulindu steers Dharmaraja
author: Author not found
Content: Dharmaraja College Kandy beat Kingswood College Kandy by 50 runs in the 34th Limited over cricket encounter for the Winston Hoole Memorial Trophy at the Pallekele International Cricket Stadium recently. Kingswood won the toss and invited Dharmaraja to take first lease of the wicket. Dharmaraja did well to score 277 runs in 46 overs. Left hand opener Pulindu Perera scored 117 runs in 101 balls with 9 boundaries and 7 sixes. Maleesha Rajakaruna scored 56 runs in 71 deliveries with 6 boundaries and 2 sixes. Chamath Ekanayake (29), Nisala Abeyrathne (19) and Arosha Mahagedara (13*) made useful contributions to bolster the score. Pulindu and Maleesha were involved in 129 runs stand for the 3rd wicket. Ravindu Bandara and Amesh Rupasinghe claimed 3 wickets each. Kingswood were bowled out for 227 runs in 46.5 overs. Kavija Gamage scored 77 runs in 98 balls with 5 boundaries and skipper Amesh Rupasinghe scored 55 runs in 60 deliveries with 6 boundaries and 2 sixes. The duo put on a partnership of 92 runs for the 5th wicket. Abdul Hakam (32) and Adhel Sheriff (20) helped to build their innings. Dakshika Manukalpa claimed 3 wickets for 32 runs. Dharmaraja: 277 (46) (Pulindu Perera 117, Maleesha Rajakaruna 56, Chamath Ekanayake 29, Ravindu Bandara 3/32, Amesh Rupasinghe 3/49) Kingswood: 227 (46.5) (Kavija Gamage 77, Amesh Rupasinghe 55, Abdul Hakam 32, Adhel Sheriff 20, Dakshika Manukalpa 3/32) (IR)

title: POLICE SAY WEAR FACE MASK IN CROWDED AREAS
author: Author not found
Content: The Police advised the public on Monday (10) to wear face masks in crowded areas during the festive season. During a media briefing, Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said considering their own wellbeing, it is better that the public wear face masks whenever they are in crowded areas. He requested the public to be aware of the shrewd businessmen who try to sell their products at higher rates. The Police Spokesman also urged the parents to be cautious and pay special attention to their children, as organized criminals are targeting children for drug smuggling. Meanwhile, he also requested the public to take necessary measures to fix their home security systems, if they have any. BY Dinithi Wijesundara

title: DEPARTURE OF A DEAR FRIEND
author: Author not found
Content: It is with great sorrow that we announce the passing away of Chandana Ranaweera, an artist, an art critic, an art teacher and an avid enthusiast of oriental culture. The name Chandana Ranaweera is a familiar one to the readers of Ceylon Today Features as he was a regular contributor to both Daily and Sunday Features with his reviews and personality features on local as well as foreign artists. When writing about local artists, he made it a point to highlight lesser-known yet deserving artists to keep their legacy alive and to create a discourse about their art. Chandana was also fascinated with the cultures of East Asian countries, in particular, Japan. He wrote about interesting and unique festivals in Japan on a regular basis, familiarising Sri Lankan readers with the culture of another part of the world.    Hailing from Alawwa, Chandana was an avid art fan since childhood and this undying passion for the artistic world led him to become an artist himself as well as an art teacher. For years, he enriched the artistic souls of students at Kandegedara Maha Vidyalaya and Rathnalankara Maha Vidyalaya in Alawwa, as a teacher. Since his retirement, he had dedicated his time to focus on his own art and the articles he wrote for Ceylon Today. He was a talented painter, with his niche being line drawings.  Chandana was a regular contributor to Ceylon Today and his untimely demise leaves a void another can hardly fill, as what made Chandana’s articles special was his undying passion for the world of art, a kind of passion hard to come by these days. Chandana faced some health issues in his last days, but his death came as a shock to many. His last rites took place at Kuliyapitiya Crematorium on 11 April. Ceylon Today, as well as its readership, will miss Chandana Ranaweera dearly. May he attain the Supreme Bliss of Nirvana!

title: SL Embassy in Ankara donates to earthquake survivors for Ramadan
author: Author not found
Content: This year, the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Ankara decided to make the customary Ramadan donation to some of the survivors of the Earthquake, who arrived in Ankara. The devastating earthquakes on 6 February, followed by over 6,000 aftershocks and flooding that occurred in the south eastern part of Turkiye, resulted in destroying over 50,000 lives and infrastructure spread in 10 provinces with over 110,000 sqm area. Accordingto offıcial estimate, over 300,000 people have migrated to Ankara, with most living in with relatives, friends and in dormitories.  The Embassy decided to provide the donation boxes to people living in Alacaatlı Neighbourhood of Cankaya District of the Ankara Province. The support for this group was extended by the local Neighbourhood Muhtar who is the elected village head. Muhtars and their village councils are elected during local elections for five years. Political parties are not permitted to nominate candidates for these posts.  The head of Muhtar, Hülya Erdoğan of Alacaatlı Neighbourhood and herall-female volunteer team invited a group of survivors to gather at their office to receive the donation. The volunteer team along with Embassy staff and members of the Sri Lankan community distributed the donation boxes. The Ambassador also interacted with the group, who shared their horrific experiences, and how they are trying their best to be resilient.  The Ambassador also had discussions with Hülya Erdoğan and her team on their mandate, which includes extending physical and mental support with counselling for survivors and funding. She assured her support in their efforts. She thanked the Embassy staff and some of the members of the Sri Lankan community who contributed in making the Ramadan donation packs and added that as the disaster occurred on the day that the formal reception of Sri Lanka’s 75th Anniversary of Independence was to take place, it was decided to add a special gift, in commemoration of the same.

title: SL Navy seizes Rs 44M worth Kerala cannabis
author: Author not found
Content: A special search operation, conducted by the Sri Lanka Navy off Valvettithurai, Jaffna in the dark hours of 9 April led to the recovery of more than 134kg (wet weight) of Kerala cannabis adrift in waters.  As an extension of these operations, an Inshore Patrol Craft, attached to SLNS Uththara in the Northern Naval Command, carried out the search in the sea area of Valvettithurai on 9 April and recovered four suspicious sacks adrift in the waters. The sacks contained about 134kg and 300g (wet weight) of Kerala cannabis which had been stuffed in 58 parcels.  It is suspected that smugglers might have abandoned the consignment of Kerala cannabis being unable to fetch them into the country, due to constant naval operations. Meanwhile, the gross street value of seized Kerala cannabis is believed to be over Rs. 44 million.  The stock of Kerala cannabis has been kept in Naval custody until it is handed over to authorities for onward action. (NV)

title: Fisheries Minister discusses Fishery issues in Batticaloa
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said issues pertaining to the Vadduwan shrimp farm will be resolved through Court or in consultation with the relevant parties. Devananda said, the shrimp farm in the Vakarai Divisional Secretariat (DS) Division in the Batticaloa District was given to 27 families affected by the tsunami and  now a single individual had taken control of the farm thus rendering these families helpless with no means of survival. A discussion was held on 10 April chaired by Devananda with the participation of State Minister Sivanesathurai Chandrakanthan at the Batticaloa District Secretariat. Devananda said the public raised many issues at the discussion but this issue was the focus of attention. Minister Devananda said a solution will be found in a month in consultation with the relevant persons or through Courts. “The Police, Navy and the Ceylon Fisheries Corporation have been operating in collaboration with assistance from Fisheries societies and federations to prevent illegal fishing practices taking place across the country including the Batticaloa District,” Devananda said. When it was brought to the attention of Minister Devananda that a group was stealing fishing nets laid on the shore, he said the Navy and Ceylon Fisheries Corporation will take action to curb it soon. The issue of the ice factory belonging to Ceylon Fisheries Corporation which was currently not in operation and that anti-social activities were taking place within the premises was also brought to his notice, the Minister said a sustainable solution will be found to the issue in three months. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Devanandasays imprudentpractices pulled country into abyss
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said imprudent political practices of the past has pulled the country into an abyss, making the country economically vulnerable. Devananda said that his prime focus is to create an environment where the people in North and East will be able to live, protecting their dignity and self-esteem. Devananda recently visited Ampara District where he met fishermen and discussed their problems. He said, as a Minister in charge of Fisheries he is committed to look into the wellbeing of thousands of salt water and fresh water fishermen in the country.  The Minister also met the people in Thirukkovil, where he discussed many problems the people were facing in their day-to-day life and pledged that expeditious action will be taken to address their problems.  The people also handed over a letter to the Minister with regard to their agitations. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: PHIs on the prowl in Galle
author: Author not found
Content: Galle District Public Health Inspector (Administration) Priyantha de Silva said that the PHIs have commenced a special operation to monitor all bakeries, hotels, canteens and restaurants in the district to determine the quality of food during the festive season. He said as part of this operation 1,200 such places have been inspected in Galle District. He added that to date they have instituted legal action against 40 traders and businessmen who were found to be selling food unfit for human consumption, selling contaminated food, maintenance of business establishments sans valid licenses and for failing to look into cleanliness of food items prepared etc.  BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Woman arrested for husband’s murder
author: Author not found
Content: Pulasthipura Police have arrested a woman, following a tip-off, for killing her 29-year-old husband in Pulasthipura on Sunday (9). Initial investigation revealed the suspect had attacked the victim with a sharp object during a verbal dispute. The injured had passed away while being admitted to the Pulasthigama Hospital.  The suspect was remanded till 21 April after being produced to the Magistrate’s Court. The post-mortem was held yesterday (10) and Pulasthipura Police is conducting further investigations.  By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Police probe into body found in gutter
author: Author not found
Content: Ratnapura Police have launched an investigation into the body of a male found in a gutter. Police found a body of a man who had  died under suspicious circumstances in Ratnapura on Sunday (9). The victim was identified as a 62-year-old resident of Ratnapura. The body lies at Ratnapura Hospital morgue following the Magisterial Inquest. The cause of the death was not revealed. The Police said further investigations will be conducted following the postmortem. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: SL inks agreementwith Japan – Manusha
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara said Sri Lanka has reached a bilateral agreement with the Government of Japan, to set up training centres aimed at Japanese employment opportunities for Sri Lankan youth. Nanayakkara, who was on an official visit to Japan, had reached this agreement when he met top Japanese diplomats and heads of employment agencies. Nanayakkara pointed out that more Japanese jobs will become available by increasing opportunities to face examinations related to the nursing service. Accordingly, Japan’s Minister of Labour has agreed to provide more opportunities for job seekers to appear for the said examinations. Meanwhile, Nanayakkara held talks with Japan’s Minister for Health, Labour and Welfare Katsunobu Kato, about the possibility of increasing the number of job opportunities for Sri Lankan caregivers in Japan. He also requested the Japanese Minister to open up job opportunities in building maintenance and cleaning sectors that are not open to Sri Lankans at present. The Minister also held talks with Minister of State in the Cabinet Office of Japan Satoshi Fujimaru, regarding the previous agreement reached to launch a training centre targeting job opportunities in Japan’s automobile industry. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Cause of fisher’s death still unknown
author: Author not found
Content: The post-mortem into the death of a fisherman, on a fishing trawler, was held, on Monday (10), by Galle District Coroner Mahesh Dharmaratne and Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) of Karapitiya Teaching Hospital Ruwan Nanayakkara. The deceased was identified as D. Sujeewaka Premakumara, a 53-year-old resident of Hakuruwela in Medayaya and a father of four. During the post mortem evidence was given by a colleague of the deceased, Sujith Sudira and the victim’s spouse H. Lasanthi Kumari. The JMO and the Coroner deferred their decision on the cause of the death and released the body to his family.  BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: High Posts Committee approves three new appointments
author: Author not found
Content: Secretary-General of Parliament Dhammika Dasanayake said the Committee on High Posts recently approved the appointments of two new secretaries to the ministries and a new ambassador. Accordingly, the Committee has approved the appointment of W.S. Satyananda as the new Secretary to the Ministry of Urban Development and Housing. The Committee on High Posts also approved the appointment of M.M. Naimuddin as the new Secretary to the Ministry of Investment Promotion, Dasanayake said. In addition, the approval of the Committee has been given to the appointment of Dr. Chanaka Harsha Talpahewa as the Ambassador of Sri Lanka to the Philippines. The Committee on High Posts of the Parliament met recently under the chairmanship of Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena and MPs John Seneviratne, Anura Priyadarshana Yapa, Thalatha Athukorala and Dr. Sudarshini Fernandopulle were in attendance.

title: Legal action against 20 crooked traders in N’ Eliya
author: Author not found
Content: Legal action has been instituted against 20 traders in Nuwara Eliya District for selling eggs at higher prices and hiding egg stocks, Chief of Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) office in Nuwara Eliya Amila Ratnayake said. He said over the last few weeks, 10 traders who sold eggs at higher prices were produced before the Hatton and Nuwara Eliya Magistrates. Also, 2,000 eggs were confiscated from a trader found to be hiding eggs. Ratnayake said such raids will be conducted until the end of the festive season in the public interest. He added that the law will be strictly enforced against crooked businessmen who try to take undue advantage of customers. By Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: PHIs prosecute 3,102 traders for selling bad food
author: Author not found
Content: Legal action has been taken against 3,102 traders and businessmen for selling food unsuitable for human consumption.  This follows islandwide raids during the festive season, the Public Health Inspectors’ Union (PHIU) said. PHIU Chairman Upul Rohana said PHIs have inspected 19,107 food outlets and business establishments island-wide so far. He said of that legal action has been instituted against the aforementioned number of traders, while final warnings had been issued to another 2,103 traders. PHIs have commenced visits to inspect food outlets island-wide to nab traders who sell unfit food items to consumers, following instructions received from the Health Ministry. Rohana pointed out the inspection process, which was kicked off in early March, would be continued till the end of this month. By Jude Samantha

title: Amaraweera orders amending Pesticides Control Act
author: Author not found
Content: Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera advised the Registrar General of Pesticides to take steps to amend the Pesticides Control Act immediately as there is a fake and substandard pesticides and herbicides racket in the country.  ‘’Under the existing laws, fines imposed and prison sentences levied in connection with the sale of substandard pesticides and herbicides, as well as illegal importation of pesticides and herbicides, that are smuggled into the country, do not have enough impact on traffickers,’’ he said.  Amaraweera said that the Pesticides Control Act should be amended and steps should be taken to include new clauses, so that smugglers of substandard herbicides and pesticides, illegally imported into Sri Lanka, will have to pay a compensation of at least Rs 1.5 million and a prison sentence of three years or both.  He added that it was also decided to allow the release of pesticides and herbicides in the market in 20 gram packets as the farmers cannot afford the increase in their prices.  Amaraweera further instructed the Registrar General of Pesticides to revoke the licences of the sales agents, who are selling pesticides and herbicides illegally imported into Sri Lanka. It was also decided to deploy several teams of officers from the Consumer Protection Authority as well as the Pesticides Registrar’s Office to conduct emergency raids. (FT)

title: Karapitiya Hospital CT scanners not functioning
author: Author not found
Content: Both CT scan machines, at Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, are non-functional, forcing the hospital authorities to send those who are seeking scans to the Hambantota Hospital. Emergency cases are being looked after at State expense via the private sector, Ceylon Today learns. As a result, due to this development, patients from low income groups, who seek treatment, have been severely inconvenienced. Those from poor families have been forced to seek help from private hospices at exorbitant costs, a spokesperson of the hospital said. He added that one of the CT scan machines had become defunct last year, while the only one that had been functioning started to malfunction from last month. BY Damsari  Liyanage – Balapitiya

author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader Udaya Gammanpila, who yesterday (10) queried how the controversial Central Bank (Amendment) Bill contained serious errors, said the draft Bill is just like a letter written by a small child. The Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) or the Ministry of Finance should inform the public about who created this draft Bill and how much they paid for it.” He said 80 amendments have been proposed to the Bill by the Supreme Court, in its 54-page determination to prevent the Bill from violating the Constitution. The Supreme Court has ruled that in order to pass Articles 19(2), 19(5), 19(6), 26, 28, and 111(2) of the Bill, the people must approve it in a referendum in addition to the majority power of two-thirds of Parliament,” Gammanpila pointed out. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Five top rankers among 26 SJB MPs ready to Join Govt– Gunathilake
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) Kandy District MP and Chairman of the Kandy District Development Committee Gunathilake Rajapaksha said 26 MPs from the SJB, including five of its top rankers would join the Government soon. Addressing a press conference held in Kandy yesterday (10), the MP stated that the SJB MPs, who consented to support the current Government, have already held a few rounds of decisive talks with the President in this connection. Rajapaksha added that before long, a sizeable chunk of lawmakers from the SJB would join forces with the President to strengthen his hands and support his bid to put the country back on track. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Pulmoddai residents claim monk involved in land grab
author: Author not found
Content: Pulmoddai residents claim that several of their lands have been taken over by the Department of Archaeology, claiming that they are historical sites. They say several paddy lands and private lands have been taken over, causing tension in many areas. In the last ten days, there has been unrest in many villages as a result of certain officials, backed by a monk in the area, attempting to demarcate land as belonging to his temple, they alleged. The people of the area have invited MP M. A. Sumanthiran and MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam, of the Illankai Tamil Arasu Katchi (ITAK), to express their dissatisfaction with the land grab that is taking place in the Eastern Province, particularly in the Pulmoddai area, which was once a peaceful place with a Muslim majority.   During last week’s dispute, a monk charged at the village people in an attempt to take the land in that area and a verbal argument between the two communities was highlighted on social media. The residents alleged the monk had joined several Buddhist clergy and had been attempting to illegally claim land and incite local tension. The Archaeology Department allegedly delegated their powers to the monks, who are also protected by the Ministerial Security Division, Sumanthiran said. In the Kuchchaweli Pradeshiya Sabha area, land grabbing is taking place and it is also alleged that the monk has attempted to change the laws to own the land. Several complaints have already been filed and a legal battle is currently ongoing. According to Sumanthiran, a significant number of people’s land have been taken over or attempted to be taken over. They have permits and deeds, but the authorities ignore them, he told the crowd gathered there.  The people claimed that the Department of Archaeology strongly supported the monk and granted him authority over land grab. Sumanthiran and Rasamanickam, who visited the area yesterday (10), were told by the community that they had never had a dispute with another community before and that this land grab in their area was ‘new’ to them. The two Tamil MPs stated that they will bring this issue to the attention of the people of the country as well as the international community and have also informed President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who confirmed that he would look into the matter after the April New Year. Rasamanickam asserted that in the last two weeks, this Buddhist priest has been frightening the people of Pulmoddai and frequently confronting the peaceful people. He said such land disputes and land grabs are occurring in the North and urged all Tamil-speaking people to come together to fight this serious issue and not to be victimised.     He claimed that long before he became a politician, the same monk had come in a Defender and attempted to grab land in a place called Vethuchenai and the people in the area chased him away. He also alleged that Muhudu Maha Viharaya and Pullmoddai areas are experiencing land grabs, which is occurring at a time when the Government is serious about reconciliation and attempting to find a national solution. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Passengers lose valuables at BIA due to their own negligence– Chandrasiri
author: Author not found
Content: The main reason for passengers losing money and valuable items at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) is their own negligence, Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) (Pvt) Ltd Chairman Major General (retd) G.A. Chandrasiri claimed yesterday (10).  He said there was no way passengers could lose valuable items in the airport premises if not for their negligence and their failure to follow the given security instructions. Addressing a media briefing to respond to recent reports that a mobile phone of a passenger had been stolen at the airport on 5 April, Chandrasiri said when analysing the complaints, with regard to losing of items, money and baggage at the airport, it has been observed that the main reason for such incidents is negligence of the passengers. He alleged that there is an organised attempt to tarnish the service given by the airport officials by spreading false news on both main stream and social media. Chandrasiri, who refuted the reports about the loss of the mobile phone said they launched a probe into the alleged incident. He said that BIA officials had even inspected the entire CCTV Camera Footages installed at the BIA but they had so far failed to unearth details regarding the incident. Chandrasiri added that he had been informed in writing that the mobile phone of the Sri Lankan passenger had reportedly been seized by the security officers of a Middle Eastern country where the passenger had been in transit while en route to Colombo. He noted that reports to this effect being published in the local media and on various social media platforms sans verification, have tarnished the image of both the national carrier and the country in general and he advised the media to verify their stories ahead of publication. He said legal actions would be taken against all those who were spreading false news on the incident.  “There are many instances that airport employees found lost items and handed them over to the passengers. However, no one speaks about that. There has been no complaint in the last five years against an airport employee over stealing passengers’ items. If anyone wants more information on items handed over to the passengers, it can be obtained from the airport security and airport Police,” he said. (MD)

title: Health Professionals question replacement of anaesthetic drug
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Ministry’s distributing an anaesthetic drug, allegedly imported from Myanmar, to replace an anaesthetic drug, which allegedly led to death of a pregnant woman, who was admitted to Teaching Hospital Peradeniya for a caesarean section on 2 April, is highly suspicious, the Association of Health Professionals (AHP) said yesterday. Sources at the Teaching Hospital Peradeniya, when contacted said the patient had developed complications following the caesarean section and had been in the Hospital’s intensive care unit (ICU) for three days, where she had died. They said an investigation was being conducted into the unfortunate incident. Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella said that immediate measures had been taken to withdraw the batch of the anaesthetic drug. A probe is also being conducted into the death as there may be various reasons for it, so it is too early to issue further comment, he noted. AHP President Ravi Kumudesh yesterday (10) alleged that the said anaesthetic had first been registered with the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) while registration had been subsequently revoked. However, the drug had been deployed in three batches to 25 hospitals, while hospitals like the Teaching Hospital Ragama had received the same batch as the Peradeniya Teaching Hospital.  He said the Health Ministry had withdrawn all batches of the said anaesthetic while a drug manufactured by Bangladesh, registered by Myanmar’s equivalent to the NMRA, had allegedly replaced the said anaesthetic. Kumudesh urged the Health Ministry not to merely blame the death of the pregnant woman on the particular anaesthetic drug and be satisfied but to also probe as to how the one drug had been replaced by another immediately. If Myanmar donated the medicines, as some of the health officials would like the public to believe, then it is worthwhile knowing how Myanmar’s health service, which is also suffering like Sri Lanka, was able to do so, he claimed. The AHP President said that the particular Bangladesh Manufactured drug, sent by Myanmar, was not registered with the local NMRA, nor has it been used in Sri Lanka before. So how will the Health Ministry and the NMRA reassure patients about its safety, he queried. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: President to hold discussions on 2025 Development Plan
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe expressed his intention to meet all Ministry Secretaries, Chairpersons of Authorities and Commissions, as well as Heads of Departments, in order to obtain their contribution to realise the targeted 2025 development plan. The President made this remark during a discussion held at the Nuwara Eliya District Secretariat yesterday morning (10). During the discussion, the President directed officials to develop a formal plan aimed at maximising the contribution of the Nuwara Eliya District, a major tourist city, to the Sri Lankan Government’s programme to establish a stable economy within a four-year timeframe. The discussion also included the unveiling of the Nuwara Eliya New Town Development Plan and the Nuwara Eliya Tourism Plan. President Wickremesinghe said that despite the belief of many that the country’s economy could not be rebuilt, the agreement reached by the Government with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), provides an opportunity for fresh hope on the country’s economy. The President emphasised the importance of developing the Nuwara Eliya District as a striking city that can attract tourists throughout the year, targeting both local and foreign. He stressed the importance of preparing the development plans while considering the needs of tourists. He explained that the plans should prioritise creating a pleasant environment for tourists to relax, rather than focusing on constructing large buildings. He also pointed out that the absence of a formal system for rainwater drainage in Nuwara Eliya City is a long-standing issue and he urged officials to implement an urgent programme to address this problem. Additionally, he directed special attention to solving the problem of drinking water in the area. He further explained that buildings in the Nuwara Eliya City should be constructed according to a proper plan, rather than constructing buildings haphazardly. He emphasised that the city has suffered due to the construction of large buildings and that officials should consider whether to turn it into a bustling metropolis like New York or maintain its identity. The President highlighted the likelihood of an increase in tourist arrivals to Nuwara Eliya with the completion of the Central Expressway and stressed the importance of developing facilities according to a proper plan. He also emphasised that no party or invester should be allowed to damage the resources of the Nuwara Eliya District and that all development should be environmentally-friendly and well-planned. Furthermore, Wickremesinghe called for government officials and political authorities to work in a well-coordinated manner in these matters. He encouraged everyone to think beyond the traditional framework and align themselves with the new programme needed by the country. There was a detailed conversation regarding the development activities to be carried out in the city under the Nuwara Eliya City Development Plan, as well as the development of Nanu Oya as a sub-city. Plans were also made to develop Nuwara Eliya as a green city, by preserving forest conservation area and five suburbs were earmarked for development with Nuwara Eliya as the central hub. Additionally, the establishment of a university in Nuwara Eliya and the construction of a Ramayana Centre were also discussed during the meeting. The President issued instructions to modernise the Nanu-Oya Railway Station and establish a high-quality economic centre nearby. The aim is to enable farmers to pack their vegetables and transport them safely and conveniently to Colombo. The development of the racecourse and the lake, improvement of parking facilities and speedy implementation of a formal water management programme in Nuwara Eliya were given special attention during the discussions. In addition, a programme to increase the income of local residents and improve their lives was discussed at length. The discussion was attended by Minister Jeevan Thondaman, Nuwara Eliya District MPs S. B. Dissanayake, C.B. Ratnayake, V.S. Radhakrishnan and M. Rameswaran, President’s Secretary Saman  Ekanayake, NuwaraEliya District Secretary Nandana Galabada, and other State  officials.

title: FAO delivers 3,820 MT of EU-funded urea fertiliser
author: Author not found
Content: Through funding from the European Union (EU), a shipment of 3,820 tonnes of urea fertiliser, procured by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), was handed over to the Ministry of Agriculture today, for distribution among smallholder paddy farmers and paddy seed farmers in Sri Lanka. This new shipment of urea fertiliser will be dispatched to over 72,200 smallholder paddy farmers who were severely impacted by the recent economic crisis in the Polonnaruwa, Badulla, Ampara, Matale, Puttalam, Kurunegala and Hambantota Districts and is integral to a four million Euro (approximately Rs1.5 billion) programme launched by FAO and the EU to address the agriculture and food security crisis in Sri Lanka, while supporting the introduction of integrated plant nutrient management strategy amongst identified paddy growers. Speaking on the support the EU has extended to revitalise Sri Lanka’s paddy cultivation sector, European Union Ambassador Denis Chaibi said, “The distribution of urea fertilisers for vulnerable farmers is one of many actions we undertook to respond to the socio-economic crisis affecting millions of people in Sri Lanka. We hope that with this new support we can prevent immediate food shortages but also contribute towards a transition to a more sustainable and resilient agriculture sector in the future.” Through this programme, every eligible farmer cultivating up to 0.5 Ha of land in the targeted districts will receive 50kg of urea fertiliser for the upcoming cultivating season. Additionally, the programme will also provide high-quality paddy seeds and the necessary technology/capacity building to boost the efficient use of fertilizer. Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said, “This initiative by EU and FAO goes beyond providing material inputs and addresses the country’s long-term need to ensure sustainability of the local agriculture sector. I am appreciative of this support extended to our farmers as this will go a long way in helping Sri Lanka become a food secure nation.” “This consignment of essential urea fertilizer will be the first component of the multi-faceted support FAO will provide through valuable funding from the EU, to boost Sri Lanka’s paddy production and revitalize the local agriculture sector. We will work closely with the Ministry of Agriculture and Ministry of Irrigation to ensure its success while helping the country’s agriculture sector improves its sustainability through capacity building and training of extension officials and farmers,” FAO Representative in Sri Lanka, Vimlendra Sharan said.  Crop failures during recent harvesting seasons due to shortages of fertiliser and vital inputs, have posed many challenges for smallholder paddy farmers to sustain their livelihoods. This programme seeks to encourage smallholder farmers through material and technical inputs to adopt scientific farming practices to enhance fertiliser use efficiency and strengthen the seed paddy production system in Sri Lanka to meet the current demand. The programme also aims to strengthen government seed farms by providing them with modern, state-of-the-art seed processing and drying machines.
