title: Plant a Tree for the New Year -CEA
author: Author not found
Content: The Central Environmental Authority (CEA) requested the public to plant a sapling, in conjunction with the auspicious start of the New Year on 14 April 2023 and join the effort of protecting the environment in line with the programme, ‘A Custom for the New Year – A Sapling for the Environment’. Jointly organised by the Ministry of Environment and the Central Environmental Authority, the programme will be rolled out, starting on 14 April up to 20 April. Anyone can join the programme by planting a sapling within that week. CEA requested to plant a medicinal plant, a plant with timber value, a fruit plant or a plant that fulfils the food requirement. Participants can enroll and register with this programme by sending a photograph taken at the time of planting, along with the name, age, address, district, Grama Niladhari Division, telephone number, name of the sapling planted, height of the sapling at the time of planting to the e-mail address [email protected]. Further, following three months after planting, a photo of the growth and maintenance of the planted sapling could be sent to the relevant email address fulfilling a performance milestone in the evaluation process and those who complete that, will be awarded an electronic certificate in recognition of their environmental contribution. Further, CEA stated a survey will be conducted after one year and a panel of judges will select the best plants in each district and award prizes and certificates to those who have planted and maintained the plants properly. Arrangements have also been made to hold the ceremonial launch of this programme under the patronage of the Minister of Environment Naseer Ahamed with the participation of the Secretary of the Ministry of Environment, Dr. Anil Jasinghe, the Chairman of CEA, Supun S. Pathirage, and CEA Director General P. B. Hemantha Jayasinghe and other officers on the New Year’s Day, at the premises of the CEA.

title: 13 Chinese nationals who were trafficked to Sri Lanka rescued
author: Author not found
Content: Recent cases of Chinese nationals who have been trafficked overseas with the promise of high salaries, but ended up trapped in illegal activities, including telecom scams and online gambling are a warning for Chinese nationals to keep a wary eye on recruitment traps overseas, the Chinese Embassy in Sri Lanka said, in a notice over the weekend, China’s Global Times reported yesterday. The criminal gang posted the so-called recruitment advertisements on Chinese social media offering highly paid overseas jobs and promising to reimburse all travel expenses to lure potential job-hunters into traps. According to a report in Ceylon Today last week, Aluthgama Police detained about 39 Chinese nationals, in connection with online financial fraud and in April 2021, Police detained five Chinese nationals in connection with running an illicit gambling site, that was located on Lauries Road in the jurisdiction of Bambalapitiya Police. Over these nefarious activities, the Chinese Embassy noted that they had rescued 13 Chinese nationals who were trafficked to Sri Lanka, cut off from contacts with their families and the outside world and forced to engage in illegal activities such as telecom scams and internet gambling, the Embassy said in its media release. The victims were subject to threats against their lives and suffered physical abuses from corporal punishment and torture when they failed to accomplish their tasks or when they attempted to escape, the Embassy said. According to the Criminal Law of the People’s Republic of China, victims involved in overseas telecom scams will most probably face punishment even if they were coerced into committing the crime, Zhao Guohua, lawyer and co-founder of Beijing Mingji Law Firm, told the Global Times on Sunday, noting that the criminals use job opportunities as bait to lure some young Chinese people who are under great employment pressure. The Chinese Embassy in Sri Lanka quickly coordinated with local Police to carry out rescue operations, upon learning of the situation, captured key members of the telecom fraud gang and the suspects involved in illegally harming and detaining the victims and successfully rescued the 13 Chinese nationals who were trapped by the scheme after they believed the so-called high salary, low threshold, short working hours, and enjoyable travelling welfare and other overseas job recruitment information. A similar rescue operation was conducted by the Chinese Embassy in Myanmar on Thursday with a Chinese national, smuggled into Myanmar and forced to engage in telecom fraud, rescued. In recent years, online gambling and telecom fraud have caused social problems in Southeast Asian countries such as Myanmar, Thailand and Sri Lanka, with some Chinese nationals falling victims to murder, kidnapping and human trafficking. Some people are lured overseas by the promise of high salaries. A major human trafficking case was disclosed on Friday by the general border inspection station for entry and exit of South China’s Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region under the National Immigration Administration. Police announced the dismantling of a large-scale trafficking gang that organised Chinese nationals to leave the country illegally by sea to engage in transnational criminal activities.  A total of 108 suspects from the gang were apprehended including 69 punished with prison sentences, ranging from nine months to eight years and fines between 5,000 yuan and 200,000 yuan (USD 29,093). One gang member said that it would promise a monthly salary of between 8,000 yuan and 16,000 yuan, even up to 20,000 yuan. Border police have reminded the public to stay vigilant and make sure to go overseas for work through a regular and legal labour agency. They should not believe recruitment ads that promise high salaries and benefits, which can not only endanger personal safety but also lead to crimes.                                               (SRM)

title: New members of the Audit Service Commission take oaths
author: Author not found
Content: The newly-appointed members of the Audit Service Commission were sworn in on 9 April before Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana. Auditor General W.P.C. Wickramaratne was appointed as the ex-officio Chairman Of the commission. Furthermore, Retired Justice Nihal Sunil Rajapaksa, Nandaseeli Godakanda, Gnananantharajah Thevagnanan and  A. M. Dharmajith Nayanakantha also took oath as members to the Commission.

title: Anti-Govt elements unable to bear progress being made – Kanaka
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Technology Kanaka Herath said nobody can destabilise the country under the guise of democracy and human rights. It is the Government’s responsibility to take legal action against any enterprise that impedes the people and the country’s future, he added. Herath emphasised that great progress has been made in many areas of the country, compared to last year, but he also asserts that some anti-Government elements have been unable to bear this shift. He made these remarks at the Rambukkana Divisional Secretariat, on the occasion of the rice distribution to low-income individuals and while participating in the inauguration of the Agri Fresh-Sabaragamuwa shopping mall, which was constructed at the Wagolla District Agricultural Training Complex in Pinnawala. Nearly 11,150 low-income families in the Rambukkana Divisional Secretariat   were given 10 kg of rice each. “There has been a discussion about the Anti-Terrorism Act, which is an Act brought for the security of the country and the people. If anyone opposes it, it is a group that advocates terrorism and not a group that loves the country and the people,” he said. Currently, the cost of living is significantly lower than it was a year ago. The price of petroleum and gas has decreased and the Government has provided a number of concessions for the people during the holiday season, but it is uncertain whether the people will receive the benefits. Today, society points the finger at politicians for any challenge, he stressed. “We must realise that if Government officials do not execute their responsibilities adequately, the populace will despise politicians. Even though society demonstrates a need for a change in the attitude of politicians and citizens, State officials’ attitudes should be transformed. The inability of Government officials to provide the required support to the Minister of the relevant ministry is a significant barrier to meeting the demands of the people,” he said. Speaking further, Herath emphasised that unnecessary pressure is caused by officials failing to take the appropriate action at the right moment, and added that they should strive to fulfil the requirements of the people rather than the agendas of destabilising conspirators.

title: Two nabbed with heroin
author: Author not found
Content: A 46-year-old man was arrested by the Mulleriyawa Police for having six grams of heroin in his possession. Police said the suspect is a resident of Mulleriyawa. Meanwhile, another suspect who had six grams of heroin in his possession was arrested by the Mount Lavinia Police. He is a 32-year-old resident of Ratmalana. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Arrested over killing wife
author: Author not found
Content: Aranayake Police arrested a man yesterday (10) for killing his wife over a family dispute. Police said the victim was 23-year-old Deshani Ranasinghe, a mother of a three-year-old child and a resident of Lambukatuwa, Millangoda. The Police discovered her body in the kitchen of the house where the couple was living. The body was taken to the hospital for the post-mortem. A wooden pole, that Police suspect was the murder weapon, was found near the body. The suspect was arrested after he surrendered to Police. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Blood Donation Campaign at Eastern Naval Command
author: Author not found
Content: As part of its social responsibility initiatives, the Navy organised a blood donation campaign at the Command Naval Hospital (East) on 8 April 2023.  On the directives of Commander of the Navy Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, the magnanimous campaign was organised by the Naval establishment SLNS Tissa. The proceedings of the event were supervised by Commander Eastern Naval Area and Commandant Volunteer Naval Force Rear Admiral Dammika Kumara. The blood collected during the drive was handed over to help meet the critical need for blood in Blood Transfusion Centres in Trincomalee and Vavuniya Government Hospitals.   The event saw a total of 350 Naval personnel from ships and establishments in the Eastern Naval Command volunteering to donate blood.

title: Army Deminers in full swing to complete demining in North
author: Author not found
Content: The Army, as defenders of the nation, perform various roles in line with global needs, trends and developments to accomplish diverse assignments in different contexts. During the last phase of the humanitarian operation, the mines remained scattered haphazardly all over the whole area posing serious threat to human habitation. In 2002, Sri Lankan Government initiated the National Mine Action Programme aiming to create a mine and explosive devices-free environment. Aimed at establishing a mechanism for effective clearance of mines in Sri Lanka, the first course on Humanitarian De-mining began in 2003 at Embilipitiya Engineers’ School. In 2007, the Sri Lanka Army’s Humanitarian Landmine Clearance Unit took the responsibility for complete clearance of landmines. Significantly, the women’s cadre of the Sri Lanka Army recently began their contribution towards the de-mining process. Under the direction of the Commander of the Army, the Chief Field Engineer and the Corps of Engineers undertook the challenge of training women de-miners. Presently, the Sri Lanka Army has 435 de-miners, of whom 283 are performing duties on site. Sri Lanka Army Humanitarian Demining Unit has so far cleared 458,635 sqm and ensured mine-free environment for human habitation. A total of 794,801 sqm is yet to be cleared. Moreover, other organisations such as DASH, HALO Trust, MAG, SHARP, NMAC, DDG, DMAO, GMAA Team Leader, HDU/MAG, HDU/NPA, Horizon, JCCP, MAG/TRO, Minetech, MMIPE, RONCO, SARVATRA, FSD and UNOPS have cleared 425.57km covering the Ampara, Anuradhapura, Batticaloa, Jaffna, Kilinochchi, Mannar, Mullaitivu, Polonnaruwa, Puttalam, Trincomalee and Vavuniya Districts. A total number of 109,846 anti-personnel mines, 221 anti-tank mines, 207,869 small arms ammunition and 43,242 unexploded ordnances have been recovered by the Army demining teams as of 3 March 2023.  With the contribution of several other organisations, led by the Sri Lanka Army Humanitarian Demining Unit, it was made possible to bring the vulnerable area to a minimum.  Once the remaining area is also cleared, basic requirements for human habitation such as public health, education, water and sanitation could be restored and human habitation facilitated.

title: Kaushalya and Kanchana Win awards at FOSWAL Literary Festival
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lankan writers Kaushalya Kumarasinghe and Kanchana Priyakantha were awarded the FOSWAL Literary Award and the SAARC Literary Award, at the 63rd FOSWAL Literary Festival, by the Foundation of SAARC Writers and the Literary Foundation of India. The FOSWAL Literary Conference was held on 26, 27, and 28 March at the Academy of Fine Arts and Literature in New Delhi, India. The Chief Guest was Nasser Munji, Chairman of the Aga Khan Foundation. The other Guests of Honour were Ramendu  Majumdar of Bangladesh, Dr. Kunsang Choden of Bhutan, Bhishma Upreti of Nepal and Kanchana Priyakantha, Suresh K. Goel, Deepak Vora and Dr. G.N. Dewey participated in the event. In addition to India and Sri Lanka, writers from Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, and Cambodia attended this festival. Kanchana Priyakantha, Kaushalya Kumarasinghe, Rashmika Mandawala, Pakyanathan Ahilan, Aruni Kalupahana, Arul Neson, Nethmi Yashoda, and Nishantha Fernando represented Sri Lanka at this conference.

title: Rat fever on the rise in Galle District
author: Author not found
Content: Galle District Regional Epidemiologist Eranda Hettiarachchi said there is a risk of rat fever spreading in the Galle District. So far 15 deaths have been reported from rat fever in the last three-and-a half months of this year. He was speaking during a programme in Galle to educate drug store owners and pharmacists in the District. He also said 127 cases of rat fever had been reported from January up to now. “Fifteen deaths have occurred during this period and among those deaths is a 13-year-old schoolgirl. Currently, the divisions of Karandeniya, Baddegama, Imaduwa, Balapitiya, Udugama, and Yakkalamulla have the highest number of patients in the district. Previously, this disease was usually contracted by those who worked in fields on a daily basis, but now that people are aware, they are getting treatment before going to work in the fields. There are also those who cultivate in mud and water-related areas,” he said. Further, he said it is advised not to get into muddy waters if you have open wounds on the feet. “Do not enter muddy water. A bacterium found in rat urine causes rat fever. If this bacterium does not enter a person’s body, it can survive for up to twenty days outside. This bacterium can also be found in landfills. As a result, if you experience symptoms such as fever, body ache, or headache after working in fields, muddy land, or cleaning garbage heaps, consult a doctor right away,” he advised. In addition, he said while rat urine transmits the disease in Sri Lanka, it has been found that it could be transmitted to buffaloes and dogs. If left untreated the animals will die. BY Farhan Nizamdin (Galle) and S. Diyagahage (Ahangama)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: UL 225 returns with cracked windshield
author: Author not found
Content: Passengers travelling on a Dubai-bound SriLankan flight, which was forced to return to Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) due to a technical issue, were transferred to another Dubai flight, airport authorities said. UL 225, carrying 189 passengers and 15 crew members, was scheduled to depart BIA at 6:25 p.m. on 7 April. However, the flight was delayed by 15 hours and departed only at 9:30 a.m. on 8 April. The Airbus A330-200, registration 4R-ALH, was forced to return to BIA at 10:40 a.m., around 1 hour and 10 minutes later. The aircraft was cruising at 38,000 feet, nearing Indian airspace, when the Captain noticed cracks in the windshield and decided to carry out an emergency landing.  After landing safely in Colombo, the passengers were transferred to another Dubai-bound SriLankan flight, which departed at 7:40 p.m. on the same day. By Adnan Ali Cassim and T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: 25 killed in road accidents within five days – Police
author: Author not found
Content: At least 25 people were killed in 265 vehicle accidents reported in the last five days, Police said. Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said 25 deaths were reported in the last five days. “We urge parents of young drivers to be more vigilant about their children’s movements,” he said. He added the accident spree began on 4 April, and that on average, five deaths were reported per day. He also urged parents to be more vigilant about those over 18. “Parents must be extra vigilant about their children who attend various events because the Police cannot check every vehicle on the road,” he added.

title: People will soon want SLPP back in power – SLPP Gen Secy
author: Author not found
Content: The day people will start seeking for the SLPP as a political party will dawn in the near future as the political scale in favour of Mahinda Rajapaksa is incomparable to any other post-independence political leader of this country, General Secretary of Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Sagara Kariyawasam said. He was speaking at a party conference in Kolonnawa and said that people will take to the streets to express their desire for a national economy based on nationalism. “When all the leaders who emerged in Sri Lanka post- Independence are placed on one side of a scale, and former President Mahinda Rajapaksa is placed on the other, the latter’s side is heavier. So, this is not a Party that can be brought down by torching houses, attacking, or threatening people,” he said. MP Kariyawasam also said during the SLPP’s tenure, no money was taken on loan and all existing debts were paid. “We, the SLPP, want to build the country without taking loans that your child will have to pay back later. Regardless of the economic difficulties, our tenure was the time when no loans were taken, but debts were settled. We can see how the leaders of the ‘Aragalaya’ protest movement are currently partying. Did the people of this country band up together for such a future?” he queried. Speaking further, he said his thinking was that the people will once again want the SLPP back in power to rule the country in the very near future, Kariyawasam said.

title: Significant Tax Cuts Led to Economic Crisis – IMF Senior Mission Chief
author: Author not found
Content: While noting that significant tax cuts and delays in anticipated reforms contributed to Sri Lanka’s economic crisis, IMF Senior Mission Chief for Sri Lanka, Peter Breuer, emphasised the need for everyone to come together to tackle the enormous economic challenge the country is facing, to support the recovery and promote stable and inclusive growth. Taking to the IMF YouTube Channel, to detail supporting recovery and promoting stable and inclusive growth in Sri Lanka, Peter Breuer states that after years of increasing economic problems and policy mistakes, Sri Lanka has committed to report and rebuild. The IMF representative emphasised that the authorities have committed to improving public financial management and strengthening the anti-corruption legal framework. He also said that in addition, the IMF will assess governance and corruption vulnerabilities and provide recommendations. “We, at the IMF look forward to working closely with the people of Sri Lanka for a brighter future for all. The IMF is here to help. The fund has approved about USD 3 billion over the next four years to support Sri Lanka in this time of need,” he said. He said since 2019, significant tax cuts and delays in anticipated reforms have left the country entering the pandemic with thin currency reserves, high debt levels and no fiscal space to buffer against shocks.  “With no reserves left, power cuts, shortages of food and medicines, and long lines for petrol emerged. Sri Lanka defaulted on its debt for the first time in its history. There are no easy solutions, but that’s where everyone must come together to tackle this enormous problem,” Breuer said. He also pointed out that Sri Lankans must make efforts to continue their way out of the crisis while supporting the less fortunate, highlighting that the global community must support Sri Lanka in this effort, so that it can once again be on a path of strong and inclusive growth. “There are no easy solutions, but that’s where everyone must come together to tackle this enormous problem,” the top IMF officials said. Working with the Fund, the Sri Lankan authorities have put together an ambitious economic recovery programme, including reforms to raise government revenue, stabilise prices, build up foreign reserves and safeguard financial stability, he explained, adding that the Sri Lankan authorities are also asking their creditors to support their efforts by granting debt relief. “When a crisis strikes, the poor are hit the hardest. The programme aims to raise spending for the poor and vulnerable, strengthen social safety nets and introduce progressive tax reforms to ensure greater contributions come from high-income earners,” he said. In addition, Breuer has also highlighted that with breathing room from external debt relief, the IMF expects Sri Lanka’s economy to gradually start to recover and expand.  “It’s critical to ensure the hard-won gains from the reforms benefit the Sri Lankan people, and the crisis will not repeat itself” he said.

title: President pledges justice for Easter Sunday victims
author: Author not found
Content: While pledging his unwavering commitment to ensuring the security of the country, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said that legal proceedings related to the tragic incidents on Easter Sunday are being processed independently and impartially, without any influence. He, in his Easter Sunday message, said the necessary groundwork towards this end has been laid, to ensure justice for all the victims. “I pledge my unwavering commitment to ensuring the security of our country, by preventing any recurrence of such heinous acts,” he said. The President said that the Government is dedicated to realising the aspirations of all Sri Lankans, regardless of race, religion, party or colour. “Easter Sunday celebrates the ability of Lord Jesus Christ, as the Son of God, to transform lives by dispelling darkness in people’s minds and bringing hope to the world. With Easter commemorating the resurrection of Jesus, it is an occasion for us to reflect on the values of love, peace, and forgiveness as espoused by Him, which are at the core of Sri Lankan culture, and we must come together with family, friends and communities, to solemnise the blessings life has to offer. “We are presently seeking to overcome an era of unprecedented hardship, uncertainty and disappointment and are looking forward to a better tomorrow. The Government is dedicated to realising the aspirations of all Sri Lankans regardless of race, religion, party or colour. I strongly believe that we can overcome these challenges in the near future,” he added. “However, it is crucial that we all unite on a common agenda that elevates us beyond narrow political objectives and regressive trends and instead paving the way for the country toward progress. Let us all unite and work for a brighter future for Sri Lanka,” he said. “I am very much aware of the extreme pain caused by the Easter Sunday attack being still fresh in your minds and I share that pain. I wish to reassure you that the legal proceedings related to this tragic incident are being processed independently and impartially, without any influence. The necessary groundwork towards this end has been laid, to ensure justice for all the victims. I pledge my unwavering commitment to ensuring the security of our country, by preventing any recurrence of such heinous acts. As we continue to face these challenges, let us draw strength from the spirit of Easter, and its message of hope and renewal,” President Wickremesinghe said.

title: SJB will neverjoin President or Govt–Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said his Party Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) will, by no means, join hands with incumbent President or his Government which is operating in undemocratic manner enacting draconian laws. Premadasa also threatened his party members with disciplinary action if they are involved in any of the on-going wheeler-dealings.  He also accused a section of the media of conducting an on-going ‘malicious’ campaign to depict that SJB is mulling measures to support the President. “A conspiracy is on to divide and destroy the SJB. There have been no discussions within the party to support President Ranil Wickremesinghe. We don’t want to associate with their relatives’ party and their relatives media,” he said. Party members who try to divide and destroy the Samagi Jana Balawegaya will be brought before a disciplinary committee, he said. “There should be discipline within the SJB which is the sole alternative to the present government,” Premadasa said in a special statement.

title: Did 248 Sri Lankan asylum seekers perish on their way to New Zealand?
author: Author not found
Content: A Government log of attempts by asylum seekers to reach New Zealand shows a fishing trawler and its 248 Sri Lankan passengers will never be seen again. Immigration Minister Michael Wood has refused to be drawn on what information the Government has about attempts to reach New Zealand shores by boat. On 29 March, the day he introduced legislation extending the time people in mass arrivals can be held in detention, from four to potentially 28 days, his office also released a list of attempts to reach New Zealand and Australia. On 12 January 2019, “a 90 foot-long fishing trawler-turned-sailboat left Maliankara near Munambam, India, with 248 Tamil migrants onboard hoping to make it to Australia or NZ. The boat or the passengers have not been heard of since”. Its fate was never known – an RNZ story detailed its departure and concerns for the safety of its crew and passengers 10 days later. Police in India said an individual arrested in connection with the investigation, Prabhu Dhandapani, told them the boat was heading to New Zealand. Wood revealed that officials started looking at changes to the mass arrivals legislation later that same year, but work was delayed by Covid. The legislation changing detention time limits was about ensuring a large number of migrants or asylum seekers would be able to access full legal advice, he said. “I don’t think this is about being a deterrent [to people-smugglers and passengers] at all. “We have other activities that take place, we invest significantly in work with other countries to go to source and discourage people-smuggling, which is enormously dangerous and takes advantage of humans who are in some of the most desperate circumstances. So that’s the deterrence.” When asked about what intelligence the government had on smuggling, he instead referenced attempts already in the public domain. “On open source there is good information out there about the number of recent, reports of vessels emanating out of south and southeast Asia. And we have been pretty clear and on record, that there is good intelligence that New Zealand is a potential destination. “It is not a likely event and our physical distance offers us some protection. But if it does transpire, it is a very high impact event. “We note that Canada, in recent years, from a similar distance, has had an arrival and 10 years after that arrival they are still effectively dealing with that situation.” The list of publicly available mass arrival attempts shows the 2019 Tamil journey from Kerela as an attempt to get to Australia or New Zealand and its outcome – “disappeared”. It also records an October 2021 event in which 63 men were arrested in Trincomalee, Sri Lanka, for “allegedly intending to join a maritime venture to New Zealand”. “Police said that these suspects had packed for a long sea journey, with required clothing and coats to be worn in cold weather and there was a large quantity of luggage,” according to a Sri Lankan daily. “The racketeers had charged each person sums ranging from Rs 2.5 million to Rs 4 million (up to $19,577) on the promise that they would be sent to New Zealand. The Police also said that these persons are being questioned to find out whether they had to pay money in advance.” The remainder of the incidents were attempts to get to Australia between 2019 and 2022. Not on the list was an incident in which Australian Border Force intercepted another Sri Lankan boat destined for New Zealand and allegedly paid crew more than USD 30,000 ($44,576.52) to turn the boat around in 2015. And in 2013, a boat with a New Zealand flag and passengers holding a sign saying: “We want to go to New Zealand. Please help us” was stopped 400km north of Perth in Western Australia. To date, no maritime mass arrival attempt has successfully reached New Zealand. Former Prime Minister John Key said in 2015 that a boat carrying 65 Sri Lankans and Bangladeshis had been en route here, and vessels were now capable of making the journey. People smuggling is punishable by up to 20 years imprisonment and a fine of up to 500,000 dollars in New Zealand. Immigration New Zealand details how people smugglers and facilitators often mislead migrants about the risks of being smuggled, the chance of success and economic conditions in destination countries. As well as the risk of death from drowning in overloaded boats, passengers sometimes suffer physical or psychological violence, can be trafficked for forced labour or sexual exploitation and can also die from dehydration or starvation. In 2019, 25 million dollars was allocated over four years on prevention measures, including the expansion of New Zealand’s network of Migration Liaison Officers offshore. On the missing 2019 boat attempt, a blog “To The Antipodes, On A Boat Without GPS” by The Times of India, after the boat carrying 248 people left India, said the passengers were Sri Lankan Tamil refugees housed in Madangir Colony in New Delhi. “The colony was a result of the India-Sri Lanka accord in the 1980s, and these refugees were largely living in abject conditions,” Police told author KP Saikiran. They avoided using GPS, fearing their movements would be tracked by security agencies, in a journey expected to take about 25 days. “The boat must have either sunk in rough seas, or it could have been captured by Sri Lankan authorities, which also would have been fatal to those on the boat,” he concluded. “In all probability, either way, they would have lost their lives,” said Police sources. “Blue Corner notices were sent to both Australia and New Zealand through Interpol for all the 248 passengers, but no favourable information has been received.” (NZ Herald)

title: Semasinghe to represent SL at WB-IMF Spring Meetings
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has assigned State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe to represent Sri Lanka in the Spring Meetings with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank, which is scheduled to be held from today (10 April) in Washington, D.C. The Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies, issuing a statement, said President Ranil Wickremesinghe had assigned State Minister Semasinghe with the IMF coordination and relevant responsibilities. Semasinghe tweeted that this will be a great opportunity for Sri Lanka to enhance cooperation with international partners to ensure debt sustainability and to further progress made towards economic recovery. Meanwhile, Central Bank Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe and Treasury Secretary Mahinda Siriwardana will also attend the meeting, the Ministry said.

title: Paperless Port Management System to ease customer hassle– Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Within the next 12 months, the Ministry of Ports and Shipping will solicit Expressions of Interest (EoI) for the Port Management System (PMS), which will eliminate the need for customers to visit over 22 departments for port clearance. The ADB and the World Bank assisted the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) in developing a paperless PMS similar to that used in the port of Rotterdam. “We are currently working on legislation to accommodate paperless work, and in the meantime, we request an EoI in two to three months for the fix of this PMS,” said Nimal Siripala de Silva, Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation.  He said the Customs Ordinance is over 100 years and that it has to be amended to suit the public and not the officials at Sri Lanka Customs. Currently, a major delay in clearance is taking place where customers are pushed from pillar to post in releasing their consignments, he added.  The PMS would implement completely paperless work, allowing a customer to clear his consignment while remaining in his office and not physically present at all departments within the port, including quarantine, tax payment, and customs clearance, according to the Minister.  He also said the PMS will put an end to corruption and shady operations within the Port. The PMS would not cost the Government anything because it would be outsourced to a specialised company.  The chosen company will run it with experienced personnel for a reasonable fee. “It should be in place within the next 12 months. “Currently, clearing goods takes more than three days,” the Minister added. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Significant Tax Cuts Led to Economic Crisis – IMF Senior Mission Chief
author: Author not found
Content: While noting that significant tax cuts and delays in anticipated reforms contributed to Sri Lanka’s economic crisis, IMF Senior Mission Chief for Sri Lanka, Peter Breuer, emphasised the need for everyone to come together to tackle the enormous economic challenge the country is facing, to support the recovery and promote stable and inclusive growth. Taking to the IMF YouTube Channel, to detail supporting recovery and promoting stable and inclusive growth in Sri Lanka, Peter Breuer states that after years of increasing economic problems and policy mistakes, Sri Lanka has committed to report and rebuild. The IMF representative emphasised that the authorities have committed to improving public financial management and strengthening the anti-corruption legal framework. He also said that in addition, the IMF will assess governance and corruption vulnerabilities and provide recommendations. “We, at the IMF look forward to working closely with the people of Sri Lanka for a brighter future for all. The IMF is here to help. The fund has approved about USD 3 billion over the next four years to support Sri Lanka in this time of need,” he said. He said since 2019, significant tax cuts and delays in anticipated reforms have left the country entering the pandemic with thin currency reserves, high debt levels and no fiscal space to buffer against shocks.  “With no reserves left, power cuts, shortages of food and medicines, and long lines for petrol emerged. Sri Lanka defaulted on its debt for the first time in its history. There are no easy solutions, but that’s where everyone must come together to tackle this enormous problem,” Breuer said. He also pointed out that Sri Lankans must make efforts to continue their way out of the crisis while supporting the less fortunate, highlighting that the global community must support Sri Lanka in this effort, so that it can once again be on a path of strong and inclusive growth. “There are no easy solutions, but that’s where everyone must come together to tackle this enormous problem,” the top IMF officials said. Working with the Fund, the Sri Lankan authorities have put together an ambitious economic recovery programme, including reforms to raise government revenue, stabilise prices, build up foreign reserves and safeguard financial stability, he explained, adding that the Sri Lankan authorities are also asking their creditors to support their efforts by granting debt relief. “When a crisis strikes, the poor are hit the hardest. The programme aims to raise spending for the poor and vulnerable, strengthen social safety nets and introduce progressive tax reforms to ensure greater contributions come from high-income earners,” he said. In addition, Breuer has also highlighted that with breathing room from external debt relief, the IMF expects Sri Lanka’s economy to gradually start to recover and expand.  “It’s critical to ensure the hard-won gains from the reforms benefit the Sri Lankan people, and the crisis will not repeat itself” he said.

title: Saudi Arabia ranks second globally in AI awareness – Stanford Report
author: Author not found
Content: Machines and software that have been trained to think and act like humans are referred to as artificial intelligence (AI) systems. The world of modern technology today is significantly impacted by AI. Saudi citizens have a high level of confidence in using artificial intelligence products and services in the Kingdom, according to a survey by the University of Stanford USA’s Artificial Intelligence Index Report, which was just released in its sixth edition (AIIR 2023) this month. Policymakers, academics, and business experts can use this report as a comprehensive resource to learn more about the state of artificial intelligence now and its potential in the future. According to the survey, the Kingdom came in second place behind China in the world for residents’ optimism and positivity toward artificial intelligence products and services offered in both the present and the future stages. Speaking at the 2019 G20 Summit in Osaka, Crown Prince and Prime Minister HRH Prince Mohammed bin Salman said: “We are in an era of scientific advancements, ground-breaking technology, and limitless growth potential. When properly applied, emerging technologies like artificial intelligence and the Internet of Things can prevent many negative effects and provide enormous benefits for everyone “. The prince’s speech that day not only demonstrated the Saudi Government’s interest in technology and the use of artificial intelligence, but it also paved the way for improved usage and execution of these concepts in the Kingdom at the present time. By Khalid Rizwan

title: SLINEX-23 wraps up on successful note
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka–India Naval Exercise (SLINEX) -23 came to a successful conclusion in the Colombo seas on 8 April 2023. Commenced on 3rd April, SLINEX -23 marked yet another milestone in maritime cooperation between the two neighbouring countries, a spokesman said and added SLINEX provides an opportunity for the Navies of the two countries to share their experiences and best practices in various aspects of naval operations and enhance their interoperability. SLINEX -23 was launched by the Offshore Patrol Vessel SLNS Samudura and SLNS Vijayabahu from the Sri Lanka Navy as well as a Dornier Maritime Surveillance Aircraft and a Bell 412 helicopter of the Sri Lanka Air Force. In addition, INS Kiltan, INS Savitri, a Dornier maritime surveillance aircraft and a Chetak helicopter of the Indian Navy joined the maritime exercise. Conducted in two phases, the harbour phase of the exercise was held from 3 to 5 April at the port of Colombo and the sea phase was conducted off Colombo from 6 to 8 April. The sea phase featured a wide range of activities, including Gunnery Exercises (GUNEX), Search and Rescue Exercises (SAREX), Screen Exercise (SCREENEX), Replenishment at Sea (RAS) Approaches, Abeam Fuelling Approaches, Visit Board Search and Seizure (VBSS) Exercises, Photo Exercises (PHOTOEX), Vertical Replenishment (VERTREP), Search and Rescue Exercises by Helo and Deck Landing Practice (DLP), the spokesman further said and added that on the sidelines of SLINEX, cultural exchange programmes, friendly sports events, Yoga exercises and sightseeing tours had been organised to promote camaraderie among naval personnel from both countries. Meanwhile, the Commanding Officers of the Indian naval ships visited the Indian Peace Keeping Force (IPKF) Monument in Battaramulla and made floral tributes. The Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka,  Gopal Baglay and State Minister of Defence,  Premitha Bandara Tennakoon visited the Indian naval ships in Colombo. In addition, personnel of the Sri Lanka Navy, family members, school children and members of the National Cadet Corps also had the opportunity to visit the ships.  As part of the harbour phase proceedings, Indian naval personnel visited Rapid Action Boat Squadron (RABS) Headquarters in Gangewadiya, Puttalam and participated in a training session on Humanitarian Assistance and Disaster Relief. Further, personnel of the Indian Navy, Special Boat Squadron (SBS) and Sri Lanka Air Force took part in a Joint Heli Rappelling training exercise at the Air Force base, Katunayake, the spokesman further added and said the success of SLINEX 23 reflects the close and friendly relations between Sri Lanka and India and their commitment to promoting regional peace and stability. It also underlines the importance of maritime cooperation in addressing common challenges and promoting shared interests in the Indian Ocean region, he said.

title: Need for political consensus on crucial economic reforms vital – LDM
author: Author not found
Content: The discussion organised by the Lanka Democratic Movement focused on the need for political consensus on crucial economic reforms in Sri Lanka. The speakers pointed out that without a common agreement on key reforms, Sri Lanka’s recovery and its ongoing programme with the IMF could be at risk. The speakers emphasised the importance of implementing these reforms adhering to a plan for a reasonable period of time. The Convener of the Lanka Democratic Movement, Rasika Jayakody, explained that Sri Lanka is not in a position to move away from the IMF bailout package as the country is in a disastrous situation as far as the economy is concerned. Therefore, Sri Lanka did not have the luxury of choosing when it had the opportunity to negotiate with the IMF on better terms. The country had to pursue the IMF option after becoming a bankrupt nation, and now, it has to swallow a better pill. Jayakody emphasised that it’s crucial to implement these reforms without failing, and policymakers must understand the gravity of the situation and move in one direction for at least five years. Economist Rohan Masakorale emphasised the importance of policy stability in Sri Lanka. Masakorale explained that the country brought its economy on the right track in 1977, and there was significant progress between 1977 and 1982. However, after that, the country lost its way, and the riots in July 1983 caused many global companies that were exploring their investment prospects in Sri Lanka to go to Thailand. Moreover, the war erupted, and Sri Lanka paid a heavy price. The biggest downfall in Sri Lanka was the failure of successive governments to ensure policy stability. Masakorale pointed out that the Janasaviya programme was a progressive attempt to alleviate poverty through sustainable means. However, the government that came to power in 1994 politicised it and created a programme that did not produce the desired results. Sri Lanka must understand the gravity of the crisis and take corrective steps with consensus. Today, India has privatised all its ports, and Sri Lanka made a mockery of the plans related to the East Container Terminal at Colombo Port. The country wasted three years debating various conspiracy theories, and now it’s paying a heavy price for that. Attorney-at-Law and Chairman of Citizens for Accountable Governance (CAG), Mangala Niyarepola, emphasised the absence of a master plan in Sri Lanka’s economy. He explained that political parties can include any fairy tale in their election manifestos as there is no mechanism to hold them accountable to their promises. Therefore, they end up doing ad-hoc projects without any rational basis, and they can manipulate the media and change public opinion closer to the election. That’s why Sri Lanka has ended up in this mess. Niyarepola said when there is no master plan, no rule of law, no mechanism to hold politicians accountable, and no transparency, no serious investor will come to the country. The majority of so-called investors coming to such a country could be driven by vested interests, which is a failure in the system that Sri Lanka must address. The country needs a grand master plan that has constitutional protection, an all-encompassing document prepared by experts and technocrats. Political parties should not be allowed to deviate from the master plan without a referendum, and an institutional framework must be set up to implement this master plan with the participation of the public. This is the only way Sri Lanka can drive the much-talked-about ‘system change’.

title: Woman strangledto death in Polpithigama
author: Author not found
Content: A woman was beaten and strangled to death in Aluthwegedara, Polpithigama, on 8 April. The deceased was a 59-year-old resident of Aluthwegedara, Polpithigama. The incident had occurred when the victim was at home with her husband. Her son-in-law had come to the house asking where his wife, the couple’s daughter, was. He then had got into an argument with his father-in-law. Investigation revealed that during the heated argument between the son-in-law and the father-in-law, the mother-in-law had intervened at which point, the son-in-law had beaten her and trampled her neck. The deceased and her husband, who were both injured in the incident were taken to the Polpithigama Hospital, however the victim succumbed to injuries. The body was then taken to the Polpithigama  morgue for the post-mortem examination. The suspect had fled the area and Polpithigama Police are conducting investigations to apprehend him. BY Amra Liyakath

title: North Port Development report to President on 21 April
author: Author not found
Content: The consultancy report for the North Port Development (NPD) Project at the Colombo Port, a USD 1 billion futuristic project on over 300 acres of land towards Mattakkuliya, has been compiled, and Minister of Ports and Shipping Nimal Siripala de Silva will present it to President Ranil Wickremesinghe and maritime stakeholders on 21 April. The Minister said in an interview with Ceylon Today that after reviewing the ADB report, they will request Expressions of Interest (EoI), but the Government will not focus on the project right away and it will take at least another five years to progress, as breakwater construction and dredging must be completed prior to calling for an EoI. The North Port will be able to accommodate six to seven port terminals depending on the demand, according to the Minister. The consultancy report, funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) that prepared the drawings and the maps for the project, will be submitted to the President as well as the maritime community, the Minister said. The North Port is a big-budget port development project located on the north side of the Colombo Port. “It is the Government’s ambitious project, involving major construction work. It must be built with private sector participation,” said the Minister in an interview with Ceylon Today. He said, it will be a USD 1 billion investment project and he is confident that international investors would express interest. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Body of Russian woman found in canal
author: Author not found
Content: Hikkaduwa Police said a body of a Russian woman was found floating in the Molapu Oya canal, near the Hikkaduwa Thotagamuwa bridge on 8 April. According to Police, the body was that of a 35-year-old Russian woman who lived alone in a villa near Molapu Oya. A fisherman had noticed the body of a woman floating in the canal and had informed the Police. The woman had reportedly come to the country about four months ago. The body was taken to the Karpitiya Teaching Hospital for a post-mortem examination on the orders of the Galle Acting Magistrate Lalith Pathirana. Hikkaduwa Police are conducting investigations. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: PPSOA distributes dry rations to underprivileged children
author: Author not found
Content: The Professional Photographic Studio Owners’ Association (PPSOA) distributed dry rations and school equipment to underprivileged children from all three communities in Akkaraipattu, at an event held at Sri Vijayarama Temple. The distribution was held under the patronage of Ampara/Batticaloa District Chief Sanganayake and Chief Incumbent of the Sri Vijayarama Temple Ven. Dewagoda Soratha Thera. PPSOA Assistant Secretary and main sponsor of the project, proprietor of Nathan Advanced Digital Colour Lab R. Prekash and General Secretary Dickshan Abeysinghe played a vital role in identifying suitable persons and arranging this event. Villagers were also provided with lunch packets. Text and Pix By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Sinhala Tamil New Year takes a better turn – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Transport Bandula Gunawardena said, the Sinhala and Tamil New Year will be more prosperous than last year and that Sri Lankans have a responsibility to make it even more prosperous next year. He was speaking  at the handing over  ceremony of 26 new buses acquired by Sri Lanka through the Indian credit line to Sri Lanka Transport Board depots in the Kandy district. Gunawardena said, the main reason for the country’s stability is because the Government, led by the President, boldly took rather painful steps without resorting to popular political decisions. He said, if the budget gap is reduced and foreign exchange reserves increase, the public will benefit, however, there will be a problem with foreign debt payment next year too. According to the Minister, giving concessions even when the country is not economically strong is the root cause of many crises and it was the IMF bailout package which brought relief. Gunawardena also said the depreciation of the rupee in relation to the dollar will result in a significant reduction in the import of goods. BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: SLPA Chair meets U.S. Transport Dept officials
author: Author not found
Content: The Chairman of the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA), Keith Bernard, met officials from the US Department of Transportation on 6 April 2023, at the Head Quarters in Colombo. Officials of the US Department of Transportation discussed further collaboration between them and the SLPA. The SLPA Chairman updated the US officials on future developments of the Port of Colombo (POC), especially, the East Container Terminal (ECT) and the West Container Terminal (WCT). He also spoke of the development of logistic facilities in the Port and emphasised the need for further training of SLPA officials. He thanked outgoing Consultant Varney, Senior Adviser, Maritime Administration, and US Department of Transportation, for his service and contribution to Sri Lanka’s maritime and transportation sector. He welcomed Joseph C. Traini, Senior Regional Manager, Asia Pacific, and US Department of Transportation Office Secretary as the incoming Consultant. Officials from the US Department conveyed their assistance to SLPA to develop the Port Sector and assured strengthening the relationship with the US Department of Transportation.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Legal action against tenshop owners
author: Author not found
Content: The Panadura MOH Office has instituted legal action against ten shop owners in Panadura town, warned twenty others, and destroyed the food items of four other shops for selling unhygienic food during the Sinhala and Tamil New Year season. According to a spokesman, cases were filed during a special operation to protect people’s health during the festive season. Ten shop owners were sued for storing cooked food with raw meat and fish, failing to cover displayed food to prevent contamination, violating label regulations, and violating hygiene laws, while four stores had their food items destroyed, and 20 were warned. A total of 34 wholesale and retail establishments, as well as restaurants, have been inspected. By Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: Will back RW at upcoming Presidential Poll – Dilum
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Investment Promotion Dilum Amunugama said, if President Ranil Wickremesinghe contests the upcoming Presidential Election, he will have his full support. He told the media in Kandy yesterday (9) that, while he could not say what decision the party he represents will make, he has decided to back the President in the upcoming Presidential Election. He added that the incumbent President has fearlessly accepted the challenge of reviving the country from a major crisis, and that he managed to stabilise the country within just a year. “I believe it is our responsibility and duty to strengthen the person who did this. At this point, we should set aside the politics of the SJB, JJB, and SLPP and strengthen the hands that have come forward to serve the country. Perhaps we would have supported Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa if he had accepted this challenge at a difficult time,” he said. Further, he said some people claim they are selling their party to Wickremesinghe. He said Wickremesinghe does not require their party because he already has a good party. “We must accept that our country was in crisis when an SLPP President presided over it. Otherwise, we cannot escape the responsibility of not seeing, not being present, and not informing me, as former President Maithripala Sirisena did. I cannot speak for the rest of our party members. I fully support President Wickremesinghe,” he added.  By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Sinhalatranslation of Quran presented to Nigerian HCin New Delhi
author: Author not found
Content: A copy of the Sinhala translation of the Quran was presented to the High Commissioner of Nigeria in New Delhi Ahmed Sule by Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda on 3 April at the Nigerian High Commission.  The presentation was done as part of High Commissioner Moragoda’s efforts to enhance dialogue with Heads of Mission of Islamic countries concurrently accredited to Sri Lanka from New Delhi.  This Sinhala translation of the Holy Quran has been published by the All Ceylon Jamiyyathul Ulama (ACJU).  Previously, High Commissioner Moragoda had presented copies of the Sinhala translation of the Quran to the Jama Masjid of Delhi, the Jamiat Ulama-i-Hind (Council of Muslim Theologians of India) as well as to the Ambassadors of Morocco and Bahrain in New Delhi.  The High Commission of Sri Lanka in New Delhi has been promoting dialogue with all major religions in India, in keeping with the policy roadmap ‘Integrated Country Strategy for Sri Lanka Diplomatic Missions in India’.

title: Mahanama beat D.S. Senanayake by 119 runs
author: Author not found
Content: Mahanama College Colombo beat D.S. Senanayake College Colombo by 119 runs in their 17th ‘Battle of the Golds’ One Day Cricket encounter played at R. Premadasa International Cricket Stadium Colombo on Saturday. Mahanama won the toss and elected to bat. They scored 327 runs for 5 wickets in their allotted 50 overs. Kavindu Amameth (78), Anjala Bandara (66), Inuka Karannagoda (57*), Sachira Weliwatta (44) and Rashmika Perera (29*) were the chief scorers. Kavindu Amameth and Anjala Bandara were involved in 106 runs stand for the 3rd wicket. Sineth Malwattage claimed 2 wickets for 42 runs. In reply, D.S.S scored 208 runs for 9 wickets in 41.3 overs. Opener Gaviru Senhas scored a fighting 124 runs in 107 balls with 12 boundaries and 4 sixes.  Sachira Weliwatte, Chamika Heenatigala and Duvindu Ranathunga claimed 2 wickets each. Mahanama: 327/5 (50) (Kavindu Amameth 78, Anjala Bandara 66, Inuka Karannagoda 57*, Sachira Weliwatta 44, Rashmika Perera 29*, Sineth Malwattage 2/42) D.S.S Colombo: 208/9 (41.3) (Gaviru Senhas 124, Himantha Keshan 25, Sachira Weliwatta 2/26, Chamika Heenatigala 2/26, Duvindu Ranathunga 2/54) (IR)

title: Decision to arrest Diana or not on 24 April
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (6) announced that his decision on whether to order the CID to arrest Tourism State Minister Diana Gamage, on charges of flouting immigration and emigration laws, will be delivered on 24 April. The Chief Magistrate announced this, having considered a request made to him by the CID, who requested the Court to issue an Order for the State Minister’s arrest, as it has come to light, that the suspect had flouted Provisions contained in Section 32 of the Code of Criminal Procedure Act.   After being noticed at the previous hearing, the Counsels from the Attorney General’s Department were present in Court. Later, Magistrate Alwis, posed a set of questions to the Attorney General’s Department, connected to the case. He inquired when a British national is not seeking Sri Lankan citizenship, whether he or she could invariably lay claim to such a right, whether it was not an offence in obtaining Sri Lankan citizenship, while holding onto his or her British citizenship and whether a British passport is provided only to its citizens. Responding to the queries, put forth by the Court, the State Counsel, representing the Attorney General’s Department, mentioned that further inquiries would need to be conducted to ascertain details pertaining to the questions raised. She observed that more time has to be spent, compiling the replies, as they had already sought information from the British Government as well. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Court stated that its decision, on the request made by the CID, will be announced on the said date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Kudu Salindu’s FR Petition fixed for 21 June
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (6) fixed the Fundamental Rights Petition, seeking assurance of the safety of notorious drug trafficker Salindu Malshika Gunaratna alias ‘Kudu Salindu’, for 21 June. This was when the relevant FR Petition was taken before a Supreme Court three-Judge Bench chaired by Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya. The Petitioners noted that the Petition has to be taken as a matter of urgency whilst the petitioner is being held in detention, and whilst the Attorney General requested for additional time. It was noted by the petitioner, that in most of the instances where suspects in Police custody have been killed, the Police have taken positions such as, the suspect tried to escape from custody whilst pointing out a hidden weapon or narcotics or tried escaping from custody and he was shot or that the suspect attempted to grab the firearm of the Police officer and in the process the gun went off or the suspect was shot by an outside party while in Police custody. Thereby, the petitioner sought an order directing respondents to take all necessary measures to safeguard the personal safety of the Petitioner whilst in detention until the final determination of Petition. ‘Kudu Salindu’ was repatriated to Sri Lanka on 15 March together with drug kingpin Nadun Chinthaka alias ‘Harak Kata’ and six others. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: NTC warns private bus operators
author: Author not found
Content: In response to the complaints that the private bus sector has failed to adhere to the recent bus fare revision, the National Transport Commission (NTC) said it has assigned mobile inspectors and issued warnings to the bus operators. In addition, fines were imposed on the buses that had not implemented the new fares on 3 April. NTC Director General Nilan Miranda said 90 per cent of the buses are following the fare revision and measures have been taken to implement the revision in 100 per cent of the buses in the New Year festive season. He said several incidents of the fare revisions not being implemented have been reported. “The NTC had assigned mobile inspectors on 3 April and warned the bus operators, who had not implemented the revised bus fares and fined them, Miranda said. Stern action would be taken if the same incident was reported several times, Miranda pledged and added a special programme has been launched by the NTC in the Western Province in this regard. “The NTC had revised the bus fares soon after the reduction of fuel prices. All the bus owners were advised to display the new bus fare revision sheet clearly visible to the passengers,” he added. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Police to round up beggars in Kandy
author: Author not found
Content: Beggers in the Kandy city limits will be removed to prevent the public from being inconvenienced, Kandy Police said. Police said a special security operation will be conducted in and around the Kandy city limits during the upcoming Sinhala-Tamil New Year festive season. Accordingly, this particular security plan is being implemented with the intention of providing additional security to the public, who are expected to converge in Kandy and its town limits due to the festive season. Furthermore, the Police advised the public to be wary and safeguard their cash and gold items from pickpockets during the festive season. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Rogue ‘doctor’ remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya yesterday (6) remanded a suspect, who was charged with fleecing patients, while posing off as a doctor at Lady Ridgeway Hospital in Borella, till 19 April. The Magistrate also instructed the Director of the Prisons Department, to produce the suspect, fully covered, before an identification parade on the said date. Borella Police told the Court that the Hospital Police had arrested the suspect and handed him over to them, after he had been roaming around the premises on 5 April. The Police added that inquiries conducted into the incident revealed that the suspect had obtained cash from patients, having deceived them by pretending to be a doctor. Borella Police said further inquiries are being conducted. By Hansi Nanayakkara
