title: Rogue ‘doctor’ remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya yesterday (6) remanded a suspect, who was charged with fleecing patients, while posing off as a doctor at Lady Ridgeway Hospital in Borella, till 19 April. The Magistrate also instructed the Director of the Prisons Department, to produce the suspect, fully covered, before an identification parade on the said date. Borella Police told the Court that the Hospital Police had arrested the suspect and handed him over to them, after he had been roaming around the premises on 5 April. The Police added that inquiries conducted into the incident revealed that the suspect had obtained cash from patients, having deceived them by pretending to be a doctor. Borella Police said further inquiries are being conducted. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Security camera footage of Wishma before death in Japan released
author: Author not found
Content: Security camera footage, showing a Sri Lankan woman before her death, in a central Japan detention facility, was publicly released yesterday (6) for the first time by lawyers representing her family. Approximately seven minutes, of roughly five total hours of government-provided security camera footage, showing Ratnayake Liyanage Wishma Sandamali, who died at the age of 33, while being held at the Nagoya Regional Immigration Services Bureau in March 2021, was shown at a press conference in Tokyo. A segment of the released footage, taken less than two weeks before Wishma’s death, shows her bedridden and begging officers to take her to hospital after telling them she was unable to move or eat. In another piece of footage, from the day of her death, an officer tries to wake an unresponsive Wishma after reporting over an intercom that her fingertips feel cold. While Wishma’s family and some members of parliament have been able to privately view the footage, which the government submitted as evidence in a lawsuit, it marks the first time a portion of it has been made available to the public. Wishma arrived in Japan in 2017 as a student, but was taken into custody at the immigration facility in August 2020, for overstaying her visa. She died on 6 March 2021, after complaining of ill health, which included vomiting and stomach-aches, for around a month. Her death sparked national outrage over her treatment, forcing the government a few months later to drop a bill revising rules on foreigners facing deportation, including asylum seekers. Wishma’s family is seeking damages from the government over her death, alleging she was illegally detained and died due to a lack of required medical care. (The Mainichi)

title: RTI Commission Orders Investment Ministry to Release Port City Agreement
author: Author not found
Content: After a four-year hearing process, the Right to Information (RTI) Commission yesterday (6) ordered the Ministry of Investment Promotion to release the TriPartite agreement on Colombo Port City Development Project (CPCDP) to the public. The agreement was entered into in 2017 between the Ministry of Megapolis and Western Development, the UDA, and the China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC) Port City Colombo (Pvt) Ltd. The Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ), which claimed that the Port city project was launched without adequate public consultations and a comprehensive Environmental Impact Assessment process in 2018, requested a copy of the above agreement from the Ministry of Megapolis and Western Development of the Good Governance Government. At that time the request was denied on the basis of the presence of confidential clauses. In November 2018, the CEJ appealed to the RTI Commission requesting the release of the agreement. The RTI Commission accepted the appeal and the hearing process continued for four years. This is one of the longest hearings held by the RTI Commission. Over this period the Public Authority (PA) was changed to the Ministry of Urban Development, Water Supply and Housing Facilities and then to the Ministry of Investment Promotion in 2022. In between, the Port City Economic Commission was established through a new Act. On 20 July 2021, at the request of both the PA as well as the Office of the Presidential Secretariat, the Presidential Secretariat was added as an added respondent to this appeal. Further to the CEJ, Feisal Mansoor, on behalf of the All-country Fisheries Society, had also requested a copy of the agreement through the RTI Act. Both cases were heard together. Delivering the final order, Commissioner Kishali Pinto Jayawardena, of the RTI Commission, said the PA was unable to establish which clauses should be kept confidential and the TriPartite agreement signed in 2014 for the Colombo Port City development is in public domain through the judiciary process. Therefore, the Commission stated they do not recognise the necessity to keep the document out of public domain. This hearing process was very time taking and the government bought several excuses such as change of governments and the necessity to seek direction from higher officers to keep denying access to this information for the public. Finally, after several requests by the Commission, PA agreed to release some of the information in the agreement to the appellants on 29 September 2021. However, this information was not sufficient to clearly understand the full impact of the project. Therefore the appellant (CEJ) requested the full agreement.

title: Several SJB MPs ready to support President– Rajitha
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Dr. Rajitha Senaratne claimed that several SJB MPs, including he and Dr. Harsha de Silva, are willing to support President Wickremesinghe and those MPs will do so as a group if the Party fails to take a decision. He was responding to questions raised by journalists, at the SJB media briefing yesterday (6).  “We will support the President as a group if the party fails to take a decision. Many want to work with the President but are a bit reluctant to contest an election with him,” he added. He added that there are no policy differences between President Wickremesinghe and the SJB. “SJB MPs quit the UNP not because there were policy differences but because they were not happy with Wickremesinghe’s decision making style. The notion that the President has put the country on a better footing is a reality,” he added. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: PresentingAnti-Terrorism Bill to Parliament delayed – Wijeyadasa
author: Author not found
Content: Presenting the controversial Anti-Terrorism Bill (ATB) to Parliament will be delayed, following a number of requests of various groups, including Opposition Parties, Minister of Justice Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said yesterday (6). However, the Bill is expected to be presented to Parliament by the end of April or the first week of May. Rajapakshe made this announcement following a meeting, held at the Justice Ministry premises, with civil society and transport trade union representatives. The Minister said the drafting of the Bill began in 2015 and there was no need to protect the President and the Government through the Bill.  “This Bill was prepared after referring to international laws. The objective of bringing it is to protect the citizens of the country and remove some clauses of the current Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) that are being misused such as the power of the President to issue detention orders. This particular power given to the President by the PTA will be removed and granted to the law enforcement authorities,” he said. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: CEB acquires Sojitz Kelanitissa power plant
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), on 28 March, acquired the 163 MW Combined Cycle Power Plant, which was operated by Sojitz Kelanitissa (Pvt) Limited. In a statement, the CEB said the acquiring process was initiated in the latter part of 2022, in accordance with the terms and condition of the Power Purchase Agreement (PPA). “The untiring efforts of the CEB team, led by CEB General Manager Eng. Rohan Seneviratne, have resulted in enhancing the CEB’s own power plant capacity by 163 MW. Under the Government of Sri Lanka policy framework, CEB signed the PPA with Sojitz Kelanitissa (Pvt) Limited in June 2000 as an Independent Power Producer (IPP) on BOOT basis. The contract period was for 20 years and the power plant is located in Colombo Kelanitissa Power Plant complex,” the statement said. CEB negotiations were very hard, especially due to economic constraints, obstacles, challenges, and many issues including legal aspects; but the CEB has managed to overcome those difficulties and finally owned a 163 MW power plant. CEB appreciates all those government entities that have helped immensely to complete the acquiring process successfully, according to the statement. Further, the CEB said it appreciates Sojitz Kelanitissa (Pvt) Limited for the operation of power plant over 19 years and for the cordial cooperation extended during the negotiation and transfer process of the facility. CEB has foreseen the future power requirements of the country and facilitated the acquisition process in order to increase its power generation capacity. The CEB owned 163 MW facilities is compatible with LNG with some minor modifications and hence enables to reduce the current cost of generation when conversion takes place, it said. (TR)

title: A’Pura Paediatric Professorial ward reopens today
author: Author not found
Content: The Paediatric Professorial ward, of the Anuradhapura Teaching Hospital (ATH), is set to be re-opened for patient admissions today (7) following the arrival of an Acting Consultant Paediatrician from the Thambuttegama Hospital.   Assistant Secretary of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) Dr. Ajantha Rajakaruna yesterday (6) said that Professorial Paediatric ward at the Anuradhapura Teaching Hospital had been shut down by end March after head of the Unit and other paediatric consultants attached to it, left the country. However, the hospital was able to obtain the services of an Acting Paediatric Consultant from Thambuttegama Hospital, permitting the opening of the ward. He noted that a retired consultant, who had been serving at the hospital, too had left owing to medical reasons. Furthermore, he said that one other consultant had left the country for foreign training. Director of the Hospital Dr. Dulan Samaraweera, when contacted yesterday (6), said while doctors serving under the Health Ministry have only gone overseas on various occasions, for specialist foreign training, the issue surrounding the professorial unit of the hospital was a concern of the Ministry of Higher Education.    By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Three arrested with Rs 92M in hash
author: Author not found
Content: The Navy intercepted a foreign dhow carrying hashish worth over Rs 92 million in Talaimannar seas and arrested three foreigners, during a special search operation conducted in the sea area of Sand Dunes, Talaimannar, yesterday (5). The drugs were in 95 packages, which had been found in three sacks, concealed in the dhow. The suspects together with drugs and the dhow were handed over to the Talaimannar Police for onward legal proceedings. (NV)

title: Hospital waste water pollutes Arabokka River
author: Author not found
Content: Residents of Hambantota District have complained that due to polluted water being released, by the Hambantota District Hospital, to the Arabokka River, the waters of the River has become contaminated and is presently unsuitable for use. They charged that due to this unwelcome situation, their health could be severely at risk, having to utilise contaminated water for their daily needs. S.V.P. Samarapala, a farmer, said that in the past few weeks a strong odour had begun to emanate from the Arabokka River due to the Hospital having released its polluted waters into it. He charged that due to the crass actions on the part of officials from the Hambantota District Hospital, the residents of the area have been forced to put their lives at risk for no fault of theirs and hence, they urged the authorities to look into this issue and provide them with relief promptly. BY Roshan Rajika – Hambantota

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Arrested for Illegal sand mining
author: Author not found
Content: The Gampola STF apprehended a suspect, who had been engaged in illegal sand mining for a number of years, in the Moragolla area. They also seized equipment used by the suspect. According to sources from the Gampola STF camp the suspect was involved in unlicensed sand mining using the clout wielded by a regional politician of the area. Residents of the area informed this correspondent that repeated requests made to authorities to help end sand mining in the area, due to the threat posed by it to the environment, as pointed out by various environment groups, such attempts had been overlooked due to political influence. However, after the recent appointment of a new head to the STF camp, action was taken on the complaints, a raid was conducted in the area and the suspect was arrested. BY Suranga Dilhan – Gampola

title: SBOA head warns MP Jagath Kumara
author: Author not found
Content: The head of the All Ceylon Samurdhi Bank Officers Association (SBOA), N. A. I. M. B. Abeysinghe, said the Samurdhi officers in the country will not henceforth fall prey to hollow rhetoric uttered by SLPP MP Jagath Kumara. He advised the MP concerned not to hoodwink Samurdhi officers or threaten them as they do not fear politicians anymore, as bankrupt MPs of the calibre of Jagath Kumara have already been shunned by the electorate.  Addressing a media conference, held in Kandy yesterday, Abeysinghe challenged the MP concerned to deny publicly that he was not currently engaged in a plot to take over the portfolio of State Minister of Samurdhi. BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Father of threedies of poisoning
author: Author not found
Content: Following a post-mortem conducted at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, into the death of a father of three, it had come to light that the victim had succumbed to complications brought about after consumption of poisonous Flame Lily (Niyagala Ala) while being inebriated.  The deceased has been identified as a 67-year-old resident of Akmeemana. It has also been revealed that the deceased had also been afflicted for some time with an injury to his spine and upon taking alcohol he had also consumed the aforementioned poisonous item resulting in his demise. By Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Bogus doctor arrested
author: Author not found
Content: An individual dressed as a doctor and carrying a stethoscope was apprehended near Lady Ridgeway Hospital for Children in Borella on 5 April evening. According to the Police, the suspect pretended to be a doctor and claimed that he could send people abroad, to defraud them. The suspect is 56-year-old and lives in Yakwila, Pannala, though he has been temporarily residing in Vathupitiwala, Rukgahawela. Further investigation revealed that the suspect defrauded people to the tune of Rs 70,000 by pretending to be a doctor at the National Hospital of Sri Lanka and claiming that they would be sent to Australia. The suspect was due to be produced in the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court yesterday (6). Borella Police is continuing investigations.

title: MELBOURNE CONSULATE GENERAL CONDUCTS MOBILE CONSULAR SERVICE
author: Author not found
Content: The Consulate General of Sri Lanka in Melbourne conducted a mobile consular service for the Sri Lankan community on 2 April 2023, during a Sri Lankan New Year Festival held in Dandenong, Victoria. During the festival, which was organized by the Sri Lanka German Technical Training Institute OBA (SLGTTIOBA), the consulate set up a booth to provide several consular services to the large numbers of visitors to the event.  During the full-day service, the Consulate staff helped members of the public who wanted to submit applications for new passports, dual citizenships, birth registrations and driving licence verifications.  The Consulate processed over 20 applications for the above, assisting applicants by reviewing the applications and supporting documents and advising on any gaps or corrections. To ensure a full service, the Consulate also provided on-site payment facilities and an online appointment facility, for those who wished to follow up with appointments to the Consulate. In addition, the staff also certified “life certificates” for pensioners and other documents.  Apart from these services, the staff fielded inquiries from over 600 visitors to the stall, on all consular matters, guiding people on applications, checklists of documents, fees, and next steps in the process.  Visitors to the booth commended the Consulate for this initiative, saying that it was very convenient for those who found it difficult to come to the Melbourne CBD, and many requested that the Consulate carry out similar services in the future.   Consul General Sandith Samarasinghe, also participated as a special guest in the official ceremonies of the New Year celebrations. During the opening ceremony in the morning, he participated in the flag raising ceremony, and conveyed the best wishes of President Ranil Wickremesinghe for the success of the event.  At the official ceremony in the afternoon, the Consul General congratulated the SLGTTIOBA for the successful New Year celebrations, which the association has been holding for over twenty years, and which was now recognized as the largest Sinhala and Tamil New Year celebrations in the world, outside of Sri Lanka. He appreciated the tireless efforts of the organizers in helping to keep alive Sri Lankan traditions and culture amongst the Sri Lankan community in Australia, and thanked the organizers for inviting the Consulate to be part of the event.  He assured that the Consulate was committed to continuing to build strong connections with the Sri Lankan community, within the overall environment of the rich Australian multiculturalism.   During the event, Consul General Samarasinghe met with Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews, and other key Australian leaders, including federal MPs, State MPs, Mayors and Councillors.  During his meeting with the Victorian Premier, the Consul General reiterated the strong ties between Sri Lanka and Australia, and the Consulate’s commitment to continue to strengthen these bilateral ties. The  Consul General also met with key leaders in the Sri Lanka community, and interacted with members of the Sri Lankan business community, associations and the general public, expressing the Consulate’s commitment to continuously engage with the community.

title: Omnipresent but Under-diagnosed
author: Author not found
Content: The global prevalence of the bipolar disorder is estimated to be around 1-2% of the population, with rates varying between countries and cultures. It affects people of all ages, races, ethnicities, and socioeconomic backgrounds, and is one of the leading causes of disability worldwide. Despite its high prevalence and significant impact on individuals and society, the bipolar disorder remains under-diagnosed and undertreated in many parts of the world. Stigma and lack of access to mental health care are among the main barriers to proper diagnosis and treatment. Presently, research is going on to better understand the causes and underlying mechanisms of bipolar disorder, as well as to develop more effective treatments.  It includes mood stabilizers, antipsychotics, and antidepressants and is among the most common treatments for bipolar disorder, and psychotherapy, including cognitive-behavioural therapy and interpersonal therapy. Bipolar disorder also known as manic-depressive illness is a type of mental health condition that affects a person’s mood, energy, and ability to function. People with bipolar disorder experience episodes of extreme highs (mania or hypomania) and extreme lows (depression), which can last for days, weeks, or even months. During a manic episode, a person with bipolar disorder may feel euphoric or irritable, have racing thoughts, talk excessively, engage in risky behaviours, and have an inflated sense of self-importance. In contrast, during a depressive episode, a person with bipolar disorder may feel sad, and hopeless, and lose interest in activities they once enjoyed. They may also experience sleep disturbances, changes in appetite, and difficulty concentrating. Causes of the disease Bipolar disorder is a complex mental illness that is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic, environmental, and neurochemical factors. The specific causes of bipolar disorder are not yet fully understood, but its contributing factors include, a. Genetics: Bipolar disorder tends to run in families, suggesting that there is a genetic component to its development. Studies have identified several genes that may play a role in bipolar disorder, although the exact mechanisms by which these genes contribute to the disorder are still being investigated. b. Neurochemical imbalances: Bipolar disorder is associated with imbalances in certain neurotransmitters, such as serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine, which are involved in regulating mood, energy, and motivation. c. Environmental factors: Stressful life events, such as trauma, loss, or major life changes, can trigger bipolar disorder in some people. Substance abuse can also contribute to the development of a bipolar disorder, as drug and alcohol use can disrupt the brain’s chemical balance and trigger mood swings. d. Brain structure and function: Studies have suggested that people with bipolar disorder may have differences in the structure and function of certain areas of the brain that are involved in regulating mood, including the prefrontal cortex and the amygdala. It’s important to note that bipolar disorder is a complex condition, and different people may experience it in different ways. Effects of the disease Bipolar disorder can have a significant impact on a person’s mood, behaviour, and overall quality of life. The major effects of the disease can be seen in: a. Mood swings: People with bipolar disorder experience episodes of extreme mood swings, ranging from periods of high energy and euphoria (mania or hypomania) to periods of intense sadness and hopelessness (depression). These mood swings can be intense and can occur unexpectedly, making it difficult for individuals to maintain stable relationships and hold down a job. b. Impaired thinking and decision-making: During manic or hypomanic episodes, individuals with bipolar disorder may experience racing thoughts, reduced need for sleep, impulsivity, and poor judgment.  This can lead to risky behaviour, such as excessive spending, substance abuse, and risky sexual behaviour. c. Relationship problems: Bipolar disorder can put a strain on relationships, as mood swings can make it difficult for individuals to maintain stable, healthy connections with others. Family members and loved ones may struggle to understand the sudden shifts in behaviour and mood and may feel frustrated or hurt as a result. d. Employment issues: Bipolar disorder can interfere with an individual’s ability to work, as mood swings can make it difficult to focus and complete tasks. Additionally, people with bipolar disorder may need to take time off work to manage symptoms, attend therapy, or receive medical treatment. e. Physical health problems: People with bipolar disorder may be at increased risk for physical health problems, such as heart disease, diabetes, and obesity, due to lifestyle factors such as poor diet, lack of exercise, and substance abuse. f. Suicide risk: Individuals with bipolar disorder are at increased risk for suicide, especially during depressive episodes. It’s important for people with bipolar disorder to seek treatment and support to manage their symptoms and reduce their risk of suicide. These are just a few of the effects that bipolar disorder can have. With proper treatment and support, however, many people with bipolar disorder are able to manage their symptoms and lead fulfilling, productive lives. Precautions In this context, some precautions can be taken to manage the condition and reduce the risk of relapse or complications and the most important among them to consider are: a. Follow the treatment plan: It is important to follow the treatment plan recommended by the healthcare provider, including taking medications as prescribed and attending therapy sessions. This can help prevent relapses and improve overall functioning. b. Avoid alcohol and drugs: Substance abuse can trigger mood swings and interfere with treatment. It is important to avoid alcohol and drugs and to let the healthcare provider know if there is a history of substance abuse. c. Monitor mood changes: It is important to monitor mood changes and report any unusual symptoms to the healthcare provider. This can help identify early warning signs of relapse and adjust treatment accordingly. c. Get enough sleep: Sleep deprivation can trigger manic episodes. It is important to maintain a regular sleep schedule and get enough sleep. d. Reduce stress: Stress can trigger mood swings and increase the risk of relapse. It is important to identify sources of stress and develop coping strategies, such as relaxation techniques or exercise. e. Seek support: Bipolar disorder can be challenging to manage on your own and so it is important to seek support from family, friends, or support groups. About the Author: Dr. Rajkumar Singh is a Youth Motivator, presently a Professor of Political Science and Dean of Social Sciences along with Dean, Student Welfare (DSW), at B.N. Mandal University, Madhepura (Bihar), India. His 22 Books published in addition to 900 Articles in National and International Journals and Daily Newspapers from 25 foreign countries. By Dr. Rajkumar Singh

title: HC Moragoda addresses the Economic Advisory Council to India’s PM
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda addressed the Economic Advisory Council to the Prime Minister of India (EAC-PM) at the invitation of its Chairman Dr. Bibek Debroy on 5 April 2023. The talk was held at the Council’s office in NITI Bhavan in New Delhi. The Economic Advisory Council to the Prime Minister (EAC-PM) is an independent body constituted to give advice on economic and related issues to the Government of India, specifically to the Prime Minister. High Commissioner Moragoda’s address to the Council dealt with key areas pertaining to Indo-Lanka relations, particularly, bilateral economic integration and cooperation. The High Commissioner stressed the importance of economic integration between Sri Lanka and India, and requested the Council to assist in that process by way of policy guidance. High Commissioner Moragoda premised his address on the policy roadmap, the “Integrated Country Strategy for Sri Lanka Diplomatic Missions in India- 2021/2023”, and answered the questions posed by the members of the Council following the talk. At present, the membership of the EAC-PM consists of its Chairman Dr. Bibek Debroy and Members Shri Sanjeev Sanyal and Dr. Shamika Ravi. Shri Rakesh Mohan, Dr. Sajjid Chinoy, Dr. Neelkanth Mishra, Shri Nilesh Shah, Prof. T.T. Ram Mohan and Dr. Poonam Gupta serve as the Council’s part-time members. The Terms of Reference of EAC-PM include analysing any issue, economic or otherwise, referred to it by the Prime Minister and advising him thereon, and addressing issues of macroeconomic importance and presenting views thereon to the Prime Minister. These could be either suo-motu or on reference from the Prime Minister. The Council attends to any other task as may be desired by the Prime Minister from time to time.

The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Father of threedies of poisoning
author: Author not found
Content: Following a post-mortem conducted at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, into the death of a father of three, it had come to light that the victim had succumbed to complications brought about after consumption of poisonous Flame Lily (Niyagala Ala) while being inebriated.  The deceased has been identified as a 67-year-old resident of Akmeemana. It has also been revealed that the deceased had also been afflicted for some time with an injury to his spine and upon taking alcohol he had also consumed the aforementioned poisonous item resulting in his demise. By Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Bogus doctor arrested
author: Author not found
Content: An individual dressed as a doctor and carrying a stethoscope was apprehended near Lady Ridgeway Hospital for Children in Borella on 5 April evening. According to the Police, the suspect pretended to be a doctor and claimed that he could send people abroad, to defraud them. The suspect is 56-year-old and lives in Yakwila, Pannala, though he has been temporarily residing in Vathupitiwala, Rukgahawela. Further investigation revealed that the suspect defrauded people to the tune of Rs 70,000 by pretending to be a doctor at the National Hospital of Sri Lanka and claiming that they would be sent to Australia. The suspect was due to be produced in the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court yesterday (6). Borella Police is continuing investigations.

title: Three arrested with Rs 92M in hash
author: Author not found
Content: The Navy intercepted a foreign dhow carrying hashish worth over Rs 92 million in Talaimannar seas and arrested three foreigners, during a special search operation conducted in the sea area of Sand Dunes, Talaimannar, yesterday (5). The drugs were in 95 packages, which had been found in three sacks, concealed in the dhow. The suspects together with drugs and the dhow were handed over to the Talaimannar Police for onward legal proceedings. (NV)

title: Hospital waste water pollutes Arabokka River
author: Author not found
Content: Residents of Hambantota District have complained that due to polluted water being released, by the Hambantota District Hospital, to the Arabokka River, the waters of the River has become contaminated and is presently unsuitable for use. They charged that due to this unwelcome situation, their health could be severely at risk, having to utilise contaminated water for their daily needs. S.V.P. Samarapala, a farmer, said that in the past few weeks a strong odour had begun to emanate from the Arabokka River due to the Hospital having released its polluted waters into it. He charged that due to the crass actions on the part of officials from the Hambantota District Hospital, the residents of the area have been forced to put their lives at risk for no fault of theirs and hence, they urged the authorities to look into this issue and provide them with relief promptly. BY Roshan Rajika – Hambantota

title: MELBOURNE CONSULATE GENERAL CONDUCTS MOBILE CONSULAR SERVICE
author: Author not found
Content: The Consulate General of Sri Lanka in Melbourne conducted a mobile consular service for the Sri Lankan community on 2 April 2023, during a Sri Lankan New Year Festival held in Dandenong, Victoria. During the festival, which was organized by the Sri Lanka German Technical Training Institute OBA (SLGTTIOBA), the consulate set up a booth to provide several consular services to the large numbers of visitors to the event.  During the full-day service, the Consulate staff helped members of the public who wanted to submit applications for new passports, dual citizenships, birth registrations and driving licence verifications.  The Consulate processed over 20 applications for the above, assisting applicants by reviewing the applications and supporting documents and advising on any gaps or corrections. To ensure a full service, the Consulate also provided on-site payment facilities and an online appointment facility, for those who wished to follow up with appointments to the Consulate. In addition, the staff also certified “life certificates” for pensioners and other documents.  Apart from these services, the staff fielded inquiries from over 600 visitors to the stall, on all consular matters, guiding people on applications, checklists of documents, fees, and next steps in the process.  Visitors to the booth commended the Consulate for this initiative, saying that it was very convenient for those who found it difficult to come to the Melbourne CBD, and many requested that the Consulate carry out similar services in the future.   Consul General Sandith Samarasinghe, also participated as a special guest in the official ceremonies of the New Year celebrations. During the opening ceremony in the morning, he participated in the flag raising ceremony, and conveyed the best wishes of President Ranil Wickremesinghe for the success of the event.  At the official ceremony in the afternoon, the Consul General congratulated the SLGTTIOBA for the successful New Year celebrations, which the association has been holding for over twenty years, and which was now recognized as the largest Sinhala and Tamil New Year celebrations in the world, outside of Sri Lanka. He appreciated the tireless efforts of the organizers in helping to keep alive Sri Lankan traditions and culture amongst the Sri Lankan community in Australia, and thanked the organizers for inviting the Consulate to be part of the event.  He assured that the Consulate was committed to continuing to build strong connections with the Sri Lankan community, within the overall environment of the rich Australian multiculturalism.   During the event, Consul General Samarasinghe met with Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews, and other key Australian leaders, including federal MPs, State MPs, Mayors and Councillors.  During his meeting with the Victorian Premier, the Consul General reiterated the strong ties between Sri Lanka and Australia, and the Consulate’s commitment to continue to strengthen these bilateral ties. The  Consul General also met with key leaders in the Sri Lanka community, and interacted with members of the Sri Lankan business community, associations and the general public, expressing the Consulate’s commitment to continuously engage with the community.

title: Omnipresent but Under-diagnosed
author: Author not found
Content: The global prevalence of the bipolar disorder is estimated to be around 1-2% of the population, with rates varying between countries and cultures. It affects people of all ages, races, ethnicities, and socioeconomic backgrounds, and is one of the leading causes of disability worldwide. Despite its high prevalence and significant impact on individuals and society, the bipolar disorder remains under-diagnosed and undertreated in many parts of the world. Stigma and lack of access to mental health care are among the main barriers to proper diagnosis and treatment. Presently, research is going on to better understand the causes and underlying mechanisms of bipolar disorder, as well as to develop more effective treatments.  It includes mood stabilizers, antipsychotics, and antidepressants and is among the most common treatments for bipolar disorder, and psychotherapy, including cognitive-behavioural therapy and interpersonal therapy. Bipolar disorder also known as manic-depressive illness is a type of mental health condition that affects a person’s mood, energy, and ability to function. People with bipolar disorder experience episodes of extreme highs (mania or hypomania) and extreme lows (depression), which can last for days, weeks, or even months. During a manic episode, a person with bipolar disorder may feel euphoric or irritable, have racing thoughts, talk excessively, engage in risky behaviours, and have an inflated sense of self-importance. In contrast, during a depressive episode, a person with bipolar disorder may feel sad, and hopeless, and lose interest in activities they once enjoyed. They may also experience sleep disturbances, changes in appetite, and difficulty concentrating. Causes of the disease Bipolar disorder is a complex mental illness that is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic, environmental, and neurochemical factors. The specific causes of bipolar disorder are not yet fully understood, but its contributing factors include, a. Genetics: Bipolar disorder tends to run in families, suggesting that there is a genetic component to its development. Studies have identified several genes that may play a role in bipolar disorder, although the exact mechanisms by which these genes contribute to the disorder are still being investigated. b. Neurochemical imbalances: Bipolar disorder is associated with imbalances in certain neurotransmitters, such as serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine, which are involved in regulating mood, energy, and motivation. c. Environmental factors: Stressful life events, such as trauma, loss, or major life changes, can trigger bipolar disorder in some people. Substance abuse can also contribute to the development of a bipolar disorder, as drug and alcohol use can disrupt the brain’s chemical balance and trigger mood swings. d. Brain structure and function: Studies have suggested that people with bipolar disorder may have differences in the structure and function of certain areas of the brain that are involved in regulating mood, including the prefrontal cortex and the amygdala. It’s important to note that bipolar disorder is a complex condition, and different people may experience it in different ways. Effects of the disease Bipolar disorder can have a significant impact on a person’s mood, behaviour, and overall quality of life. The major effects of the disease can be seen in: a. Mood swings: People with bipolar disorder experience episodes of extreme mood swings, ranging from periods of high energy and euphoria (mania or hypomania) to periods of intense sadness and hopelessness (depression). These mood swings can be intense and can occur unexpectedly, making it difficult for individuals to maintain stable relationships and hold down a job. b. Impaired thinking and decision-making: During manic or hypomanic episodes, individuals with bipolar disorder may experience racing thoughts, reduced need for sleep, impulsivity, and poor judgment.  This can lead to risky behaviour, such as excessive spending, substance abuse, and risky sexual behaviour. c. Relationship problems: Bipolar disorder can put a strain on relationships, as mood swings can make it difficult for individuals to maintain stable, healthy connections with others. Family members and loved ones may struggle to understand the sudden shifts in behaviour and mood and may feel frustrated or hurt as a result. d. Employment issues: Bipolar disorder can interfere with an individual’s ability to work, as mood swings can make it difficult to focus and complete tasks. Additionally, people with bipolar disorder may need to take time off work to manage symptoms, attend therapy, or receive medical treatment. e. Physical health problems: People with bipolar disorder may be at increased risk for physical health problems, such as heart disease, diabetes, and obesity, due to lifestyle factors such as poor diet, lack of exercise, and substance abuse. f. Suicide risk: Individuals with bipolar disorder are at increased risk for suicide, especially during depressive episodes. It’s important for people with bipolar disorder to seek treatment and support to manage their symptoms and reduce their risk of suicide. These are just a few of the effects that bipolar disorder can have. With proper treatment and support, however, many people with bipolar disorder are able to manage their symptoms and lead fulfilling, productive lives. Precautions In this context, some precautions can be taken to manage the condition and reduce the risk of relapse or complications and the most important among them to consider are: a. Follow the treatment plan: It is important to follow the treatment plan recommended by the healthcare provider, including taking medications as prescribed and attending therapy sessions. This can help prevent relapses and improve overall functioning. b. Avoid alcohol and drugs: Substance abuse can trigger mood swings and interfere with treatment. It is important to avoid alcohol and drugs and to let the healthcare provider know if there is a history of substance abuse. c. Monitor mood changes: It is important to monitor mood changes and report any unusual symptoms to the healthcare provider. This can help identify early warning signs of relapse and adjust treatment accordingly. c. Get enough sleep: Sleep deprivation can trigger manic episodes. It is important to maintain a regular sleep schedule and get enough sleep. d. Reduce stress: Stress can trigger mood swings and increase the risk of relapse. It is important to identify sources of stress and develop coping strategies, such as relaxation techniques or exercise. e. Seek support: Bipolar disorder can be challenging to manage on your own and so it is important to seek support from family, friends, or support groups. About the Author: Dr. Rajkumar Singh is a Youth Motivator, presently a Professor of Political Science and Dean of Social Sciences along with Dean, Student Welfare (DSW), at B.N. Mandal University, Madhepura (Bihar), India. His 22 Books published in addition to 900 Articles in National and International Journals and Daily Newspapers from 25 foreign countries. By Dr. Rajkumar Singh

title: New ruse adopted in drug tenders – AHP
author: Author not found
Content: Bidding in tenfold, dividing the profit among the competitors while giving commissions to officials and calling tenders for a single bid has become the latest method of the drug mafia, the Association of Health Professionals (AHP) alleged. Although the Health Minister said that the AHP’s revelation that the Rs 7,000 medicine was to be purchased for Rs 70,000 was misleading and malicious, he took immediate measures to cancel the tender which confirms what was to take place, AHP President, Ravi Kumudesh said yesterday (5). But it is clear that this kind of tender cancellation is part of this mafia and not the fairest decision that could be taken as it is cancelled only till such time that the person they want to award the tender comes along, he alleged. The opportunity to bid for a particular medicinal drug at a low cost is lost when cancelling tenders, he said.“Thereby we have to resort to emergency purchases due to the prevailing shortage of medicine in hospitals which is all part of the mafia itself,” Kumudesh alleged. Bidding tenfold and awarding tenders to a single bidder is a time-honoured technical racket, he alleged adding that a single drug company could do that while dividing profits among competitors. The experts who are in charge of such technical decisions are directly responsible for such malpractices, the AHP alleged. Kumudesh called on the Government and the Health Minister to reveal the assets of all parliamentarians before assessing the assets of trade union leaders using the Act which Minister Manusha Nanayakka hopes to introduce. He said the Minister of Labour could not introduce Acts without discussing them with stakeholders. The Health Ministry on Monday (3) refuted allegations that the antiviral injection Ganzyclovien and the antibiotic Linezolid, through the Asian Development Bank (ADB), were being purchased at higher prices, violating the due procurement process.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Private sector to handle fertiliser distribution– Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: Fertiliser distribution that was carried out by the Government thus far will be handed over to the private sector in the 2023 Maha Season, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. He added that steps will also be taken to provide financial subsidies to farmers to purchase chemical and organic fertiliser, seeds and other agricultural inputs. For such purpose, a QR code will be given to every farmer, he said. “In the 2022/23 Yala Season, the Government has spent Rs 6.5 billion for the distribution of urea and MOP, while Rs 2 billion had to be spent for the distribution of TSP in the Yala season,” he said. Amaraweera emphasised that the purpose of the arrangement is to provide farmers with the opportunity to purchase essential agricultural inputs with the subsidy. “Further, the Government has decided to provide farmers who are cultivating paddy in the Yala Season a sum of Rs 20,000 for one hectare and Rs 40,000 for two hectares for the purchase of fertiliser and seeds or parachute trays required for parachute paddy cultivation,” he added. He also said the Government will provide mud fertiliser free of charge and take steps to issue a coupon to all farmers to purchase other agricultural inputs. (FT)

title: Price of lunch, fried rice, kottu drop by 20%
author: Author not found
Content: The All Island Canteen Owners’ Association (AICOA) announced that the price of a lunch packet, fried rice and kottu will be reduced by 20 per cent in line with the reduction in domestic LP gas and fuel prices. AICOA Chairman Asela Sampath said the new prices came into effect from midnight yesterday (5). Apart from that, the price of a cup of milk tea and plain tea will be reduced by Rs 10 while a cup of milk tea now costs Rs 90 and a plain tea costs Rs 30. Sampath however stated that the cost of short eats will not be reduced. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Excise Officers call off token strike
author: Author not found
Content: The one-day token strike planned by the Sri Lanka Excise Department Trade Union Collective will not take place today (6). Secretary of Sri Lanka Excise Department Trade Union Collective and Secretary of the Sri Lanka Excise Officers’ Association Nirosh Jayakody said this at a media briefing in Anuradhapura yesterday (5). Jayakody highlighted that incentives are paid to all officers working in the Sri Lanka Excise Department as well as departmental officers of the combined services, and that the incentive was paid for three years before being discontinued this month. “Although the administration and Finance Ministry provided some explanations, the main reason was a lack of funds to pay the incentives. We forwarded proposals to the Ministry of Finance four times, through the administration on how to get the money to pay the incentive and how to strengthen the fund from time to time.” However, no action was taken by the Ministry of Finance. As a result, we had decided to hold a one-day symbolic strike with the uniformed staff and all unions of the combined services in the Sri Lanka Excise Department on 6 April,” he said. Speaking further, he said not only should all excise offices be closed, but all liquor factories as well, but if that happened, the Government will lose approximately Rs 1 billion per day, depending on present production levels. “Several rounds of discussions took place as we were preparing to take trade union action. Then, on 4 April, discussions were held with the Excise Commissioner in the morning and with State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya and Director General of Trade Unions to the President Saman Ratnapriya in the evening. By evening, we had a satisfactory response,” he said. Claiming that Siyambalapitiya and the Excise Commissioner said a system will be prepared and finalised within a month to pay the incentives to the excise officers, he said, “After that system is completed, the payment date will be determined, and we agreed on that. Because the Government is presently unable to pay salaries, and losing tax money is also a problem, we have decided to cancel the strike scheduled for 6 April.” Jayakody mentioned that Siyambalapitiya will intervene in all future activities with regard to the matter and Ratnapriya promised that they will intervene and take necessary action as well. Thus, they will not hold the strike today and will continue to work as usual, he said. “We decided on 4 April that if this system is not put in place within a month, we will resort to strike action. If we go on strike, we will seize all of the factories that produce alcohol. Our officers are in charge of their security seals and work in their excise units. If our workers stop working, alcohol production will come to a halt on that day. There is a lot of alcohol production these days for the holiday season. Some organisations work 24 hours a day, while others work 16 hours. Every day, we estimate that between Rs 1 billion – 1.1 billion is collected as revenue. A significant amount is also made through activities such as raids,” he added. By Thisara Samal – Anuradhapura

title: ‘Irrationalprofessionals’hampered Covidcontrol efforts
author: Author not found
Content: Former Secretary to the Ministry of Covid Prevention, Primary Health Care and Epidemics, Dr. Amal Harsha de Silva, issuing a clarification on the news item ‘Gota hampered Covid control efforts’ published in Ceylon Today on Wednesday (5), said the article published did not represent the facts he had forwarded at the Covid Workshop of IHP with the World Bank held on 4 March in Colombo. “I never mentioned that former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa hampered Covid operations.” Unfortunately, his activities were hampered by unscientific and irrational professionals who gathered around him,” Dr. de Silva said. He said some of the professionals have still not accounted for their actions.  “Certain people misguided the whole Cabinet of Ministers stating that burying the Covid dead would spread the virus, which caused tremendous hardship to the public and antagonised Islamic countries which created the economic downturn. I said the President had to leave and the professionals who advised him had remained unpunished. The former President was extremely concerned about the businesses and doctors prevented opening of the country,” he elaborated. Speaking further, Dr. de Silva said defence was somewhat guided by a few professionals with unscientific approaches and he thinks it is unfair by the former President to state that he hampered the operation.  “I who have worked with many ministers think that it was a great decision taken by former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa to appoint Dr. Sudarshani Fernandopulle as the Minister to control Covid. The problem was that a group of doctors in high powered committees took many decisions in defiance of the Covid Control Ministry’s thinking. I think the former President tried a lot with many of the wrong advisors which is very unfortunate.” (DJ)

title: Corporate sector pledges Rs 525M for Suwaseriya
author: Author not found
Content: Founder of the ‘1990’ Suwaseriya ambulance service SJB MP Dr Harsha de Silva said the corporate sector has pledged Rs 525 million to support the ambulance service to continue following the request to the public to come forward to save the service. In a tweet, Dr de Silva, said the assistance of the corporate sector was recently requested due to a lack of State funds to operate the free ambulance service. Commending the assistance provided by the corporates he said Rs 525 million received for this year will support the operations of 105 ambulances. The programme to save the ambulance service has been launched by the Board and Management of the Suwaseriya ambulance service. This is due to the Treasury being unable to fully fund its operations which may lead to the service being unsustainable in 2023.  Thereby, it was launched to request corporate and individuals to provide funding for an ambulance at a cost of Rs 5 million each. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: TU leaders asked to declare assets
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara said steps are being taken to obtain assets and liabilities statements from trade union leaders who are yet to submit their declarations. Issuing a statement, Nanayakkara said yesterday (5) that trade union leaders of government and semi-government institutions are required to submit their assets and liabilities statements according to the Declaration of Assets and Liabilities Act. He pointed out that, however, no union leader has provided such a statement thus far to the Labour Secretary annually as required by law. “Therefore, the Labour Secretary is presently making an effort to obtain assets and liabilities statements from such union leaders at the earliest. The Ministry of Labour has not acted on the matter in the past. The Ministry Secretary will request such assets and liabilities statements in the future from union leaders from government and semi-government institutions,” he added. Nanayakkara said Government employees are bound by the Establishment Code. It sets out guidelines when appointing officers to trade unions. “Some employees who have worked in trade unions for twenty to thirty years have not done their assigned work, even for a single day. The people should decide whether it is correct to appoint people to trade unions in government and semi-government institutions and pay salaries for 20 years for not doing their work. Government businesses are maintained by people’s taxes. Is it fair to make collective agreements and allow such union leaders to get two or three salaries and receive millions in overtime payments even when such institutions are making losses?” queried Nanayakkara. (NV)

title: Festive shoppers warned against unruly elements
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Police have put in place a number of strategies to ensure public safety during the upcoming New Year festive season. Various plans have been devised to keep the public safe from fraudulent activities. Police advise the public when making purchases to be alert and inspect whether the goods are fit for consumption. Those who use personal vehicles and motorcycles for shopping have been advised to keep the vehicles properly locked when leaving them in designated parking areas. The public has also been warned to be wary of the spread of counterfeit currency notes by both retailers and consumers. During the holiday season, people have been asked not to leave helmets or any other belongings in parked motorcycles. People are reminded to be wary of pickpockets in crowded areas and to keep their personal belongings safe. The public has been advised not to adorn children with gold jewellery if the child is accompanying them on shopping trips. People are urged to be aware of the general price of goods and to avoid paying exorbitant prices. Furthermore, senior citizens have been asked to wear facemasks while shopping for their own safety and health. Individuals taking tours have been asked to pay attention to the weather and avoid risky activities such as bathing in dangerous waterfalls. The public who travel away from home for shopping have been asked not to share or publicise such information on social media. During the holiday season, police will conduct special operations to apprehend those driving under the influence of liquor. (TR)

title: D.V. Upul appointed Fisheries Corp Chair
author: Author not found
Content: Former Southern Provincial Minister D.V. Upul has been appointed as the Chairman of the Ceylon Fisheries Corporation. The appointment letter was handed over at a ceremony held at the Fisheries Ministry in Maligawatta on 4 April. He is the father of State Minister of Petroleum Resources Development D.V. Chanaka. State Minister of Fisheries Piyal Nishantha de Silva and State Minister of Petroleum Resources Development D.V. Chanaka were also present at the occasion. (NJ)

title: K.B.K. Hirimburegama sworn in as new Ombudsman
author: Author not found
Content: K.B.K. Hirimburegama, a retired High Court Judge, was sworn in as the Parliamentary Commissioner for Administration (Ombudsman) in the presence of President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the Presidential Secretariat on Tuesday (4). The appointment was made with immediate effect by the President under Article 156(2) of the Constitution and Section 3(1) of the Parliamentary Commissioner for Administration Act No. 17 of 1981. Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake was also present at the occasion.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Elderly couple murdered by grandson
author: Author not found
Content: An elderly couple was killed by their grandson in Navelagama, Ballaketuwa, on 4 April night. The deceased are 75-year-old and 69-year-old residents of Navelagama, Ballaketuwa. According to Police, the murder occurred following a dispute over money. A sharp object was used, they added. The suspect’s grandfather was pronounced dead on admission to the Demodara Hospital and his grandmother died while receiving treatment at the Badulla Hospital. The murderer fled the area, and Ballaketuwa Police are conducting investigations. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: S. Korea open to skilled workers
author: Author not found
Content: A high-ranking representative of the well-known South Korean company Hyundai Marine Company said he expects to provide more job opportunities to Sri Lankan youth in South Korea. A delegation including the CEO of Hyundai Marine Company Kim Byong Boo, who visited Sri Lanka to look into the interview process and training related to the selection of Sri Lankan youth for South Korean jobs, made this remark when they met Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse in Parliament on Tuesday (4). The delegation stated that the youth of this country were highly skilled and they expect to bring more trained Sri Lankan youth for jobs in the country. They further said it was important for these workers to be disciplined young persons with good qualities. They pointed out the need for the Government to intervene and provide proper vocational training in the country and send trained workers to South Korea without delay. It was also assured that the facilities and safety of the workers in South Korea will be provided to the maximum extent. There is a high demand for trained workers in ship construction and repair, electricians, welders etc. and they are entitled to high salaries, they said. The Deputy Speaker addressing the gathering requested to provide support for the construction of a fully equipped training centre to bring out skilled workers in Sri Lanka. He also said in addition to professional skills, it is expected to provide an understanding of the Korean language, culture, etc. through this programme. The delegation expressed their interest  and pointed out that they expect to provide more job opportunities in South Korea to the youth of this country. MPs Weerasumana Weerasinghe and Sampath Athukorala were also present at the occasion.

title: Expert panel to be given GA’s report
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya, on 4 April, instructed the Court Registrar, to submit the Government Analyst’s report, pertaining to the death of Janashakthi Insurance PLC Director Dinesh Schaffter, to the panel of medical experts, who were appointed to perform a fresh post-mortem inquiry. She gave this instruction, after taking into consideration a request made by the Counsel, looking into the interests of the family of the deceased.  President’s Counsel Anuja Premaratne, appearing for the aggrieved party emphasised the necessity of presenting the findings of the Government Analyst, for the consideration of forensic and medical experts, who are currently performing a fresh post-mortem inquiry into Schaffter’s demise.  Afterwards, the Additional Magistrate fixed further proceedings of the inquiry to 24 April, as the panel of medical experts sought a few weeks more to finalise their report for submission to Court. On 27 February, the Court appointed a five-member panel of medical experts, to perform a fresh post-mortem inquiry, into the death of businessman Dinesh Shaffter, in order to ascertain whether his death was a murder or a suicide. The five-member panel consists of Professor Asela Mendis (Chairman), Professor B.C.R. Perera, Professor D.H.S. Fernando and two JMO’s Dr. Siva Subramanium and Dr. B.R. Ruwanpura. They have been tasked with performing a fresh inquiry, to decide the actual cause of death of the late businessman.  The aggrieved party had identified several contradictions and inconsistencies, in the first post-mortem report, compiled by the Colombo Judicial Medical Officer. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Three killed in cab – three-wheeler collision
author: Author not found
Content: Three people were killed in a road accident that occurred in Nugayaya, Wellawaya. According to Police, the accident occurred when a cab travelling from Wellawaya to Thanamalwila collided with a three-wheeler travelling in the opposite direction. The driver of the three-wheeler, along with his wife and father, who were passengers, died at the Wellawaya Hospital. A 11-year-old, who was injured in the accident, was admitted to the Moneragala Hospital and is currently under treatment. The accident killed the 44-year-old driver of the three-wheeler, a Police Sergeant assigned to Thanamalvila Police, his 42-year-old wife, and his 70-year-old father. The cab driver involved in the accident was arrested, and further investigations revealed that he was under the influence of liquor and did not have a valid driving licence. The bodies of the victims are lying at the Wellawaya Hospital morgue. Wellawaya Police are carrying out further investigations. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Drinking water for Vavuniya
author: Author not found
Content: The Vavuniya Peraru Water Supply Project, which supplies drinking water to Vavuniya and its surrounding areas, will be expanded, Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development Jeevan Thondaman said. Minister Thondaman toured the Vavuniya Peraru Water Supply Project and held talks with officials while on an observation tour to the North. The Minister also queried about present developments and growth potential. In addition, the Minister paid a visit to the desalination and sea water purifying project underway in the Kilinochchi Vadamaradchi East Thalaiady neighbourhood. Through this initiative, plans have been made to provide drinking water to many locations, including Jaffna, Chavakachcheri, Karaveddy Kodikamam, and Puttur. “The project was to be completed at the beginning of April 2023. However, there has been a small delay as a result of the economic crisis and inflation in the country. Nevertheless, we aim to wrap up the work by the beginning of 2024. I want to express my gratitude to the hardworking staff, including the project manager. Three hundred thousand persons will have access to clean drinking water through this initiative,” the Minister added. (SRM)

title: Three arrested with Rs 93M in cannabis
author: Author not found
Content: Three suspects with Kerala cannabis worth over Rs 93 million were apprehended in the northern waters on 4 April, during a special operation carried out by the Sri Lanka Navy and Coast Guard in the sea area west of Delft Island A dinghy loaded with over 283 kg (wet weight) of Kerala cannabis was seized while the suspects were apprehended. As a result of constant search operations led by the Navy, a suspicious dinghy was intercepted in the sea area and six sacks of Kerala cannabis were found in it. The sacks contained 76 parcels of the narcotic weighing about 283.7kg (wet weight). The suspects nabbed in the operation are residents of Pesalai in Mannar who are between 19 and 51 years of age. The suspects along with the stock of Kerala cannabis and the dinghy were handed over to the Delft Police for legal action. (NV)

title: Five saved from drowning
author: Author not found
Content: The lifesavers attached to Sri Lanka Coast Guard (SLCG) lifesaving posts at the Hikkaduwa and Mirissa public beaches saved four locals and a foreigner from drowning on Saturday (1 April), SLCG said. The locals saved included two males aged 29 and 30, two females aged 27 and 29, and the foreigner saved; a Russian woman aged 31, it said. In 2023, SLCG lifesavers attached to 16 life-saving posts countrywide have rescued 69 from drowning, including 28 foreigners, SLCG said. (PA)
