title: Devotees gatherat Kelaniya RajaMaha Viharaya
author: Author not found
Content: A large number of devotees were seen at the Kelaniya Raja Maha Viharaya, engaging in religious observances at the Viharaya on Bak Poya Day (5). Bak Poya marks Lord Buddha’s second visit to Sri Lanka to advise the kings Chulodara and Mahodara who were preparing to commence a war against each other. It is said that Lord Buddha on reaching Nagadeepa, preached to the Naga tribe and made them understand the value of peace and averted war between the two kings. (Pix by Sarath Kumara)

title: Gota hampered Covid control efforts – Dr. Amal Harsha de Silva
author: Author not found
Content: The former Head of State’s involvement in Covid control made it difficult for those engaged in it to function to their fullest capacity, Secretary to the State Ministry of Primary Health Care, Epidemics and Covid Disease Control Dr. Amal Harsha de Silva said. Addressing a workshop on ‘The response of Sri Lanka’s health system to the Covid-19 pandemic,’ Dr. de Silva said yesterday (4) that the advice which had been given to former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa on several matters including Covid control had cost him (Rajapaksa) his position as the Head of State.  He said one must be very cautious when taking advice. Dr. de Silva, who was also the Secretary to the State Ministry of Covid-19 control, said while the President had been ousted by the people, there were those who had given him advice during the height of the pandemic who were doing quite well in society. Those persons were now attempting to get close to the incumbent Head of State and the Government, he cautioned. Noting that he had been instrumental in getting the private sector involved in testing for the virus, Dr. de Silva said it had seemed irrational to stop them from getting involved when it was considered okay for them to carry out open heart surgery. The Secretary to the Sports Ministry said his visit with the State Minister of Covid Control to the airport at the time had shown that certain measures and instances should have been downplayed and that advisories and governance were key to manage the situation well. Citing further incidents, he alleged that although the military involvement had been helpful, there had been instances when those medical practitioners who had examined patients with Covid were rounded up and quarantined. Meanwhile, Executive Director and Fellow of the Institute for Health Policy, Dr. Ravi Rannan-Eliya observed that even if it was democratic to use the military for pandemic prevention it should be done judiciously rather than just by issuing orders or vague instructions.  Project Investigator, Institute for Health Policy, Dr. Sanjaya Perera said the military had run 233 quarantine facilities while handling 80 per cent of arrivals in the country. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: MPs want Law College Principal summoned to Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: Several MPs yesterday (4) requested Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena to summon the Principal of Sri Lanka Law College to Parliament for defying the Parliament’s decision to allow law students to sit for the exams in their preferred languages, Sinhala, Tamil or English. “The Gazette Notification, under which a regulation was imposed, to conduct law examinations in English, was defeated in Parliament on 21 March 2023. According to that, the Law College exams cannot be held in only the English medium. However, we learn that the Law College Principal has now launched a campaign against conducting exams in the Sinhala and Tamil media,” MP Dayasiri Jayasekara stressed. “The Law College Principal cannot do such a thing. This is clearly neglecting Parliament decisions. Actions should be taken against him,” Jayasekara told the Speaker. Opposition Leader SajithPremadasa also agreed with Jayasekara on the matter. MP Vasudeva Nanayakkara said the Principal of the Law College should be summoned before the committee on privileges and ethics.   BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Fuel quota increased for the festive season
author: Author not found
Content: The existing fuel quota was increased from midnight yesterday (4) for the Sinhala –Tamil New Year festive season, on the instructions of President Ranil Wickremesinghe, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. This had been planned previously and as per estimates the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) has ordered and received the required fuel stocks to increase the fuel requirements for the festive season. Accordingly, the fuel quota for passenger three-wheelers (special) has been increased from 10 l to 15 l, three-wheelers (general) from 5 l to 8 l, motorcycles from 4 l to 7 l, busses from 40 l to 60 l, cars from 20 l to 30 l, land vehicles from 15 l to 25 l, lorries from 50 l to 75 l, quadric cycle from 4 l to 6 l, special purpose vehicles from 20 l to 30 l and vans from 20 l to 30 l.

title: Amended labour laws to be finalised next month – Manusha
author: Author not found
Content: The first draft of the Bill to replace existing complex labour laws will be finalised by the end of next month, Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara said. He said once the new draft is drawn up, it will be submitted to civil society groups, trade unions, stakeholders and to all those who form independent views for discussion on the new laws. The Minister elaborated that the public could also submit their views in this regard to his ministry and noted that ministry officials will be available to iron out any thorny issues in the draft. Nanayakkara was speaking during a media briefing held at the ministry premises yesterday (4). He maintained that amending the existing labour laws is the need of the hour if the country is to thrive in several sectors.

title: Rope in more to tax bracket to make it fair – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena says that in order to reduce the tax burden on the people, the Commissioner General of the Inland Revenue Department must bring people who are not paying taxes, at the moment, into the tax bracket. He said if taxes are collected and information is obtained through the computer network system, of the State’s main tax collecting institutions, such as the Inland Revenue Department, the Excise Department and the Customs Department, the State’s tax revenue will definitely increase. When asked if it is possible to prepare a system to subject private tutoring classes to income tax, calculate their income tax, and receive tax, he said it is possible. “If the tax net is greatly expanded, even though the income of many people will be small, the tax burden will be small and fairer,” he said. Speaking at the Cabinet media briefing yesterday, he said the tax burden would then be reduced. “There are many people in the country who are not taxed at all. Taxation was necessary in order to increase State revenue as instructed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the tax limit proposed by the IMF had to be agreed to,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Sri Lanka’s First Ten Women Gantry Crane Operators receive certificates
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s first 10 Women Gantry Crane Operators received their certificates from Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva at a function held on Monday (3) at the Ministry Auditorium. The course was conducted at the Sri Lanka Ports Authority’s (SLPA) Mahapola Ports and Maritime Academy by National Union of Seafarers Sri Lanka, and with financial aid from the International Labour Organization (ILO). The four-month training programme included both theoretical and practical sessions. At present, eight women yard crane operators who completed training at the Mahapola Ports and Maritime Academy efficiently engage in port operations at SLPA terminals. It was also revealed at the occasion, that more women gantry operators were expected to engage in port operations after successfully completing training. It is said that more private and foreign sector employment opportunities await new women gantry operators who successfully complete training courses. Expressing his views at the occasion, the Minister said a conducive environment is being created for the sector to thrive in the future. “It is a good trend that we are receiving assistance from the private sector to develop our ports. Although women in Sri Lanka generally work in more conventional areas, such as nursing, teaching, and clerical work, we are glad that we could provide them with more opportunities that go with the latest technology,” he said. He also said more women will be attracted to these opportunities in the future. Speaking via Zoom, Director, Sri Lanka Country Office of ILO Simrin Singh said, her warmest wishes were with the 10 women gantry operators who were awarded with certificates after successfully completing training. She also said as the resident representative of ILO, she was glad that ILO was able to contribute financially to this training course. Several officials of the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation, SLPA and National Union of Seafarers Sri Lanka also attended the event.

title: Additional Rs 3B allocated to purchase paddy – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has allocated an additional Rs 3 billion to purchase paddy in the 2022/23 Maha Season, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. He said previously, the Government had allocated Rs 10 billion to purchase paddy, but this sum had already been utilised. Amaraweera said President Ranil Wickremesinghe had agreed to provide additional funds to purchase paddy if necessary and accordingly the said additional amount has been allocated. Cabinet approved paddy purchases in the Maha Season through District Secretaries and Divisional Secretaries instead of the Paddy Marketing Board.Further, the Government has also taken steps to convert the purchased paddy into rice and provide 10 kg of rice per family for two months to 2.9 million low-income families.

title: Laugfs slashes gas prices
author: Author not found
Content: After Litro Gas Lanka reduced the price of a 12.5 Kg domestic gas cylinder by Rs 1000, Laugfs Gas PLC too slashed the prices of its domestic gas cylinders by a significant amount yesterday (4). Accordingly, the price of a 12.5 Kg cylinder of domestic gas will be reduced by Rs 1,290 and a 5Kg cylinder by Rs 516. Therefore, the new price of a 12.5 Kg cylinder of gas will be Rs 3,990 and a 5 kg cylinder will be Rs 1,596. Meanwhile, Litro Gas Lanka Chairman Muditha Peiris announced the price of Litro domestic gas which was reduced at midnight yesterday (4). Accordingly, the price of a 12.5 Kg cylinder of domestic gas will be reduced by Rs 1,005, a 5Kg cylinder by Rs 402, and a 2.3 Kg cylinder by Rs 183. Peiris said by lowering the prices, the new price of a 12.5 Kg cylinder of gas will be Rs 3,728, a 5 kg cylinder will be Rs 1,502, and a 2.3 kg cylinder will be Rs 700. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: SL will lose USD 10B X-Press Pearl compensation claim – CEJ
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka will lose the compensation claim of an estimated USD 10 billion if legal action pertaining to the MV X-Press Pearl ship fire is not instituted within the next 45 days, the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) said. A report published by CEJ stated that under Sri Lankan Law, the case to claim compensation has to be filed within two years of the incident, thereby before 29 May 2023. It was observed that the failure to do so would be a failure on the part of the Attorney General’s Department and the Cabinet of Ministers. “For now, there is a request for USD 6.4 billion as compensation for the harm caused to the marine environment, the shore and the neighbouring communities, tourism, fishermen, and the pollution it caused to the atmosphere. Based on legal advice, CEJ identifies that the existing legal precedents in Sri Lanka are sufficient to receive compensation which was reiterated by other professionals. However, at present, the Cabinet, the Ministry of Justice, together with the Attorney General’s Department, have taken the decision to conduct legal proceedings in Singapore, creating a sense of uncertainty. We have been informed that an Australian has advised the Government of Sri Lanka to do so and that the Singaporean authorities are already preparing for the necessary proceedings. The former and present Ministers of Justice Ali Sabry and Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe are aware of this situation. We have also learnt that Sri Lanka has borrowed USD 4.5 million to fund this endeavour,” the report stated. By Faadhila Thassim

author: Author not found
Content: The former Head of State’s involvement in Covid control made it difficult for those engaged in it to function to their fullest capacity, Secretary to the State Ministry of Primary Health Care, Epidemics and Covid Disease Control Dr. Amal Harsha de Silva said. Addressing a workshop on ‘The response of Sri Lanka’s health system to the Covid-19 pandemic,’ Dr. de Silva said yesterday (4) that the advice which had been given to former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa on several matters including Covid control had cost him (Rajapaksa) his position as the Head of State.  He said one must be very cautious when taking advice. Dr. de Silva, who was also the Secretary to the State Ministry of Covid-19 control, said while the President had been ousted by the people, there were those who had given him advice during the height of the pandemic who were doing quite well in society. Those persons were now attempting to get close to the incumbent Head of State and the Government, he cautioned. Noting that he had been instrumental in getting the private sector involved in testing for the virus, Dr. de Silva said it had seemed irrational to stop them from getting involved when it was considered okay for them to carry out open heart surgery. The Secretary to the Sports Ministry said his visit with the State Minister of Covid Control to the airport at the time had shown that certain measures and instances should have been downplayed and that advisories and governance were key to manage the situation well. Citing further incidents, he alleged that although the military involvement had been helpful, there had been instances when those medical practitioners who had examined patients with Covid were rounded up and quarantined. Meanwhile, Executive Director and Fellow of the Institute for Health Policy, Dr. Ravi Rannan-Eliya observed that even if it was democratic to use the military for pandemic prevention it should be done judiciously rather than just by issuing orders or vague instructions.  Project Investigator, Institute for Health Policy, Dr. Sanjaya Perera said the military had run 233 quarantine facilities while handling 80 per cent of arrivals in the country. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: MPs want Law College Principal summoned to Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: Several MPs yesterday (4) requested Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena to summon the Principal of Sri Lanka Law College to Parliament for defying the Parliament’s decision to allow law students to sit for the exams in their preferred languages, Sinhala, Tamil or English. “The Gazette Notification, under which a regulation was imposed, to conduct law examinations in English, was defeated in Parliament on 21 March 2023. According to that, the Law College exams cannot be held in only the English medium. However, we learn that the Law College Principal has now launched a campaign against conducting exams in the Sinhala and Tamil media,” MP Dayasiri Jayasekara stressed. “The Law College Principal cannot do such a thing. This is clearly neglecting Parliament decisions. Actions should be taken against him,” Jayasekara told the Speaker. Opposition Leader SajithPremadasa also agreed with Jayasekara on the matter. MP Vasudeva Nanayakkara said the Principal of the Law College should be summoned before the committee on privileges and ethics.   BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Fuel quota increased for the festive season
author: Author not found
Content: The existing fuel quota was increased from midnight yesterday (4) for the Sinhala –Tamil New Year festive season, on the instructions of President Ranil Wickremesinghe, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. This had been planned previously and as per estimates the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) has ordered and received the required fuel stocks to increase the fuel requirements for the festive season. Accordingly, the fuel quota for passenger three-wheelers (special) has been increased from 10 l to 15 l, three-wheelers (general) from 5 l to 8 l, motorcycles from 4 l to 7 l, busses from 40 l to 60 l, cars from 20 l to 30 l, land vehicles from 15 l to 25 l, lorries from 50 l to 75 l, quadric cycle from 4 l to 6 l, special purpose vehicles from 20 l to 30 l and vans from 20 l to 30 l.

title: Amended labour laws to be finalised next month – Manusha
author: Author not found
Content: The first draft of the Bill to replace existing complex labour laws will be finalised by the end of next month, Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara said. He said once the new draft is drawn up, it will be submitted to civil society groups, trade unions, stakeholders and to all those who form independent views for discussion on the new laws. The Minister elaborated that the public could also submit their views in this regard to his ministry and noted that ministry officials will be available to iron out any thorny issues in the draft. Nanayakkara was speaking during a media briefing held at the ministry premises yesterday (4). He maintained that amending the existing labour laws is the need of the hour if the country is to thrive in several sectors.

title: Rope in more to tax bracket to make it fair – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena says that in order to reduce the tax burden on the people, the Commissioner General of the Inland Revenue Department must bring people who are not paying taxes, at the moment, into the tax bracket. He said if taxes are collected and information is obtained through the computer network system, of the State’s main tax collecting institutions, such as the Inland Revenue Department, the Excise Department and the Customs Department, the State’s tax revenue will definitely increase. When asked if it is possible to prepare a system to subject private tutoring classes to income tax, calculate their income tax, and receive tax, he said it is possible. “If the tax net is greatly expanded, even though the income of many people will be small, the tax burden will be small and fairer,” he said. Speaking at the Cabinet media briefing yesterday, he said the tax burden would then be reduced. “There are many people in the country who are not taxed at all. Taxation was necessary in order to increase State revenue as instructed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the tax limit proposed by the IMF had to be agreed to,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Barath Arullsamy new PHDT Chair
author: Author not found
Content: General Secretary of the Ceylon Workers’ Congress and Minister of Water Supply and Plantation Infrastructure Development, Jeevan Thondaman, has appointed Barath Arullsamy as the Chairman of the Plantation Human Development Trust (PHDT). The PHDT is a prominent organisation responsible for human resource development, infrastructure and sector development of the plantation sector. The said agency comes under the Ministry of Water Supply and Plantation Infrastructure Development. Arullsamy, who is a political, trade union, social, and international activist has previously held the post of PHDT Chairman and during his tenure had achieved many milestones in uplifting the living standard of the people and was reassigned accordingly. He also holds the post of Vice President of the Ceylon Workers’ Congress. It is noteworthy that he is also in charge of the party’s International Affairs.

title: Catholic Bishops’Conference urges Govt to uphold Constitution
author: Author not found
Content: The Catholic Bishops’ Conference in Sri Lanka (CBCSL) alleged that the Government’s conduct, demonstrated by persons holding positions of responsibility amounted to interfering with the entire judicial process and undermined its independence. President and Secretary of the CBCSL, Rev. Drs. Harold Anthony Perera and J.D. Anthony Jayakody said on Monday (3) that media reports had revealed that an Interim Order had been given by the Judges of the Supreme Court regarding a fundamental rights case directing the Treasury Secretary and the Attorney General’s Department to not withhold the funds already allocated to conduct Local Government Polls in the 2023 Budget. The duo said, “It was reported that a Member of Parliament had requested the Speaker to refer the conduct of the Judges of the Supreme Court that delivered that Interim Order as a breach of Parliamentary privileges.” They alleged that the Speaker had accepted the request and made a referral to the Parliamentary Committee on Ethics and Privileges. Rev. Dr. Perera who is the Bishop of Kurunegala and Rev. Dr. Jayakody who is the Auxiliary Bishop of Colombo alleged that the State Minister had proceeded to take action based on the aforesaid Interim Order made by the Supreme Court with regard to Local Government Elections until the Parliamentary Committee concluded its probe. “In our view, such conduct directly violated the independence of the Judges to perform their powers and functions without any interference as enshrined in Article 111C of the Constitution and also threatens to disrupt the very doctrine of the separation of powers of our motherland,” they said.     Rev. Drs. Perera and Jayakody said the duty of the Government and other institutions was to respect and observe the independence of the Judiciary, while such interference demonstrated by these individuals of the Government had already been widely criticised locally and internationally as being serious and unwarranted encroachment on the Judiciary’s independence and its function within the country. They urged the Government to restrain and defend any attempts made by certain individuals under cover of privileges to curtail media institutions that were directly critical towards its (Government) activities which directly threatened to infringe on the freedom of speech and expression which were also preserved by the country’s Constitution.  (DJ)

title: EU launches GRACE Project with Euro two million grant
author: Author not found
Content: European Union (EU) together with its implementing partner World Vision launched the socioeconomic recovery project GRACE (Grassroots Conflict Prevention) at the Divisional Secretariat in Wattala on Monday (3 April), a statement on its website said yesterday (4). Wattala is one of the many communities that will benefit from this grant of two million Euros over an 18-month period, it added. The other areas of intervention will include Kalpitiya, Nawagaththegama and Mundalama (Puttalam District) and Ja-Ela (Gampaha District). Set in the broader context of EU support towards the socioeconomic recovery in the aftermath of the Covid-19 pandemic and the subsequent economic crisis, the GRACE project will support over 130,000 individuals including women and young people with training on conflict resolution and improve their income opportunities, EU said. The project will build on the medium to long-term assistance, also focusing on the promotion of early warning and conflict transformation, violent conflict resolution and economic stabilisation of vulnerable households. It will also engage faith leaders through trainings and community dialogues, the statement said. EU is also supporting another project focusing on the immediate life-saving and protection needs of households most affected by the economic crisis. Implemented by World Vision, ACTED and Save the Children, that project works with 60,000 vulnerable individuals including 4,200 households for multipurpose cash assistance (MPCA) and 840 households for cash for protection, EU said. With these interventions, percentage of households with an acceptable food consumption has already increased from 67 per cent to 78 per cent within the last few months, EU said. Meanwhile, EU Ambassador to Sri Lanka Denis Chaibi speaking at the launch of the ‘Wattala Project’ said, “Sri Lanka is in the midst of a severe crisis, which hits certain Sri Lankans harder than others. This is why the EU is working with World Vision to identify those most affected. Within these communities, the EU is paying particular attention to women and young people for them to fully contribute to cohesion efforts. We will also work with ‘natural’ mediators to mitigate the risk of tension due to the economic crisis. We will also provide support to small and medium enterprises to create new employment opportunities for the many rather than the few.” World Vision Lanka National Director Dr. Dhanan Senathirajah in his speech said, “The past few years have been very challenging for vulnerable communities. People can no longer afford food for their families and schooling for their children, which brings them higher levels of distress. World Vision Lanka welcomes this new project which looks to support families with their income opportunities and aims to build social cohesion.” (PA)

title: SLINEX-2023: Annual Maritime Exercise by the Navies of India and Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: The 10th Edition of annual Indian Navy–Sri Lanka Navy bilateral maritime Exercise SLINEX-2023 is scheduled in Colombo from 3-8 April 2023. The Exercise is being conducted in two phases; the Harbour Phase in Colombo from 3-5 April followed by Sea Phase from 6-8 April, off Colombo. The Indian Navy will be represented by INS Kiltan (Advanced Anti-Submarine Warfare Corvette) and INS Savitri (Offshore Patrol Vessel) while Sri Lanka Navy will have SLNS Gajabahu (Advanced Offshore Patrol Vessel) and SLNS Sagara (OPV). In addition, Indian Navy Chetak helicopter and Dornier Maritime Patrol Aircraft along with Sri Lanka Air Force Dornier and Bell 412 helicopters would also participate in the Exercise. The Exercise will also feature the Special Forces of the two Navies. The previous edition of SLINEX was conducted in Visakhapatnam from 7-12 March 2022. SLINEX-2023 aims to enhance interoperability, improve mutual understanding and exchange best practices/ procedures in multi-faceted Maritime operations between both Navies. The Harbour Phase would include sports fixtures, yoga sessions and cultural events which would provide an opportunity for personnel from both Navies to learn from each other, reinforce shared values and build bonds of friendship and camaraderie. Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, Commander of Sri Lanka Navy along with Vinod K. Jacob, Deputy High Commissioner, took part in the opening of SLINEX-2023 on 3 April 2023. Gopal Baglay, High Commissioner of India is scheduled to host the visit of Premitha Bandara Tennakoon, State Minister of Defence onboard the indigenous Indian Naval ships. To spread awareness and interest towards the Armed Forces both the Indian Naval ships will be kept open for a large number of visitors including schoolchildren. A coordinated Indian Navy-Sri Lanka Navy Band/Cultural Performance in collaboration with Swami Vivekananda Cultural Centre will be organised for the public at Dutch Hospital and Viharamahadevi Park on 3 and 5 April 2023. Harbour training activities, SME interaction and training at HARD simulator will also be progressed during SLINEX-23. A reception for Senior Officials from Sri Lanka will be hosted onboard the Indian Navy ships by the Indian High Commissioner on 4 April. The Sea Phase would include multi-dimensional exercises like surface and anti-air firing exercises, seamanship evaluations, helicopter and maritime patrol aircraft operations including cross deck flying, advance tactical manoeuvres, search and rescue and Special Forces operations at sea, which will further enhance the high degree of interoperability already established between the two friendly Navies. SLINEX exemplifies the deep engagement between India and Sri Lanka which has strengthened mutual cooperation in the maritime domain. Interaction between the SLN and IN has also grown significantly in recent years, in consonance with India’s ‘Neighbourhood First Policy’ and the PM’s vision of ‘Security and Growth for all in the Region (SAGAR)’.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: If eggs are sold at Rs 35 the Bakeries can reduce prices
author: Author not found
Content: All Ceylon Bakery Owners’ Association (ACBOA) said there is a possibility of reducing the price of bakery products other than bread, if the price of an egg is reduced to Rs 35. ACBOA Chairman N.K. Jayawardana noted that with the arrival of eggs from India, it is expected that the problems in the egg market will be resolved within a week. “The egg price in the local market should decrease within a week. If the egg price comes down, the price of bakery items could also be reduced, except for bread. Bakeries and hotels are still buying an egg at Rs 55,” he said. He added that there are also claims that the bakery industry has never reduced prices although fuel prices have been reduced and noted that fuel price reductions do not affect bakery production. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Kohona chairs 8th GlobalDiplomats’ Chinese Cultural Night
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lankan Ambassador to China Dr. Palitha Kohona has been designated the Chairman of the 8th Global Diplomats’ Chinese Cultural Night 2023. The spectacular event was organised by Lookwe at the Grand Ballroom of the China World Hotel recently. Addressing the gathering, Dr. Kohona praised China for having made tremendous economic progress since opening up its economy. He said that China’s successful elimination of absolute poverty, consistent with the UN Sustainable Development Goal I, was an unprecedented achievement in human history. He added that the elimination of poverty was an aspiration of all countries, to realise a world ‘where poverty, hunger and deprivation do not stalk anyone’. He also emphasised the need to deal with the threat of climate change which has to be addressed as a priority “for the sake of our children and their children”. Dr. Kohona said that Sri Lanka is stable today and it was safe and open to tourists.  It has been identified as a ‘must visit’ destination with countless world class attractions, in particular the smiling hospitality of its people. He emphasised the important Buddhist sacred sites which attracted Chinese monks and traders for millennia. Dr. Kohona also invited Chinese investors to think of Sri Lanka as a desirable offshore location, in the middle of an economically booming region, when they were considering expanding overseas. On the sidelines of the cultural night, which attracted over 600 participants from the diplomatic and business elite of Beijing, a forum was held on the internationalisation of Chinese brands and Belt and Road Country Promotion.  At this forum, Dr. Kohona also emphasised the need for Sri Lankan businesses/ products to gain wider access to the lucrative Chinese market which will contribute significantly in uplifting the poor of Sri Lanka and eliminating poverty. (SRM)

title: UNP Dharma Yathra today
author: Author not found
Content: The Dharma Yathra religious programme, organised by UNP Buddhist Committee, will be held at Siri Kotha today (5). Chief incumbent of Parama Dhamma Chethiya Maha Pirivena, Deputy Registrar of Sri Kalyani Samasri Dharma Maha Sanga Sabha and Vice President of World Buddhist Sanga Council Dr. Maitipe Wimalasara Therawill deliver sermons from 9.30 a.m. The programme will be telecast live on Facebook. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Police tear gasprotesting fishers
author: Author not found
Content: Point Pedro fishermen yesterday (3) protested near the Point Pedro Divisional Secretariat, blocking the Jaffna – Point Pedro main road, against the use of purse seines in fishing, the Point Pedro Police said. The protesters chanted slogans stating “allow the fishermen to live or let them to die”, “stop purse seines destroying the livelihood of fishermen” and “stop the use of every banned fishing gear”. The efforts made by the Point Pedro Divisional Secretariat officials and Point Pedro Police to settle the situation ended in failure and the Police used tear gas to disperse the protesters. Vehicular movements on the Jaffna – Point Pedro road were interrupted for several hours due to the protest. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: South African HR defenders want genuine Truth and Reconciliation Process in SL
author: Author not found
Content: South African human rights defenders said for the transitional justice process in Sri Lanka to be successful, the South African Government should insist on perceptions of fairness, transparency, inclusivity, and legitimacy in its dealings with Sri Lanka. The South African Government is legitimising a seriously flawed process by extending the invitation to two people who are perceived as lacking credibility and legitimacy due to their close ties to the previous regime, they said in an official statement. The South African undersigned civil society organisations, which are members of the South African Coalition for Transitional Justice (SACTJ), urged the South African Government to withdraw its invitation to Sri Lankan officials to discuss the transitional justice system in light of the country’s ongoing human rights violations. “We urge the South African Government to work with Sri Lanka instead to ensure that the Government ends the pervasive impunity for serious human rights violations, continues to tolerate dissent and resistance from civil society organisations, and fosters an environment that is conducive to an effective international justice process in accordance with the advice of various UN agencies,” seven top South African human rights defenders said in their official statement. They expressed concern about the Sri Lankan Government’s attempt to comprehend and establish credible transitional justice mechanisms in accordance with co-sponsored UN resolutions, claiming that the two Sri Lankan officials who recently visited South Africa lack credibility and legitimacy due to their close ties with former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, who is alleged to have committed gross international human rights violations. The Foundation for Human Rights, Human Rights Media Center, Khulumani Support Group, Violence Prevention Agency, Centre for the Study of Violence and Reconciliation, Open Secret, and Centre for Applied Legal Studies questioned Foreign Minister Ali Sabry and Minister of Justice Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe’s trip to South Africa on the invitation of South Africa’s Minister of International Relations and Cooperation Dr. Naledi Pandor to learn from South Africa’s experience in conflict resolution. Further, Sri Lanka’s intent on TRC is lofty and pointed out the failure of the Sri Lankan Government to ensure criminal accountability for gross human rights violations perpetrated during the 1983-2009 war. They recalled that the former President came under fire when he visited Singapore, where a case was brought against him on the basis of the principle of universal jurisdiction in Singapore for his alleged role in the gross human rights violations during the last stages of the war. They also pointed out that a separate case was brought against him in the US in 2019, during his presidency, for putting his close allies in positions of power. They also said some of the prominent persons have been sanctioned by countries including the US and Canada for their alleged involvement in the commission of gross human rights violations. Further, they said Minister Sabry, who served as the former President’s personal Attorney and represented him in numerous corruption cases while also serving as the Minister of Justice at the time, raised serious questions about a potential conflict of interest given that Gotabaya was the President at the time. The present Justice Minister at the time acknowledged that he had spoken with the Attorney General to block the arrest of the President in the Avant Garde floating armoury case. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: ACEPA urges Govt to enhance local egg production
author: Author not found
Content: The All Ceylon Egg Producers’ Association (ACEPA) urged the Government to work towards uplifting egg production in the country rather than trying to impress people with imported eggs. ACEPA Secretary Ratnasiri Alahakoon said that the hydrogen peroxide used to help extend the shelf life of the imported eggs was a chemical that was normally used to cleanse wounds. “If that was the case, how was it that the same chemical substance was not given to local egg farmers during the Covid-19 period, when they had to travel in vans and retail eggs at nine to ten rupees in fear, that the produce would pass shelf life and would have to be destroyed,” he said. “Further, are the State authorities trying to impress upon the general public it is fine to use chemicals, such as hydrogen peroxide, formalin or carbide water mixture to increase shelf life of perishable consumer products such as eggs, fish, fruits vegetables etc,” he queried. Alahakoon claimed that while egg farmers in Sri Lanka had been banned from using antibiotics as poultry feed additives, they had been asked to use Probiotics and Prebiotics. This is to prevent antibiotic resistance in animals and humans alike. However, it is a known fact that antibiotics are widely used as feed additives in chicken farms in India. He claimed that although the Bakery Owners were widely promoting the imported eggs it was highly doubtful as to how safe the Indian eggs were to be used in cakes and pastries – which are favourites amongst children.   He said that while an Indian egg had been purchased at Rs 16 each it was being retailed to the consumer at Rs 35 in Colombo and its suburbs. What needs to be found out is who benefits from the additional Rs 19. Alahakoon said that while the consumer was being made use of to promote the necessity of at least importing eggs to the country, the subject minister and his supporters are trying to impress on the people that importations would stop once the country is able to enhance local egg production, he alleged. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: EU launches GRACE Project with Euro two million grant
author: Author not found
Content: European Union (EU) together with its implementing partner World Vision launched the socioeconomic recovery project GRACE (Grassroots Conflict Prevention) at the Divisional Secretariat in Wattala on Monday (3 April), a statement on its website said yesterday (4). Wattala is one of the many communities that will benefit from this grant of two million Euros over an 18-month period, it added. The other areas of intervention will include Kalpitiya, Nawagaththegama and Mundalama (Puttalam District) and Ja-Ela (Gampaha District). Set in the broader context of EU support towards the socioeconomic recovery in the aftermath of the Covid-19 pandemic and the subsequent economic crisis, the GRACE project will support over 130,000 individuals including women and young people with training on conflict resolution and improve their income opportunities, EU said. The project will build on the medium to long-term assistance, also focusing on the promotion of early warning and conflict transformation, violent conflict resolution and economic stabilisation of vulnerable households. It will also engage faith leaders through trainings and community dialogues, the statement said. EU is also supporting another project focusing on the immediate life-saving and protection needs of households most affected by the economic crisis. Implemented by World Vision, ACTED and Save the Children, that project works with 60,000 vulnerable individuals including 4,200 households for multipurpose cash assistance (MPCA) and 840 households for cash for protection, EU said. With these interventions, percentage of households with an acceptable food consumption has already increased from 67 per cent to 78 per cent within the last few months, EU said. Meanwhile, EU Ambassador to Sri Lanka Denis Chaibi speaking at the launch of the ‘Wattala Project’ said, “Sri Lanka is in the midst of a severe crisis, which hits certain Sri Lankans harder than others. This is why the EU is working with World Vision to identify those most affected. Within these communities, the EU is paying particular attention to women and young people for them to fully contribute to cohesion efforts. We will also work with ‘natural’ mediators to mitigate the risk of tension due to the economic crisis. We will also provide support to small and medium enterprises to create new employment opportunities for the many rather than the few.” World Vision Lanka National Director Dr. Dhanan Senathirajah in his speech said, “The past few years have been very challenging for vulnerable communities. People can no longer afford food for their families and schooling for their children, which brings them higher levels of distress. World Vision Lanka welcomes this new project which looks to support families with their income opportunities and aims to build social cohesion.” (PA)

title: SLINEX-2023: Annual Maritime Exercise by the Navies of India and Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: The 10th Edition of annual Indian Navy–Sri Lanka Navy bilateral maritime Exercise SLINEX-2023 is scheduled in Colombo from 3-8 April 2023. The Exercise is being conducted in two phases; the Harbour Phase in Colombo from 3-5 April followed by Sea Phase from 6-8 April, off Colombo. The Indian Navy will be represented by INS Kiltan (Advanced Anti-Submarine Warfare Corvette) and INS Savitri (Offshore Patrol Vessel) while Sri Lanka Navy will have SLNS Gajabahu (Advanced Offshore Patrol Vessel) and SLNS Sagara (OPV). In addition, Indian Navy Chetak helicopter and Dornier Maritime Patrol Aircraft along with Sri Lanka Air Force Dornier and Bell 412 helicopters would also participate in the Exercise. The Exercise will also feature the Special Forces of the two Navies. The previous edition of SLINEX was conducted in Visakhapatnam from 7-12 March 2022. SLINEX-2023 aims to enhance interoperability, improve mutual understanding and exchange best practices/ procedures in multi-faceted Maritime operations between both Navies. The Harbour Phase would include sports fixtures, yoga sessions and cultural events which would provide an opportunity for personnel from both Navies to learn from each other, reinforce shared values and build bonds of friendship and camaraderie. Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, Commander of Sri Lanka Navy along with Vinod K. Jacob, Deputy High Commissioner, took part in the opening of SLINEX-2023 on 3 April 2023. Gopal Baglay, High Commissioner of India is scheduled to host the visit of Premitha Bandara Tennakoon, State Minister of Defence onboard the indigenous Indian Naval ships. To spread awareness and interest towards the Armed Forces both the Indian Naval ships will be kept open for a large number of visitors including schoolchildren. A coordinated Indian Navy-Sri Lanka Navy Band/Cultural Performance in collaboration with Swami Vivekananda Cultural Centre will be organised for the public at Dutch Hospital and Viharamahadevi Park on 3 and 5 April 2023. Harbour training activities, SME interaction and training at HARD simulator will also be progressed during SLINEX-23. A reception for Senior Officials from Sri Lanka will be hosted onboard the Indian Navy ships by the Indian High Commissioner on 4 April. The Sea Phase would include multi-dimensional exercises like surface and anti-air firing exercises, seamanship evaluations, helicopter and maritime patrol aircraft operations including cross deck flying, advance tactical manoeuvres, search and rescue and Special Forces operations at sea, which will further enhance the high degree of interoperability already established between the two friendly Navies. SLINEX exemplifies the deep engagement between India and Sri Lanka which has strengthened mutual cooperation in the maritime domain. Interaction between the SLN and IN has also grown significantly in recent years, in consonance with India’s ‘Neighbourhood First Policy’ and the PM’s vision of ‘Security and Growth for all in the Region (SAGAR)’.

title: Police probe into theft of gold, cash
author: Author not found
Content: Dam Street Police yesterday (3) informed Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya that they had commenced a probe into a complaint related to theft of gold items and cash, running into millions of rupees, in exchange for a concrete stone concealed in a handkerchief on the pretext of selling a gemstone. Police said they had commenced the probe, into a complaint lodged by Abdul Heiruwan, a resident of Jampettah Street, Colombo 12. They also said they had received four other complaints, related to similar incidents. The Police added that they are conducting further investigations into the theft and having perused the submissions, Magistrate Jayasuriya instructed the Police to file a progress report in Court at the next hearing. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Litro gas down by Rs 1,000 from midnight
author: Author not found
Content: The price of a 12.5 kg domestic cylinder of Litro Gas will be reduced by around Rs 1,000 from midnight today (4), Litro Chairman Muditha Peiris said. He said the new prices will be announced this morning based on the pricing formula. He said several factors, including the global drop in petrol prices and the strengthening of the Sri Lankan rupee, influenced the significant price reduction. (TR)

title: Education Ministry suspends issuing school admission letters
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Education will no longer issue letters admitting students to intermediate Grades in national schools. The Ministry yesterday (3) made a special announcement regarding student admission to intermediate Grades. The Education Ministry stated national schools will be notified after 21 April about the admission procedure of students to intermediate grades, from Grades 2 to 4 and Grades 7 to 10, in accordance with the relevant circulars. The announcement also states that until then, the ministry will not issue any letters admitting students to intermediate Grades in national schools. (TR)

title: Health Ministry refutes allegations
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Health refuted allegations that the antiviral injection Ganzyclovien and the antibiotic Linezolid, through the Asian Development Bank (ADB), were being purchased at higher prices, violating the due procurement process  Refuting allegations made by Academy of Health Professionals (AHP), a senior spokesman for the Ministry yesterday (3) said that the technical evaluation committee of the related procurement process was currently evaluating the bids. Also, the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) had set the maximum retail prices for the drugs related to this procurement process. Accordingly, the sum of Rs. 8,500 had been set for a Ganzyclovien vaccine, he said. He said the allegations made by certain associations that the Ministry was going to buy the relevant drugs at higher prices than the above-mentioned, namely the vaccine of Rs 7,000 at Rs 77,000 and the antibiotic ofRs 200 for Rs 2,200 were baseless. It is completely under the procurement process as well as the government prices. Quoting Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, the spokesman said that it was regrettable that such associations presented false and misleading information. It was also revealed, during a special discussion held at the Ministry, that Sri Lanka was currently receiving one of these medicines. Therefore, the minister instructed the relevant officials to immediately suspend the purchase of the relevant medicine under the ADB Fund. President of the AHP Ravi Kumudesh on Sunday (2) accused the Health Ministry of attempting to procure an antiviral injection which was Rs 7,000 at a whopping Rs 77,000. He noted that the same could be purchased at Rs 9,000 from a common pharmacy.   (DJ) BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Sri Lankan shortlisted for C’wealth short story prize
author: Author not found
Content: Rukshani Weerasooriya Wijemanne (38) has been shortlisted for the Commonwealth Short Story Prize 2023. Her shortlisted story ‘Principles of Accounting’ is the story of a young man, caught in a cycle of failure. He dreams of being ‘successful’, and longs to find significance. Wijemanne is one of six writers shortlisted for the Asia Prize, which was won last year by Singaporean Sofia Mariah Ma and in 2021 by Sri Lankan Kanya D’Almeida. The World’s most global literature prize showcases 28 writers from 19 countries and highlights the ‘beat and pulse’ of contemporary storytelling. Asia shortlist includes writers from Bangladesh, India, Malaysia, Pakistan, Singapore and Sri Lanka, ranging in age from 26-54. They are all new to the prize this year – none has been shortlisted before. Judges hail stories that ‘brim with the energy and urgency of the present moment’ and writers ‘who with their varied styles and strategies, stretch our sense of the real’. Stories range from fables to family dramas, tackling a range of themes and topics from violence and war to environmental damage, from love and loss to unexpected friendships. Twenty-eight outstanding stories have been shortlisted by an international judging panel for the world’s most global literature prize. The writers come from 19 countries across the Commonwealth and the shortlisted entries tackle subjects from illness, human trafficking and decay, to relationships and hope – as well as family secrets, growing up gay in a hostile world, generation gaps, bittersweet friendships, and making one’s way in the world of work. They span genres from speculative and comic fiction to historical fiction and crime. The Commonwealth Short Story Prize is awarded annually for the best piece of unpublished short fiction from any of the Commonwealth’s 56 Member States. It is the most accessible and international of all writing competitions: in addition to English, entries can be submitted in Bengali,Chinese, Creole, French, Greek, Malay, Portuguese, Samoan, Swahili, Tamil, and Turkish. Such linguistic diversity in a short story prize in part reflects the richness of the Commonwealth; not least it’s many and varied literary traditions. In 2023, 475 entries were submitted in languages other than English.

title: JAAF condemns attack on Apparel factory MD, another
author: Author not found
Content: The Joint Apparel Association Forum (JAAF) has condemned the recent attack on two persons, including the Managing Director at an apparel factory in Halpe, Katana. The Managing Director of the factory has been identified as an Omani national, currently on an observation visit to Sri Lanka. “On Thursday (30 March), a group of individuals launched a vicious and heinous attack on the Managing Director and a security official of an apparel factory in Halpe, Katana. The Joint Apparel Association Forum (JAAF) vehemently condemns this cowardly attack and calls for an impartial investigation and swift legal action from the officials in charge,” JAAF said issuing a special statement on the incident. The JAAF added, “The victims of the assault were reported to have sustained injuries after a group illegally entered the factory and broke into the residence of the Managing Director, an Omani national, who is currently on an observation visit to Sri Lanka. The factory, which is an SME, provides employment to over 300 individuals.  “As the apex body of the apparel industry, we condemn such acts of violence. We call on law enforcement authorities to act swiftly and take prompt action to uphold the rule of law and bring the instigators of this attack into custody. We empathise with those affected by the incident and request that the matter be allowed to reach a peaceful resolution in accordance with the laws of the land.”  On 30 March, a group of individuals had launched a vicious and heinous attack on the Managing Director and a security official of an apparel factory in Halpe, Katana. The group had illegally entered the factory and broke into the residence of the Managing Director, the JAAF said in a statement issued in this regard. Deeming the incident a ‘cowardly attack’, the JAAF called for an impartial investigation into the matter, adding that the relevant officials in charge must take swift legal action. “As the apex body of the apparel industry, we condemn such acts of violence. We call on law enforcement authorities to act swiftly and take prompt action to uphold the rule of law and bring the instigators of this attack into custody. We empathise with those affected by the incident and request that the matter be allowed to reach a peaceful resolution in accordance with the laws of the land”, a release issued by the JAAF said.

title: LG Polls contestant teachers left high and dry
author: Author not found
Content: About 2,000 teachers, who gave in their nominations for the Local Government Election 2023, have been forced to stay at home as the election has been delayed indefinitely, President of Sri Lanka Professional Principals’ Association (SLPPA) Sunil Premathilaka claimed. He demanded that the Minister of Education should take immediate steps to summon all teachers, who had been granted leave for the LG Polls, forthwith without shedding crocodile tears on behalf of the plight faced by scores of students here. Premathilaka said currently there is a shortage running up to 26,000 teachers in the teaching service. Due to the delayed LG Polls, a total of over 2,000 teachers who had decided to contest the election were left high and dry, he added. He said as there was yet lingering uncertainty about the staging of the LG election, it had become difficult to seek the assistance of teachers who had submitted their nominations to contest the Poll. He alleged that the Education Ministry also failed to pay the monthly salaries of teachers who had decided to contest the LG Polls, since the previous month and observed that in light of this situation it had become difficult for them to celebrate the forthcoming Sinhala-Hindu New Year. By Mithun Jayawardena

title: Former NCP Chief Minister indicted
author: Author not found
Content: The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) yesterday (3) handed over indictments to former Chief Minister (CM) of the North Central Province (NCP) S. M. Ranjith, before Colombo High Court Judge Mahen Weeraman. This was pertaining to charges against Ranjith, who has been accused of receiving a fuel allowance in excess of five million rupees, while serving as the former CM of the NCP. After the handing over of the indictment, Judge Weeraman enlarged the accused on bail in two sureties of one million rupees each and impounded his passport. He was warned by the Court not to leave for overseas till the completion of the trial and sans the Court’s consent. When the case convened, the accused was present in Court, after being noticed at the previous hearing. The Bribery Commission has charged Ranjith with having violated Provisions contained in the Bribery Act via his actions, committed between 27 September, 2012 and 31 December, 2014, while serving as the former CM of the NCP. By Hansi Nanayakkara
