title: President receives table of auspicious times
author: Author not found
Content: Following customs and traditions, the ‘Nekath Seettuwa’, the table of auspicious times for this year’s Sinhala and Tamil New Year, was presented to President Ranil Wickremesinghe by Minister of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Vidura Wickremanayake and the Department of Cultural Affairs at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (3).  Auspicious periods comprise various timings such as the sighting of the new moon, bathing rituals for the old year, New Year’s Eve, Punya Kalaya or inauspicious time, timings for cooking, working, eating, anointing, setting off for work, planting trees, and more. This was organised by the Department of Cultural Affairs of the Ministry of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs. Senior Advisor to the President on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayake, Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake, Secretary of the Ministry of Buddha Shasana Religious and Cultural Affairs Somaratne Vidanapathirana, Additional Secretary Tilak Nandana Hettiarachchi, Director (Promotion) Dr. Prasad Ranasinghe, Director of Cultural Affairs Bhagya C. Katudeniya and several others attended this event.

title: Job cheat gets 15 years in jail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (3) sentenced a bogus job agent to 15 years of rigorous imprisonment, who was convicted on 15 charges of cheating.  The suspect, identified as Pubudu Pathirana, failed to be present in Court when the case was called. Therefore, the Chief Magistrate issued an open warrant for his arrest.  He was convicted on 15 charges of cheating people to the tune of Rs 5 million, via the placement of advertisements on Internet promising employment in Japan. During the evidence given at the trial, it had come to light that the convict had operated an employment agency at Rosmead Place, Colombo 7, under the name of Roshan. It was also revealed that the convict had obtained cash amounting to Rs 1.8 million from various people, who had arrived at his agency, on the promise of offering them employment in Japan. The Cinnamon Gardens Police had filed 44 separate cases against the convict, on charges of for having hoodwinked the public by guaranteeing them jobs in Japan after posting adds to that effect on Internet, in 2017, 2018 and 2019. When the case was convened yesterday (3) the Court handed out its verdict, with regard to 15 of the 44 cases filed against the convict by the Police. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Public funds should not be taken to cover State Institution losses
author: Author not found
Content: Public funds must not be used to recover the losses of State institutions, UNP Chairman Wajira Abeywardena said. He lamented that the country has fallen into a tragic situation due to the mismanagement and imprudent economic policies of previous governments and its immature plans to change everything overnight. While addressing the media in Galle yesterday (3), Abeywardena said, President Ranil Wickremesinghe has planned to implement a short-term development plan until 2026 and a long-term plan until 2032. He also expressed confidence that if these plans are implemented accurately, Sri Lanka will become a developed nation when the country celebrates its 100th Independence Day in 2048. Tourism is one of the main sectors which bring foreign income, next to the export industry. President Wickremesinghe has taken every possible action to uplift the tourism industry. Last Friday the President visited Galle where he discussed many issues prevailing in the tourism sector in the area, Abeywardena said. The President who met with the owners of tourist hotels inquired about the plight of their businesses and the problems they face in their day-to-day operations. He also pledged that the Government is ready to provide more support and concessions to promote the tourism industry. Therefore, none should be allowed to disrupt the development of the country for their personal political gains, Abeywardena added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: House owner arrested over tenant’s murder
author: Author not found
Content: Minuwangoda Police have arrested a suspect following a tip off, over the murder of a 42-year-old man in Minuwangoda on Sunday (2). According to Police, the 42-year-old victim was a resident of Paththaduwana, Minuwangoda. The suspect is the owner of the house where the victim was living in. Initial investigation revealed the suspect had attacked the victim with a sharp object during an argument. The body of the victim lies at Gampaha Hospital Morgue following the Magisterial Inquest. Police said, further investigations will conducted following the post-mortem. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Muchena Raises Concerns Over Proposed Anti-Terrorism Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Senior Director for Regional Human Rights impact, at Amnesty International, Deprose Muchena, during his concluding mission to Sri Lanka, has expressed concern about the proposed anti-terrorism legislation that would replace the draconian Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), and that the International Monetary Funds (IMF) Agreements and terms and conditions linked to the bailout decision should be made transparent and available for public scrutiny. He said the counter-terrorism provisions must be in accordance with International Human Rights Law. Muchena concluding his six day official visit to Sri Lanka, on 2 April, met and engaged with a number of important stakeholders, including members of the government, activists, political parties, members of civil society and the International Monetary Fund (IMF), as part of his ongoing advocacy work to advance human rights in Sri Lanka and the surrounding region, besides launching the South Asia regional Amnesty International’s Annual Report 2022-23. On the International Monetary Fund (IMF) he reiterated their concerns that the bailout package for Sri Lanka, which is USD 2.9 billion must meet minimum international human rights standards and not result in cuts on vital public goods and services, at a time when Sri Lankans continue to suffer the impacts of an economic crisis. Any agreements and terms and conditions linked to the bailout decision should be made transparent and available for public scrutiny. “At a time when many actors, including some in the international community, have chosen to turn a blind eye to the urgent human rights challenges in Sri Lanka, my visit to the country was an opportunity to listen to affected communities, understand their concerns and have their lived experience guide our work to protect and strengthen human rights in the country,” he said. He added that the AI stands in solidarity with victims of human rights violations from across the island, many of whom they had met and heard their concerns, over the past few days. He said, the AI will continue to work to uphold and protect their right to freedom of peaceful assembly and freedom of expression. The victims of human rights violations in the context of the civil war and its aftermath as well as organisations working on enforced disappearances, must also urgently and genuinely be engaged by the government to hear their long-standing demands for truth, justice and reparation, he emphasised. The delegation is particularly grateful to the mothers of the disappeared from the North and the East, members of the strong and resilient Sri Lankan civil society and Aragalaya protest groups, and members of the fishing community for their time and sharing their valuable insights on a gamut of issues including the economic crisis, the right to protest, and transitional justice among others. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Indian Scholarships for estate workers’ children
author: Author not found
Content: The Government of India has been extending scholarships for the children of estate workers for G.C.E. Advanced Level, Undergraduate courses and Vocational/Technical education in Government Technical Colleges in Sri Lanka. Students who have passed the G.C.E. Ordinary Level (with minimum 6 credit passes) or Advanced Level examination and below 25 years are eligible to apply for the scholarship. High Commission of India now invites applications for the award of these scholarships. Application forms could be downloaded from the website – www.hcicolombo.gov.in – or obtained physically from the High Commission (No.36-38, Galle Road, Colombo-03) and the Assistant High Commission of India (01A, Mahamaya Mawatha, P.O. Box 47, Kandy). Applicants are requested to submit the completed application forms along with photocopies of birth certificate, result sheet of G.C.E ‘O’ Level or ‘A’ Level, latest salary slip of parents and Estate Superintendent’s certificate regarding parent’s occupation. Duly completed forms may be submitted physically or by post to ‘Honorary Secretary, CEWET c/o High Commission of India, P.O. Box 882, Colombo-03’ before 29 April 2023.

title: President meets DG of Indian Good Governance Centre
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe met Bharat Lal, Director General of the Indian National Centre for Good Governance (NCGG), at the President’s official residence at Paget Road on 1 April. Lal visited Sri Lanka to discuss potential ways to enhance the country’s civil service and improve government institution performance by implementing effective monitoring measures. During the meeting, Lal shared India’s success in incorporating Information Technology into public service delivery, which resulted in significant progress and cost savings. The President requested Lal’s assistance in setting up a University of Governance and Public Policy in Sri Lanka.Also present at the meeting were President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake and Indian High Commissioner Gopal Baglay.

title: Tons of coding talent on display at Real Hack 4.0
author: Author not found
Content: 10QBIT was the Diamond Sponsor of Real Hack 4.0, the foremost Inter-University Hackathon, organised by the Software Engineering Students Association (SESA) and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) Student Branch of the University of Kelaniya. In the first phase of the Hackathon, all teams competed virtually in a 24-hour endurance competition conducted on HackerRank, an online platform. Fifteen teams from government and private universities; representing the Universities of Moratuwa, Peradeniya, Colombo, Jaffna, Sri Jayewardenepura, Informatics Institute of Technology (IIT) and Sri Lanka Institute of Information Technology (SLIIT) qualified for the final Hackathon. Their task was to create a patient monitoring system for the health sector. Team ‘The_ChiMerRa’ from the University of Colombo School of Computing won the coding challenge. Team ‘KernelPanic’ from the University of Moratuwa took second place while Team ‘Archtype2K’ of the Sri Lanka Institute of Information Technology came in third. Hackathon judges included Dinuja Wickramarachchi and Yohan Corera from 10QBIT. 10QBIT’s educational partner Aqcellor, which is an accelerator programme and knowledge platform, also participated. “Our team was thrilled to see the enthusiasm and curiosity of the students, who asked thoughtful questions and showed a genuine interest in the Aqcellor Entrepreneurship Programme. We were impressed by the innovative ideas and projects that were being developed during the hackathon,” stated Sharika Mubarack, Aqcellor Co-Founder and President of South-East Asia. Aqcellor is committed to supporting and empowering the next generation of entrepreneurs through its Entrepreneurship Programme and provides opportunities for individuals to develop their skills and turn their ideas into reality. Sanju Hettigedera, GM, Aqcellor, Sharika Mubarack, Chatura Madhumal, Yohan Corera, Dinuja Wickramarachchi, Celina Caren, Iresha Aluthge and Subarshan Thiyagarajah represented 10QBIT and Aqcellor.

title: Real-Time Search and Rescue Exercise conducted in Panadura
author: Author not found
Content: A comprehensive Real-Time Search and Rescue (SAR) Exercise was conducted, along the shoreline of the Panadura Beach recently, by No. 07 Squadron in collaboration with the Regiment Special Forces (RSF) personnel of No. 04 Search and Rescue Training course. Pilots, RSF personnel and Air Gunners along with RSF instructors, took part in this training exercise conducted by the Regiment Special Forces Training School with the participation of a Bell 212 helicopter from No. 07 Helicopter Squadron at SLAF Base Hingurakgoda and two boats with lifesavers from the Rapid Action Boats Squadron Sri Lanka Navy, combat diving personnel from the RSF Wing and Navy were deployed at Panadura Beach for this real-time Search and Rescue exercise. The training programme included Winch Operations and Rope Rescue Operations, which are used to search and recover victims in flood situations and at sea as well as seafarers in distress. The RSF Rescue teams were deployed at many SLAF establishments, including all helicopter squadrons, to conduct SAR missions in the country and they conducted many Search and Rescue operations to save the lives of victims. The exercise was conducted under the supervision of the Commanding Officer of No. 7 Helicopter Squadron, Wing Commander Sameera Vidanapathirana and the Commanding Officer of the Regiment Special Forces Wing, Wing Commander Sumith Bandara, who led the training programme under the guidance and direct supervision of Director General Air Operations, Air Vice Marshal Sampath Wickramaratne and Director General Ground Operations, Air Vice Marshal Waruna Gunawardana.

title: Two arrested with banned agrochemicals
author: Author not found
Content: Two persons were arrested with agrochemicals, that were prohibited from being imported into Sri Lanka, during a raid conducted by the Divulapitiya Police. The arrested suspects are 40 and 45-year-old residents of Wellawaya and Diyatalawa. According to the Police, the suspects were apprehended while transporting a load of prohibited agrochemicals, in a lorry, without the approval of the Registrar of Pesticides. According to Police, approximately 1,950 packets of various weights of various types of agrochemicals were seized, with a total value of approximately Rs 1,672,500. Divulapitiya Police are continuing with investigations. BY Amra Liyakath

title: ‘Guwan Hamuda Herali Perali’ takes off
author: Author not found
Content: The first phase to plant three million jackfruit trees across the country, under the theme Guwan Hamuda Herali Perali, was launched on 1 April at the Anuradhapura Air Force Base under the patronage of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. This programme has been implemented in conjunction with the Government’s food security programme with the aim of creating a local and foreign jackfruit market and to promote jackfruit among the Sri Lankan people. Under this programme, 75,000 jackfruit trees are expected to be planted within this year. The book ‘Guwan Hamuda Herali Perali’ written about the jackfruit plantation was also presented to the President. In addition to jackfruit cultivation, this book also contains information on related products. Minister of State for Defence Premitha Bandara Tennakoon, President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayake, Secretary of the Ministry of Defence General Kamal Gunaratne (Rtd)  and several others attended the event.

title: State sector salaries, pensions, Samurdhi by 10 April
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya assured that State sector salaries, pensions and Samurdhi allowances would be paid by 10 April. He said President Ranil Wickremesinghe confirmed in the Budget 2023 speech that there will be a special allowance for the State sector in the fourth quarter of 2023. Addressing the media in Kegalle, he said settling salaries, pensions, and allowances was a huge burden on the Government’s cash flow, but the President has directed that all these must be paid. “In light of the Sinhala, Tamil New Year, State employees will receive their April salaries before 10 April 2023. Paying salaries, as well as pensions and the Samurdhi allowances, could be a significant drain on cash inflows in April. However, the President has directed the Finance Minister to pay these salaries, pensions, and allowances,” he said. In addition, he said they will balance the cash inflow and expenses using all financial strategies. “This also demonstrates that Sri Lankan State employees are perceived and treated differently. In the Budget 2023, the President also stated unequivocally that a special allowance will be given to State employees at the end of this year’s quarter, and that it will happen at any cost,” he added. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Minister pays surprise visit to BIA
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva pointed out that private sector has been facilitated to construct warehouse facilities, to store 35,000 metric tonnes of aviation fuel, to resolve the aviation fuel issue. The Minister conducted an surprise inspection tour of the BIA on 31 March, to inspect these developments. A special discussion was also held with airport security officials and authorities on further strengthening airport security. The number of tourists arriving in Sri Lanka is increasing, as the tourist season begins, potentially causing passenger congestion, particularly at the arrivals terminal of the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA). In a bid to address the issue, airport management has worked to maximise facilities by managing available space in the terminal and airport. As a result, there are now 25 immigration and emigration counters at the arrivals area. Meanwhile, in addition to the existing two On Arrival Visa counters, two new counters have been set up and the space for customs operations has been increased. The relocation of the airport duty-free shopping complex to a more convenient location has improved service to passengers arriving at the airport. The passenger lounges now have better amenities. The Minister said Visa scan machines will be installed at the airport by next year. He said the new measures would reduce passenger congestion at the airport and would also include modern technology to make airport operations easier. “We have also taken steps to implement a Management System at both the airport and the Port of Colombo. Their progress has been slowed in the past due to the Covid – 19 pandemic. However, the current environment is ideal for launching these activities,” the Minister said. Commenting on the expansion of constructions of the second terminal at the airport, the Minister said that the Japanese Government stopped the expected loan facility with the statements made by the Central Bank that the country is bankrupt. “However, after reaching  successful agreements with the IMF, the international community has now recognised us an able economy. Therefore, we hope to re-establish discussions with the Japanese Government for aid to start constructions of the second terminal,” the Minister said. Airport & and Aviation Services Sri Lanka Ltd.  Chairman  – Maj. Gen. G.A. Chandrasiri (Retd.),  eputy Chairman – Dr. Ajith Mendis, several officials of the airport including  its security staff were present.

title: Seek SC opinion if anyone believes ATB violates FR– Wijeyadasa
author: Author not found
Content: If anyone believes that the proposed Anti-Terrorism Bill (ATB) violates the people’s fundamental rights, they can seek the Supreme Court’s opinion on the Act, Minister of Justice, Prisons Affairs, and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe asserted. He said those who oppose the Act have two weeks to file a petition with the Supreme Court and the Government would provide judicial assistance if necessary. He also said if someone claims that there is a better Act and that this Act should be repealed, the Government is willing to investigate those new ideas too. He said terrorism could be launched at an unknown time. Meanwhile, sources have confirmed that the Anti-Terrorism Bill will be introduced in Parliament this month. Many individuals and groups criticised the bill, claiming that it could jeopardise the public’s fundamental rights. Meanwhile, the International Commission of Jurists (ICJ) has expressed concern over the proposed Anti-Terrorism Bill. Issuing a statement the ICJ said it is extremely concerned, in particular, by clause 4(1)(a) of the Bill, which, if adopted in its current formulation, would introduce the death penalty for “the terrorism offence of murder”. “Purported threats to national security, whether or not arising in connection with acts of ‘terrorism’, should not be used as a justification for the death penalty,” ICJ’s Senior Legal Adviser Livio Zilli said issuing the statement. The Bill does feature certain improvements on the PTA. However, the ICJ considers that the Bill’s other problematic aspects clearly outweigh the positives, the statement noted. In addition, the ICJ expressed particular concern over the overbroad and vague definition in clause 3 of “acts of terrorism” that can be interpreted in a manner that stifles dissent and to crush peaceful protests. It also pointed out that clause 16 identifies disobeying any direction issued under the Act as a “terrorist offence”. This creates a fresh category of offences likely to be misused by the present government and future administrations against any kind of opposition. “If enacted as currently formulated, these vague and overbroad offences, similar to and building up on those contained in the PTA, are open to abuse and, as such, they violate Sri Lanka’s international legal obligations and the country’s own constitutional guarantees under Article 13,” Zilli added. Highlighting that the ICJ has consistently called for the repeal of the Prevention of Terrorism Act, the ICJ renewed its call on Sri Lanka to repeal the PTA and immediately halt attempts to replace it with an even worse piece of legislation. BY Kumud Upul Shantha

title: Nawaloka Medicare expands healthcare services
author: Author not found
Content: Nawaloka Medicare (Pvt.) Ltd opened its new building in Negombo, on 28 March 2023. The seven-storey facility, which is located in the heart of the Negombo city, boasts modern and state-of-the-art technology and is well-equipped to serve the healthcare needs of the local community. Nawaloka Medicare (Pvt.) Ltd Chairman Harshith Dharmadasa said, “We are delighted to announce the opening of our new building in Negombo. This state-of-the-art facility is a testament to our commitment to providing world-class healthcare services to the people of Sri Lanka.” The new building is spread over a property size of 30,000 square feet, fitted with modern interior designs and state-of-the-art equipment. It offers a range of services, including channel consultations, inpatient rooms, laboratory services, an opthalmology unit, a dedicated pharmacy, and an optical centre in partnership with Vision Care, a spokesman said. Nawaloka Medicare (Pvt.) Ltd’s laboratory chain is another vital component of the company’s healthcare services. The main laboratories are located in Negombo, Gampaha, Kurunegala, Homagama, Kotahena, Batticaloa, Trincomalee, and Wennappuwa. Care labs provide over 1000 services, and there are more than 20 company-owned collecting centres all over the island. The opening of the new building is a significant milestone for Nawaloka Medicare (Pvt.) Ltd, and it demonstrates the company’s continued dedication to providing the highest quality healthcare services to the people of Sri Lanka. The new facility in Negombo is set to play a vital role in the healthcare sector in the region, providing the latest technology and modern infrastructure to support a wide range of healthcare needs, the spokesman said.

title: Medical specialists advise to increase fluid intake
author: Author not found
Content: People should be cautious because the high temperatures in the afternoon these days can cause a variety of complications, Dr. Renuka Jayathissa, Consultant Medical Nutritionist, Head of the Department of Nutrition at Medical Research Institute said. She said drinking more water than usual, eating melons, bananas, and fruits, avoiding strenuous work, limiting sun exposure, and travelling with an umbrella should be the focus these days. Dr. Jayathissa said children under the age of five should be given at least two cups of water each day, school-going children should be given six cups of water each day, and adults should be take at least ten cups of water each day. Dr.Jayathissa added that because the salinity in the body increases with high temperatures, fruits like melons and bananas should be consumed more frequently to replenish these salts. She said was speaking at a media briefing in Colombo. Athula Karunanayake, Director General of Meteorology said the prevailing hot weather will last until the end of April. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: COPE finds access to vocational training limited
author: Author not found
Content: Only one-fourth of GCE Ordinary Level and GCE Advanced Level dropouts have access to vocational training. This was recently revealed at the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE). It was revealed during the meeting that only 105,000 opportunities are available for nearly 500,000 O/L and A/L dropouts. Although the courses offered by the Sri Lanka Vocational Training Authority (VTA) should be prepared in parallel to the requirements of the international job market, the methods used by the VTA, to conduct research on course development, are outdated, it was also revealed. Officials of VTA were summoned before the COPE to discuss the Auditor General’s reports on VTA for years 2017 and 2018. The COPE instructed the VTA to immediately enhance the quality of the researchers according to the global standards and provide a report within three months. Meanwhile, the committee also questioned the conflict of interest caused by the VTA Chief Accountant as he holds the post of Internal Auditor of the authority as well. It was revealed that after the suspension of the VTA Director General the post is still vacant. Procedural impropriety was found when the committee questioned who was responsible for the signing of cheques for salaries. BY Anuradha Herath and Krishan  Pathirath Jayasuriya

title: WILL NOT PERMIT LAW AND ORDERTO BE VIOLATED DURING MYTENURE – PRESIDENT
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe assured that no one will be allowed to violate the country’s law and order during his presidency. He also said he will prioritise doing what is right over doing what is popular, and that presenting popular ideas can lead to the destruction of the country. As the Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces, the President said this during his address to the Tri-Forces, Police Officers and other rankers at the Air Force Base in Anuradhapura. The President said, no one is entitled to engage in violent protests on the streets, but political parties had the right to express their opinions or criticise him in a peaceful manner. He said, the importance of doing the right thing, and said the International Monetary Fund (IMF) agreement was tabled in Parliament to assess whether parliamentarians had the courage to make the right decisions for the betterment of the country. Wickremesinghe referred to the IMFagreement as an example and expressed his expectation for everyone’s assistance to make the IMF programme successful. He also said if the country adopts a fresh approach and embarks on a new journey, it can achieve significant development within the next 25 years. The President asserted that Sri Lanka will win the economic war, similar to the successful fight against terrorism, adding that measures would be taken to establish economic independence in the country. He acknowledged that the Armed Forces and Police will continue to play a crucial role in achieving economic independence, and also assessed the actions of the Armed Forces and Police in maintaining law and order during the previous year.  He expressed his gratitude to the Armed Forces for fulfilling their responsibility, as without their efforts, Sri Lanka would have become an anarchic State. He also said the ongoing competition between world powers was affecting the Indian Ocean, and he intends to take action as the President to protect Sri Lanka from this influence. The President said, future military situations can be shaped by technology and knowledge, unlike in the past. He highlighted the need for the Armed Forces and Police to be equipped with modern technology and knowledge to overcome future challenges. The President initiated the Defence 2030 programme, aiming to strengthen the Defence Forces of Sri Lanka. Wickremesinghe also announced that stringent laws will be introduced to combat the drug scourge, and no amnesty will be granted to drug offenders. The President said he had instructed the Minister of  Law and Order Tiran Alles, and Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe to take strict action against such offenders and utilise the support of the Armed Forces in this effort. Minister of State for Defence Premitha Bandara Tennakoon, Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of Staff to the President Sagala Ratnayake, Secretary to the Ministry of Defence General Kamal Gunaratne (Rtd), Chief of Defence Staff General Shavendra Silva, Army Commander Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage, Air Force Commander Air Marshal Sudarshan Pathirana, Navy Commander Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, Inspector General of Police C.D. Wickramaratne and around 1,200 other rankers of the Tri-Forces and Police were present on this occasion.

title: Restoration of 497 abandoned water tanks begins
author: Author not found
Content: Restoration of 497 tanks in 11 districts that had not been renovated in six or seven decades began on 31 March, with World Bank assistance of USD 44 million. Restoration of 72 tanks in Trincomalee District and 29 tanks in Anuradhapura District began under the leadership of Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera. The Minister visited the Divulwewa and Palugaswewa tanks in Gomarankadawala on 1 April. This restoration began as part of the Ministry of Agriculture’s Climate Smart Irrigation Agriculture Project (CSIAP). Amaraweera said, the goal of this restoration programme is to provide water to farmers who lack water for cultivation, particularly due to climate change. The Minister also directed officials of the Climate-Friendly Irrigated Agriculture Project to prioritise cultivation of additional food crops over paddy cultivation. Thus, seeds, technology, and financing to cultivate additional food crops such as green gram, cow pea, soybeans, maize, and kurakkan will be made available. This project identified 870 abandoned tanks that have never been restored, and 497 of them will be restored this year. The Minister also said, the Department of Agrarian Development will restore another 30 tanks this year and Rs 300 million has been allocated for this purpose.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Minor tremor off Beruwala coast
author: Author not found
Content: A minor tremor of 3.7 magnitude was felt in the seas off the coast of Beruwala yesterday (30). The tremor was felt around 1:02 p.m. yesterday, about 24 kilometres off the coast of Beruwala. However, the Geological Survey and Mines Bureau (GSMB) confirmed that there is no tsunami threat.

title: First stock of Indian eggs released to bakeries
author: Author not found
Content: The first stock of eggs, which was imported from India via the Sri Lanka State Trading Corporation, was released to the local market at the SPET R Storage facility in Kolonnawa yesterday. The first such stock was released to owners of local bakeries, while the head of the All Ceylon Bakery Owners’ Association N.K. Jayawardene stated that a stock of one million eggs had been distributed among the member unions at Rs 35 each. He stated that the entire stock of eggs had been brought to the country with the approval of the relevant State institutions. Jayawardene added that the egg price would come down even further in the coming weeks and noted that his association will distribute eggs to hotels, restaurants and canteens at an affordable price. BY Prasanga Pavuluhewa – Katunayake

title: Two ContemptPetitions againstTreasury Secy for considerationon 22 May
author: Author not found
Content: Two Petitions seeking Contempt of Court charges against Secretary to the Treasury, Mahinda Siriwardana, over failure to comply with the Supreme Court Order to release funds to conduct the Local Government Election, were fixed for consideration on 22 May. This was when the Petitions filed by Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) General Secretary Ranjith Madduma Bandara and National People’s Power (NPP) MP Vijitha Herath were taken up by five-Judge Supreme Court Bench chaired by Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya yesterday (30). The Petitions were filed seeking an order declaring that the non-provision of adequate funds to conduct the LG Election, is a violation of rights guaranteed by the Constitution and that he should be convicted and punished for the act of contempt of Court for disobeying the previous order of the Supreme Court.  They further sought to declare that the funds allocated to the Election Commission for conducting elections, other than parliamentary elections, as per the Activity Budget Estimates for the fiscal year of 2023 and/or the Budget for the year 2023 be disbursed in a due manner in order to enable the Election Commission to hold the Local Government Polls 2023. They also sought an order to issue an interim order, restraining the Secretary and their officials and any other State functionary from withholding any funds allocated for the purpose of conducting Local Government Polls 2023 until the final determination of the Application. By Faadhila Thassim

title: SC orders AG to submit documents on Jude Jayamaha’s Pardon
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (30) ordered the Attorney General to submit documents pertaining to the presidential pardon granted by former President Maithripala Sirisena, to Royal Park murder convict, Jude Shramantha Jayamaha. This was when the Fundamental Rights (FR) Petition, filed by the Women and Media Collective, challenging the Presidential Pardon, was taken before Supreme Court Justices Janak de Siva, Yasantha Kodagoda and S. Thurairaja. Jayamaha was sentenced to death for the murder of Yvonne Jonsson at the Royal Park Condominium Complex in Rajagiriya in 2005, after which he was later granted Presidential Pardon by Sirisena in 2019. Previously the Supreme Court issued an interim injunction preventing Jayamaha from leaving the country until the final determination of the case. By Faadhila Thassim

title: Shanakiyan confronts Pillaiyan on land issues in the East
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Rural Road Development and the Leader of the Tamil Makkal Viduthalai Pulikal (TMVP) Sivanesathurai Chandrakanthan, alias Pillaiyan, and Ilankai Tamil Arasu Katchchi Batticaloa District MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam had a heated argument at the Batticaloa District Secretariat over land issues. Shanakiyan and his supporters charged into the District Secretariat following a sit-in protest, yesterday (30), joining those who were victimised by the State Minister’s alleged land grab. He also told his supporters that next time they will have their meals inside the District Secretariat as a protest.  He said, Pillaiyan is not ‘Mother Theresa’, but a man who went to prison and also used his photo of being arrested to gain political mileage. He said people were cheated over his photos of being arrested. “He is now taking all the lands belonging to the people and working closely with few government officials to take over land under the Mahaweli Development Scheme.” MP Shanakiyan accused Pillaiyan of engaging in various atrocities against the Eastern people, such as giving lands to his political allies in the Batticaloa region and taking over land under the Mahaweli Development Scheme. Shanakiyan also alleged that Pillaiyan does not hold any meetings at the Divisional Secretariat level and is working closely with government officials to give land to his supporters in a place called Ramar Theevu in Vakarai and Mayilaththamadu and many other areas. The MP also alleged that Pillaiyan is ‘using’ the District Secretariat as his TMVP office for his political activities. Shanakiyan claimed that Pillaiyan has taken land in the name of ‘Chandrakanthi’ and has offered prawn farming to his political supporters, which has resulted in over 700 families being deprived of their livelihood. Shanakiyan and some protesters forcefully opened the gate of the District Secretariat, but the Police pushed them back. Pillaiyan reportedly commented that if someone gatecrashes, that is how they should be dealt with. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Prof. Jeewandara only Sri Lankan nominatedfor BSI Award
author: Author not found
Content: Director of the Department of Allergy, Immunology and Cell Biology of the University of Sri Jayewardenepura, Prof. Chandima Jeewandara has been shortlisted for the Early Career Research Excellence Award conferred by the British Society for Immunology (BSI). Prof. Jeewandara is the only Sri Lankan national to be nominated for the 2023 BSI Immunology Awards, which aims at celebrating the remarkable achievements of individuals and teams shaping the future of immunology. He is among five other finalists announced for the BSI Early Career Research Excellence Award. Prof. Jeewandara has been a member of the BSI since 2012. The winners shortlisted for the six BSI awards – Research Excellence Award, Early Career Research Excellence Award, Outstanding Team Award, Diversity and Inclusion Award, Public Engagement Award and Immunology Teaching Excellence Award – will be announced on 20 April  at the ‘Transforming the Immunology Landscape’ event during the BSI Immunology Awards networking reception and ceremony.

title: Anti-Corruption Act not drafted at IMF behest
author: Author not found
Content: The Government had drafted the Anti-Corruption Act not at the behest of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), but with the genuine motive of overcoming corruption and fraud in this country, Minister of Justice, Prisons Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said. He said the Government was looking to gain the support of all and sundry towards the ratification of the proposed Act and to end the sordid culture of corruption and fraud in Sri Lanka. He remarked that the decision taken by the Government to seek the intervention of the IMF to get the country back on the rails economically was shrewd on the part of the President. The Minister opined that as per provisions contained in the newly proposed Counter Terrorism Bill, suspects could only be detained with the consent of the Judiciary and not otherwise. He also challenged those who oppose the Counter Terrorism Bill to prove as to how the Government could stifle the country’s trade union sector by using the new Bill. Dr. Rajapakshe made these comments during a media conference held at his Ministry with regard to the submission of the new Anti-Corruption Act to Parliament and related issues.

title: Hotel manager dies of gunshot injuries
author: Author not found
Content: A hotel manager who had been injured in a shooting incident, in Weligama, had succumbed to his injuries at dawn yesterday (30) while being treated in the Matara Hospital ICU. The hotel manager had been admitted to the hospital after he had been shot at by an unknown group that had arrived in a motor car in the night of 29 March. Initial inquiries conducted into the shooting had revealed that his assailants had targeted him two years ago as well and a sibling of his had sustained injuries. Police added that the assailants had used a T-56 Rifle for the shooting and they suspect that the incident could be related to underworld activity.   By Dinithi Wijesundara and Udaya Ranaweera (Matara)

title: 2.26 million Sri Lankans Not Eating Enough
author: By October 2022, 2.26 million of the country’s population had stopped consuming adequate food, owing to the economic crisis, a report issued by the Hector Kobbekaduwa Agrarian Research and Training Institute revealed.
Content: According to the report, in 2021 and 2022, the demand for Kohila had increased to 45 per cent as most have used whatever vegetable they could get hold of. The consumption of beans however has decreased by 30 per cent, carrots by 29 percent, pumpkin by 27 per cent, Brinjal by 27 per cent, and leafy vegetables by 10 per cent. It was also revealed that over 38 per cent of the country’s population reduced their food intake and 45 per cent reduced the frequency of food intake. Further, 68 per cent of the estate sector spent most of their daily earnings on food, while 75 per cent of the people in Ratnapura, Ampara, Matara, Hambantota districts have spent all their income on food. The relevant report titled ‘Economic Crisis and Household food Security in Sri Lanka- 2022’ focused on the impact of the economic crisis on households and revealed the impact on food consumption patterns of people owing to the economic crisis. Further, according to the report, 43 per cent of the urban sector, 52 per cent of the rural sector and 67 per cent of the plantation sector suffered from food insecurity and by the fourth quarter of 2021, household consumption of adequate food had dropped to 3.4 per cent. Over 25 per cent in urban areas, three per cent in rural areas and seven per cent in plantation did not receive protein-rich food, the report revealed. 66 per cent in urban areas, 46 per cent in rural areas and 41 per cent in plantation areas are deficient in vitamin A food. The report further revealed that 78 per cent of the plantation sector did not consume meat and fish The Hector Kobbekaduwa Agrarian Research and Training Institute released five reports including one on the research carried out regarding the ban on chemical fertiliser yesterday (29). Other researches focused on the impact on households due to the economic crisis, and recommendations to prevent crop damage caused by wild animals.

title: Activity-based English programme launched for Grade 1
author: Author not found
Content: The Education Ministry yesterday (30) launched an activity-based oral English Language programme for Grade 1 students, with the goal of providing students with practical speech training and building their confidence from the first day of school. Speaking at the event, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha emphasised the importance of English as a learning tool, as well as the importance of a good education, in order to be prepared for future professional fields in the country. According to him, the Ministry of Education has already trained 13,800 primary school teachers for the programme. Premajayantha said, no professional can continue to rely on previous knowledge and by knowing today what will happen tomorrow through updated knowledge of English, which is very important as a link language. He said this is important in providing an education suitable for the future professional field in Sri Lanka. “My expectation is to provide practical speech training, so that it can be handled without hesitation or nervousness and approximately 13,800 primary teachers have been trained so far. Apart from a few schools, English medium education did not exist in the country after 1962 and in the year 2000, GCE Advanced Level subjects were taught in the English medium to some extent, and now more than 550 schools above Grade six teach science, commerce, and arts subjects in the English medium,” he noted. He also claimed that in international schools in Sri Lanka, local and foreign children are educated in English from the start, and that the field of foreign employment in the future is largely open to them. In order to close the gap, he stressed that English language education will be expanded in Government schools and that this programme will be integrated with the compulsory English subject that is taught in grades two and three beginning next year. Under the patronage of Premajayantha, the programme was launched at the Primary Section of Samudradevi Balika Vidyalaya. In addition, Premajayantha said there is no possibility of neglecting the Sinhala language in violation of the constitutional law that states that basic education from Grades 1-5 should be provided in the mother tongue. “It is hoped that parents’ expectations will bear fruit, allowing children to open up to the world ahead. A pleasant environment will be created in the classroom for both the teacher and students to engage in practical activities and happily engage in the learning-teaching process. Educators should be on the lookout for friendly and enjoyable strategies to teach subjects such as mathematics and the environment in the same way through the new STEAM – Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics – process that will be implemented in the education sector in Sri Lanka in the future,” he noted.

title: New academic facility opened at SLPA
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva yesterday (30) opened a new academic facility in the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA). This new facility, located at the Mahapola Ports and Maritime Academy, is named, ‘SAYURA’. It consists of the latest facilities to create new training courses and opportunities for trainees in the ports and maritime sector. It was highlighted that the Mahapola Ports and Maritime Academy will conduct courses according to international standards for SLPA employees and those who seek employment opportunities in the commercial shipping sector. The Minister, after recognising the need to modernise the maritime education facility, ordered the construction of the new educational premises. The Minister said that he was glad to have such opportunity to expand the port training centre enabling provision of new knowledge to create new employment opportunities that bring foreign exchange to the country. He also said that it was also right time to remember the Late Lalith Athulathmudali who pioneered the establishment of the Mahapola Training Academy and who made an invaluable service to the development of the port sector in Sri Lanka. “Professionals and employees serving at the port must update their knowledge at a frequent pace in order to keep up with a vastly developing sector with new knowledge, innovations and modern technologies. Therefore, the port training facility should perform a pioneering task in this area. It should take measures to strengthen the recognition and credibility placed by the international port community in the Port of Colombo located at an extremely important geo-strategic point,” he said. The Minister also said that he had already discussed with the Shipping companies to offer priority for pass-outs from the Mahapola training centre when providing jobs in the sector. The Minister highlighted that a programme should be arranged to provide students with training for practical knowledge in tugs and other vessels. “Steps will be taken to recruit women gantry crane operators to utilise young spirit to boost productivity in the port sector and also as pointed out by the International Labour Organization,” he said. Here, it was emphasised that more new disciplines should be introduced at the Mahapola training centre along with its expansion and the facility should be upgraded as a Maritime Academy. Secretary to the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K. D. S. Ruwanchandra, SLPA’s Managing Director Susantha Abeysiriwardena, Director (Human Resources) Nalin Aponso, Director (Security) Major General Sudath Perera (Retd), Acting Director (Logistics) G. Zavia Miskin, Harbour Master Captain Nirmal P. Silva, Chief Manager (Training) S. H. Thilakapala, a number of Executive Officials, staffs and students under training and port trade union representatives attended the event.

title: SLAF Prize Giving
author: Author not found
Content: A prize giving ceremony organised by the Seva Wanitha Unit of the Sri Lanka Air Force was held under the aegis of Air Force Commander Air Marshall Sudarshana Pathirana at the Air Force Headquarters yesterday. Via the prize giving ceremony the Sri Lanka Air Force appreciated the 339 students of its members who had successfully passed the Year 5 Scholarship Exam and they were presented with gifts by the Air Force Commander. The event had been organised by Chairperson of the Air Force Seva Wanitha Unit Chamini Pathirana.

title: Two nabbed with Kerala cannabis
author: Author not found
Content: Two men were apprehended, by the Okkampitiya Police, in possession of nearly 12 Kg of Kerala Ganja, during a raid on 29 March 2023. The arrested duo were a 23-year-old Embilipitiya resident and a 26-year-old from Moneragala. Another suspect who was in possession of 14 Kg of Kerala ganja had escaped during the raid. The Okkampitiya Police is conducting further investigations.   BY Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Joseph Michael Perera’s body taken to Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker of Parliament Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana and President Ranil Wickremesinghe paid their last respects to the late Joseph Michael Perera, a former Speaker of the Parliament of Sri Lanka and Cabinet Minister, in Parliament yesterday (30). Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse, Leader of the Opposition Sajith Premadasa, Cabinet Members, Members of Parliament and former Members of Parliament were present to pay their respects.Furthermore, former Presidents MP Mahinda Rajapaksa and Maithripala Sirisena and former Speaker Karu Jayasuriya were also present to pay last respects. Ambassadors, The Parliament Secretariat staff headed by Dhammika Dasanayake, Secretary-General of Parliament, former members of staff and staff affiliated to the Parliament and relatives of the Late former Speaker were present.  Upon the arrival of the hearse carrying the remains of Joseph Michael Perera, at the main steps of the Parliament Complex, Speaker of Parliament Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana, President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse and Party Leaders, Secretary General of Parliament Dhammika Dasanayake and Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera received the coffin bearing the remains of the late former Speaker. Thereafter the Serjeant-at-Arms, Deputy Serjeant-at-Arms and Assistant Sergeant-at- Arms escorted the coffin, along the red carpet which was kept at the special ceremonial hall located in the front hall of the Parliament building. Speaker of Parliament and the President signed a note of condolence after paying their last respects. Thereafter, Deputy Speaker, Leader of the Opposition, Party Leaders, and former Presidents, Members of Parliament, Ambassadors, The staff of the Secretariat and other dignitaries also joined to pay their last respects.

title: Monk against attemptsto cause ethnic disharmony
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Incumbent of the Mihinthalawe Raja Maha Viharaya, Ven. Walawahengunawewe Dhammaratana Thera, said that all those who tend to spread extremist religious views in an attempt to destroy ethnic harmony, should be banished from this country.  The Thera stated that he unreservedly condemns all those politicians and their henchmen, who air their views aimed at damaging ethnic unity in Sri Lanka while attempting to gain cheap political mileage via such tactics. The Chief Incumbent aired these views to the media in Medawachchiya on 29 March. The monk, known for his outspoken views, also condemned the damages caused, by an unknown group, to a Statue of a Hindu God which had been temporarily constructed at Vedukkunari Archaeological Site at Vavuniya. BY Gayan – Medawachchiya

title: Vietnam Buddhist Nuns Visit Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: Most Ven. Thich Nu Dieu Xinh, the Chief Nun, of  Tinh Xa Buu Son Temple Dinh Quan, Dong  Nai, in Vietnam accompanied by Ven. Bhikkhuni Dieu Phap (Nhu)  MÀ (Peradaniya University), along with Ven. Bhikkhuni An Dieu, an undergrad at the Buddhist and Pali University of Sri Lanka, studying for her doctorate in Buddhism, were in Sri Lanka recently to donate  Supplementary Food Packets among the cancer patients at the Apeksha Cancer  Hospital  in Maharagama and expectant women at the Nursing Home. The donation of the Supplementary Food Packets was done via the courtesy of sponsor Nguyen Thi Thanh Dang, the Chairperson of the Members Council at Trung Nhan Caterpillar Fungus Co. Ltd. Dang has been making similar donations for the well-being of cancer patients in the world during past five years.  The Chief Nun and her companions also visited some temples in several districts and distributed dry rations to low-income families and simultaneously donated useful items to school-going children and offered sangeeka daana to the monks in the temples they visited. The group, led by the Chief Nun from Vietnam, visited several temples in the North Central Province, Abayagiriya Royal Temple  Anuradhapura, and Pandulagama as well. The Chief Nun also took steps to provide items useful to school children at Ambalantota,  on the directives of Southern Province Sanganayaka Ven. Baragama Wimalabuddhi Thera.                                                                                          (WIRUMA)

title: Protest against Saliya Pieris
author: Author not found
Content: A protest was held in front of the Fort Railway Station yesterday (29), against former President of the Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) Saliya Pieris, alleging that the latter “works in favour of underworld drug kingpin Nadun Chinthaka Wickramaratne, alias ‘Harak Kata’.” The protesters claimed that they are family members and relatives of victims of the underworld member who is in Police custody. They displayed photographs of alleged victims and urged Pieris not to work for underworld figures like ‘Harak Kata.’ A woman who claimed to be the wife of a person who was murdered on the orders of ‘Harak Kata’ said, “It is so unfair that the lawyers are speaking on behalf of persons like Harak Kata. Before taking steps to protect underworld figures, justice should be served to their victims. Harak Kata killed my husband and the Police are yet to launch an investigation into that. It is a shame that the lawyers are trying to protect underworld leaders saying that they can represent any person. They should not feed their families with Harak Kata’s proceeds from drug trafficking. Equality should prevail,” she alleged.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Twenty CPC staffers sent on compulsory leave
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly 20 Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) employees identified as trade union leaders have been sent on compulsory leave for allegedly disrupting CPC operations, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said yesterday (29). The Minister said yesterday at a media briefing held at the Ministry premises that they (TU leaders) have been barred from entering the CPC premises as well. He claimed that the trade union action on 28 March was a complete failure because the CPC employees refused to participate in it. However, he claimed that trade union leaders had forced the employees to participate in the strike during the lunch hour and taken them off duty after providing alcohol. He said as a result, the pipelines were abruptly closed, and jet fuel distribution was hampered. He said there are two types of trade unions participating in the protest. He explained that one type is staff of CPC and Ceylon Petroleum Storage Terminal Ltd (CPSTL) who withdrew from duty and fully committed to trade union action, and the other type is retired employees who work in trade unions. “Approximately 95 per cent of the employees did not participate in the trade union action. I directed the heads of these two institutions to take the strictest disciplinary and legal action possible against the individuals who were attempting to disrupt the institutions’ smooth operations. These 20 people have been sent on compulsory leave. An investigation will be conducted to determine how these people entered the terminals,” he said. In addition, he said these individuals are supported by the SJB, JJB, JVP, or SLPP. He highlighted that a committee will be formed to examine the CCTV footage and investigate the complaints made by staff before deciding on the next course of action. The CPC Trade Unions’ Collective staged a Satyagraha on 27 March. They later called off the Satyagraha on 28 March and decided to go on strike, withdrawing from fuel filling and distribution. The Minister then called for strict action against employees and trade union activists of both CPC and CPSTL, in the event they disrupt fuel distribution or hinder the work of other employees. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Organ donation needs more awareness in SL
author: Author not found
Content: There should be more awareness regarding organ donation in Sri Lanka, Deputy Director General of National Hospital Colombo, Dr. Kumara Wickremesinghe said.  Addressing the media at the Health Promotion Bureau (HPB) following the landmark surgical intervention of heart-lung transplant surgery which took place at the National Hospital Sri Lanka (NHSL) on 23 March, he said that delay in donating organs of patients who are brain dead could result in the depleting quality of the organs.      “Even after relatives get medical reassurance that the patient is brain dead they delay in giving approval as they feel that something could be done to revive the patient,” he lamented. Dr. Wickremesinghe explained that if the person had not given prior approval for his or her organs to be donated then it is up to the relatives to decide as to whether they wished to donate the organs of their loved one who was brain dead.  There was further demand for heart-lung transplant in the country and steps would be taken to master the technology and the surgical capacity further by involving other units and hospitals in the process. He said that there was a list of patients who required organ transplants in several hospitals in the country. Fielding questions Dr. Wickremesinghe said when obtaining organs, there was a method of reviewing as to whether the organ was being bought or being donated.    In a landmark surgical intervention, the Colombo National Hospital surgeons transplanted a heart and a lung to a single patient (recipient) who was suffering from severe lung disease which had gradually affected her heart. The patient had been at the NHSL prior to the surgery.  He said local surgeons had been preparing for the pivotal surgical intervention for the patient with the lung disease from 2021. “However since we had never undertaken such a serious surgical venture and lacked experience, the Sri Lankan team also sought the expertise of their counterparts at MGM Hospital Chennai, India”, he said. Dr. Wickremesinghe said doctors from India had arrived in Sri Lanka and examined the patient and explained what was needed. A surgical plan was drawn out inclusive of the medicinal drugs that would be required, surgical consumables and equipment required. “We met Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella and explained that a policy decision needed to be taken to make the surgery a possibility,” he explained. “A decision was taken to perform the transplant surgery at the NHSL,” he said adding that the Director General Health Services (DGHS) issued a circular calling for the NHSL to prepare for the surgery. Dr. Wickremesinghe said that a special Intensive Care Unit (ICU) had been set up, while the patient continued to remain under the care of Cardiologist at the hospital. Cardiothoracic Surgeons, Anaesthetists, Cardiologists, Consultant Thoracic Surgeons, Organ Transplant Surgeon, Respiratory Surgeon nursing, Perfusionists and health assistants made up the team that performed the transplant.  The donor was a brain dead person. Four or five attempts were made to harvest organs from brain dead patients in the past but had failed. The first organ to be harvested is the lung which is the primary entry point for any germ while the patient’s size also matters. But the lungs harvested from brain dead patient from the Teaching Hospital Kurunegala were ideal for the patient at NHSL, he said. “It took over 18 hours to perform the transplant which included harvesting the organs and transplanting them in the recipient. It was a tremendous surgical feat that was accomplished. Surgeries were carried out in two separate theatres in two hospitals. Although the chief surgeon was from India, local doctors too closely assisted in the procedure until the surgery was complete and the patient was transferred to the ICU. He said the country required more such surgeries in the future. The patient who underwent the heart- lung transplant is still warded in the ICU while she was still in critical condition. But within the next few days it is hoped that she would recover and be normalised, he added. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: No fuel shortage, no need for panic
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara requested the public not to panic over a fuel shortage. At a media briefing held yesterday (29), Wijesekara vowed that there would be no fuel queues in the country. Wijesekara said Sri Lanka has fuel reserves enough for four years. “I request the public not to panic about a fuel shortage. We are working hard to avoid such a situation from happening. We experienced that last year and now we can provide fuel and electricity without interruption,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Minimum bus fare slashed to Rs 30
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Transport Lasantha Alagiyawanna said bus fares will be reduced by 12.9 per cent to reflect the decrease in fuel prices. He was speaking at a media briefing held yesterday (29). He said the minimum bus fare has been reduced to Rs 30. Alagiyawanna said the price revision will apply to busses operated by the Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB), private busses, and luxury coaches. The Minister said the Government is yet to decide on train fare revisions. Meanwhile, the All-Island Three-Wheeler Drivers’ Union (AITWDU) also decided to reduce three-wheeler fares from yesterday (29). AITWDU President Lalith Dharmasekera announced fare reductions for the first and second kilometre. “The charges for the first kilometre will be Rs 100 and the second kilometre will be Rs 80. We request that the meter taxi drivers reduce the fare according to the announcement,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek and Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Sara Jasmine is dead – Police
author: Author not found
Content: The third DNA test to determine whether Pulasthini Mahendran alias Sara Jasmine, wife of Atchchi Muhammadu Muhammadu Hasthun, the suicide bomber responsible for the Katuwapitiya St. Sebastian’s Church bombing on 21 April 2019, was among those who died inside the Sainthamaruthu safe house raided on 26 April 2019, proved that it was in fact that of Sara Jasmine, Police said yesterday (29). The Police received the Government Analyst’s report with regard to the third DNA test on Sara Jasmine yesterday (29). Police said DNA of Sara Jasmine’s mother was compared with the DNA samples of several bones found at the Sainthamaruthu blast site. “The result of the test positively proved that the two persons had a relationship of a mother and a child. Accordingly, the DNA test determined Rajaratnam Kavitha has a 99.9999% of probability to be the biological mother of the person whose bones were subjected to the test. “ Just days after the Easter Sunday Attacks, several persons, including children, were killed in a bomb explosion inside a house in Sainthamaruthu, Kalmunai on 26 April 2019. Mohamed Rilwan, one of Zahran Hashim’s brother detonated the bomb. Despite the fact that 17 people died in the explosion, the DNA samples taken from the bodies on two occasions did not match Rajaratnam Kavitha. There were suspicions that Sara Jasmine had fled to India, following a testimony of a witness before the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) on the Easter Sunday Attacks, who claimed she could have tipped off Indian intelligence about the impending attack. The remains of those killed in the Sainthamaruthu bomb blast in 2019 were exhumed on 27 April 2022, following an order from the Kalmunai Magistrate’s Court. The remains buried at the Ampara cemetery were exhumed in the presence of the Ampara Magistrate, the Judicial Medical Officer (JMO), and Police Officers involved in the initial investigations, as well as the Government Analyst. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: 28-year-old killed in cab crash
author: Author not found
Content: A 28-year-old man was killed when he was hit by a cab in Palei on 28 March. Investigations showed the victim had a personal dispute with the cab driver. The deceased is a resident of Muhamalai. The cab driver was arrested and admitted to Palei Hospital under Police protection. Palei Police are conducting investigations.    By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Mobile patrols increased in Kandy
author: Author not found
Content: In the wake of increased number of complaints by tourists in Kandy over being harassed, Kandy Police sources said the number of mobile patrols will be increased.  Central Province DIG Mahinda Dissanayake said several mobile Police units will be deployed henceforth in and around Kandy town and its city limits daily from 4 to 10 p.m. Meanwhile, he said Police were on the watch and in the past few days had arrested some tour guides who were under the influence of liquor and had harassed tourists visiting Kandy. BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Prisoner escapes while being taken to witness stand
author: Author not found
Content: Baddegama Police said a prisoner who was being taken to the witness stand at the Baddegama Chief Magistrate’s Court had escaped having jumped through a window of the Court room. According to Police, the prisoner had been detained at the Galle Prison. They added that around 30 cases related to possession of illegal drugs and theft had been pending against the suspect. The suspect is a 40-year-old resident of Baddegama.  BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Wild elephants run amok in Galenbindunuwewa
author: Author not found
Content: A herd of wild elephants attacked two persons and damaged several cultivations in Padikaramaduwa, Galenbindunuwewa. One of the victims is the Head of the Wildlife Office in Ritigala and he had succumbed to his injuries while the other individual was rushed to hospital. According to Padikaramaduwa villagers, around 50 wild elephants had run amok in the village, damaging crops and houses. The deceased is 42-year-old P.B.J. Wijekoon, a resident of Matale, and a father of two. By Krishnaka Sachin – Maradankadawala

title: Minipe Farmer Colony suffers ‘teething’ issues
author: Author not found
Content: Sources said many patients residing at the Minipe Farmer Colony which encompasses around 20 Grama Seva Divisions have been severely inconvenienced due to their inability to obtain treatment for dental problems at hospitals for want of sufficient facilities. Villagers said that though there are two hospitals in Ambagahapelessa and Morayaya areas neither of them were equipped with facilities to cater to dental issues. They alleged that despite a dental unit being set up at the Morayaya Hospital there was no dentist to treat patients. BY Sunil Ihalagedera – Hasalaka

title: Python released to Molagahawila Reserve
author: Author not found
Content: Officers attached to the Kahatagasdigiliya Wildlife Department Office captured a ten foot-long python from a garden at a house at Ranpathwila area in Kahatagasdigiliya and then released it to the Molagahawila Reserve in Kahatagasdigiliya. BY Balasuriya – Galenbindunuwewa
