title: Tea prices dip
author: Author not found
Content: Several Estate owners and Directors said following the rupee stabilising in comparison to the US dollar in recent days and weeks the price of a kilo of tea had decreased by Rs 200. They said during the past few months a sum of Rs 1,250 was quoted for a kilo of upcountry tea. But, said that it had come down to Rs 1,050 for a kilo of tea. However, they warned that if the rupee were to strongly stabilise in the face of the dollar, the price of a kilo of tea could further decrease dealing a severe blow to the industry. By Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: FOURTH ROUND OF NEGOTIATIONS HELD IN COLOMBO
author: Author not found
Content: The fourth round of negotiations on the proposed Sri Lanka-Thailand Free Trade Agreement (SLTFTA) was held in Colombo from 27 to 29 March. This initiative aligns with the President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s vision to enhance economic relations with large and emerging economies, with particular focus on ASEAN countries. On 26 March, a 35-member Thai delegation led by Auramon Supathaweethum, Director General of the Department of Trade Negotiations, arrived in Sri Lanka for the fourth round of talks. Along with their focus on trade negotiations, the delegation also strengthened long- standing religious and cultural ties between the two countries by offering over 500 alms- bowls to the Gangaramaya Temple on the same day. The National Trade Negotiations team representing Sri Lanka at the talks was led by chief negotiator of the Presidential Secretariat K.J. Weerasinghe. The team comprised officials from various departments, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Trade, Commerce and Food Security, Ministry of Industry, Department of Trade and Investment Policy, Attorney General’s Department, Department of Commerce, Department of Agriculture, Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) and Board of Investment (BOI). They participated in the negotiations on behalf of Sri Lanka. During the third round of negotiations in January, discussions on the proposed Sri Lanka- Thailand Free Trade Agreement focused on areas such as trade in goods, trade in services, investment, rules of origin, customs cooperation, trade facilitation, and economic cooperation. The fourth round of talks will build on the principles already agreed upon, and delve deeper into these areas. Additionally, discussions will be held on trade remedies, technical barriers to trade (TBT), and legal matters. Prior to the fourth round of negotiations, the National Trade Negotiations Committee and relevant sub-committees engaged in discussions with various industry sectors and stakeholders. The points raised during these discussions were taken into consideration and used appropriately during the fourth round of talks. The Sri Lankan negotiating team’s goals for the talks focussed not only to increase Sri Lankan exports and access to the Thai market, but also to improve market access to other ASEAN countries through the Thai market, and to reduce existing non-tariff barriers. The Government hopes to sign the agreement in the first quarter of 2024.

title: FR petition filed seeking interim order
author: Author not found
Content: A Fundamental Rights petition was filed before the Supreme Court on behalf of drug kingpin Nadun Chinthaka Wickramaratne, alias Harak Kata, seeking an interim order directing the respondents to take all necessary measures to ensure his safety while in detention. Further, an Interim order preventing the Petitioner being taken out from Criminal Investigation Department for the purpose of any investigation other than under the custody and care of a gazetted Police officer, designated by Court, on the recommendation of the Attorney General, was also sought. The Petitioner said that in most of the instances where suspects in Police custody have been killed, the Police have taken positions such as, the suspect tried to escape from custody whilst pointing out a hidden weapon or narcotics or tried escaping from custody and he was shot or that the Suspect attempted to grab the firearm of the Police officer and in the process the gun went off or the suspect was shot by an outside party while the suspect remained in Police custody. It was observed that if a suspect in detention is taken out for any investigation in charge of a designated officer, preferably a gazetted officer having taken appropriate precautions such as using handcuffs and leg chains, Police will not be able to rely on such improbable grounds. Further, an interim order was sought directing the petitioner to be produced before Courts in any case where he has been named as an Accused or a Suspect under the custody and care of a gazetted Police officer designated by Court on the recommendation of the Attorney General. Western Province SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon, the Inspector General of Police (IGP), Attorney General and four others were named as respondents in the petition. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: TNPFA, Delft Island residents protest
author: Author not found
Content: A protest was held in front of Nedunthivu (Delft Island) Divisional Secretariat yesterday (29)  demanding to halt the construction of a Buddhist temple on the historically known site -Vediyarasan Fort preserved by the people of the island. Delft Island residents joined the Tamil People’s National Front (TNPF) in their protest and Police from other parts of Jaffna were brought to the island.   According to the protesters, the Department of Archaeology has designated the Nedunthivu Vediyarasan Fort as a Buddhist heritage site. Protesters held slogans saying that introducing Buddhism would destroy the island’s history. By T. Pratheepan

title: Fmr Jaffna MC members irked by Thiagarajah’s order
author: Author not found
Content: A dispute has arisen between Northern Province Governor Jeevan Thiagarajah and former members of the Jaffna Municipal Council over Thiagarajah’s order to transfer the authority over the Navalar Cultural Hall from the Jaffna Municipal Council to the Central Government. The Governor has ordered the Jaffna MC to vacate the Navalar Cultural Hall by 6 April. Several former MC members submitted a petition to the Governor’s Secretariat regarding this matter yesterday (28). The Governor told Ceylon Today that the Jaffna MC does not have work nor has proven any good work conducted at the said hall. “This is a decision to run the hall properly,” he said.  However, the former MC members rejected his claims. The group led by former Jaffna Municipal Council member V. Partheepan visited the Northern Province Governor’s Secretariat and handed over a petition stating that the Navalar Hall was jointly operated by the Department of Hindu Religious and Cultural Affairs of the Ministry of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs, and the Jaffna MC. Navalar Cultural Hall has been operating under the Jaffna Municipality and has a public library, but the hall has been requested to be returned after many calls from the Ministry. The issue of handing over operations to the Department of Hindu Religious and Cultural Affairs has been debated by the two parties at every meeting for a prolonged period, but the MC has consistently rejected the proposal. The joint venture was approved after many Hindu prelates, devotees, and academics requested it, and on 21 November 2021, then MC Mayor V. Manivannan, members of the Department of Hindu Religious and Cultural Affairs, and others decided to operate the hall jointly. However, the petitioners say unexpectedly on 6 April the Governor requested the MC to vacate the building, claiming that the Ministry of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs will handle operations under the guidance of the Department of Hindu Religious and Cultural Affairs. “When the joint venture was announced and the progress is continuing on that path, with no proper reason the MC asked to vacate,” they added. The petitioners denounced the action and insisted that the joint meeting was scheduled for 2021 and that it must proceed as per schedule. The protesting former MC members said the Navalar Cultural Hall has served as a memorial to Sri Arumuka Navalar, who was born 200 years ago. They held commemorative programmes in collaboration with the Department of Hindu Religious and Cultural Affairs. They said they wish to elevate their programmes to bring honour to Navalar in the future too, but they alleged that the Governor of the Northern Province is working in line with the Government, irking the Tamil community. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Order suspending Magisterial inquiry extended
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (28) extended the Order staying the proceedings of the Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court against Western Province SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon, over the alleged criminal breach of trust, with regard to Rs 17.8 million recovered from the President’s House on 9 July 2022. This was when the Petition filed by SDIG Tennakoon, against his being summoned by the Fort Magistrate, was taken up before Court of Appeal Justices Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and M.A.R. Marikkar. The Colombo Fort Magistrate on 26 January summoned SDIG Tennakoon to appear before Court on 16 February, in connection with criminal breach of trust over the Rs 17.8 million recovered from the President’s House on 9 July during anti-Government protests. SDIG Tennakoon later filed a Petition challenging such issuance of summons.  When the Petition filed by SDIG Tennakoon was taken up on 15 February, Court issued an interim order staying the proceedings of the case and summoning of SDIG Tennakoon until the final determination of the Petition. While the relevant order was extended until 19 May, Court ordered objections to be filed before 3 May. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Suwaseriya heading for a crash?
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Dr. Harsha de Silva appealed to the public to ‘adopt’ a 1990 Suwaseriya ambulance to assist the operations of the emergency ambulance service, as the Treasury has informed it cannot bear the full cost owing to the present economic turmoil in the country. Dr. de Silva tweeted that due to the present economic situation, the Treasury is unable to fully fund its operations, which may lead to the Suwaseriya service being unsustainable in 2023.  “This donation to the Government of Sri Lanka for 1990 Suwaseriya will be fully tax deductible. Try to get this in before the 31 March end of tax year deadline,” MP de Silva said. In an effort to save the project, the Board and management of Suwaseriya have floated a proposal, requesting corporate and individual donors to ‘Adopt an Ambulance’ at a cost of Rs 5 million, he said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: ITAK opposes Anti-Terrorism Act
author: Author not found
Content: Ilankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi (ITAK) MP M.A. Sumanthiran said his Party is vehemently opposed to the Anti-Terrorism Act that was gazetted recently. Speaking at a media briefing held yesterday (28), the ITAK MP said the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) has been replaced with a new Act called the Anti-Terrorism Act, which has been published in the Government Gazette. “The PTA was enforced for more than 40 years in the country and it was heavily criticised. Many persons called for its repeal. When the present President was the Prime Minister in 2017, he promised the European Union that he would repeal the PTA. It was discussed with people’s representatives and public organisations, and many mistakes were pointed out and corrected at the time. They used the 2019 Easter Attacks as an excuse not to carry it out,” Sumanthiran said. The recent Anti-Terrorism Bill cannot be compared with the PTA, he said and asserted “It is even worse than that. We totally oppose this new Bill and will take legal action against it.” If a new law is to be brought on top of PTA, it should be agreed on with the public organisations first, while the Human Rights Commission had already put forward a report last year regarding repealing the Anti-Terrorism Act. That means there is no need for a special law to prevent terrorism, he stressed. “The Government has deviated from the democratic path without holding the elections and stalled the Provincial Council Elections for a prolonged period. Now even after the announcement of the Local Government Election, only one person in the country is holding back the elections citing the economic situation,” he alleged. This action, the MP added, is proof that the Government is nothing but a dictatorship. “Therefore, in this environment, we strongly condemn the fact that the Government has brought a special law called the Anti-Terrorism Bill to suppress, oppress and punish the people who protest against it,” he stressed. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: CPC TUs end Satyagraha campaign
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) trade unions ended their Satyagraha campaign which was held in front of the Kolonnawa Petroleum Terminal premises on 27 March. This was shortly after Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said he has called for the termination of employees of both the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) and the Ceylon Petroleum Storage Terminals Ltd (CPSTL) who disrupt the distribution of fuel. The Petroleum Trade Unions’ Collective launched the protest on Monday (27) against the Government’s alleged ongoing attempts to privatise the CPC. The trade unions stressed they would withdraw from fuel filling and distribution. The Minister tweeted that he has instructed to take necessary disciplinary steps with regard to the termination of employment of those employees or trade union activists who disrupt the distribution of fuel and the work of other employees, or who act in violation of the essential service orders.

title: Enhanced Safety Measures for Tourists at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: Complaints with regard to alleged incidents of harassment against tourists at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), Katunayake have significantly increased recently. As a result, a special programme will be launched to accept complaints and catch those who harass tourists at the airport premises, Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva said. The Minister said instructions have been given to establish specific counters to accept complaints from the tourists and to also widen the CCTV system at the BIA. He gave these instructions during a meeting held with the airport authorities yesterday (28). The Minister pointed out that numerous complaints have been received that the tourists are subjected to harassments from porters, taxi drivers and brokers at the BIA premises.  Since the number of tourist arrivals has increased now, the authorities must pay a special attention to protect the tourists from these harassments, the Minister told the authorities.  Also, it was decided at the meeting to increase the fine from Rs 10,000 – Rs 100,000 imposed on those who harass tourists. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ali Sabry, Wijeyadasa conclude S. Africa visit
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lankan Government delegation comprising Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry, and Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, concluded the three-day working visit to South Africa from 21-25 March 2023, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced yesterday (28).  The Cabinet of Ministers in January this year approved the concept of a Truth and Reconciliation mechanism as proposed by the Cabinet Sub-Committee on Reconciliation, which is chaired by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. The proposed concept states that an independent, domestic mechanism of truth seeking is identified as a meaningful way for Sri Lanka to advance and secure peace, after the country’s arduous journey of ending conflict of three decades. The Cabinet also authorised the Minister of Foreign Affairs and the Minister of Justice to operationalise this concept and to initiate discussions and facilitate the drafting of a Truth and Reconciliation law. It is in support of this process, the current visit took place at the invitation of the South African Government.  During the visit, the two Ministers paid a Courtesy Call on the South African President Cyril Ramaphosa and held bilateral meetings with the Minister of International Relations and Cooperation of South Africa Naledi Pandoor and the Minister of Justice and Constitutional and Constitutional Development Ronald Lamola. They also met with former South African President Thabo Mbeki as well as Roelf Meyer, former Minister of Constitutional Development and one of the chief negotiators, along with President Ramaphosa, for the end of apartheid in South Africa and paving the way to the first democratic elections in the country. Meetings were also held with officials from the Public Prosecutions Office of South Africa, the Pan African Bar Association of South Africa, “Freedom park”, “In Transformation Initiative” and the “Institute for Justice and Reconciliation”.  During the call on President Ramaphosa, the South African President warmly recalled his friendship with President Wickremesinghe and said that he wishes to further consolidate the bilateral relations with Sri Lanka. He further stated that South Africa is committed to sharing their experiences in relation to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission with a view to assisting Sri Lanka in the reconciliation process.    Foreign Minister Sabry and Minister Pandoor exchanged views on important bilateral issues as well as the current situation in Sri Lanka. Minister Sabry especially briefed the South African Minister on the progress being made by the Government of Sri Lanka with regard to national efforts on reconciliation and the promotion and protection of human rights. While acknowledging that the South African model would need to be adapted to the Sri Lankan context, both Ministers agreed to work together in sharing experiences and expertise in developing the contours of a truth-seeking mechanism that would best suit the needs of the Sri Lankan people. The interactions with the South African Minister of Justice and other experts provided valuable insights with regard to the South African experience in the establishment of their Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

title: Petitions seeking Contempt charges against Nishantha fixed for 27 June
author: Author not found
Content: Three petitions, seeking Contempt of Court charges be filed against State Minister of Water Supply Sanath Nishantha, were fixed for consideration on 27 June by the Court of Appeal. This was when the Contempt of Court Petitions filed by lawyers Vijith Kumar and Priyalal Sirisena and the Judicial Service Association of Sri Lanka (JSASL), were taken up before President of Court of Appeal Justice Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and Justice M.A.R. Marikkar yesterday (28). The Petitioners observed that Nishantha, who spoke at a media conference, held at the SLPP Headquarters on 23 August, had expressed critical views on the manner in which Magistrates acted in granting bail to the suspects involved in the ‘Aragalaya’ protest movement and that the MP has damaged the honour and the image of the Judiciary. The petitioners further charged that Nishantha has been in Contempt of Court through the aforementioned act, adding that it is a punishable offence in accordance with Article 105 (3) of the Constitution. Accordingly, the petitioners requested the Court to issue an order, to summon, before the Court, the original video clips of the relevant press conference which were aired by several private television channels. Furthermore, the petitioners also requested the Court to issue an interim order for Nishantha to refrain from making any statements that may be in contempt, in the future. Deputy Solicitor General Lakmini Girihagama, making submissions yesterday (28), informed Court that the Government Analyst report on the relevant media briefing has been produced to Court and the 2-Judge Bench ordered for a copy of the report to be submitted to the Attorney General’s Department.  The Attorney General previously informed Court of Appeal that two Contempt of Court charge sheets have been filed against Nishantha. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Cabinet greenlights Sampur Solar Power Plant
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved setting up a 135 MW solar power plant in Sampur, Trincomalee in two stages under a joint venture between the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) and the National Thermal Power Corporation of India (NTPC). In the first stage, it is expected to implement a 50 MW solar power project with a total investment of USD 42.5 million and to construct a 40 km long 220 kV transmission line from Sampur to Kappalthurai. The estimated cost of this transmission line is reportedly USD 23.6 million and it is expected to complete the first stage in two years from 2024 to 2025. Also, a solar power plant with an additional capacity of 85 MW will be constructed at a total cost of USD 72 million in the second stage. It has been planned to construct a 76 km transmission line with a capacity of 220 kV from Kappalthurai to New Habarana at an estimated cost of USD 42 million. Meanwhile, Cabinet approved entering into a Memorandum of Understanding on cooperation in the field of renewable energy between India and Sri Lanka.  The Cabinet Paper was tabled by the Minister of Power and Energy. The Government plans to generate 70 per cent of the electricity requirement by 2030 from renewable energy sources, become independent in power supply, and neutralise carbon emissions by 2050. (TR)

title: Marked increase in influenza cases at LRH – Dr. Perera
author: Author not found
Content: A marked increase has been observed in the number of children with influenza and influenza-like symptoms treated at the Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH), Consultant Paediatrician Dr. Deepal Perera said. Dr. Perera, yesterday (28), said there was a marked increase in the number of paediatric patients with fever, cold and cough, some of them suffer from diarrhoea, while others experience eye discharge. He said many patients had tested positive for influenza while others had contracted a viral infection. He urged parents to give their children the right Paracetamol dosage and ensure they get adequate rest. “Make sure your children have adequate amounts of natural liquid food. Seek immediate medical attention should the child continue to look ill,” he added. Dr. Perera urged parents to be watchful when their children suffer from a prolonged cough even once the cold and fever are cured as it may be due to wheezing or it may be a symptom of tuberculosis, especially if there is an adult who has contracted the disease. The Paediatrician urged parents not to send their children to school, Montessori or day care centres if they experience symptoms of influenza or any other viral infection as it is contagious. Further, he urged parents to ensure that their children wear a mask to prevent the spread of infection. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Health bigwigs finally appear before HRCSL
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Ministry bigwigs, who finally appeared before the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL), after repeated warnings issued by the Commission, accepted that there is a health emergency in the country and as a result emergency purchasing of medicinal drugs is being conducted outside the normal purchase procedure. Health Ministry Secretary S. Janaka Sri Chandraguptha accepted the fact that there is a health emergency in the country when he appeared before the HRCSL. While the Health Ministry Secretary pointed out that under such circumstances the health service could purchase medicines outside the normal system, the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) Dr. Vijith Gunasekara said that he would purchase medicines outside of the normal procedures as per the instructions of the Health Ministry Secretary. Chandragupta, Gunasekara and Director General Health Services (DGHS) Dr. Asela Gunawardena and a delegation of the NMRA appeared before the HRCSL yesterday (28),  when the petition filed by the Sri Lanka Medical Association (SLMA) and the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), stating that the drug shortage and the steep increase in the cost of pharmaceuticals was the result of weak and very inefficient health administration, was taken up. While Authorities from the Health Ministry and the NMRA avoided appearing before the HRCSL on three previous occasions, the Health Ministry Secretary at the onset declared that there was no health problem as mentioned in the media. However Dr. Ananda Wijewickrama and Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa, who appeared on behalf of the plaintiffs, queried as to how emergency purchases of substandard drugs was currently taking place in the country. The NMRA CEO, in response, noted that emergency purchasing had been carried out outside the normal purchasing procedure after the Health Secretary had notified that there was a health emergency in the country and he had the authority to do so. Responding to Dr. Sanjeewa’s query as to who declared the health emergency in the country Health Ministry Secretary Chandragupta responded that the President had made the declaration. It was pointed out here that the Ministry of Health was currently working towards purchasing a large quantity of non-essential medicines under the Indian credit line and other grants sans proper guidance of specialists. It was alleged that the Health Ministry has created an opportunity to purchase medicines from companies that had been blacklisted without the proper tender procedure. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: GSMB carries out 15 raids on large-scale racketeers
author: Author not found
Content: The Geological Survey and Mines Bureau (GSMB) raided 15 large-scale illegal sand mining operations in Hambantota last week, Minister of Environment Naseer Ahamed said. The Minister said these raids were carried out to crack down on illegal sand mining and forged sand transport licences in Hambantota and Kurunegala, as his Ministry is on a mission to end such nefarious activities. Accordingly, in Hambantota, around 15 raids were carried out on illegal large-scale sand mining activities. It was also found during the raids that many sand dealers in Kurunegala were using forged transport permits. He alleged that under former GSMB administrations, many illegal activities took place. He added that this had contravened many of the standard procedures. Ahamed said he strictly requested that transport route permits should be issued indicating the starting point and the route they will take clearly. Also, the vehicle numbers must be registered, so that if they deviate from the route, they can be arrested and permits could be revoked. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Fmr Kotte MC Opposition Leader remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (28) remanded, till 4 April, the former Opposition Leader of the Kotte Municipal Council, who was charged with torching the private residence of President Ranil Wickremesinghe on 9 July 2022. The suspect was identified as Chandima Nayanajith. He was arrested and produced in Court by the CID yesterday (28). The CID informed Magistrate Gamage, that further inquiries, pertaining to the conduct of the suspect, with regard to the aforementioned incident, are yet proceeding. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: PUCSL Chair receives notice of proposed axing
author: Author not found
Content: Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) Chairman Janaka Ratnayake said yesterday (28) that he has received notice of proposed grounds for his removal from the post. He said a response, denying all the allegations mentioned against him, will be sent to Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara soon. Ratnayake said it is clear that purported allegations against him have been maliciously concocted by certain parties. He denied all the allegations levelled against him. “The PUCSL is expected to function as an independent regulator. That is evident from the provisions contained in the PUCSL Act. Also it is necessary to obtain the approval of the Constitutional Council with regard to the appointment of members,” he said. Speaking further, Ratnayake requested President Ranil Wickremesinghe to advise the Minister of Power and Energy to instruct Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) to forward a revised proposal of the electricity tariff hike.  Ratnayake claimed that this revised proposal will ensure the interests of all consumers, including those in low income groups, so that a proper cost-based tariff revision, which is not discriminatory or unreasonable could be approved. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Over 10,000 sea turtle hatchlings released
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Coast Guard (SLCG) passed the 10,000 milestone in releasing sea turtle hatchlings to the sea, when on Sunday (26 March) it released 2,514 sea turtle hatchlings, increasing the total number of sea turtle hatchlings released to the sea thus far for the year to 10,557, SLCG said. This composite number of 2,514 sea turtle hatchlings released was arrived at via the activities of SLCG life-saving posts located in Mirissa, Hikkaduwa, Moragolla, Panadura, Mount Lavinia, Dehiwala, and Wellawatte, spanning over seven days to Sunday, it said. In addition, SLCG personnel attached to these posts recovered 1,572 sea turtle eggs and moved them over to safer locations for hatching, SLCG said. From the beginning of 2023 to Sunday, SLCG has preserved 41,342 turtle eggs and set free 10,557 hatchlings into the ocean, SLCG in conclusion said. (PA)

title: Eravur residents up in arms
author: Author not found
Content: The name change of Punnakuda Road in the Eravur city limits in the Eastern Province by the Eastern Province Governor to Elmis Walgama Road has been rejected by residents and 74 organisations, who claim it disrupts communal harmony. In this regard, Minister of Environment Naseer Ahamed, who also serves as President of the Eravur District Committee, has issued a strong letter rejecting the proposal. He told Ceylon Today that on 3 March, Secretary to the Governor L.P. Madanayake sent a letter to the Provincial Director of the Department of Road Development, Eastern Province, renaming Punnakuda Road after Elmis Walgama, who was born in Talpe, a village in Galle. He added that Punnakuda is a popular place like Pasikuda and such a name change is pointless in the present context. The justification provided by the Governor’s Office is that Elmis Walgama lived in Eravur from the age of 12 and eventually became a prominent businessman and social worker. “He was also said to own a hotel bakery and cultivated 600 acres of paddy in Kopavelly,” it was said. Dr. Sunil Ariyapala, R.M. Gunaratna, M. Premawathi, Tissa Chandrasiri, Anoma Priyadharshini, Nalanie Jayasinghe, H.W. Asha, H. Nuwan, and W.M. Wasantha were among those who proposed changing the road’s name. These persons have stated that persons who have rendered outstanding service to the country in the past must be honoured. Eastern Province Governor Anuradha Yahampath has approved this proposal, and the Minister said she lacks the authority to suggest and approve such name changes. He said these are minor issues, but residents are not in favour, and he claimed that this type of social disharmony was planned to disrupt the Government. “I have sent a letter stating that the people have rejected this, and I would like to request that the good Governor refrain from doing such unwarranted work,” he added. According to him, the name change will not occur or be accepted. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Two bodies found
author: Author not found
Content: Hambantota Police discovered a body of a 30-year-old with stab wounds on 27 March. The body was discovered following a tip-off. The victim’s identity had not yet been confirmed. However, the body was taken to the Hambantota Hospital mortuary for a postmortem examination. The Hambantota Police are investigating. Another suspicious death was recorded on 27 March. The body of a 25-year-old woman was found in a canal in the Niriella area.  The investigations have revealed that she was a resident of Niriella. On the same day the mother of the deceased had made a complaint to the Police about her missing daughter. The postmortem was due yesterday (28) and the body was placed at Ratnapura Hospital. The cause for the death is yet to be verified and the Elapatha Police are investigating. BY Dinithi Wijesundara

title: EP Governor launches canal project
author: Author not found
Content: Eastern Province Governor Anuradha Yahampath launched a programme to facilitate the release of water from Mavil Aru to Panikkankeni via the construction of a new canal, which will increase the water capacity for the Yala and Maha Seasons. According to the Governor, the release of water and the resultant increase in its capacity will enable the farmers in the province to carry out paddy cultivation on around 2,000 acres. She was seen undertaking a tour of the area to inspect the progress of the project on 27 March. By W.M. Wickremasinghe – Kantale

title: SL only facilitating ferry service between Karaikal and KKS – Ports Minister
author: Author not found
Content: The ferry service, between Puduchcheri Union Territory in Tamil Nadu and Kankesanthurai (KKS) in the Northern Province, would be operated by anyone who has ferries and follows international maritime law with a proper licence and insurance, according to Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva. He added that the first ferry line of the new service, on this route, is scheduled to call at the port of KKS, on 29 April. He added the fee and charges are decided by the ferry service company. He did not reveal the company’s name. Karaikal in the Union Territory of Puducherry and KKS are connected by a 56-nautical-mile ferry service. The immigration office at KKS Jetty, the Minister said, is fully operational and ready to start.  “We are only facilitating anyone with the approval of both the Indian and Sri Lankan Governments to begin ferry services.” He stated that one ferry service will be operated by a Sri Lankan, and five others are earmarked as well from India. Last year, Puducherry Chief Minister N. Rangasamy said at the Assembly, presenting the Budget for 2022-23,   that under the Sagarmala scheme, it was proposed to commence commercial cargo handling operation at the Puducherry Port, in association with Chennai Port Trust this year  and the project is going to be a Public-Private Partnership arrangement with a shipping services entity. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Appeal Court fixes Cardinal’s Writ Petition for consideration
author: Author not found
Content: The Writ Application, filed by Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith, against the IGP, the Secretary to the Ministry of Public Security and three others, for the non-implementation of certain recommendations, made by the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) appointed to investigate and make recommendations on the 2019 Easter Sunday Attacks, was fixed for consideration on 9 May by the Court of Appeal. This was when the Petition was taken up yesterday (27) by Court of Appeal Judges Dhammika Ganepola and Sobhitha Rajakaruna. In the Petition, it was stated that the PCoI handed over its Final Report, with recommendations to the incumbent President in January 2021 and that the report had made several findings of serious negligence and or lapses on the part of numerous public officials, including officials serving in the Police and recommended that disciplinary action be taken against them. It was noted however, that despite the lapse of a lengthy period of time, since the Final Report was tendered and in spite of continuous agitations calling for the implementation of its recommendations and calling for accountability, no steps have been taken to consider or implement the recommendations. Among other relief, the Writ Application sought directives from the Court of Appeal to the IGP and the Secretary to the Ministry of Public Security, directing them to implement the recommendations of the PCoI. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: AG’s Petition against Mudalige’s release to be recalled on 3 April
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo High Court yesterday (27) ordered to recall, on 3 April, the appeal filed by Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam, against the release of Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) Convener Wasantha Mudalige from the case filed against him under the Provisions of the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis released Mudalige from the case, filed under the PTA, stating that no offences had been committed by the suspect, as per Provision of the PTA. The High Court Registrar informed that the case will be called on the aforementioned date, as the presiding Judge had gone on vacation. IUSF Convener, Wasantha Mudalige, was present in Court. The Attorney General has filed an appeal with the High Court, stating that the order, issued by the Colombo Chief Magistrate, to release the accused from the case was contrary to the law and to issue an order. The Attorney General in the appeal seeks an order to invalidate the verdict issued by Chief Magistrate Alwis as well. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Committee to study Professionals’ proposals on tax scheme
author: Author not found
Content: A four-member committee was appointed by the Government to look into the proposals, submitted by the Professional Trade Union Alliance (PTUA), on the newly introduced income tax scheme, which has affected professional categories severely. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Hansamal Weerasuriya said yesterday (27) that four officials from the Inland Revenue Department (IRD) had been appointed to study the proposals, which had been submitted by the professional body and suggest solutions to the colossal issue which had the professional trade union from over 40 State and semi-government and private sector trade unions striking. Dr. Weerasuriya said that they saw this as a positive move by the government, although they have not made a noticeable move towards resolving the crisis issue, which had severely affected the professional categories since the implementation of the Inland Revenue Act (amended). He noted that the PTUA members had held a zoom meeting with the Washington Office of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) last week, while the unions had impressed upon the IMF the injustice in the way in which the professional categories were being taxed by the Government whilst shouldering the blame on to it. The GMOA Media Committee member warned that the PTUA would watch how the Government proceeds with resolving the tax issue and move into further trade union action should it fail to either amend the Act further or repeal it. With the IMF not being so explicitly keen on taxing professionals almost mercilessly, the Government cannot continue to blame the IMF for the present crisis. Further, if we are to save the country from a greater crisis in the near future, due to the shortage of doctors, financiers, engineers and other professional bodies, owing to the governments’ uncaring attitude, then the PTUA would do all things possible to push the Government into reverting its stance on the IR Act (Amended). Several Trade Unions of the PTUA called off their strike after the Presidential Secretariat wrote noting that the President and the Government were prepared to consider the proposals submitted by it in a positive light.        By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: TID allowed to detain Easter attacks suspect
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Pasan Amarasena yesterday (27) permitted the Terrorism Investigation Division (TID), to detain a suspect, till 22 June, in connection with aiding and abetting in the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks. The suspect was identified as Ajmal Sahil Abdulla Sulfikar, a resident of Watadeniya, Welamboda. The TID informed Magistrate Amarasena, that their probe had revealed that the suspect had taken part in discussions and weapons training classes, conducted by the Easter Sunday terror blasts ringleader Zahran Hashim and his followers, at a house situated in Sippikulam, Hambantota, as part of a rehearsal for the Easter Sunday carnage, on 21 and 22 July, five years ago. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: HRCSL Report on 9, 10 May ‘22 mayhem by April end
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) will present a report, on the complaints regarding the torching of houses, other damage and destruction of property, theft, robbery, and endangering public safety and security on 9 and 10 May 2022, by the end of April. In a statement, the HRCSL said it has received approximately 70 complaints with regard to such incidents which occurred on 9 and 10 May 2022. The Inspector General of Police (IGP) was scheduled to provide a statement, to explain the two circulars identified as relevant to this inquiry, as well as to provide evidence with regard to correspondence and directions made in the lead-up to the aforesaid incidents, the commission said. “The inquiry with regard to the said complaints is on-going. The evidence of numerous persons including the complainants, as well as Police officers from relevant Police divisions, has already been recorded. The Commanders of the Tri-Forces have also been informed to provide explanations as to how incidents of such magnitude occurred during a period when an Order under Section 12 of the Public Security Ordinance was in force and to provide clarification as to steps taken by the Tri-Forces to maintain public order and provide public security during the relevant period,” the commission added. At the conclusion of the inquiry, the HRCSL will make Recommendations, as envisaged by the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka Act, including recommendations as to human rights-compliant measures, which should be taken by the Government to ensure public security and maintain public order.

title: Food to feed 10M destroyed post-harvest in 2021 – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: Food harvest enough to feed over 10 million people had been destroyed in 2021 due to post-harvest damage, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said, adding that the country loses 20 per cent of harvest due to such damage. Over 221,955 MT of vegetables and 290,151 MT of fruit are destroyed annually due to the lack of proper transportation, he said. Accordingly, annually about 19 per cent of vegetables and 21 per cent of fruits are thus destroyed.   He added that post-harvest damage in Sri Lanka is at a very high level and the country loses nearly 20 per cent of the harvest due to post-harvest damage, noting that the amount of food wasted is very high in urban areas.  ‘’In 2016, it was planned to present a Cabinet Paper for the establishment of the first food research laboratory, with all facilities, but since the work was not completed, it was decided to submit another Cabinet Paper. The absence of a well-known food research laboratory in our country is a serious deficiency,’’ he said.                             (FT)

title: Petition against SDIG Tennakoon dismissed with costs
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (27), dismissed with costs, the Writ Application seeking an order to be issued to the Attorney General to arrest Western Province SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon and produce him before Court, as a suspect in connection with the attack on anti-Government protesters by SLPP supporters on 9 May 2022. This was when the relevant Writ Application filed by Attorney-at-Law Ramalingam Ranjan was taken up before President of Court of Appeal Justice Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and Justice M.A.R. Marikkar. Attorney-at-Law Maithri Gunaratne, appearing on behalf of the Petitioner, noted that SDIG Tennakoon had failed to prevent the attack and had breached his duty due to which he should be sent on compulsory leave or that disciplinary action should be taken against him for such failure. President’s Counsel Romesh de Silva, making submissions on behalf of SDIG Tennakoon, noted that he had done everything in his capacity to prevent the attacks based on information received by him due to which the Writ Application should be dismissed in the first instance. Following consideration of submissions made by both parties, Court dismissed the Application with costs on the basis that sufficient facts to issue orders requested for in the Petition has not been established. The Inspector General of Police (IGP), SDIG Tennakoon, Attorney General and the Director of the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) were named as respondents in the Petition. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Govt to spend Rs 20B to purchase Maha paddy
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is prepared to spend up to Rs 20 billion to purchase paddy in the Maha season, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said.  He said this year, the Government has made arrangements to purchase the Maha season paddy through District and Divisional Secretaries.  The Minister has also decided to give 10 kg of rice to each low-income family for two months and if such programme cannot be continued, the Government is ready to provide financial assistance as a subsidy to them. “Some say that we are giving these subsidies because an election is coming. As the government, we do not give concessions to the people by looking at the votes,” he said. (FT)

title: Cabinet Nod for Three Foreign Firms
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said 450 dealer-operated fuel stations, currently operated by the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC), will be given to three foreign companies, following the Cabinet giving its approval yesterday (27). Apart from that, these companies will be given another 50 fuel stations each at new locations. The Cabinet has granted its approval for three foreign entities to enter the fuel retail market in Sri Lanka and licences will be granted to China’s Sinopec, United Petroleum of Australia and RM Parks of USA, in collaboration with Shell PLC. The Minister, in a tweet, said the energy committee and other relevant procurement committees had given their approval and recommendation to award licences for these three companies to operate in Sri Lanka. “The three companies will be allocated 150 dealer-operated fuel stations each, of which is currently operated by the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC). They will be granted a license to operate for 20 years to import, store, distribute and sell petroleum products in Sri Lanka,” the Minister said. Following the forex crisis and fuel shortage that hit the country, Parliament passed legislation in October 2022 allowing foreign competition in the local fuel market, ending a 19-year duopoly. According to the new law, private companies will have to finance the import of oil from their own foreign exchange reserves and agree to retain their profits in Sri Lanka for at least a year. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: AI Snr Director Deprose Muchena here for Annual report launch
author: Author not found
Content: Senior Director of Amnesty International, Deprose Muchena, arrived in Colombo for regional launch of the Annual Report 2023, which is scheduled for 28 March. Muchena will be the key speaker at the event. Given the current economic crisis and human rights situation in Sri Lanka, he aims to use his presence to highlight and stress on the urgent need to protect and promote the rights of the island’s 22 million people. Muchena is the Senior Director for Regional Human Rights Impact at Amnesty International, where he oversees Amnesty regional offices across the world, to lead the mandate of expanding human rights footprint. He has previously worked with United States Agency for International Development (USAID) and Open Society Initiative for Southern Africa (OSISA). He has co-edited two books and holds two Master’s Degrees from the University of Cape Town and University of Zimbabwe. He has undertaken advanced Leadership training at Harvard University, Syracuse University, and INSEAD Business School.

title: Youths in peace walk
author: Author not found
Content: A large number of youths, from all three communities, took part in the recent peace walk, which was organised by the District Youth Forum, which was established by Peace and Community Action (PCA), under the Y-CHANGE project, which was funded by GCERF and HELVETAS. Over 250 youths from the District’s 20 Divisional Secretaries Divisions participated in the peace walk, which began from two points and was co-ordinated by coordinators from the Divisional Youth Forum and District government officials. One peace walk began from Brown & Company Junction in Ampara and the other got underway from the Ampara Town Clock Tower Junction. The youths,  carrying slogans stressing communal amity, peace and harmony among all three communities, reached the District Secretariat and handed over  a memorandum, containing conflicts, identified during their research work which lasted eight months,  to the Asst. Government Agent  Wimalasena  Seneviratne at the Kachcheri  Auditorium, where a Cultural programme, stressing on communal amity, too was staged by  youths from all three communities. National Director of PCA T. Thayaparan chaired the events. District Women Development Officer Sureka Edirisinghe, NGO coordinator I. L. Irfan, Youth Empowerment Project Co-ordinator I.Suthawasan,  District Integration Officers  F. Piratheeskaran and K.T. Rohini were present. BY M. A. P. Deen – Ampara

title: Tissa Central OSA to modernise school
author: Author not found
Content: Tissa Central National School, in Kalutara North, will be renovated and modernised by its Old Students Association (OSA), according to the school’s Principal, Malinda Jayathunga. The very old main gate was completely removed and replaced with a much more attractive and much stronger one and the College name board was also replaced with a stone name board, a very rare type of school name board. Both of these modernisation/refurbishment costs exceeded Rs 1.6 million, according to Jayathunga. Tissa Central National School’s modernised Name Board and Main Entrance were ceremonially opened by OSA members and members, the Principal and Vice Principals, as well as parents and family members of OSA members. Doctors, Engineers, Lawyers, Teachers, Politicians, Journalists, Businessmen, Company Owners, Shop Owners, Electronic Technicians, and many more Tissa Central College alumni were among those in attendance. It was reported that this historic occasion was very important and a red-letter day in the school’s history, because almost all of the school’s past students were present, some of whom had never visited their Alma Mater after leaving the school. And, they had a fantastic opportunity to meet and greet their ‘old friends’ and classmates. There were no political speeches made at the event. BY S. S. H. Lunuwila – Wadduwa

title: NBRO Turns Out Fibre Paving Blocks From Fabric Waste
author: Author not found
Content: What comes first and foremost to our minds about the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) is its prime roles such as landslide-related studies and research, mitigation and developing landslide resilience. Like any other nation, Sri Lanka, too, confronts natural calamities such as drought, floods as well as landslides accompanied by heavy rains. The role played by NBRO in identifying the landslide-prone locations in the Central Hill Country and its timely action to protect a large number of lives falling victim to such disasters should be lauded. The NBRO provides a tremendous and immeasurable service to resolve environment-related issues in Sri Lanka, predominantly to the apparel industry. The NBRO is a Semi-Government research institute established in 1984, currently functioning under the Defence Ministry engaging in landslide research studies while carrying out landslide mitigation work, developing landslide resilience and providing a timely warning to people in landslide-prone areas. Apart from the duties vested to it, the NBRO has been focusing towards providing a sustainable solution to the mounting apparel industry waste. The apparel industry is one of the major sectors which earns foreign exchange for the country. In 2021 the apparel industry contributed 44 per cent of the total export income while focusing on sustainable manufacturing processes. Due to not having textile waste recycling facilities in Sri Lanka the mounting textile waste has become a severe issue that needed to be resolved. The industry is taking various steps to resolve this issue. It is a compulsory and timely need to find a reliable and sustainable solution. The textile industry disposes of nearly 44,100 metric tons of off-cut textile waste per year.  A mass utilisation method is required to address this issue. The Building Materials Research and Testing Division (BMRTD) of NBRO has invented an effective and alternative mechanism to put an end to the textile waste issue by manufacturing a product utilising the waste material. It has manufactured fibre -reinforced paving blocks for outdoor sports surfaces as well as residential areas. The NBRO strives towards making a safe, sustaining and resilient environment through research and development activities while proving a timely solution to industrial problems. Fibre-reinforced paving block The fabric fibre reinforced paving block has been developed with many features such as improved shock absorption and water infiltration under the Research and Development (R & D) activities based on the request made by the textile industry to utilise the synthetic fibre blended fabric off-cuts as a value-added product. Research activities The research was carried out by Eng. G. K. B. Maheshi Gannoruwa at BMRTD under the supervision of Snr. Prof. S. M. A. Nanayakkara, University of Moratuwa. The NBRO had received the patent for this development under the Intellectual Property Act (IPA) of Sri Lanka. Throughout this research project Eng. (Dr.) Asiri Karunawardena, Director General of NBRO and Eng. Sunethra Muthurathne and the Director of BMRTD extended their fullest support and cooperation to successfully implement this project. Manufacturing process A huge amount of synthetic fibre mixed off-cuts disposed of by the apparel industry is being incinerated in cement kilns; Fabric off-cuts, cement, sand and other admixtures are used as raw materials to manufacture environmentally friendly paving blocks. The block consists of 26 per cent fabric content by volume and acts as reinforcement while improving the flexural properties of the block. Benefits The fibre-reinforced paving blocks have the capability to absorb 21 per cent ‘impact force’ when compared with the conventional concrete pavements while facilitating ‘better and healthy’ foot comfort for its users. In addition, these blocks have high skid resistance {80 Unpolished Slip Resistance Value (USRV}) to prevent accidents while moving in wet conditions. These blocks have water infiltration capacity and will facilitate the rainwater to reach the ground easily passing the blocks during a downpour. Technology These blocks have been manufactured according to the SLS 1425 Standards, fulfilling the specified requirements, for comprehensive strength abrasion resistance and skid resistance. Furthermore, these blocks also conform to the Splitting Tensile Strength (STS) requirements specified in BSEN 1338 standard while indicating its ‘strength result’ as 5.4N/mm2, a standard that is not attained by concrete paving blocks. High Quality As a deviation point from conventional paving block manufacturing methods, fabric fibres are used as the reinforcement to manufacture these blocks. Therefore, the durability of these paving blocks is especially evaluated; for their practical applicability and to ensure that fabric incorporated into the cement matrix is not subject to considerable deterioration during its performance. Fabric fibre-reinforced paving blocks are recommended for walking paths, jogging tracks, sports arenas, home gardens and children’s play areas due to improved shock absorption, water infiltration and skid resistance characteristics. The dimensions of a single block are 200mm in length, 100 mm in width and 60mm in height. As a pilot project 12,000 of these paving blocks have been laid on a jogging track located at Sri Lanka Light Infantry (SLLI), Panagoda. According to user comments, treading on these blocks facilitates better comfort for their feet, Eng. Maheshi Gannoruwa added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Cyclist critically injured in mishap
author: Author not found
Content: A 27-year-old was critically injured in an accident involving a motorcycle and a bicycle near Arali Bridge at Vaddukoddai, in the Jaffna District, early yesterday (27), Police said.  Sureshkumar Nikshan, 27, a resident of Arali Central, in the Vaddukoddai Police Division, was the victim, according to Police. According to preliminary investigations, the victim had attempted to enter the Arali Jaffna main road, from the Arali Mutthu Mariamman Kovil but was hit by a motorcyclist travelling from Jaffna to Arali. The victim was rushed to the Jaffna Teaching Hospital by ambulance. Vaddukoddai Police were conducting inquiries into the accident. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Driver killed as van hits tree
author: Author not found
Content: The driver of a van was died on the spot when his vehicle veered off the road and crashed into a roadside tree, in Kodikamam, Jaffna early yesterday (27), according to Police. The accident occurred directly opposite the Mirusuvil Army Camp. The driver, Kumaraswamy Kajeefan, 27, was a resident of Paranthan in the Kilinochchi District, according to Police. Kodikamam Police are conducting additional investigations into the accident. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Vavuniya agri farm to be relocated to Omanthai
author: Author not found
Content: Northern Province Governer Jeevan Thiagarajah has taken steps to relocate the Vavuniya Agriculture Farm, which is located in Thandikulam along the A09 Road and is overseen by the Northern Province Ministry of Agriculture, to Omanthai soon. The farm has been established on more than 65 acres of land, under the jurisdiction of the Northern Province Ministry of Agriculture, and 100 acres of land will be allocated in Omanthai to establish this farm. The Governer has written to the Vavuniya South Divisional Secretary requesting that the Central Government take over the aforementioned lands from the Provincial Government. He said, in his letter, that the aforementioned lands should be taken over by the Central Government in order to expand and expedite regional development in the Northern Province. Because the Northern Provincial Council refused to allocate land in a specific location for the Vavuniya Dedicated Economic Centre, it was built in the Mathavaikukam area and is now abandoned, according to the Governer. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: PARLIAMENT SITTINGS IN APRIL
author: Author not found
Content: Parliament is scheduled to convene next on 4 April, Secretary General of Parliament Dhammika Dasanayake said. Instead of the second Parliamentary week in April, from 18 to 22, it was also decided that the Parliament will convene from 25 to 28 April, the Secretary General said. This was decided at the Committee on Parliamentary Business meeting, held last Friday (24), under the chairmanship of Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena. Accordingly, Parliament will convene on 4 April at 9.30 a.m.  One hour, from 9.30 a.m. to 10.30 a.m., has been allotted for Questions for Oral Answers. Thereafter, until 5.00 p.m. an order published in the Gazette Notification 2306/15, under the Order under the Sri Lanka Export Development Act, pertaining to amending of the CESS Tax and Two Regulations under the Imports and Exports (Control) Act, published in the Gazette Notification 2320/46 and 2320/47 are to be approved following debate. Time has been allotted from 5.00 p.m. – 5.30 p.m. for Questions at the Adjournment Time.

Manufacturing process A huge amount of synthetic fibre mixed off-cuts disposed of by the apparel industry is being incinerated in cement kilns; Fabric off-cuts, cement, sand and other admixtures are used as raw materials to manufacture environmentally friendly paving blocks. The block consists of 26 per cent fabric content by volume and acts as reinforcement while improving the flexural properties of the block. Benefits The fibre-reinforced paving blocks have the capability to absorb 21 per cent ‘impact force’ when compared with the conventional concrete pavements while facilitating ‘better and healthy’ foot comfort for its users. In addition, these blocks have high skid resistance {80 Unpolished Slip Resistance Value (USRV}) to prevent accidents while moving in wet conditions. These blocks have water infiltration capacity and will facilitate the rainwater to reach the ground easily passing the blocks during a downpour. Technology These blocks have been manufactured according to the SLS 1425 Standards, fulfilling the specified requirements, for comprehensive strength abrasion resistance and skid resistance. Furthermore, these blocks also conform to the Splitting Tensile Strength (STS) requirements specified in BSEN 1338 standard while indicating its ‘strength result’ as 5.4N/mm2, a standard that is not attained by concrete paving blocks. High Quality As a deviation point from conventional paving block manufacturing methods, fabric fibres are used as the reinforcement to manufacture these blocks. Therefore, the durability of these paving blocks is especially evaluated; for their practical applicability and to ensure that fabric incorporated into the cement matrix is not subject to considerable deterioration during its performance. Fabric fibre-reinforced paving blocks are recommended for walking paths, jogging tracks, sports arenas, home gardens and children’s play areas due to improved shock absorption, water infiltration and skid resistance characteristics. The dimensions of a single block are 200mm in length, 100 mm in width and 60mm in height. As a pilot project 12,000 of these paving blocks have been laid on a jogging track located at Sri Lanka Light Infantry (SLLI), Panagoda. According to user comments, treading on these blocks facilitates better comfort for their feet, Eng. Maheshi Gannoruwa added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: First term of 2023 school year begins today
author: Author not found
Content: The first school term, for the 2023 academic year, will commence today (27), the Ministry of Education announced. Accordingly, all Government and Government-approved private schools will begin their first term for 2023 today. The first phase of school holidays will be in effect from 5 to 16 April 2023, according to the Ministry of Education. The second phase of the first school term will begin on 17 April and will last until 12 May. title: Free rice distribution to 2.9M people begins today
author: Author not found
Content: The programme to distribute free rice to 2.9 million people will begin today (27). Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera announced that the Government will convert paddy purchased from farmers into rice and distribute it to low-income families. He said during the Maha season, the Government has made arrangements to purchase 61,300 metric tonnes of paddy from farmers. “In the first phase, Rs 10 billion was allocated. The Ministry of Finance decided that rather than the Paddy Marketing Board, District Secretaries and Divisional Secretaries should purchase paddy. This rice will be distributed to two million low-income families,” he said. In addition, he said the Government has decided to provide free rice for two months at the rate of 10 Kg of rice per family per month. According to the Minister of Agriculture, the rice subsidy was originally intended for two  million families, but it was later increased to 2.9 million. The Minister revealed these details on 25 March while attending a ceremony at Lunama in Hambantota. “This free rice has been requested by 52% of all families in the Hambantota district. Despite significant development in the Hambantota district in the past, and despite a large number of people cultivating paddy, there are still 52% of families requesting subsidies,” he said. The Minister also highlighted that free rice will be distributed to low-income families in the Hambantota district today  and in Agunakolapalassa and Weerakatiya, as requested.

title: Sword used to sever man’s hands recovered
author: Author not found
Content: The sword used in the recent severing of a man’s hands, in Koralawella, Moratuwa, was discovered among the rocks in the coastal area off the Mosses Road area in Egoda Uyana yesterday (26), the Mt. Lavinia Divisional Crimes Unit confirmed. On 21 March, the suspect was seen severing a man’s hands with a sword, in Korelawella, Moratuwa and then walking away with the victim’s limbs in his hands. According to Police, the attack was carried out over a personal dispute. Later, the suspect had surrendered before the Moratuwa Magistrate on March 24 through a lawyer. It has been revealed that the attacker had previously committed a similar crime, after which, however, the victim’s hands were reattached. Police suspect that the perpetrator had taken the victim’s limbs in this instance in order to prevent them from being reattached. However, during interrogations he has mentioned that he threw the victim’s severed limbs into the sea. BY Iranga Fernando – Moratuwa

title: IMF loan will help country get back on its feet – Harin
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Tourism and Lands, Harin Fernando said it was a great achievement for the country that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) granted the loan to Sri Lanka in such a short period of time and that if China and India had not delayed to respond to the debt restructuring, the IMF loan assistance would have come sooner. He also said the people have been given hope for a better tomorrow as a result of obtaining the loan. However, Fernando claims that some political leaders and members of the Opposition were undermining the country internationally by joking that IMF loans will not be paid under the present Government and that the country cannot be brought to its former glory. He also said, with the exception of a few hypocritical politicians in Sri Lanka, people around the world are pleased that the IMF is taking steps to provide this loan to Sri Lanka. The Minister told the media yesterday (26) in Kandy, “People will receive relief under the programme that will be implemented with the receipt of this loan in at least six to seven months. The country, which was destroyed by the wrong decisions of politicians, is now moving in a positive direction, thanks to President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s correct leadership and political experience, and the Opposition still had the opportunity to think from the people’s perspective and support this programme.”  He said if this money is not wasted in unnecessary endeavours and if fraud and theft is kept at bay in accordance with IMF guidelines, this country could be brought back on the road to development fast. By Y.K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: PM chairs Buddha Sasana Fund meeting
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena chaired the meeting of the Buddha Sasana Fund at the Prime Minister’s Office with the participation of Minister of Buddha Sasana and Religious Affairs Vidura Wickremanayake and Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa. They discussed the present position of the Fund and reviewed the progress and examined the proposals for the propagation of Buddhism and development of places of worship.

title: Luxury ship docks at Galle
author: Author not found
Content: The super luxury cruise ship SEABOURNA ENCORE sailed from Thailand to the Galle Port yesterday (26) under the Bahamas flag, carrying over 550 foreign passengers. The tourists on board the ship were supposed to leave for Colombo after seeing the Galle Fort and the beaches in the surrounding area. The ship had 437 crew members and 552 tourists on board. The ship was docked in Galle and the passengers were brought to shore by boats. BY Siri Gardiyage – Koggala

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Person arrested for jeering at Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: An individual who booed at Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardena was arrested near Pitipana Junction in Homagama during the laying of the foundation stone for a Buddhist temple, Homagama Police said. According to Police, the suspect is a 43-year-old businessman living in Pitipana. The suspect was driving his lorry from Homagama to Moragahahena, on the high level road and the ceremony was taking place at Pitipana junction, where the Minister was present. The suspect had then began booing and protesting against the Minister and the crowd that was witnessing the event. Police seeing the incident pursued the lorry and arrested the suspect. BY Hashan Puspika – Pannipitiya
