title: Chairman IOC donates 500 Indoor Solar Cooking systems through Lanka IOC
author: Author not found
Content: During his recent visit to Sri Lanka, Chairman Indian Oil Corporation Limited (IOC) Shrikant Madhav Vaidya donated 500 Indoor Solar Cooking Systems called ‘Surya Nutan’ to the Government of Sri Lanka through Lanka IOC. One such Cooking system was physically presented to and unveiled by President Ranil Wickremesinghe who was highly appreciative of the unique innovation and noble initiative. Surya Nutan is an indigenous indoor solar cooking system designed, developed and patented by IOC’s Research & Development Centre. Surya Nutan is a stationary, rechargeable and always kitchen connected indoor cooking solution capable of catering cooking needs of households. It has the capability to Cook food through boiling, steaming, frying and baking and works on both solar and auxiliary energy sources simultaneously. The product gets charged and discharged simultaneously while performing its function of indoor cooking. This low maintenance, easy and safe to use cooking system and has long life. These Solar Cooking systems shall shortly be delivered to the Government of Sri Lanka by Lanka IOC. The momentous occasion was marked by presence of Secretary, Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, India Pankaj Jain, High Commissioner of India to Sri Lanka Gopal Baglay and other dignitaries of Energy delegation from India were also present. Lanka IOC is the only private sector fuel retailer in Sri Lanka with presence through its near 250 sheds across the length and breadth of Island nation, meeting the energy needs of every sector of the society. With its approach of giving back to the society, Lanka IOC has been regularly engaging itself into various CSR initiatives such as donation of Rs 200 million to President’s Fund, making provisions of dry rations to the needy, donation of essential medicines to hospitals, etc with an aim to support every strata of society.

title: Chairman IOC presents sustainably-made jacket to the President of Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman Indian Oil Corporation Limited (IOC) Shrikant Madhav Vaidya visited Sri Lanka along with Energy Delegation from India comprising Secretary, Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, India Pankaj Jain, JS/OSD (International Cooperation), MoPNG Esha Shrivastava, CMDs of many leading energy corporate In India and held numerous high level meetings with Government of Sri Lanka on exploring the areas of common interests between India & Sri Lanka in the Energy Sector. The energy delegation also met President Ranil Wickremesinghe where Vaidya presented him with a unique sustainably-made jacket made by IOC under #IndianOil’s #Unbottled Campaign highlighting IOC’s resolve for Going Green. During the special occasion, High Commissioner of India to Sri Lanka Gopal Baglay was also present. It is noteworthy that recently, Vaidya had also presented similar jackets to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and renowned American businessman and co-founder of Microsoft, Bill Gates, both of whom were highly appreciative of the campaign and supported it by wearing the jackets. Under the ‘Unbottled’ campaign, IOC aims to convert 100 million PET Bottles annually to make uniforms for our on-ground teams and non-combat uniforms for Armed Forces. The popularity and encouragement achieved from the ‘Unbottled’ campaign has been inspiring for IOC to walk the extra mile and make all possible efforts to usher in a brighter tomorrow by reigning in the menace of single-use plastic. Indian Oil Corporation Limited is the parent company of Lanka IOC which holds 75.12 per cent shares of the company and has played a leading role in arranging regular fuel supplies to Sri Lanka through Indian Credit Line as well as beyond during the most critical fuel situation faced by the country.

title: Philip Gunawardena: A profound influence on the thought and imagination of modern Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: Don Philip Rupasinghe Gunawardena (1901-1972), as a political leader, exercised a profound influence on the thought and imagination of modern Sri Lanka. He was a natural-born leader who instinctively understood the hopes and aspirations of the people; he was close to the heartbeat of the nation. As a leader, he realised if he is too far ahead of his followers he would lose contact with them; on the other hand, if he was content with merely echoing the sentiments of his followers he would not be able to lead. He knew the right balance. Philip Gunawardena was largely instrumental in disseminating the idea of socialism in Sri Lanka. He did so in his unique way by de-Europeanising socialist thought and by connecting it to the wellsprings of indigenous culture and investing it with local resonances. He was able to speak in the cultural idiom of the people regarding issues that mattered most to them. Looking back on his efforts, one has to conclude that this was indeed the correct strategy. He was a proud and complex national leader. His pride grew out of his deep self-confidence to have abiding faith in ourselves. He was a complex man who realised that one has to engage manifold forces that impinge in any given historical moment and respond simultaneously to contradictory and unavoidable demands. He had his triumphs and defeats, unwavering loyalties and unanticipated betrayals. Through it all, he displayed his characteristic courage and force of personality as the Lion of Boralugoda. Philip Gunawardena’s manifold activities were guided by deep moral imagination. The idea of social justice was at the heart of it. He valued equality not as an end point, but rather the point of departure for social transformation. In this regard, I am reminded of the contemporary French thinker Jacques Rancière, who said, “Equality is not a goal to be achieved, but a point of departure, a supposition to be maintained in all circumstances”. One important facet of Philip Gunawardena’s thinking relates to this profound understanding of the dynamics of history. He saw clearly how history flows through us and shapes us; it was his belief that our discomfiture before the future grows out of our loss of historical identity. The capacity to grasp the complexity and many-sidedness of a historical situation marks off the enlightened leader from a less enlightened one. And he certainly was an enlightened leader. Devising ways of channelling the energy of the past towards the momentum of the present was one of his preoccupations. Philip Gunawardena, despite his occasional setbacks, was an optimist at heart. This optimism flowed from his belief that the future will embrace the historical aspirations we bring to it. Hence, a true understanding of Philip Gunawardena as a thinker and leader demands that we pay close attention to his distinct historical imagination. Philip Gunawardena’s voice gave new urgency to the aspirations of the nation in search of a better world; that search was animated by the effort to rediscover the cultural identity and national self-respect that were shattered under colonialism. He unleashed a new yearning for social betterment, cultural growth and national self-understanding. Philip Gunawardena was a patriot and national leader who had the ability to feel into the lives of the people, his recognition of the force of culture, his leadership qualities and his endeavours to restore the moral supremacy of the nation. The 51st Commemoration of National Hero, the late Philip Gunawardena, will be held at the Jasmine Room of the BMICH, Colombo 7, on 29 March at 3:45 p.m., chaired by Mahanayake of the Kalyani Chapter, Most Venerable Malwane Panngasara Nayaka Thera. Keynote speakers are Vice Chancellor of Uva-Wellassa University, Prof. Jayantha Lal Ratnasekera and Art Historian and International Award-winning Film-MakerDr. SinhaRaja Tammita-Delgoda. By Prof. Wimal Dissanayake

title: Online lecture by Dr. Prithiviraj Fernando on 30 March
author: Author not found
Content: The National Trust Sri Lanka’s Monthly Lecture Series No: 149 by Dr. Prithiviraj Fernando will be held online on 30 March, 2023 at 6 p.m. The lecture is titled ‘History and Future of Sri Lanka’s Elephants’. Anyone interested in attending the lecture can do so by clicking on the following link: https://us02web.zoom.us/j/81147932173. The National Trust – Sri Lanka conducts monthly lectures generally on the last working Thursday of each month. The lectures are open to the members and the general public. The HNB Sustainability Foundation is the principal sponsor of the events of the National Trust – Sri Lanka. Further information can be obtained from the Trust Office Tel. 0112682730/ 0719566929 Dr. Fernando obtained his PhD from the University of Oregon, USA. He pioneered genetic analysis of Asian elephants using their dung and radio tracking of elephants in Sri Lanka. After his PhD, he joined Columbia University New York, where he conducted research on Asian elephants and Javan rhinos. His work resulted in the recognition that Borneo elephants were indigenous and not introduced to Borneo. In 2004, he returned to Sri Lanka and set up the Centre for Conservation and Research (CCR) of which he is the Chairman. The focus of CCR has been on conducting research and conversion of findings to policy and management to better mitigate the human-elephant conflict and conserve elephants. He has conducted field work on elephants and human-elephant conflict in Sri Lanka, Indonesia, Laos, Cambodia, Borneo, Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar and Vietnam. Dr. Fernando is a Research Associate of the Smithsonian Institution USA and has received the Whitley Award from HRH Princess Anne and Sri Lankan Presidential Awards for Scientific excellence.

title: Jobs exclusively for NP residents – Governor
author: Author not found
Content: Northern Province Governor Jeevan Thiagarajah said there was no truth to TNA MP M. A. Sumanthiran’s claim that people from other provinces will also be considered in the programme to provide 100,000 jobs to Northern Province residents. Governor Thiagarajah said only permanent residents of the Northern Province will be given priority when making the appointments. Thiagarajah said these statements were irresponsible statements. He said, except for those in the   Northern Province those from other provinces will not be taken into consideration in any way. The Government has not taken any such decision in this regard and will concentrate on providing jobs to those who permanently reside in Jaffna, Thiagarajah added. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: No plans to do away with CSD – Sagala
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has no intention to do away with the Civil Service Department (CSD), Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of the Presidential Staff, Sagala Ratnayake said. He said the Civil Service was approved as a depreciable service according to the 2015 Cabinet Paper, but that period has now lapsed. He said, members of the Civil Service could request a service extension beyond 55 years enabling them to serve up to 60 years. Ratnayake said there has been no change in policies and that there were no plans to modify them in the future. Ratnayake was speaking at an appreciation ceremony held recently at the Civil Service Department headquarters in Katubedda, Moratuwa to acknowledge the contribution made by Civil Service officers. The ceremony was chaired by the Minister of State for Defence, Premita Bandara Tennakoon. During his visit, Ratnayake interacted with members of the Civil Service Department inquiring after their work and engaging in friendly banter. The Director General of the Civil Service Department, Major General Ranjith Kalkahewege (Retired), presented a commemorative gift to Ratnayake and Minister Tennakoon to mark the occasion. Following the ceremony, the Minister and Ratnayake held a meeting with the Director General and senior officials of the Civil Service Department to discuss the future affairs and operations.

title: PMD celebrate’s President’s birthday at Mihindu Seth Madura
author: Author not found
Content: The President’s Media Division (PMD held a special programme to celebrate President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s birthday. The event was organised for resident disabled war heroes at the Attidiya ‘Mihindu Seth Madura’. Mihindu Seth Madura is a residential care facility that offers ongoing care, attention, and support to war veterans with special needs due to debilitating injuries. Minister of State for Defence Premitha Bandara Tennakoon and Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayake were present at the event and inquired about the well-being of the war heroes. Director General of the President’s media Division, Dhanushka Ramanayake, along with Media Directors Shanuka Karunaratne and Meesha Gunawardena, as well as Senior Assistant Secretary to the President  Sudheera Nilanga Vithana, Deputy Directors, senior and other staff members  presented gifts. The group also interacted with the war heroes and offered their assistance. A war hero was given the opportunity to wish President Ranil Wickremesinghe on his mobile phone. Chief of Defence Staff General Shavendra Silva, Army Commander Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage, Army Rehabilitation Director Brigadier Shiron Ekanayake, and Commandant, ‘Mihindu Seth Medura’ Brigadier T.S Balasooriya attended the event.

title: Govt will further liberalise economy for foreign investors – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who claimed the future of Sri Lanka rests on whether the country goes ahead with the IMF agreement or not, stressed that “if we failed to do this, we will be cursed by the future generations.” He also said the Government will liberalise the economy further for foreign investors. “The structural reforms we do will enable us to have a growth enhancing economy. We will liberalise the economy further. There are those who think liberalisation is not a good word. And we will open it out for foreign investors.  We are also looking at different areas of investment in manufacturing but that means we have to go into higher end. Secondly, modernising agriculture and fisheries, making Sri Lanka a regional logistics centre, upgrading and expanding our tourism,” the President made this remark during a discussion with media organisation heads at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (23). The President also said, the Government intends to take necessary action to pass the best Anti-Corruption Act in South Asia in Parliament shortly. He said this in response to questions on how to ensure fiscal discipline and fiscal transparency when it comes to utilising IMF money. Stressing that the previous IMF agreements failed 16 times due to people’s perceptions, particularly due to the media and that the 17th time can be successful if the Government can get the media’s support. “The IMF process is tough. This cannot be done in a hurry. It is a four-year process. We cannot engage in political games like before. We need to forget the mistakes we made in the past and we must get together to come out of this crisis,” he added. “I asked Parliament to give approval for the IMF agreement. I don’t require it by law. But Parliament voting for this agreement will strengthen it. The country has already voted for it. At least that’s what the reactions I have. And, I would like to get the assistance of Parliament. “It is also necessary to show the creditors that the country has accepted the principle which is included in this IMF agreement. Firstly, it’s the restructuring of the debt. But, that is not limited to restructuring of the debt. It is restructuring our economy.  “We are moving towards a new Sri Lanka. By 2048 we will be a high middle income country. We cannot go on with stagnation and low growth. We just remember that all upheavals we had in the country relate back to this issue. We had one in 1971, which was related to unemployment, 1980s one was not mainly on language, but that the Tamil youth had no employment. Same thing happened in 1989. We have the ability to start anew. So, this is a historic process,” he said. Responding to the question of alleged attempts to suppress media freedom, the President said, “I was the one who removed criminal defamation law. And, I was the one to introduce the Right to Information Act. I also brought independent commissions to Parliament on three different occasions. Why would I suppress media freedom?” In response to why the Government is divesting five State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs), some of which are not loss-making, President Wickremesinghe queried back. “Not all SOEs are loss-making. But, we must repay our debts. Therefore, we must restructure.  Why is the Government getting involved in businesses? That is not part of the Government mandate. There was no such during the times of D.S. Senanayake. We had enough money to fund the Gal Oya Development Project. Now we seek loans from China to build the Moragahakanda Project. In which country where there’s a law saying all assets should be owned by the Government?” “Who earns through these State Enterprises? Is it the country? There is no responsibility. What we aim for is accelerated development. It’s only us that want to keep all of these. India has even sold their airports. They were anyway making profits. We also must go there. The Government is there to provide State services, protecting law and order, solving problems of the people. Do we have a good education system today? We have spent more money on petroleum than on education last year. We either look ahead like the developed nations or fall behind like North Korea,” he said.

title: Legal action must be instituted in next 58 days – MEPA
author: Author not found
Content: Legal action in connection with the MV X-Press Pearl fire should lawfully be instituted within the next 58 days, officials of the Marine Environment Protection Authority (MEPA) said. This was during a discussion held at the Sectoral Oversight Committee on Environment, Natural Resources and Sustainable Development in Parliament. MP Ajith Mannapperuma chaired the committee while representatives from MEPA, Central Environment Authority, Attorney General’s Department, Environmental Damage Assessment Committee scientists, marine and environmental law experts, fishing community and environmental organisations attended the discussion. They focused on whether legal action to recover the estimated USD 6.2 billion as compensation should be instituted in Sri Lanka or Singapore. Chairman of the MEPA Attorney-at-law Asela Rekawa said that a committee comprising lawyers, experienced in the law of the sea, was appointed to decide on the civil case to recover compensation and the committee decided that the action should be instituted in Sri Lanka. He added however, that Cabinet approval was granted to institute legal action in Singapore and thereby the Attorney General’s Department is currently deciding on what needs to be done. They further focused on who will be responsible in the event there is any injustice caused by instituting actions in Singapore. Discussions also focused on the refusal of permission for the expert committee, appointed to assess the damage caused by the ship fire, to go close or inside of the ship.

title: Fertiliser companies to reduce price of urea
author: Author not found
Content: Fertiliser companies decided to reduce the price of a 50kg bag of urea by Rs 7,000. This was following a discussion held with Minister of Agriculture, Mahinda Amaraweera and the representatives of several fertiliser importing companies. Amaraweera requested the representatives to reduce the price of fertiliser sold by these companies, especially since the Government is supplying urea to farmers at Rs 10,000 and due to the strengthening of the rupee. Accordingly, the representatives agreed to sell a bag of urea, which is currently being sold at Rs 18,500 at Rs 11,500. Meanwhile, Amaraweera said that the Ministry of Agriculture has focused on further reducing the price of a bag of urea that is currently given to farmers by the Department of Agrarian Development. (FT)

title: LPBOA urges Transport Minister to resign
author: Author not found
Content: Transport Minister Bandula Gunawardena must resign, if he is unable to investigate why the price of bus spare parts and service rates are not being reduced despite the appreciation of LKR against USD, the Lanka Private Bus Owners’ Association (LPBOA) said yesterday (23). LPBOA Chairman Gemunu Wijeratne said the Minister could investigate the matter by appointing a special committee. He noted that if Gunawardena is unable to appoint a separate committee or take a decision in consultation with the National Transport Commission (NTC), with regard spare parts and service prices, he should resign and must allow for a person, who can give actual solutions, to be appointed to the position. “There is a possibility of reducing bus fares in April after the revision of fuel prices on 1 April,” he said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Underwear thief handed over to Police
author: Author not found
Content: A thief who stole undergarments and nightwear from the Colombo National Hospital (CNH) women’s hostel for nurses, was apprehended and handed over to the Maradana Police. Secretary of the All Ceylon Nurses’ Union (ACNU), S.B. Mediwatte said yesterday (23) that the thefts had been taking place over the past one year, but the victims had informed the hospital authorities of the losses to no avail. Later, they informed the nursing unions, which had taken action to bring the series of undergarment thefts to the attention of the Hospital Authorities, including the Deputy Director General of the CNH and the Chief Nursing Officer, in writing. There was also a threat to the security of the nurses even if the thievery was being carried out by a person within the hospital. Mediwatte said measures were taken by the authorities to bring it to the attention of the NHSL Security. Mediwatte said according to video footage taken by nurses the thief who entered the nurses’ hostel was stripped to his underwear. The thief was apprehended by the security earlier this week when he entered the nurses’ hostel as usual to steal undergarments that were drying on the clothes lines. However, he was apprehended while leaving the premises and handed over to the Maradana Police, Mediwatte said. (DJ)

title: Foreign cigarettes worth Rs 600M seized
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Customs Investigation Division seized a container of foreign cigarettes, worth more than Rs 600 million, yesterday (23). Customs Spokesman Deputy Director (Legal) Sudatta Silva said the raid was conducted at the Jaya Container Terminal (JCT).  “The cigarettes in the container had been declared to the Customs as A4-sized papers. The container has arrived from Cambodia for re-export. The raid was conducted following information received by the Customs Revenue Investigation Unit that it was part of an international racket. The container landed in the country on 27 February, and as soon as the shipment was received, the Customs Officers seized the container,” Silva said. The Customs Officers found 71 A4-sized paper packets, 439 empty cardboard boxes, and a stock of foreign cigarettes. Further investigations being conducted by the Mobile Branch of the Customs Revenue Investigation unit.  Silva said that they expect seek assistance of foreign institutions for further investigations. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: LG polls put off again
author: Author not found
Content: The Election Commission (EC) announced yesterday (23) that postal voting for the Local Government Election 2023 will not be held as scheduled, and as a result the election will not be held on 25 April. Accordingly, postal voting scheduled for 28, 29, 30, 31 March and 3 April will not be held. In a statement issued, after holding a discussion with political party secretaries, the EC said, it will not be able to conduct the Local Government polls as announced on 25 April. A new date for the election will be decided in the near future, the EC said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Anti-Terrorism Bill gazetted
author: Author not found
Content: The Anti-Terrorism Bill, which repeals the current Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), was published in the Government Gazette yesterday (22). The Bill says, under Section 105 clause (25), any person who commits an offence can be taken under this Act and the “person” is defined as an individual, a group of individuals, an association, an organisation, or a body of persons. The Bill also allows the President of the country to declare curfew ‘notwithstanding’ the provisions of the Public Security Ordinance (Chapter 140). The Bill, gazetted by the Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms, was to make provision for the protection of the National Security of Sri Lanka and the people of Sri Lanka from acts of Terrorism, other offences associated with Terrorism and certain specified Acts constituting the offence of Terrorism committed within or outside Sri Lanka, for the prevention of the use of Sri Lankan territory and its people for the preparation for Terrorism outside Sri Lanka, to provide for the detection, identification, apprehension, arrest, detention, investigation, prosecution and punishment of any person who has committed an act of Terrorism or any other offence associated with Terrorism, for the repeal of the Prevention of Terrorism (Temporary Provisions) Act, No. 48 of 1979. The Section 48 of the Bill cites the powers of the President in declaring curfew. It says, “Notwithstanding the provisions of the Public Security Ordinance (Chapter 140), the President may by Order, published in the Gazette (hereinafter referred to as a “Curfew Order”), declare curfew under this Act, for a period specified in such Order, either to the entirety or part of Sri Lanka including its territorial waters and air space, for the purposes referred to in subsection (2) and subject to the provisions of subsection (3). The President may make a Curfew Order, for the purposes of controlling, detecting or investigating the occurrence of systematic and widespread committing of terrorism and other offences under this Act. It is also for the protection of national or public security from terrorism and other offences under this Act, or to prevent the systematic and widespread committing of offences. It says the maximum period of any Curfew Order shall not exceed twenty-four hours at a time and there shall be an interval of a minimum period of three hours between two periods of Curfew. A Curfew Order may be made subject to such exemptions that may be imposed to provide for humanitarian needs. Any such Curfew Order shall specify categories of persons, who are exempted from the application of such Order, specify any person who may be authorised to issue permits. The Section 85 says the Order, under subsection (1), shall include prohibitions on the entry and where necessary, may include prohibitions on taking photographs, video recording and making sketches of the Prohibited Place. In addition to the publication of the Order in respect of a Prohibited Place in the Gazette, sufficient publicity through other means shall be given. Clause 6 of Section 85 further says any person willfully contravening an Order made under subsection, by entering or remaining in a prohibited place without lawful authority, commits an offence, and shall on conviction be liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years and to a fine not exceeding rupees three hundred thousand or to both such fine and imprisonment. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: “Saliya Peiris first protected ‘Aragalaites’; now protecting ‘Harak Kata’”
author: Author not found
Content: “President’s Counsel Saliya Peiris, who protected those who were in ‘Aragalaya’ is now going to the Court to represent drug lord ‘Harak Kata,’” State Minister of Power and Energy Indika Anuruddha Herath claimed. Speaking in Parliament, the State Minister claimed, “This drug lord is travelling in jets and Saliya Peiris, PC appears on his behalf in Court. Then how can he ‘advise’ on selecting the Inspector General of Police (IGP)? This is a shame. The true faces of those who pointed fingers at politicians are now being revealed to the country. We have to act thinking about this country. The Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) too should think about the country. The whole Parliament took a collective decision to protect the language rights in legal education. Some people did not speak about that issue. But there are some who appear on behalf of international drug dealers. The country is unstable today because of these types of opportunistic persons. “The conduct of the trade unions poses a grave threat to the country’s economy. We have to look into this matter. As a result of the conduct of these trade unions, the institutions have collapsed. The objective of trade unions is to appear for the rights of their employees and professionals. But it is shame to watch how these so called trade union leaders are behaving now and speaking in front of TV cameras. “Some trade union leaders proudly say that they were able to turn seven ships away from the Port. Ports are a crucial part of our economy. Is this what a trade union is supposed to do? They are trying to topple the Government by turning away ships.” “In the past, we had a huge respect for the teachers. Now the trade unionists, like Stalin, are damaging that image. Why is he playing with the future of the children? Parents struggle much to send their children to school. “Same thing applies to the university education. This is done by so called students’ unions. These student union leaders are in universities for about 10 years without graduating. This is a very dangerous situation. “We have to take steps to manage the IMF financial assistance we obtained. Those who claim that they became independent during the tenure of Gotabaya Rajapaksa told not to go to the IMF at that time. But now they are ridiculing this Government saying they are watching how the Government is going to manage the IMF financial assistance. The Opposition made similar predictions all the time and all of them were wrong.” “The Opposition even said that IMF would not support Sri Lanka without holding the election. But that did not happen. Thanks to President Ranil Wickremesinghe we were able to win. We also thank Minister Ali Sabry. “Everyone is now pointing fingers at President Ranil Wickremesinghe. But he accept the responsibility of rebuilding country. We stopped unnecessary expenditure. “The President has won the trust of international community. To gain their trust it is not necessary to hold elections. We have to bring a proper election system and all the 225 MPs should get together for that purpose.”

title: ITU RO and IC in Delhi Will Catalyse Development of Innovations
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Technology Kanaka Herath stated that the Regional Office (RO) and Innovation Centre (IC) of The International Telecommunication Union (ITU) which was inaugurated in New Delhi will catalyse the development of ground-breaking innovations with global implications in the region.  The State Minister made these remarks on 22 March, while attending the opening of the International Telecommunication Union’s Regional Office and Innovation Centre in New Delhi, India. Herath has been invited by the Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to attend the event and share his thoughts whilst representing Sri Lanka. The inauguration of the International Telecommunication Union Regional Office and Innovation Centre was presided over by Prime Minister of India Shri Narendra Modi. Dignitaries, including ministers and heads of institutions from the South Asian region’s telecommunications and information technology sectors, along with scholars in the field, were in attendance. Herath conveyed President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s warm congratulations on the occasion. “India has been an abiding ally of Sri Lanka for a considerable period of time and its assistance during our economic crisis is remembered with deep appreciation. Sri Lanka is presently undergoing a process of digital transformation, and the “SL UNIQUE DI” (SRI LANKA UNIQUE DIGITAL IDENTITY PROJECT) initiative has received significant support from India. Thanks to this project, the progress of digital transformation in Sri Lanka is being expedited,” Herath said. By 2030, all efforts to construct a digital economy that utilises modern technologies will have begun. As a first step, an international conference and exhibition will be conducted in Sri Lanka from October to November this year. I would like to invite the ministers of all the nations represented today, especially the Secretary General of the International Telecommunication Union, to join in this international conference and exhibition, which is being organised with the assistance of the World Bank. The International Telecommunication Union Regional Office and Innovation Centre in New Delhi is of international significance. Being the origin of invention in the South Asian region, this institution will undoubtedly serve as an essential launch pad for future discoveries boosted by digitalisation. It is also a centre for supporting South Asian technical and sustainable development, he said. On this occasion, Minister of Railways and Communications and Information Technology of India Ashwini Vaishnaw and Secretary General of the International Telecommunication Union Doreen Bogdan-Martin represented that union and the countries of the South Asian region in telecommunications and information technology.  Ministers from the field and heads of institutions were present. Herath represented Sri Lanka with Additional Secretary of the Ministry of Technology M.P.N.M. Wickramasinghe, and Acting Director General of the Sri Lanka Telecommunications Regulatory Commission (TRC) R.G.H.K Ranatunga, The International Telecommunication Union, headquartered in Geneva, is a coalition of 193-member nations and 900 organizations, including multinational corporations, regional corporations, and universities. This organisation is a specialised United Nations agency for international information and communication technologies.

title: State Defence Minister praises Army troops for services
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Defence Premitha Bandara Tennakoon praised the services rendered by the Sri Lanka Army troops at Army Headquarters in the Defence Headquarters Complex, Sri Jayewardenepura, Kotte on Tuesday (21). State Minister Tennakoon, accompanied by the Chief of Staff and Senior Adviser to the President on National Security Sagala Ratnayake expressed his views during his maiden visit to Army Headquarters. Army Commander Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage received the visiting officials on arrival and invited them for a cordial interaction with senior officers and troops serving at the Army Headquarters. The Commander presented mementos to the State Minister and the Chief of Staff to the President to symbolise the visit.

title: At least 8,000 TB cases detected annually
author: Author not found
Content: At least 8,000 to 9,000 tuberculosis (TB) patients are detected annually, Acting Director National Programme for Tuberculosis Control and Chest Diseases (NPTCCD) Dr. Nirupa Pallewatta said. Addressing the media in view of the ‘National Tuberculosis Day’ she noted that the disease could be completely cured if detected and treated early. Dr. Pallewatte said, at least seven per cent of the patients diagnosed with the disease succumb to it.  That amounts to about 500 to 600 patients, diagnosed with the disease, die of it. Therefore, it is important to be aware of the disease and seek treatment as early as possible.      Dr. Mizya Cader of the NPTCCD said, Southeast Asian countries bore 43% of the world’s TB burden. While Maldives has the least number of TB patients and Sri Lanka is just above that country as the island did not have such a large TB burden. In 2022, there were 8,342 patients detected in Sri Lanka. When considered from 2016, the number of cases detected annually swayed between 8,000 and 9,000. But the number of patients being detected plummeted in 2020 and 2021 -during height of Covid-19, she explained. In 2020, there were 7,700 patients detected with tuberculosis, while in 2021 only 6,700 patients were identified. But by 2022 the patient numbers increased and reached the 2019 level, she explained. “We also have continuously said that there were an estimated 4,000 TB patients that have gone undetected. But that is due to the WHO estimations,” Dr. Cadre elaborated. They have estimated that Sri Lanka should be able to detect 63 TB cases for 100 000 of the population. in 2022 we have only detected 36.6 patients for every 100 000 of the population, Dr. Cader said. There is about a 5,000 difference between the estimated amount and the numbers that were detected that year.  She observed that should WHO estimations be accurate the NPTCC would need public support to detect these numbers that have been overlooked in order to treat them owing to the stigma and censure that the disease faced. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: 12-Hour water cut on Saturday
author: Author not found
Content: A 12-hour water cut will be imposed in several areas on Saturday (25), from 11.00 a.m. to 11.00 p.m. as electricity will be disconnected at the Ambathale stormwater pumping station due to essential maintenance work by Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB). Accordingly, water supply will be suspended in municipalities of Colombo, Dehiwala, Mount Lavinia, Kotte and Kaduwela, Maharagama, Boralesgamuwa and Kolonnawa Urban Council areas, Kotikawatta, Mulleriyawa Provincial Council areas and Ratmalana and Katubedda on Saturday (25). Residents of these areas are requested to call NWSDB hotline 1939 for any inquiry. (NV)

title: Over 300 families left without clean drinking water
author: Author not found
Content: Around 300 families residing at Denmark Watta, Madoldeniya as well as at SAARC Friendship Village in Nawalapitiya have been inconvenienced due to the lack of safe drinking water, as wells have started to dry up in recent times. The villagers allege that this is happening due to the construction of a tunnel underneath Madoldeniya. They alleged CEB had undertaken a project three years ago to construct a power plant, by building a 1.5 km long dam across Mahaweli River in Moragolla, Nawalapitiya. As a result, water in the wells in the area have started to dry up. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Pakistan’s National Day Celebrated in Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: The High Commission of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan and the Pakistani community based in Sri Lanka celebrated the 84th National Day of Pakistan to make Pakistan a strong, vibrant, and progressive State. The High Commissioner of Pakistan Maj. General (Retd) Umar Farooq Burki HI (M) hoisted the national flag of Pakistan to the tune of National Anthem in a colourful ceremony, held at the Pakistan High Commission. Later, the messages of the President and the Prime Minister of Pakistan were read out to the audience. High Commissioner, Maj. General (Retd) Umar Farooq Burki HI (M), added that Pakistan greatly values its relations with Sri Lanka which are based on mutual trust and understanding. It is a matter of great satisfaction that these mutually beneficial relations, rooted in history, have become truly multi-dimensional, covering fields of politics, trade, defence, culture, education and people-to-people contacts. Furthermore, the High Commissioner also extended sincere greetings and best wishes on behalf of the Government and people of Pakistan to the Government and people of Sri Lanka for the continued progress, peace, national unity and harmony in the years ahead.

title: CID ordered to submit report ensuring safety for ‘Harak Kata’, ‘Kudu Salindu’
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage instructed the CID on Wednesday (22) to submit a detailed report within a week, as to how they could ensure the safety of the two noted criminals Nadun Chinthaka Wickramaratne alias ‘Harak Kata’ and Salindu Malshika Guneratne alias ‘Kudu Salindu’. The two drug peddlers are currently detained by the CID for grilling into their  activities. The Magistrate gave his order to the CID having perused a request made to that effect via a motion submitted by PC Rienzie Arseculeratne who appeared for the two suspects. The Counsel stated that Court should issue an order to the CID to ensure the safety of his clients as they are being interrogated on a detention order while  there was a serious threat to their lives. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: At least 8,000 TB cases detected annually
author: Author not found
Content: At least 8,000 to 9,000 tuberculosis (TB) patients are detected annually, Acting Director National Programme for Tuberculosis Control and Chest Diseases (NPTCCD) Dr. Nirupa Pallewatta said. Addressing the media in view of the ‘National Tuberculosis Day’ she noted that the disease could be completely cured if detected and treated early. Dr. Pallewatte said, at least seven per cent of the patients diagnosed with the disease succumb to it.  That amounts to about 500 to 600 patients, diagnosed with the disease, die of it. Therefore, it is important to be aware of the disease and seek treatment as early as possible.      Dr. Mizya Cader of the NPTCCD said, Southeast Asian countries bore 43% of the world’s TB burden. While Maldives has the least number of TB patients and Sri Lanka is just above that country as the island did not have such a large TB burden. In 2022, there were 8,342 patients detected in Sri Lanka. When considered from 2016, the number of cases detected annually swayed between 8,000 and 9,000. But the number of patients being detected plummeted in 2020 and 2021 -during height of Covid-19, she explained. In 2020, there were 7,700 patients detected with tuberculosis, while in 2021 only 6,700 patients were identified. But by 2022 the patient numbers increased and reached the 2019 level, she explained. “We also have continuously said that there were an estimated 4,000 TB patients that have gone undetected. But that is due to the WHO estimations,” Dr. Cadre elaborated. They have estimated that Sri Lanka should be able to detect 63 TB cases for 100 000 of the population. in 2022 we have only detected 36.6 patients for every 100 000 of the population, Dr. Cader said. There is about a 5,000 difference between the estimated amount and the numbers that were detected that year.  She observed that should WHO estimations be accurate the NPTCC would need public support to detect these numbers that have been overlooked in order to treat them owing to the stigma and censure that the disease faced. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Epidemiology Chief debunks listeriosis spread claims
author: Author not found
Content: Epidemiology Acting Chief Dr. Samitha Ginige, yesterday (22) reassured the public that there was no danger of a listeriosis spread in the island. Addressing the media at the Health Promotion Bureau (HPB) Dr. Ginige urged the public to refrain from creating undue fear regarding the bacterial infection. “Only one death has been reported in the country due to listeria infection,” he reassured noting that it had taken place at the end of February. Dr. Ginige said the infection could cause a slight stomach ache in a healthy person. He or she may not show other symptoms like vomiting or diarrhoea. The Acting Director of the Unit said on rare occasions those suffering from cancer, kidney disease, and long-term illnesses as well as those with low immunity were vulnerable to the disease and could even die if infected. “The deaths of two people going to Sri Pada were due to listeriosis, but has not been confirmed through laboratory or epidemiological tests,” Dr. Ginige said revealing that tissue taken from the bodies of the victims were being further examined to identify the exact cause of death. He said no listeriosis had been detected in tests carried out on persons who went to Sri Pada and admitted to hospital. The Epidemiology Chief said it was not confirmed whether the bacteria was present in food and water samples taken from shops en route to Sri Pada. “However, pay close attention to hygienic condition of food and water that is consumed,” Dr. Ginige advised the public.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Further proceedings deferred to 4 April
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate T. N. Illangasinghe yesterday (22) deferred further proceedings of the trial, pertaining to the death of former Director of Janashakthi Insurance PLC Dinesh Schaffter, to 4 April. When the case was called yesterday (22) Additional Magistrate Illangasinghe, fixed further hearing of the case to 4 April, as the presiding Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya was not present in Court. PC Anuja Premaratna appearing for the aggrieved party, informed Court that a lengthy probe was needed by the five-member team of specialist doctors to overcome contradictions in Schaffter’s post-mortem report and determine whether the deceased committed suicide or whether he was  murdered. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ridiyagama Safari Park welcomes four lion cubs
author: Author not found
Content: Mira, a five-year-old lioness at Ridiyagama Safari Park, gave birth to four cubs on 18 March. According to safari park staff, two of the four cubs are healthy, and two cubs were rejected by the lioness. The two cubs abandoned by their mother have been relocated to the Dehiwala Zoo and are being cared for by zookeepers. They added that weak animals are rejected at birth. Ridiyagama Safari Park is home to 20 lions. About 10 of them were born at the safari park. The remaining 10 lions were flown in from China, Germany, and Africa.                                                         (TR)

title: Govt Analyst ordered to submit blood sample reports
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (22) ordered the Government Analyst (GA) to submit reports related to five blood samples which were recovered from Temple Trees after the anti-Government protesters occupied the building on 9 May. This is connected to the case filed into the damages caused to property of Temple Trees. The Magistrate gave this order following a CID request. The Magistrate gave the Order after perusing a request made to this effect by the CID, with the latter stating that the reports connected to blood samples were needed to further expedite the probe into the case. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Teachers stage protest demanding teacher transfers
author: Author not found
Content: Teacher trade unions, including the Ceylon Teachers Services Union (CTSU) and the Ceylon Teachers Union (CTU), held a protest oppositae the Colombo Fort Railway Station yesterday (22), demanding the Government implement teacher transfers forthwith. They demanded that national school teacher transfers should be implemented immediately and that there should be no political interference in teacher transfers, despite Government assurances that teacher transfers continue as usual except for teachers of O/L and A/L Grades.  Meanwhile, another group staged a protest against the teachers’ protest, close to the same venue. Pic by Sarath Kumara By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Japanese investors discuss investment opportunities with BoI
author: Author not found
Content: The Board of Investment (BOI) explained to Japanese investors who arrived in Sri Lanka that the Investor Facilitation Centre (IFC) will be a single window for conducting business where each investor will get a personal official to look into matters until the investor commences operations in the country. A group of Japanese investors and Japan’s Deputy Head of Mission Katsuki Kotaro visited the BOI to discuss investment opportunities in Sri Lanka. The investors were invited to invest in five new industrial and privately managed zones to be established in the Northern Province and the Trincomalee district. Further, discussions are underway to grant tax benefits to investors in the future. Investors had a productive discussion with Investment Promotion State Minister Dilum Amunugama, BOI Director General Renuka M. Weerakone and other officials on key investment opportunities in Sri Lanka where the investors conveyed interest in investing in diverse sectors such as medical equipment manufacturing, pharmaceutical, travel and the tourism industry especially cultural tourism, the hotel industry, property development and real estate. Speaking at the meeting, the State Minister said, “Sri Lanka has come a long way in making reforms and progress since the economic crisis. The approved IMF programme will definitely help enhance investor-confidence, creating a conducive ecosystem to do business, thereby attracting much-needed FDIs to the country,” He  explained the special investment policy which is in progress to ease doing business where the BOI would be empowered to further facilitate investors. Weerakone told investors, “Sri Lanka is making great progress as a country and has strong economic sectors and companies that are strongly looking forward to establishing investment partnerships with countries such as Japan. In this context, the BOI is looking forward to increasing and developing cooperation with Japan through novel investment projects.” By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Sri Lanka, Maldives to Champion Water Vulnerability
author: Author not found
Content: At a well-attended dialogue, Sri Lanka and the Maldives highlighted critical challenges on climate change and water faced by Small Island Developing States.  The discussion underscored the importance of collaboration when lobbying for concrete commitments towards solving these challenges, at the upcoming UN 2023 Water Conference. The Climate Envoy for the Maldives, Sabra Noordeen stressed the dire issue of water vulnerability in the Maldives, expressing the need for urgent action to reduce the global water crisis.  The President’s Advisor on Environment, Climate Change and Green Finance, Dr. Mallawatantri supported this standpoint, highlighting Sri Lanka’s issues.  Although rich in water resources, inadequate protection and management adversely affects the availability of quality water, and preservation of water sources through optimum management is a priority for Sri Lanka. The Dutch Envoy for Water Affairs, Ovink addressing the forum online said, “These challenges will be discussed at the water conference, which presented a unique opportunity to share challenges and best practices, leading to collective action and solutions for the water crisis.” Dr. Mark Smith, Director General, IWMI called for ‘bolder changes to ensure water security’ as water scarcity rapidly increases. He outlined eight missions for science-based action for a water secure future, to be collaboratively achieved with other stakeholders. Bonnie Horbach, Ambassador for the Netherlands urged for cohesive action that ‘went beyond promises, stating that climate change and water issues transcend boundaries acutely affecting many countries, including the Netherlands.’  She encouraged participants to share knowledge and expertise to achieve imperative changes for a secure planet. The dialogue had participants from all sectors who had opportunity for an interactive discussion with the speakers and an eminent panel comprising Ms. Priyanka Dissanayake of the World Bank, Leel Randeni, Director Climate Change Secretariat of Sri Lanka and IWMI’s Dr. Nishadi Eriyagama. The UN 2023 Water Conference will be held from 22- 24 March in New York and aims to bring about firm commitments to deliver on water actions in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.  These actions will also contribute towards outcomes of  COP28.

title: Appeal for Shamel
author: Author not found
Content: Shamel(18 months) has been diagnosed with a rare life-threatening genetic condition known as ‘Spinal Muscular Atrophy’ (SMA) in November 2022. SMA, also known as a number one gene killer among children and causes weak muscles, damaged brain cells and spinal cord. The condition has affected Shamel’s ability to independently sit, stand, crawl, walk, eat, and even breathe. It is reported that it could lead to fatality depending on the symptoms if untreated. Shamel requires Zolgensma, a one-time gene therapy which comes at a cost of 3 million Singapore dollars. (2.1 million US Dollars). However, Zolgensmait is said must be administered before he becomes two years. The parents cannot afford to raise such a huge sum and thus make an appeal to crowd fund the price of the medication to give their only child a fighting chance. To date, the total amount collected is SGD 1.7 Million and there is a deficit of 1.3 million to be collected within the next few weeks. Contributions could be made to: SampathBank Kandy Super branch A. R. Pilapitiya A/c 100753883450 Parents are contactable on +65 90959847 and more information could be obtained through  www.hopeforshamel.com

title: Brandix ‘RightToRead’ initiative gathers momentum
author: Author not found
Content: Inspired by the challenge to provide Sri Lankan children with better access to learning materials and the transformative power to read and comprehend English, Brandix launched the ‘RightToRead’ project in 2018 in collaboration with the Ministry of Education. Brandix introduced the ‘ReadToMe’ English learning tool, created by English Helper – India, to improve reading and comprehension skills of Sri Lankan students. Last Monday, Julie Chung, US Ambassador to Sri Lanka, visited Susamayawardhana Vidyalaya in Borella, to observe the progress of the project and experience how children and educators in Sri Lanka engage with educational technology. Brandix Lanka Limited, Director, Ajit Johnpillai, said: “Education is the most powerful tool to enrich communities and futures, and Brandix is committed to build a strong foundation for transformational learning for students across Sri Lanka. The progress we have made with Right ToRead over the past two years is promising, and the potential for change in the education sector, harnessing such digital technologies is immeasurable. Brandix will continue its commitment to deliver Inspired Solutions for the people of Sri Lanka.” Susamayawardhana Vidyalaya was one of the first schools connected with RightToRead, and the visitors toured the smart classroom constructed by Brandix, to support the school’s journey in reaping the benefits of English proficiency. As technology infrastructure and resources are limited, Brandix will also provide interactive smartboards to 10,194 schools across the country to give students access to the ReadToMe programme. The programme aims to touch the lives of over 4 million students in Sri Lanka. Brandix has already installed smartboards at 1,260 schools across the island, connecting over 790,000 students.

title: Lack of Eggs Hampers Supply of Meals to Hospitals, Schools
author: Author not found
Content: Those who supply meals to hospitals and schools in and around villages in the Polonnaruwa Mahaweli ‘B’ Zone said they are currently experiencing severe difficulties due to a lack of eggs at both retail and wholesale shops. They charged that while certain shops have eggs, they tend to sell them at Rs 60 per egg, while other shop owners have a habit of concealing eggs to be sold to their friends and regular customers at a higher price. Consumers in and around Polonnaruwa, Dimbulagala, Aralaganwila, and Manampitiya claimed that certain traders only supply eggs to hoteliers and that the price of an egg hopper had risen to 130 rupees. They said providing quality meals to hospitals and schools have been hampered as a result of this unwelcome situation. BY Nimal Jayaratne – Manampitiya

title: Ellawela waterfall –a deathtrap
author: Author not found
Content: A discussion to protect the lives of those who visit the Ellawela waterfall in Wellawaya would be held soon, Wellawaya Divisional Secretary K. H. A. Kelum Nishantha said. He said due to proper safety measures not being followed around 20 individuals who had visited the scenic waterfall had died in the recent past.  Nishantha said this was a serious issue that must be addressed. According to Nishantha, as a result of constant downpours being experienced in the area surrounding Wellawaya in the past few weeks, visitors to the waterfall should exercise extreme caution before venturing into the waters. BY Nishantha Abeygunawardena- Badulla

title: SL hosts Third Meeting of IORA Working Group on Maritime Safety and Security
author: Author not found
Content: The Third Meeting of the Indian Ocean Rim Association’s (IORA) Working Group on Maritime Safety and Security (WGMSS), chaired by Sri Lanka, was held in Colombo on 20 March with the participation of the 23 IORA Member States. Secretary General of IORA Secretariat Salman Al Farisi and representatives of the Secretariat participated virtually from the IORA Secretariat in Mauritius. Inaugurating the meeting, Foreign Secretary Aruni Wijewardane highlighted the importance of the IORA as a forum to enhance maritime cooperation in the Indian Ocean region. On the area of Maritime Safety and Security, the topic under discussion at the Colombo Working Group, Wijewardane said the growing importance of the Indian Ocean requires awareness among IORA Member States on related issues as well as of agreed principles and regulatory frameworks.a “The Indian Ocean Rim region faces many traditional and non-traditional safety and security challenges including piracy, armed robberies at sea, transnational organised crime such as human smuggling, human trafficking and drug trafficking, as well as illicit trafficking in wildlife, IUU fishing, ocean pollution, over-exploitation of marine resources, and illegal transport of hazardous material. Climate change and destruction of ocean biodiversity also challenge the safety and security of the Indian Ocean. Critical infrastructure connected to the ocean which is physically, digitally and environmentally vulnerable needs to be protected.” Furthermore, she said Sri Lanka will assume the Chair of IORA in the latter half of this year for the period from 2023-2025. In this role, Sri Lanka will build on the important work done by Bangladesh as the present Chair and the UAE as the past Chair. Sri Lanka remained confident that collaboration among IORA Member States would lead towards a safe, secure, prosperous and sustainable Indian Ocean for the prosperity of its member states and beyond. Secretary General of IORA Salman Al Farisi, connecting virtually, highlighted that it is important for Member States to continue strengthening their dialogue and efforts to seek solutions to address common safety and security challenges in the region since Maritime Security and Safety is a key development issue in the region. Heads of Mission of IORA member states and dialogue partner countries based in Colombo, Commander of Sri Lanka Navy, Senior Officials of relevant line Ministries and Government agencies including Ministry of Fisheries, Sri Lanka Navy, Sri Lanka Coast Guard, Sri Lanka Ports Authority, Merchant Shipping Secretariat, Disaster Management Centre and Marine Environment Protection Authority, the Global Maritime Crime Programme (GMCP) of United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, and officials of the Max Planck Foundation as well as representatives of the GIZ attended the inauguration event. Representatives of the following IORA Member States were present: Australia, Bangladesh, Comoros, France, India, Indonesia, Iran, Kenya, Madagascar, Malaysia, Maldives, Mauritius, Mozambique, Oman, Seychelles, Singapore, Somalia, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Tanzania, Thailand, United Arab Emirates and Yemen. A three-day workshop titled ‘Cooperation for Maritime Security,’ jointly organised by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Max Planck Foundation for International Peace and the Rule of Law is slated to be held on the sidelines of the WGMSS meeting from 21 to 23 March.

title: KURUWITA DRINKING WATER UNFIT FOR CONSUMPTION – RHO
author: Author not found
Content: The drinking water around the Kuruwita town limits, released by the Kuruwita Pradeshiya Sabha, was unfit for consumption, Kuruwita Regional Health Officer (RHO), Indika Karunaratne said. He said tests carried out by health officials showed that the water being released for drinking by the PS was contaminated with human and animal excreta. Karunaratne said the water contained E. coli and Coliform bacteria. According to Karunaratne, if 10 samples of water is tested, each sample would contain these bacteria. He added that water consumed by people in the Ratnapura District was contaminated  and said constant reminders made to the Kuruwita PS to remedy the situation has fallen on deaf ears. BY K.A.S. Piyathilaka – Kuruwita

title: Ali Sabry on visit to South Africa
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry is presently in South Africa, holding talks with regard to addressing Truth and Reconciliation through domestic mechanisms, which the country remains committed to. Minister Sabry is accompanied by Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe. The Government “agreed” to study the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) model and see how they could derive a model suitable for Sri Lanka as part of ethnic and reconciliation efforts announced to the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC). Several MPs, including Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva, travelled to South Africa in 2014 as part of a high-level delegation to learn more about the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, but the matter was never followed up.  As on previous occasions, the South African Government invited the Minister to obtain insights with regard to the South African experience in setting up their Truth Commission. Cabinet approved the concept of a Truth and Reconciliation Mechanism as proposed by the Cabinet Sub-Committee on Reconciliation, which is chaired by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Cabinet also authorised the Minister of Foreign Affairs and the Minister of Justice to operationalise this concept and to initiate discussions and facilitate the drafting of a Truth and Reconciliation Law. He was invited by South Africa’s Minister of International Relations and Cooperation Dr. Naledi Pandor.   By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Hill country leopard population increases
author: Author not found
Content: The number of wet zone, hill country leopards (Panthera Pardus Kotiya) has increased significantly in recent times, according to environmentalists. However, leopard deaths have also increased, a representative of Knuckles Ape Environmental Organisation, Saminda Vidanage, pointed out. With the increase in population, these leopards tend to roam, posing a threat to both themselves and humans, he said. According to the environmentalists, 15 leopards in 2020, eight in 2021 and a seven in 2022 had perished in the hill country due to human acts. So far this year, two leopards have died after being caught in traps set up in Nuwara Eliya and Bulathkohupitiya. BY Chandrasiri Mahagama – NuwaraEliya

title: SL Govts deceived IMF for 16 years after obtaining its assistance – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Successive Sri Lankan Governments, throughout the past 16 years, deceived the International Monetary Fund (IMF) after obtaining its financial assistance, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena claimed. Addressing the Cabinet media briefing yesterday (21), Gunawardena said after obtaining financial assistance, past Governments failed to adhere to the conditions they pledged to fulfil. If that happens this time too, the country will face a grave disaster, he said. He said President Ranil Wickremesinghe has clearly stated that the full agreement with the IMF will be presented to Parliament. “We have deceived the IMF 16 times before this, by not acting in accordance with the conditions we agreed upon. If this happens again, the country will sink deeper into the abyss. As a result, I believe it is critical to focus on building a national consensus on working in accordance with the IMF programme rather than working to fulfil other political agendas,” he said. Furthermore, Gunawardena said it is his personal opinion that those political parties opposed to the IMF deal can present their alternative suggestions and potential solutions to Parliament, where those proposals can be debated and approved. “My personal idea is that whoever opposes the agreement the Sri Lankan Government is signing with IMF, should come up with their proposals without only criticising the agreement. I would even consider holding a referendum on this,” he said. When asked if the Government is receiving a financial assistance of Rs 9 billion or Rs 3 billion, he responded that there is no agreement on the financial assistance. “The IMF loan will be received as an assurance regarding the country’s economic stabilisation. This will aid in receiving other loans, such as those from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the World Bank,” he elaborated. BY Thameenah Razeek
