title: Enviro Water Systems encourages Sri Lanka to ‘Be the change’ on World Water Day 2023
author: Author not found
Content: Enviro Water Systems, one of the leading water treatment solution providers in Sri Lanka, is marking World Water Day 2023 by reminding all Sri Lankans to be more mindful when using water in their daily lives. Founded in 2004, Enviro Water Systems provides solutions for innovative water management that enhance reliability while ensuring lower energy consumption and maintenance costs. The company is a provider of state-of-the-art technology using world-renowned brands and also is a reliable after sales service partner. The World Water Day 2023 campaign, called “Be the change”, encourages people across the globe to take action in their own lives to change the way they use, consume and manage water. Although 71% of the Earth is covered in water, the majority of it is salt water and only 3% is fresh water. Only 1% of it is usable and 2% is ice and glaciers. Sri Lanka is known to be a land that is blessed with an abundance of water resources. However, in recent years there have been regular water scarcities in several parts of the island due to spatial and temporal variations in rainfall and changing weather patterns. There are also areas where there is insufficient water throughout the year while in some areas, there is water available but it’s not safe for consumption. Overall, it is clear that the availability of water in Sri Lanka is not necessarily the primary concern. The core water security issues lie in its management as studies have shown that over 50% of the country’s rainfall goes to the sea and is not utilized at all. Every year, Sri Lankans have to undergo numerous water cuts during dry seasons. To be better equipped to face this situation it is best to reduce the need by changing the way is used, consumed and managed. This helps in reducing the consumption habit in short term and saving water over the long term. Daily habits at home can be modified to reduce water consumption. Leaving the tap open when brushing teeth or shaving and letting the water run when soaping up in the shower wastes large amounts of water daily. As a result, a household with four adults can waste as much as 12 units of water per month. On the other hand, by introducing a little cleaning kitchen water and bath water can be reused for gardening and flushing toilets. By changing these bad habits, water consumption can be cut down and the water bill reduced. Additionally, the government’s expenditure on water treatment can be reduced thereby helping the economy of the country. It is also important to introduce mechanisms to reduce the use of fresh water in industries and introduce mandatory regulations for reuse of wastewater and promote those industries. Enviro Water Systems portfolio of solutions includes water treatment, sewage treatment, waste water treatment, water treatment chemicals and preventive maintenance. The company’s objective is to go beyond providing of waste water management solutions but also assurance of its premier quality of treated water. By using the expertise of its qualified, hands on, and experienced professionals, it is able to deliver high quality, cutting edge, cost effective and environmentally friendly technological solutions for customers by understanding their needs individually.

title: Sri Lanka no more a bankrupt country – President
author: Author not found
Content: Claiming that Sri Lanka can no longer be treated as a bankrupt country, following International Monetary Fund’s (IMF) approval for an extended arrangement under the Extended Fund Facility (EFF), President Ranil Wickremesinghe said he will table the full agreement with the IMF in Parliament today (22).  He is also due to make a detailed statement on the IMF facility in the House. In a special statement yesterday (21), the President said, “The IMF has certified that Sri Lanka is capable of restructuring its debt. Sri Lanka will no longer be treated as a bankrupt country.” Normal economic activities can resume with this assurance. As our foreign exchange situation improves, the restrictions placed on imports will be gradually lifted, he said. The President said that essential goods, medicines and goods related to the tourism industry will be included in the first round. He expressed his gratitude to all countries that helped Sri Lanka to finalise the deal, including the heads of the IMF.  Right after the news that IMF approved an extended arrangement under the EFF on Monday (20) night, the President said, “In the 75 years of Sri Lanka’s independence, there has never been a more critical period for our economic future.  Our official creditors have declared their support, following continuous and positive engagements over the last few months and we are pleased that the IMF Executive Board approved our programme, enabling Sri Lanka to access up to USD 7 billion in funding from the IMF and IFIs. From the very start, we committed to full transparency in all our discussions with financial institutions and with our creditors. I express my gratitude to the IMF and our international partners for their support, as we look to get the economy back on track for the long term through prudent fiscal management and our ambitious reform agenda. “Since taking office last July, it has been my priority to stabilise Sri Lanka’s economy and achieve sustainable levels of debt,” the President said. “To do so, we have taken some tough decisions, but we did so with a commitment to widening our social safety nets, protecting the vulnerable, rooting out corruption and ensuring we can grow an inclusive and internationally attractive economy. The IMF programme is critical in achieving this vision for our country, and we are committed to successfully completing the IMF programme and achieving debt sustainability. We will continue to engage with all our creditors, and I encourage both our bilateral and commercial creditors to strengthen and foster coordination in the context of our forthcoming engagement. The IMF programme will also be imperative to improving Sri Lanka’s standing in and access to international capital markets and it will demonstrate that Sri Lanka is once again a country attractive to talent, investors and tourists.” Sri Lanka reached a Staff-Level Agreement with the IMF on a four-year programme, supported by the Extended Fund Facility on 1 September 2022. The programme, amounting to USD 3 billion, is expected to restore macroeconomic stability and debt sustainability while protecting vulnerable groups and safeguarding Sri Lanka’s financial system. Since September, the Government of Sri Lanka has held official creditor meetings to update stakeholders on the country’s reform agenda and share information transparently as well as engaging with commercial creditors. Following the IMF Executive Board approval, the disbursement of the first tranche under this programme is expected to take place in the coming days. (NV)

title: PM orders to suspend liquor licences in Maharagama DS
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena instructed officials to suspend the issuance of permanent excise licences for liquor sales in Maharagama Divisional Secretariat Division. This decision was taken at the Maharagama Regional Coordination Committee meeting held on 20 March. The PM also instructed to suspend the issuance of excise permits issued daily for events such as musical shows, carnivals and various other occasions. The progress of development projects in Maharagama was reviewed and special attention was paid to social welfare programmes. It was revealed that 13,377 applications have been received for the Government’s new social welfare programme and relevant data of 2,560 persons has been collated. Gunawardena instructed the officials to involve Samurdhi Development Officers in carrying out social welfare programmes.

title: Fuel price reduction likely next month – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: There is a possibility of a significant reduction in fuel prices next month, during the routine price revision, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (21), Wijesekara said the Government would be able to procure fuel shipments at a lower and competitive bidding after the IMF bailout was received. The Minister also said it may be possible to reduce electricity tariffs by December this year. “There were several practical issues when it came to opening of Letters of Demand and obtaining credit facilities due to lack of guarantee to suppliers. However, after the IMF assistance we will be able to purchase fuel at lower and competitive biddings. We will be able to obtain long-term credit facility as well,” he said At the same time, global market prices have been reduced in recent days and the LKR has been appreciated against the USD, he said. Furthermore, Wijesekara said the plan to restructure the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) and Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) would be presented to Parliament within a month. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Indian Armed Forces on Strategic Study Tour to SL
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation of 19 Indian Armed Forces officers led by Group Captain Yunus Syed Muzaffar from the 46th Indian Higher Air Command Course conducted at College of Air Warfare, Secunderabad arrived in Sri Lanka as part of a Strategic Study Tour from 20-24 March. The visit focuses on interactions with senior defence hierarchy as well as visits to military establishments and industrial organisations to broaden the vision of the trainees. The delegation started their visit by paying homage to the martyrs of Indian Peace Keeping Force at the memorial in Battaramulla followed by interactions with High Commissioner of India Gopal Baglay, Chief of Defence Staff General Shavendra Silva and Air Force Commander Air Marshal Sudarshana Pathirana. The delegation is also scheduled to visit Galle, Hambantota, Diyatalawa, Kandy and Katunayake and interact with various agencies to get deeper insights about Sri Lanka. India’s ‘Neighbourhood First Policy’ seeks to promote institutional linkages between the Armed Forces of India and Sri Lanka. Such Study Tours help strengthen the existing bonds of camaraderie and enhance people to people connections to achieve regional peace, security and stability.

title: “IGP cannot be appointed at the whim of drug lords” – Chanaka
author: Author not found
Content: “The Inspector General of Police (IGP) cannot be appointed at the whim of drug lords,” Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP D.V. Chanaka said yesterday (21) in Parliament. “There is a clear conspiracy to use the dollars we receive from tourists and Sri Lankan citizens employed in foreign countries for illegal acts. It is clear now that certain people used the ‘Aragalaya’ for undiyal transactions and to bring drugs into the country,” he alleged. The MP claimed, “Billions of dollars are being used to bring drugs into the country. We earn foreign currency mainly through tourism and foreign remittances, Now we can see that certain people who spoke on behalf of leaders of ‘Aragalaya’ are representing drug kingpins. They are going to the Courts to represent drug lords and at the same time they give ‘advice’ to appoint the next IGP.”  “Now we have a question. Should we appoint the IGP according to the instructions of ‘Harak Kata,’ who is the most famous drug kingpin in Sri Lanka at present? Are these lawyers representing the views of ‘Harak Kata’? This is nothing but a conspiracy. ‘Aragalaya’ is a conspiracy. The dollars received by our country are being used to bring drugs from foreign countries.” “Therefore, we request both the President and the Minister of Public Security to launch a probe to find out whether the dollars received are utilised through our banking system in a legal manner. It is okay if a separate Police unit is set up for that purpose. We have imposed restrictions on imports. If we utilise the foreign currency we have properly, then there would not be a gap between imports and exports. There would be no problem in running the country. We can import fuel, coal and other essential items without any problem.” “It should be mentioned that no leaders in this country would appoint the IGP according to the instructions of drug lords. Therefore, I request all the State officials and the Opposition not to support such types of sinister attempts.” “Another thing. There is a discussion on holding elections. I would like to say that except for former Premier Mahinda Rajapaksa, the rest of the 224 MPs do not have a right to speak about this matter. I can give you plenty of examples of how these people including the JVP postponed elections from 2015 to 2018. The JVP says they were not aware of that. Are they babies? The same goes for members of the ‘Helicopter’ alliance. The election which was scheduled to be held last year was postponed. Some members of the ‘Helicopter’ alliance were ministers at that time.  How can they speak about holding elections then? All of them got together to postpone the elections at that time and now they want to hold the election for their own political gains.” “These are not the real problems of ordinary citizens. The real problems are increased fuel prices, increased electrify bills and increased commodity prices. The Government is working to resolve these burning issues. We will go for an election after stabilising the country. The Opposition always said this Government is not democratic. They said we will not get IMF assistance because the Government is not following democratic principles. We have now obtained the IMF assistance. It shows that the whole world accepts that the Government is following democratic principles.”

title: Italian Envoy meets DG Civil Aviation
author: Author not found
Content: Italian Ambassador Rita Giuliana Mannella paid a courtesy call on Director General of Civil Aviation and Chief Executive Officer P.A. Jayakantha recently at Civil Aviation Authority of Sri Lanka (CAASL) headquarters. The discussions revolved around the Italian carrier’s new business opportunities and the Ambassador provided suggestions and their proposed airline operational plans on resuming international passenger operations between the two countries. Chief Commercial Officer of Leonardo Company Roberto Pierdominici was present at this meeting.

title: Germany’s Envoy for Indo-Pacific Policy to visit Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: Director Indo-Pacific Policy, South Asia and Afghanistan, Ambassador Erik Kurzweil of the German Federal Foreign Ministry will be on an official to Sri Lanka from tomorrow (22) to 25 March to hold political discussions and consultations with the Government. Ambassador Kurzweil, together with German Ambassador Holger Seubert and Deputy Head of Mission Olaf Malchow, will conduct political discussions and consultations with senior members of the Government and also will hold several meetings with representatives of the Opposition, think tanks, civil society, press, German companies in Sri Lanka and other stakeholders, the German Embassy in Sri Lanka said yesterday (21). The discussions will focus on strengthening ties between the two countries in all spheres, especially as the two countries celebrate the milestone of 70 years of diplomatic relations this year. Ambassador Kurzweil will also pay a visit to the recently launched Hatch MakerStudio, a community workspace, which provides access to state-of-the-art digital technology and equipment to encourage start-ups and innovations. The German Federal Government financed the MakerStudio. (SRM)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Remembering fallen Police Officers
author: Author not found
Content: A memorial was held near the Police memorial statue at the Central Province DIG’s Office to commemorate Police heroes who sacrificed their lives for the country coinciding with the 159th Police Heroes Day which fell yesterday (21). The event commemorated 3,146 Police Officers who sacrificed their lives in the performance of their duty since PC Tuan Saban laid down his life attempting to arrest Utuwankande Saradiel on 21 March 1864. By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: IMF programme will restore SL’s debt sustainability – CBSL
author: Author not found
Content: The Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL), which raised the policy interest rates of Sri Lanka at the beginning of March to secure the long-awaited International Monetary Fund (IMF) bailout, said yesterday (21) that the IMF programme will restore Sri Lanka’s debt to sustainable levels. This was after news broke that the IMF had approved the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) to bail out Sri Lanka. In a tweet, the CBSL said it is key to ensuring a sustainable exit from the country’s crisis, securing long-term growth, and investing in human and economic development. Following the IMF approval, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa tweeted that IMF assistance to Sri Lanka is necessary and welcomed it. “It should now be combined with a plan: to reduce corruption, support the poor and increase economic growth. Governance reform, listening to the voice of the people, and a global outlook will be the ingredients of success,” he tweeted. On the approval of the bailout, SJP MP Dr. Harsha de Silva tweeted “relieved” and appreciated President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s commitment to get the job done.    “Notwithstanding our political differences, the professionalism of the Government and the CBSL in the process must be commended,” he said. He further said, “If the previous members (lot) did this in 2020, our people would not have suffered this way. We could have come out with much less pain. Their arrogance and greed finally bankrupted us. Let’s look forward. Debt restructuring will be hard. Reform is the key,” and added that a sustainable solution is to break down walls and build bridges to the world. The European Union (EU) Office in Colombo tweeted that it welcomed the IMF Executive Board’s approval and thanked the creditors including the EU Member States for working together to help Sri Lankans. Meanwhile, US Ambassador to Sri Lanka Julie Chung said her government welcomes the approval of Sri Lanka’s IMF package. “It’s great news and an important step on the road toward economic recovery. The Government of SL will need to continue reforms and conclude debt restructuring agreements to ensure the programme – and the economy – stay on track,” she said. She added that structural and lasting reforms that address good governance and transparency are critical to ensure all citizens of Sri Lanka can prosper. The IMF said its Board approved a 48-month extended arrangement under the EFF of SDR 2.286 billion (about USD 3 billion) to support Sri Lanka’s economic policies and reforms and the objectives of the EFF-supported programme are to restore macroeconomic stability and debt sustainability, safeguarding financial stability, and stepping up structural reforms to unlock Sri Lanka’s growth potential. To the IMF Board, tackling corruption should continue, including revamping anti-corruption legislation. They said a more comprehensive anti-corruption reform agenda should be guided by the ongoing IMF governance diagnostic mission that conducts an assessment of Sri Lanka’s anti-corruption and governance framework. IMF Mission Chief for Sri Lanka Masahiro Nozaki added that they also noted that they do not intervene in local election processes and that the IMF has never recommended postponing Local Government (LG) Elections in Sri Lanka.   By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: 84th Anniversary Buddhist Temple at Mandir Marg in New Delhi
author: Author not found
Content: A special ceremony was held to mark the 84th anniversary of the establishment of the Buddhist Temple at Mandir Marg New Delhi. The Viharya, a Branch centre of the Maha Bodhi Society of India, was opened on 18 March 1936, and Ven. Hammalawa Saddhatissa Thera was the first monk in charge. Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda was the chief guest. Staff members of the High Commission and a large number of Sri Lankan and other Buddists residing in the city participated in the anniversary Pinkama.

title: Illegally imported confectionery items to be seized
author: Author not found
Content: An Islandwide operation has been launched to seize stocks of chocolate and confectionery items that have been imported, violating the Provisions of Food Act, President of the Public Health Inspectors’ (PHIs) Union Upul Rohana said. Following the current economic crisis in the country, import restrictions have been imposed on foreign confectionery items, including chocolate. However, it has been found that some businesspersons continue to import foreign manufactured confectioneries, violating the Food Act, he said. “According to the Food Act, there are limitations on importing confectionaries. As a result, information such as manufacture date, expiry date and ingredients of the products should be clearly displayed on the package in two languages used in Sri Lanka. This can be only done if the product is imported following legal measures. However, it has been informed to us that the products that do not display this information are in the local market,” he said. As a result, all the confectionery items including chocolate that have been imported violating the Food Act will be seized, Rohana said.  BY Jude Samantha

title: SLRC shares knowledge and experience with Pera Uni Students
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Red Cross Society (SLRCS), Sri Lanka’s largest humanitarian organisation, hosted a two-day residential programme for undergraduates from the Faculty of Agriculture, University of Peradeniya (UoP) in Galgamuwa. The residential workshop was a knowledge and experience sharing field visit organised as part of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) and International Committee of Red Cross (ICRC), Empress Shoken Fund-funded Ground Water Recharging for Disaster Preparedness Project, which is being executed by the Kurunegala Branch of SLRCS. The programme commenced at the SLRCS Kurunegala Branch training hall with an introduction to the organisation, Climate Change Adaptation (CCA), Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR), and the Ground Water Recharging for Disaster Preparedness Project. In the initial discussion, the students were separated into three groups: agriculture engineering, soil and agriculture, and social science aspects. The students were instructed to gather information and uncover results with a preference for their chosen groups, and to submit their findings at the end of the residential workshop. On their field trip in Galgamuwa, the students spoke with villagers and beneficiaries, while SLRCS resource personnel accompanied the students to raise awareness about groundwater recharging linked to CCA and DRR. The students enjoyed, while learning far more than they could have imagined. As discussed at the initial stage, the students presented their findings with great enthusiasm at the Irrigation Training Institute (ITI) in Galgamuwa, using PowerPoint presentations, videos, and discussions. The students’ communication and analytical skills based on their findings were greatly appreciated by the resource personnel and staff of SLRCS. The Ground Water Recharging for Disaster Preparedness Project is developing 65 homesteads in the Ihala Palukadewa region, with 42 of them now running extremely effectively. These home gardens could be used to assess the success and feasibility of the project’s groundwater recharge technologies. The project’s positive influence on people’s mindsets, as well as the rise in soil moisture level owing to groundwater recharge, is strongly represented in these existing homesteads. The project’s indirect advantage is that it will help to alleviate the present economic crisis and food shortages. Branch Executive Officer of the Kurunegala Branch of the Sri Lanka Red Cross Society, Sarath Wickramasinghe said: “It was a pleasure to work on the project with the Faculty of Agriculture at the UoP. My team has worked relentlessly via the project for a better environment for the people. One of the key goals of the project is to raise awareness and capacity, and being able to interact with students is confirmation that the project’s execution is in good hands, since they represent the future of this specific industry. We are excited to continue working together to help Sri Lankan communities thrive in the future.”

title: Cabinet Nod for divesting five key SOEs
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka has decided to divest State held stakes in five key State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs) and their subsidiaries to raise USD 3-4 billion, sources said. The Government has approved the appropriate Cabinet document, which states that shares in the listed State-run firms, such as Sri Lanka Telecom and Lanka Hospitals, must be sold on the Colombo Stock Exchange. In this regard, Sri Lanka Telecom and Lanka Hospitals have informed the Colombo Stock Exchange that the Secretary of the Ministry of Finance has already communicated the Cabinet decision to them. The Securities and Exchange Commission of Sri Lanka (SEC) and the Colombo Stock Exchange (CSE) are presently revising internal guidelines and amending listing requirements to allow SOEs to be listed in the CSE, Manil Jayesinghe, country managing partner at EY Sri Lanka & the Maldives and Chairperson of the SEC-CSE joint committee for new products, told Finance Today. “Once this structure is in place, SOEs will be able to readily enter the capital market for fundraising, and the public will be able to become owners of SOEs,” he added. Moreover, this will help encourage attempts to restructure SOEs. The Sri Lankan Government has also established a fully government-owned holding company to accelerate the State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs), reform process under the supervision of newly formed SOE restructuring unit. Specifically, “as mentioned by the government in this year’s budget,” SriLankan Airlines, Sri Lanka Telecom, Colombo Hilton, Waters Edge, and Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation (SLIC), along with their subsidiaries will be restructured and sold as a first step. “The money from this will be used to strengthen the country’s foreign exchange reserves and the value of the rupee,” sources said. On 21 September last year, Finance Today exclusively reported, that the government is prepared to undertake changes in the airline, telecom, insurance, and hotel sectors. The money from this will be used to strengthen the country’s foreign exchange reserves and the value of the rupee.  Sri Lanka Telecom is already a listed company, and Malaysia’s UT Group already owns 49%. Reports say that they are ready to sell their shares if State ownership falls into the hands of another investor. Sri Lanka Insurance is a former private company that was taken over by the government following a Court case. It has a value of over 500 million dollars, and the government hopes to get between USD 3-4 billion by giving these government firms to the private sector. The Insurance Corporation, which also has controlling stakes in the listed Lanka Hospital, Litro Gas Lanka, and the Grand Hyatt Colombo, owns Canwill Holdings (Private) Limited. The Colombo Hilton is owned by Hotel Developers, and is estimated to be worth around USD 100-115 million. The Sri Lankan Government is working with Lazard, the country’s financial advisers for the debt restructuring process, to figure out what needs to be done about SriLankan Airlines’ accumulated debt. By Ishara Gamage

title: Motorists advised to be careful on 18th Bend
author: Author not found
Content: Motorists were advised to drive carefully on the 18th Bend from Hasalaka to Hunnasgiriya, as the area has been prone to landslides and earth slips, the traffic division of Hasalaka Police said, Police said this situation has emerged during the recent heavy downpours in the area. Police have advised drivers to exercise extreme caution when striving to overtake vehicles on the 18th Bend. BY Sunil Ihalagedera – Hasalaka

title: AG to file limited objections on 4 April
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General is due to file limited objections, on 4 April, in connection with two cases filed, seeking to ensure the safety of drug kingpin Nadun Chinthaka Wickremeratne alias ‘Harak Kata’ and notorious drug trafficker Salindu Malshika Gunaratna alias ‘Kudu Salindu’. Deputy Solicitor General Shanil Kularatne, appearing on behalf of the Attorney General requested time to file limited objections, while requesting for a date after the vacation as he is inundated with work. President’s Counsel Nalin Ladduwahetty and Attorney-at-Law Hafeel Farisz, on behalf of ‘Kudu Salindu’ argued that if the case is taken up after the vacation, it will be pure academic and that it should be taken up as a matter of urgency. Further, President’s Counsel Saliya Peiris, appearing on behalf of ‘Harak Kata’, noted that he previously wrote to the Inspector General of Police (IGP) with regard to reports of imminent threat to the lives of those in custody and despite such move, certain drug offenders were killed, noting thereby that this should be taken as a matter of urgency leaving no room for the system to be blamed. The Writ Application on behalf of ‘Kudu Salindu’ was filed by his mother on the basis that there is imminent danger to his life and that he should be produced before Court. They argued that Madush’s wife wrote to the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL), the Director of the Colombo Crimes Division (CCD) and the Red Cross, urging immediate intervention to protect the life of her husband. However, despite such pleas, Madush was killed on 20 October 2020, just prior to his period of administrative detention, under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), was to end after he was illegally moved to the custody of the Colombo Crimes Division from the Criminal Investigations Department (CID) where he was held. Further, they observed that there have been similar incidents where drug offenders have been shot after having been taken by Police to recover weapons and thereby that there is an imminent threat to the life of the petitioner. The Petition on behalf of ‘Harak Kata’ was filed by his father Mervin Wickremeratne seeking an order to ensure there is no imminent threat to his son’s life. The Inspector General of Police (IGP), the Defence Ministry Secretary and the Director of the CID were amongst the Respondents named in the Petition.  Both ‘Kudu Salindu’ and ‘Harak Kata’ were repatriated to Sri Lanka from Madagascar with six others on 15 March morning. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Morayaya Hospital lacks drinking water
author: Author not found
Content: Scores of patients, who are receiving in-house treatment and those visiting the Morayaya Hospital, have been severely inconvenienced due to the non-availability of safe drinking water. According to the patients, even the staff serving at this hospital had been faced with this challenge and are unable to offer safe drinking water to the patients who are receiving treatment. The Morayaya Hospital, which is also the first such hospital in the Minipe Farmer Colony, currently caters to people from 25 villages within 10 Grama Niladhari Divisions. BY Sunil Ihalagedera – Hasalaka

title: Opposition Parties give ultimatum to Treasury Secy
author: Author not found
Content: The Opposition Parties in Parliament gave an ultimatum to the Finance Ministry Secretary to release funds to hold local government election 2023 as per the Order given by the Supreme Court. Chairman of the Freedom People’s Alliance (FPA) Prof. G.L. Peiris said if the Finance Ministry Secretary fails to adhere to the Supreme Court Order, all the Opposition Parties in Parliament would go to the Supreme Court, seeking an Order to enact the previous Interim Order with regard to releasing funds for holding the LG Polls. Prof. Peiris said they will seek an order from the Supreme Court to enact the previous Interim Order issued to the Finance Ministry Secretary and the Attorney General to suspend withholding funds allocated for the election through Budget 2023 without further delay.  If the Finance Ministry Secretary fails to release funds within a week, we will seek an order from the Supreme Court to take steps against him considering that he is in ‘Contempt of Court,’ Prof. Peiris said. BY Bingun Menaka Gamage and Krishan Pathirath Jayasuriya

title: Chung announces arrival of U.S. food assistance
author: Author not found
Content: US Ambassador to Sri Lanka Julie Chung yesterday (20) announced the recent arrival of 770 MT of fortified rice and 100 MT of fortified vegetable oil, through the US Department of Agriculture (USDA)/ Foreign Agricultural Service (FAS), ‘McGovern-Dole Food for Education Programme’ as grant aid, the US Embassy said in a statement. Chung made the announcement during a visit to the Guruaragama Primary School, Embilipitiya, to observe a school feeding programme supported by the United States Government’s assistance.  The Ambassador met teachers and parents as well as schoolchildren as she toured the school’s classrooms. “This is the second school I’ve visited in a week that is receiving food assistance from the United States, last week I was at St. John’s Maha Vidyalaya in Colombo North where USAID is working with the World Food Programme to support a USD 7 million school feeding programme,” she said. In partnership with Save The Children and alongside the Sri Lankan Government and local communities, USDA/FAS is implementing the ‘Promoting Autonomy, Literacy, and Attentiveness through Market Alliances (PALAM/A) project in Sri Lanka.  This USD 27.5 million initiative began providing food shipments at the height of the pandemic and will be completed this year.  The project, which includes monitoring and oversight provisions, improves literacy and nutrition while reducing short-term hunger of school-age children. Since 2021, USDA food aid has provided protein supplements using yellow split peas and Alaskan pink salmon to over 95,000 children in 835 primary schools distributed over seven districts (Nuwara-Eliya, Badulla, Moneragala, Ratnapura, Kilinochchi, Mullaitivu, and Trincomalee), it added. More broadly, the United States Government has provided food assistance to nearly two million Sri Lankan schoolchildren over the past year. Among the others who were present at this occasion were Education Minister Susil Premajayantha, Sabaragamuwa Province Governor Tikiri Kobbekaduwa, and USDA/FAS Senior Regional Agricultural Attaché Mariano J. Beillard. (PA)

title: Order staying Magisterial proceedings against SDIG Tennakoon extended
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (20) extended the Order issued, staying the proceedings of the Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court against Western Province SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon, over alleged criminal breach of trust with regard to Rs 17.8 million recovered from the President’s House on 9 July 2022. This was when the Petition filed by SDIG Tennakoon, against his being summoned by the Fort Magistrate, was taken up before Court of Appeal Judges Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and M.A.R. Marikkar. Accordingly, the case was fixed for 28 March. The Colombo Fort Magistrate on 26 January summoned SDIG Tennakoon to appear before Court on 16 February in connection with criminal breach of trust over the Rs 17.8 million recovered from the President’s House on 9 July during anti-Government protests. SDIG Tennakoon later filed a Petition challenging such issuance of summons.  When the Petition filed by SDIG Tennakoon was taken up on 15 February, Court issued an interim order staying the proceedings of the case and summoning of SDIG Tennakoon until the final determination of the Petition. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Lawyers should improve their professional competence – Minister De Silva
author: Author not found
Content: Lawyers should improve their professional competence and self-education with dedication, Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva said. He made this remark at General Sir John Kotelawala Memorial Mooting Competition hosted and organised by the Moot Court and Debating Society of the General Sir John Kotelawala Defence University (KDU). The event was held recently at the KDU premises. Minister de Silva attended it as Chief Guest. The minister emphasised that Lawyers should improve their professional competence and self-education with dedication. “In order to develop such skills Lawyers and Legal Practitioners should engage investigating case studies with strong commitment. Dedication and commitment will bring opportunity towards stability in this discipline,” the minister said. He said that the legal sector is a very important field in the country and its practitioners, including lawyers have a prominent role in the law making process. Therefore, studies conducted on related subjects lead to the advancement in the field, he added. The National Mooting Competition is held annually with the participation of teams from all law schools in the country. In the interests of bringing something novel, constructive and appealing to the mooting arena, the Competition re-introduces the specialty of domestic Criminal Law and Forensics, with an aim to expand and build upon law students’ knowledge and understanding of the Domestic Criminal Justice Framework while allowing them to tackle fictional scenarios and cases derived from familiar circumstances. Over the course of the Competition, participants are given the opportunity to meet, interact with and be recognised by prominent jurists and the foremost legal academics also guaranteeing them an opportunity to mark their entry into the domestic legal arena and highlight their advocacy and research skills before the most eminent legal minds in the country. KDU Vice chancellor Major General Milinda Peiris, Dean of the Faculty of Law W.S. Wijesinghe and a number of invitees also attended the event.

title: Spoken English in schools from 30 March
author: Author not found
Content: As the English language is very important for the students to succeed in the future, the Education Ministry has decided to teach ‘Spoken English’ in all national schools, starting from Grade 1 from 30 March, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said. Attending a certificate awarding ceremony for National Olympiad winners, at the New Art Gallery of the University of Colombo, Premajayantha said necessary reforms will be brought to school syllabuses from Grade 6-13 in parallel to international standards. The pilot project in this connection will kick off next week. “Furthermore, it is planned to teach Artificial Intelligence (AI) with Information Technology (IT) soon. I am working on fulfilling the dream of achieving the Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) on education. From next month, steps will be taken to improve human resources at schools by recruiting 8,000 National College of Education (NIE) teachers and 26,000 graduate teachers,” the Minister said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Police mark 159th anniversary today
author: Author not found
Content: The 159th Anniversary of the Sri Lanka Police falls today (21) and the commemoration of Police Officers who died while on duty will be held at the Police War Heroes’ Memorial, with participation of their families and relatives. The Sri Lanka Police was constitutionally formed on 3 September 1866 while its anniversary is annually marked on 21 March. When perusing historical data concerning the demise of Police Officers on duty, one of the most significant sources of information is related to the construction of a memorial statue on the Colombo-Kandy road at the Mawanella Police Division. The memorial statue had been built by District Agent E. R. Saunders in memory of PC Saban. PC Saban had been killed in attempting to arrest Uthuwankande Saradiyel on 21 March 1864 which was 24-months prior to the constitutional setting up of the Police Department Saban had succumbed to injuries after being gunned down by Mammale Marikkar, an accomplice of Saradiyel,. The next Police Officer to follow suit was PC No. 289 K. Thmabimuttu who had been killed in the Borella Police Division in 1894. Subsequently various Police officers from different ranks had sacrificed their lives in the performance of their duty such as tackling of crime, prevention of accidents, ensuring reduction of vice and maintenance of law and order. According to data, a total of 3,143 Police officers had died on duty. While a total of 1,567 officers had been rendered disabled while on duty. So far the Government has provided relief to members of the families of Police officers who had perished on duty and for those disabled while on duty and the Government has implemented a programme to provide compensation to family members and relatives. Furthermore, the Government has decided to give prominence to children of Police officers who die on duty when admitting children to State schools and to financially look after parents of unmarried Police officers who had died due to terror activities while on duty before 19 May 2009.

title: EC to hold another meeting with Party Leaders
author: Author not found
Content: Another meeting between the Election Commission (EC) and Political Parties will be held on Thursday (23) to discuss about holding the Local Government Election 2023. EC Chairman Nimal Punchihewa told Ceylon Today that the Government is ‘silent’ over holding the Election. He said the meeting will be held to decide the next step but they are ready to hold it on 25 April as decided.  Meanwhile, the Samangi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), filed a Fundamental Rights (FR) petition at the Supreme Court (SC) yesterday (20), claiming that the Finance Ministry was violating the 3 March Supreme Court interim order to the Finance Secretary on the Local Government (LG) election. Following the Supreme Court order, the Election Commission announced that the LG election would be held on 25 April but the Treasury responded with a letter stating that there are insufficient funds to hold the poll. SJB Colombo Mayoral Candidate Mujibur Rahuman said going against the SC order is Contempt of Court, hence, they have filed a petition against the government’s stance on the LG poll. “The Government cannot backtrack nor violate the SC order,” he stressed and added that the Government is blocking the polls in order to prevent the defeat they would face if the poll is held. Rahuman said the SLPP and the UNP will be sent home in an election and that fear is the reason to drag holding the election further. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Jeevan to seek relief for Poonagala landslide affected
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development Jeevan Thondaman, while instructing authorities to take necessary measures to provide immediate relief to those affected by landslides in the Poonagala Kambaragala Estate, urged the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) to submit a comprehensive report on the incident. Minister Thondaman, who is also the General Secretary of Ceylon Workers’ Congress (CWC), said he was expecting to submit a detailed report on the impact of the landslide and the affected persons to the Cabinet meeting today (21) to pursue further action. Some 220 persons from 62 families were affected and 40 houses were completely damaged due to landslide on Sunday evening (19) at the Kambaragala Estate in Poonagala, Bandarawela.  Thondaman also directed the officials of the NBRO, Geological Surveys and Mines Bureau (GSMB) and other relevant authorities to inspect other landslides prone areas in close proximity and make necessary arrangements to relocate people if there are tenants in threatened areas. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: CBSL seeks AG’s instruction on suing three pyramid schemes
author: Author not found
Content: The Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) has sought instructions from the Attorney General (AG) in connection with filing criminal cases against three prohibited pyramid schemes. In a newspaper advertisement, the CBSL announced that a special investigation, launched into the operations of ‘Fast3cycle International Pvt Ltd.’, Sport Chain App, Sport ‘Chain ZS Society Sri Lanka,’ and ‘Onmax DT’, following numerous complaints, has found out that these three are prohibited pyramid schemes. Accordingly, the CBSL decided that the three pyramid schemes, their directors, promoters, and founders have acted in violation of Section 83C of the Banking Act. Ceylon Today on 18 February published an investigative article on ‘Onmax DT’, which is a ponzi scheme, where they convert the amount that the LKR investor pays into USD with the promise to invest it in various businesses. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Money printing down Rs 2.9 T
author: Author not found
Content: Government of Sri Lanka’s (GoSL) demand-pull inflationary face value money printing (FVMP) debt fell by 0.48 per cent (Rs 13,944 million) to Rs 2,916,020.26 million (Rs 2.916 trillion) yesterday (20), thereby marginally deflating demand-pull inflationary pressure.  GoSL’s  at least direct, theoretical MP borrowing costs (BCs) decreased by 6.48 per cent(Rs 5,789.33 million) to Rs 83,609.34 million yesterday due to buying pressure of Treasury (T) Bills and T Bonds in secondary market trading due to high yields offered, but at the expense of not lending to the private sector, the engine of growth. Led by swap settlements between the GoSL and Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL), contracted liquidity by Rs 250,517 million (USD 742.73 million)  yesterday. Conversions are based on Thursday’s (16 March) administered ‘spot’ value which was Rs 327.29 to the US dollar. Consequently market’s net shortfall increased by 524.43 per cent (Rs 264,461 million) toRs 214,033 million yesterday. Swaps between GoSL and CBSL are foreign reserves neutral. MP, coupled with being the steward of the country’s foreign reserves and of its debt is the exclusive prerogative of the CBSL. CBSL which administers daily ‘OMO’ (open market operations) lacks transparency. GoSL’s FVMP debt is equivalent to the totality of CBSL’s T Bill and T Bond holdings. GoSL’s MPBCs are prorated to the outcome in secondary market trading of T Bills and T Bonds on the reference day. ‘Spot’ trades are settled after two market days from the date of transaction. CBSL, the steward of GoSL debt and its foreign reserves deals in ‘spot.’ The  ‘spot’ is administered to minimise GoSL’s foreign debt in rupee terms and to lower the cost of ‘essential’ imports like medicines and energy imports which are met from the country’s foreign reserves and not from the market, to prevent further depreciative pressure on the rupee as Sri Lanka is an import dependent economy. Issuing of T Bills and T Bonds is a popular way GoSL raises money domestically to meet its local commitments. Investing in T Bills and T Bonds is generally considered as being riskless, because, in the event GoSL is unable to repay such debt, CBSL is normally mandated to print demand pull inflationary money and repay such creditors.   BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Teacher TUs to protest tomorrow
author: Author not found
Content: Teachers’ trade unions are preparing to hold a protest tomorrow (22) at Fort Railway Station against the President’s decision to dissolve the Teacher Transfer Board, Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) General Secretary Joseph Stalin said. He said all the teachers’ trade unions will participate in a trade union action to demand the President’s decision to dissolve the Teacher Transfer Board. Speaking further, Stalin said the discussion with regard to the matter held at the Education Ministry yesterday (20) failed. It is reported that the President held discussions with teacher Transport Board Director and another individual. It has been decided during the meeting to double check the proved transferred before implementing them, Stalin claimed. However, the President cannot intervene in this as the board was appointed by the Education Ministry. When we asked the Education Minister and the Secretary are not aware of the decision taken by the President, he said.

title: FR challenging Duminda’s presidential pardon re-fixed
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (20), re-fixed the Fundamental Rights (FR) Petitions, filed against the Presidential pardon granted to Duminda Silva, who was sentenced to death in 2016 over the murder of Bharatha Lakshman Premachandra, to 30 March. Previously, the Supreme Court issued an Interim Order suspending the operation of the Presidential pardon granted to Silva, while an order impounding Silva’s passport was also made and the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) was directed to implement the interim order. While Silva was sentenced to death in 2016 for the murder of Bharatha Lakshman Premachandra in 2011, President Gotabaya Rajapaksa granted him a special Presidential pardon in 2021. This was when the Fundamental Rights (FR) Petitions filed by the daughter and the wife of late Premachandra, former MP Hirunika Premachandra and Sumana Premachandra,  respectively, against the Presidential pardon was taken up before Court. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Academics, civil society say ‘stop intimidating Judiciary’
author: Author not found
Content: Eighty-seven (87) top officials, civil society members and intellectuals said they are dismayed, over the alleged attempts, being made by the President and some Government MPs, to intimidate the judiciary, on the false pretext that the Supreme Court has violated the privileges of the MPs through its verdict on releasing funds for Local Government Election 2023. They demanded that the President and the Government desist from interfering with the judiciary or the Election Commission, curtailing their independence in a manner that impedes the people’s democratic liberties and rights and also to end misusing political power to harm the country’s democratic institutions and processes for their partisan and personal political interests and ambitions. They also noted that the government should respect the interim order of the Supreme Court on the local elections. This allegation has been made after the Supreme Court granted leave to proceed with a fundamental rights application filed against the withholding of funds for the purpose of conducting local government elections. The Court has also made an interim order restraining several state functionaries from withholding any funds allocated by the Budget for the year 2023 for the purpose of conducting the local elections. Some of the civil society members and academics include, Dr. Mario Gomez, Dr. P. Saravanamuttu, Dr. Jehan Perera, Prof. Arjuna Parakrama – University of Peradeniya, Prof. Deepika Udagama – University of Peradeniya, Prof. Emeritus Jayadeva Uyangoda – University of Colombo, Prof. Emeritus Kapila Gunasekera – University of Peradeniya, Prof. Emeritus Siri Hettige – University of Colombo and Prof. Emeritus. Vijaya Kumar – University of Peradeniya “We vehemently condemn these fresh actions by the government to undermine the democratic process of our country. We also fully endorse the statement issued by the Bar Association of Sri Lanka on this matter. The BASL has warned that any attempt to interfere with the independence of the judiciary is a serious affront to the rule of law, the rights of the people of the country, and democracy,” they said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Delegation leaves for S Africa to study TRC
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation, including Minister of Justice Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe and  Minister of Foreign Affairs M.U.A. Ali Sabry, will leave for South Africa today (21) to further study on establishing a Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) in Sri Lanka. The South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) was set up by the Government of National Unity to help deal with what happened under apartheid, which resulted in violence and human rights abuse from all sides in South Africa. During the visit, the Sri Lankan delegation will study further about establishing a Truth Commission similar to South Africa within the Sri Lankan context. The South African High Commissioner in Sri Lanka recently invited the Government to visit South Africa to explore about the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission to establish peace and reconciliation. The idea of establishing a South Africa-style truth and reconciliation commission, to look into atrocities during the war against terrorism, was first mooted by the late Minister Mangala Samaraweera in 2015, when the ‘Good-governance’ Government was elected. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Case against Wele Suda deferred
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (20) deferred further proceedings of the case against drug kingpin Wele Suda and another to 9 June. Gampola Vidanage Samantha Kumara alias Wele Suda and another have been charged before the High Court, with unlawfully accruing profits amounting to Rs. 60 million, via the narcotic trade. When the case was called yesterday, the State Counsel, on behalf of the prosecution, informed Judge Marasinghe, that they intend to amend the indictments filed against the two accused. Accordingly, the Court ordered to defer further proceedings of the trial, to the aforementioned date. The Attorney General has indicted death row inmate Wele Suda and another accused before the High Court, with earning the aforementioned sum via the narcotics trade from 1 December 2008 to 1 December 2009 and with having flouted Provisions contained in Sections of the Money Laundering Act. By Hansi Nanayakkara

BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Father, son killed in accident
author: Author not found
Content: A father and son succumbed to injuries following an accident in Seeduwa on 18 March, Police said. The Police Media Division said the accident occurred when a van travelling from Kotugoda towards Seeduwa collided head on with a bicycle. The deceased were identified as 45-year-old and 14-year-old residents of Raddoluwa, Seeduwa. The van driver was arrested and Seeduwa Police are conducting investigations. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: 25-year plan to bring country out of morass
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe was of the view that in the event the IMF identifies Sri Lanka as a non-bankrupt country, the Government would get an additional 10 years to repay the debt that has to be paid this year. Meanwhile, he said new debts would arise and the Government would then have to borrow money because the annual foreign exchange earnings were insufficient to meet needs such as importing fuel and fertiliser. The President said there was a balance of payment which means that foreign earnings were less than the money that must be spent to purchase the needs from abroad. The President was addressing the 32nd Interact District Conference held at Temple Trees yesterday (19). “Secondly, how do we stabilise the Rupee? Compared to the Dollar the Rupee has now gone up to Rs 300. Once we have this agreement with the IMF, the Rupee will gradually come down to Rs 200 or Rs 185. Now we have a period of stabilisation and that is four years. We have agreed with the IMF, they have given us targets to achieve. We have agreed that the budget will not be a deficit and that the budget will have a surplus by 2026, and that we will then be able to pay back the money that we borrowed. Now that is not a very good situation. Once we stabilise the economy and we can restructure the debts, we must also find a means of paying off all our debts and coming to a situation where we have a surplus in the country; every year, like Japan, Singapore, Germany, or Korea. At the end of the day, we must have a surplus. Our foreign exchange earnings must exceed our requirements but for the time being we have to import fuel, medicine, and certain other basic foodstuff. So that is the next stage,” he said. Speaking further he said “In order to win this encounter, stabilising the economy alone was not enough. You must make the economy grow. Unless you make the economy grow, we will go down again. “As far as I am concerned, we have not only to lay the groundwork but also to restructure our debt, to stabilize our economy, so that we can repay our debt in ten years’ time. In order to build the new economy in which we will be prosperous, and we will also be able to become a developed economy giving a better future for those who will be living in the next 40-50 years, I need a team. When I lay that plan down, I need a team for that match”. That is going to be the big match. We have to decide whether we are going or make it, whether we are going to develop the country or whether we are going to let it slide. For that game who is my team? My team is going to be all of you. What we will lay down now, is the 25-year plan,” he said. The President also pointed out that by 2049, there will be a prosperous Nation. He said Sri Lanka will be like the people in Malaysia and the people in some of the European countries. “We will have no debt, and more than that, each of you will have earned at least a few thousand dollars a month or maybe more. Now I say, each of you because, during the next 25 years all of you; the oldest here will be 45. You will not even be 50. Some will be less. It is your future that we have to talk of. Unless I stabilise the economy, we cannot develop as a country to become a prosperous society. Once we stabilise the economy, we can go ahead to develop the country. Some of you might be thinking of going abroad for education. I understand the difficulty of getting into universities here and the problems you face in the universities. Some of you might be thinking of going abroad and leaving Sri Lanka. Some of you may be thinking of going abroad to work and coming back. All I want to say to all those who are thinking of going abroad is not to abandon the country. In the next two years, you will see the country developing and then you will see that you have a future. This is a 25-year match. The second innings will be much longer than the first innings. The first innings is only four years, second will be 21 years after that,” he said. He said it is a must to become the most prosperous country in our region, not have poverty, to have employment, to have a green economy, to have a s-economy, to be modern in technology and modern in thinking. “There has to be a very marked change in the way the county is governed. That is what you call a system change. We must have that system change thinking of the Interactors here. What is the country you want? What is the society you want? What are the changes you want? In that case, you have to participate in building that country. Because you will finally take over the leadership. So what you have been trained here is not merely to run the road trip. But every one of you in different ways will help to build the country and hopefully run the country and some of you, I hope will be able to come forward as Rotarians and make the speech that I have been making today. So I don’t want to take any more of your time, but I wish you all the best in your future endeavours and wish the Interact all the best,” he said. Meanwhile, the President emphasised that the Royal College cricket team’s effective captaincy ultimately led to the team’s victory at a time when all of the matches were being lost and that his effort was to lift the defeated country to the path of victory similar to what the captain of the Royal College cricket team did. The President recalled that when he assumed office last July, the country was experiencing numerous crises such as shortage of fuel, food, and fertiliser. He compared this to the Royal team, which had suffered a string of defeats, and claimed that many people believed the country would not be able to recover. However, President Ranil Wickremesinghe stressed that his team was able to change that situation and create economic stability in the country in the last seven months and emphasised that Sri Lanka is no longer a bankrupt state. He said that everyone would be able to witness a  developing country in the next two years, and to make Sri Lanka the most prosperous country in the region, it is necessary to build the economy in addition to stabilising it today. The President added that the 25-year plan to make Sri Lanka a successful nation by 2048 has already been implemented and it can only be achieved with the commitment of the current youth. This conference was organised by S. Thomas’ College, Wesley College, Visakha Vidyalaya, and Girls’ High School, Kandy and drew about 700 students from various schools across the island. President  Wickremesinghe was welcomed by the Chairperson of the 32nd Interact District Conference, Abdullah Siddeek who delivered the welcome speech. Appreciating his support and participation in the Interact Global Youth Movement, District Governor of the Rotary International District 3220 for Sri Lanka and the Maldives Pubudu De Zoysa presented a memento to the President and Interact District Conference President Abdullah Siddeek presented the President with a plaque. Speaking Further the President also said: “Your District Governor was worried that I may not turn up here today after the Royal-Thomian Match yesterday. I want to tell her that the match was over yesterday, and a new day begins today. It was, I must say, an interesting match and I must commend both the Royal and the St. Thomas teams. In a way, it’s training in leadership for the Captains of both sides, as well as those who will be playing next year. How do you prepare for a match, how do you work together with your coach, how do you try to win the match and how do you prevent losing a match. This is what you have to go into. Well, yesterday was a decisive day instead of being a draw unlike previous Royal- Thomian matches. There was an outcome. As for the Thomians, they have to study why they lost. Why royal won. What are the weaknesses in your strategies and how can you win the D.S. Senanayake shield next year. So that itself is a test in leadership. For Royal College, and especially its Captain, it is another test. Having lost many matches, first, how do you prevent a defeat and second, how do you win. So instead of looking at how to prevent a defeat, he decided to go for victory. It was good leadership and I must commend him for turning a situation in which Royal was losing all matches, into a victory in the final encounter. Now I am also trying to do what the Royal cricket Captain had done. Last July, I was asked to take over the country. At that time, there was a shortage of fuel, a shortage of fertiliser, and a shortage of food and there was a shortage of everything. We had no money. We couldn’t make our payments. The government had no money. It was a difficult task. It was like the Royal team which had lost most of the matches and many thought that we won’t be able to come out of it. So far, in the last seven months, we have been able to; my team has been able to stabilise the situation. There is fuel now. There is electricity. There is fertilizer and by April, there will be enough rice and other foodstuff. We will no longer be declared a bankrupt Nation, but a Nation that can restructure its debts. That will happen in the next few days. So like the Captain of the Royal Team, I also have to perform the same function. How do we turn this economy around? The results of the IMF Board of Directors only give us a breathing space where they will say that we are no longer bankrupt and we can restructure the debt.

title: POLICE PROBE FISHERMAN’S DEATH

title: Fmr MP Piyasena dies in road mishap
author: Author not found
Content: Former Digamadulla District MP P.H. Piyasena was killed in an accident near the Alayadivembu Cemetery on the Pottuvil-Akkaraipattu road. Piyasena was riding his motorcycle to the cemetery, to participate in a shramadana to clear the area, as is customary, when he was hit by a private bus bound for Polonnaruwa from Pottuvil. He was rushed to Akkaraipattu Base Hospital and later transferred to Kalmunai Base Hospital, as his condition was critical, where he died. The funeral was held at the Akkaraipattu Hindu burial grounds, where the accident occurred. He was 61 years old and the father of three children. BY M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Environmentalists up in arms over cutting down trees in and around N’Eliya
author: Author not found
Content: Environmentalists in Nuwara Eliya opposed the cutting of undecayed fertile trees and trees that were more than 50 years within the Nuwara Eliya city limits and several surrounding areas such as Udyana Road, near the racecourse and Upper Lake Road. He said during British rule, cypress trees were planted to protect the water resources and for the environmental and aesthetic beauty of the Nuwara Eliya area in keeping with environmental concepts of the Governors of the time  but now it was just the opposite as orders were being given to cut down trees. Environmentalists have serious doubts they said as to whether officials had any understanding of these valuable trees. When asked about the allegation, Nuwara Eliya Divisional Secretary Prageeth Danansuriya said he did not have expert knowledge about trees but had given permission to cut those based on recommendations given by Hakgala Botanical Garden’s technical officers. Five trees had been cut down after being identified as posing a threat and branches of another were also cut. “The State Timber Corporation is responsible for cutting trees but has been temporarily halted while a thorough investigation is being conducted. I am prepared to investigate the matter and take  disciplinary action, if trees were cut down without permission or without following proper procedure,” he said.   BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: 11 MOTORCYCLISTS ARRESTED FOR RACING ON HIGH LEVEL ROAD
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 11 motorcyclists were arrested for racing on High Level Road, endangering the public, Police said. Police said 11 motorcycles were also seized yesterday (19). The suspects are aged 18-30 and are residents of Maharagama, Pannipitiya, Kottawa, Arawwala and Piliyandala. The arrests were made based on complaints received by the 119 Police Emergency Centre from area residents. Motorcyclists had raced in this location previously and the Police had released them after a strict warning. In addition, Police will investigate individuals betting money on these races.  By Hashan Pushpika – Pannipitiya

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: GSMB says no need to fear minor tremors
author: Author not found
Content: A minor earth tremor of 2.6 on the Richter Scale was reported in Kirinda on Saturday (18) and another of magnitude 3 was reported from Gomarankadawala at 3.30 p.m. yesterday (19), the Geological Survey and Mines Bureau (GSMB) said. However, the GSMB said the public should not unduly fear the minor tremors that have occurred so far. GSMB Senior Geologist Danushka Hettiarachchi yesterday said many earth tremors occurred throughout the day yesterday between the Indo-Australian plate where Sri Lanka is located and the Asian plate located above it. We have drawn attention to the issue of whether any release of energy during the tremors occurred in Sri Lanka, he said. He added that there should be no undue fear of any damage occurring. Meanwhile, Geography Professor Atula Senaratne of the Peradeniya University said the Richter scale reading of the tremors that have occurred in the last 30 – 40 years was less than 4. Therefore, huge earthquakes in the country were out of the question. However,tremors reading 2, 2.5, 3, and 3.5on the Richter scale may occur in the future too, he added. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Excise revenue down 12.2% to Rs 25.1B
author: Author not found
Content: Excise revenue decreased by 12.2 per cent in the first two months of 2023 compared to the first two months of 2022. According to Excise Department reports, excise revenue in the first two months of last year was Rs 28.6 billion, while excise revenue in the same period this year was Rs 25.1 billion. Excise Commissioner Saman Jayasinghe said despite the fact that the alcohol tax has been raised by 20 per cent effective 1 January 2023, overall excise revenue has decreased due to a decrease in regular sales of taxable alcohol. Meanwhile, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya recently said in Parliament that according to World Health Organization studies, illicit liquor consumption in Sri Lanka has increased by 300 per cent. Another reason for the increase in the sale of illegal spirits, he said, is the inability to buy regular spirits due to irregularities at spirit stores.

title: RW has no powers to hold Presidential Poll this year – Herath
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) executive committee member, MP Vijitha Herath said President Ranil Wickremesinghe has no powers to hold a Presidential Election this year. Speaking to the media yesterday (19), MP Herath said in terms of the Constitution, a succeeding President has no powers to hold a Presidential Election before the expiry of the full term of five years. While referring to the rumours that the President hopes to hold a Presidential Election, he said President Wickremesinghe is empowered to conduct a Presidential Election only after November 2024. Speaking further, he urged the Government to immediately bow to the Court decision and provide the necessary funds to hold the LG Polls. “The Executive and the Cabinet have no right to go against it. Also, provide the basic infrastructure needed to hold the election on 25 April, which is presently scheduled,” he urged. MP Herath emphasised that the Court is a body that can give judgments against any ruler who acts unconstitutionally. He said the President, the Cabinet, the Parliament and the people of this country are obliged to bow to Court decisions. “If these Court decisions are ignored, legal action can be instituted against any such person on charges of Contempt of Court,” he added. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi
