author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Fmr MP Piyasena dies in road mishap
author: Author not found
Content: Former Digamadulla District MP P.H. Piyasena was killed in an accident near the Alayadivembu Cemetery on the Pottuvil-Akkaraipattu road. Piyasena was riding his motorcycle to the cemetery, to participate in a shramadana to clear the area, as is customary, when he was hit by a private bus bound for Polonnaruwa from Pottuvil. He was rushed to Akkaraipattu Base Hospital and later transferred to Kalmunai Base Hospital, as his condition was critical, where he died. The funeral was held at the Akkaraipattu Hindu burial grounds, where the accident occurred. He was 61 years old and the father of three children. BY M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Environmentalists up in arms over cutting down trees in and around N’Eliya
author: Author not found
Content: Environmentalists in Nuwara Eliya opposed the cutting of undecayed fertile trees and trees that were more than 50 years within the Nuwara Eliya city limits and several surrounding areas such as Udyana Road, near the racecourse and Upper Lake Road. He said during British rule, cypress trees were planted to protect the water resources and for the environmental and aesthetic beauty of the Nuwara Eliya area in keeping with environmental concepts of the Governors of the time  but now it was just the opposite as orders were being given to cut down trees. Environmentalists have serious doubts they said as to whether officials had any understanding of these valuable trees. When asked about the allegation, Nuwara Eliya Divisional Secretary Prageeth Danansuriya said he did not have expert knowledge about trees but had given permission to cut those based on recommendations given by Hakgala Botanical Garden’s technical officers. Five trees had been cut down after being identified as posing a threat and branches of another were also cut. “The State Timber Corporation is responsible for cutting trees but has been temporarily halted while a thorough investigation is being conducted. I am prepared to investigate the matter and take  disciplinary action, if trees were cut down without permission or without following proper procedure,” he said.   BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: 11 MOTORCYCLISTS ARRESTED FOR RACING ON HIGH LEVEL ROAD
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 11 motorcyclists were arrested for racing on High Level Road, endangering the public, Police said. Police said 11 motorcycles were also seized yesterday (19). The suspects are aged 18-30 and are residents of Maharagama, Pannipitiya, Kottawa, Arawwala and Piliyandala. The arrests were made based on complaints received by the 119 Police Emergency Centre from area residents. Motorcyclists had raced in this location previously and the Police had released them after a strict warning. In addition, Police will investigate individuals betting money on these races.  By Hashan Pushpika – Pannipitiya

title: Over a million welfare applications processed – Shehan
author: Author not found
Content: Over one million applications, for the Government’s welfare benefit programme, have been verified at the moment, State Minister of Finance Shehan semasinghe said. According to Semasinghe, the ongoing information survey for the verification of 1.1 million welfare benefit applications has been completed. The highest verification rate of the 1.1 million welfare benefit applications is in Kalutara District at 46%, followed by Badulla District at 34% and Galle District at 32%. The State Minister also stated that the process of verifying whether 3.7 million applications, received from 334 Divisional Secretariats across the island, are eligible for receiving the welfare allowance is being conducted systematically. Semasinghe also highlighted that the information survey will conclude on 31 of this month and failure to provide accurate information prior to the deadline will lead to the loss of welfare benefits. Therefore, the State Minister requested all applicants to provide accurate information to the officials conducting the information survey.

title: Appeal Court appoints bigger Bench
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (16), appointed a numerically superior Bench to hear the Writ Application, challenging the deduction of Advance Personal Income Tax (APIT) from the salaries of Judges. The Order was issued when the case was taken before Court of Appeal Justices Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and M.A.R. Marikkar.  While the Writ Application was filed by the Judicial Service Association of Sri Lanka (JASL), a motion was filed by President’s Counsel Romesh de Silva requesting the appointment of a numerically superior Bench in view of certain developments in the case. Whilst the Application was previously heard before a three-Judge Bench comprising Justices Sobitha Rajakaruna, Dhammika Ganepola and Neil Iddawela, the Petitioner, by way of the Motion, requested for additional Judges in order of seniority to hear the case. When the case was taken up yesterday (16), President of Court of Appeal Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne ordered the appointment of two additional judges to hear the Application and thereby it will be heard before a five-judge bench. Further, the interim order issued preventing the collection of Advance Personal Income Tax (APIT) from Judges was also extended to 22 March. Romesh de Silva PC with Sugath Caldera, Niran Anketel, Harith de Mel and Wasanthakumar Niles, instructed by Sanath Wijewardene, appeared on behalf of the Petitioner. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: SLLDC expects to pump 2M cubes of sea sand
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Land Development Corporation (SLLDC) said it expects to obtain 2,000,000 cubes of sea sand this year and provide it to the public at an affordable price. This will be done by pumping sea sand stretching 10-15 km from Muthurajawela to the Negombo coastal line. This project is conducted on the instructions of Minister of Urban Development and Housing Prasanna Ranatunga. However, considering the reports that this project will affect the fisher folk along the coastal line from Colombo to Negombo, the Minister instructed the officials to obtain environmental impact assessment from Central Environmental Authority and NARA. Ranathunga further instructed the authorities to sign a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Department of fisheries and Aquatic Resources to uplift the infrastructure of the areas where fisher folk who could be affected live. “Necessary measures should be taken to inform the religious leaders and the fishermen’s unions regarding this matter prior to the agreement,” the Minister further instructed. For the uplift of infrastructure, Ranathunga agreed to provide a sum of Rs 200 million. BY Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Sajith assists actress Susantha
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa yesterday (16) visited veteran actress Susantha Chandramali, who is currently undergoing treatment for cancer and provided her with a cheque of Rs 800,000 for future treatment. A facebook post of Susantha, seeking financial assistance to purchase medicine went viral this week. In the post, she said she was first diagnosed with cancer in 2020 and she was cured. However, according to the latest medical tests, she is diagnosed with cancer again. The veteran actress said owing to the current medical shortage in the country, she has to buy the medicine from outside, as Apeksha Hospital in Maharagama does not have those particular medicines any more. She said the medicine is high priced and she cannot afford to buy it continuously. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: A suicide every four hours in SL
author: Author not found
Content: A suicide is happening in Sri Lanka once in every four hours and the majority of them are reported among males, Director of National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) Dr.  Rohan Ratnayake said yesterday (16). Addressing a workshop at the Sri Lanka Institute of Development Administration (SLIDA) Dr. Ratnayake said 2,833 males and 574 females have committed suicide in 2022. Owing to the current economic crisis, it is observed that the number of suicides amongst apparel factory employees has increased and as a result, suicides in the Gampaha District have increased at an abnormal rate, he pointed out. “Many of these suicides happen due to flash decisions. At the same time, 18 per cent of suicides have happened by consuming hazardous pesticides,” he said. Financial issues, relationship issues, consuming alcohol, family issues, assaults and various illnesses are among the main reasons for suicides.  Suicides are reported mainly from elderly males, LGBTQI+ community, young women and prisoners, he added. Speaking further, he said 15.6 per cent from every 100,000 of population died by suicide in 2020, 2021 and 2022. Also, the ratio of attempts at suicides is 1:15. The NIMH Director said, he WHO has rated Sri Lanka as the 3rd in the list of countries that have the highest suicide rates. “But this is not true. Sri Lanka is in the 30th place. We have informed the WHO to correct this,” he said. (If you needs mental health assistance dial 1926: the hotline of National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH)) BY Amith Maduranga Gamage

title: Four Sri Pada pilgrims die of suspected food poisoning
author: Author not found
Content: Four Sri Pada pilgrims have died of alleged food poisoning recently, Public Health Inspectors (PHIs) said, urging pilgrims and those engaging in excursions to be wary of the food they consume and the water they drink. One among them had died from Listeria infection, a foodborne bacterial illness that can be very serious. President of the Public Health Inspectors Union of Sri Lanka (PHIUSL), Upul Rohana yesterday (16) said that at least four persons had died and ten persons were being treated for symptoms of food poisoning. “However, the Regional Epidemiologist and Regional Director Health Services were investigating as to whether the victims were cases of food poisoning or a bacterial infection. He appealed to the Sri Pada Pilgrims, those going on pilgrimages to other places of devotion and the trip goers to especially be cautious of the food and water they consume. “Be very conscious of food and drinking water safety as it would be best to take food which has been prepared at home,” he advised. It would also be preferable to take water, that has been boiled and cooled at home, in a container. Be careful to purchase food and water to drink from places that are certified as healthy places.  Rohana advised the public to seek medical attention if they had symptoms of food poisoning such as diarrhoea, vomiting, body pain and fever symptoms. Health officials in the district were alerted when they received a culture positive Listeria case, of a woman who had been helping her daughter to run a shop at Sri Pada. She had suffered from vomiting, headache and altered consciousness. The woman had succumbed to the illness a few days later despite the medical attention she had received. The second case had been that of a 16-year-old girl, who had fallen ill after climbing to Sri Pada and had sought treatment for food poisoning symptoms.  The Regional Epidemiologist and relevant authorities had taken samples for investigation. Meanwhile, President of the Sri Lanka College of Microbiologists (SLCMB), Dr. Rohini Wadanambi, reiterated that the Regional health authorities were carrying out investigations. However, listeriosis which was allegedly diagnosed in the first victim was caused by Listeria monocytogenes, bacteria which lived in moist environments soil, pasture, decaying vegetation and animals. She said that the disease causing bacteria lived in cold temperatures and could even grow under refrigeration and other food preservation measures. Those at high risk were the immune suppressed groups, elderly persons, pregnant women and infants.  The disease could cause meningitis and blood stream infections. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SDIG Tennakoon the next IGP?
author: Author not found
Content: Western Province Senior Deputy Inspector General (SDIG) Deshabandu Tennakoon will be appointed as the 36th Inspector General of Police (IGP) of Sri Lanka, Ceylon Today reliably learns. Current IGP C.D. Wickramaratne is due to retire on 25 March after completing his tenure and SDIG Tennakoon will take his seat. Among the current successors, SDIG Tennakoon had been at the forefront in terms of seniority, since he was Assistant Superintendent of Police (ASP). However, it is reported that the seniority hierarchy was changed due to a technical issue, when he was appointed to the position of DIG. At that stage, SDIGs Lalith Pathinayake and Nilantha Jayawardena were respectively in the order of seniority after SDIG Tennakoon. His ranking was changed due to a technical issue in entering the IGP commendation data, while appearing for the interview for the position of DIG from the position of Senior Superintendent of Police (SSP), he lost four points. The reason for this was the provision of data in the old format instead of Form 230B in the IGP’s Commendation Register. Then the order of seniority was Nilantha Jayawardena, Lalith Patinayake and Deshabandhu Tennakoon. However, attention of the relevant authorities has been drawn to the service of SDIG Tennakoon with regard to operations launched under his guidance to eradicate the drug menace and underworld operations in the Western Province His service during Covid-19 pandemic was highly praised too. Tennakoon, who joined the Police service as an ASP, is a graduate of University of Sri Jayewardenepura and a distinguished alumnus of Nalanda College, Colombo.

title: SC allows Petition challenging several Govt institutions
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (16) granted leave to proceed with a Fundamental Rights Petition, filed by the Centre for Policy Alternatives (CPA), challenging the refusal of several Government Institutions to take necessary steps to hold the Local Government Election 2023. The Petitioner stated that the conduct of the Government Printer and the Inspector General of Police are indicative of a coordinated campaign to procrastinate the holding of LG Election. It was stated that the President, in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, and the Secretary to the Treasury have not, until the very last minute on the 23 February 2023 indicated that there is a challenge in the allocation of funds to conduct the elections. The Petitioner further noted that the exercise of franchise, as required in terms of the law, is essential for a country to be a democracy, and the conduct of elections must be treated as an essential, for Sri Lanka to be and remain a democratic republic. Attorneys-at-Law Viran Corea with Luwie Ganeshathasan and Khyati Wikramanayake instructed by Moahan Balendra appeared for the petitioner whilst Senior Additional Solicitor General Priyantha Nawana with State Counsel Indumini Randeni appeared for the respondents. By Faadhila Thassim

title: Writ filed seeking Order ensuring ‘Harak Kata’s safety
author: Author not found
Content: A writ application was filed before the Court of Appeal yesterday (16) to ensure the safety of drug kingpin Nadun Chinthaka Wickremeratne alias ‘Harak Kata’ who was arrested in Madagascar and repatriated to Sri Lanka. The Petition was filed on behalf of ‘Harak Kata’ by his father Mervin Wickremeratne seeking an order to ensure there is no imminent threat to his son’s life. The Inspector General of Police (IGP), the Defence Ministry Secretary and the Director of the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) were amongst the Respondents named in the Petition. Previously, a Writ Application was filed to ensure the safety of notorious drug trafficker Salindu Malshika Gunaratna alias ‘Kudu Salindu’ who was also arrested in Madagascar and repatriated to Sri Lanka. The Writ Application was filed by Gunaratna’s mother on the basis that there is imminent danger to his life and that he should be produced before Court. Both ‘Kudu Salindu’ and ‘Harak Kata’ were repatriated to Sri Lanka from Madagascar with six others on Wednesday (15) morning. (FT)

title: Leaders criticising SC under the guise of privileges – PAFFREL
author: Author not found
Content: If any negative consequence outside a democratic framework happens due to the attempts to suppress democratic rights of the people, the Government has to bear the sole responsibility of that, People’s Action for Free and Fair Elections (PAFFREL) Executive Director Rohana Hettiarachchi said. Addressing the media, he said with the current situation it indicates that Local Government (LG) Election 2023 will not take place on 25 April 2023. Pointing out that the Executive and the Legislature should collaborate Hettiarachchi said the President needs to act responsibly in order to maintain a safe society.      He said “the political leaders have now started to criticise the orders given by the Supreme Court under the guise of Parliamentary privileges. The Court verdicts are not only being criticised, but are also being ignored. This is a very serious issue. “Elections should be held in a country at the appropriate time. What is more important is that democracy be realised. People would rebel against the rulers if they are not allowed to vote and elect someone they prefer,” he stressed. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Japan Contributes Another USD 1.8M for SL’s Vulnerable Children
author: Author not found
Content: The Government of Japan has provided a new contribution of over USD 1.8 million, to UNICEF’s emergency response, for the most vulnerable children in Sri Lanka. The new contribution will enable over 600,000 children to access clean water, good hygiene and sanitation, and treatment for malnutrition. Sri Lanka faces an economic crisis which is disproportionately affecting the poor and vulnerable households, with dire implications for children. Access to a nutritious diet has emerged as a potent threat to children. The practice of proper hygiene through hand washing with soap has been identified as inconsistent especially among the most vulnerable, further compounding the situation of children. Ambassador of Japan to Sri Lanka, Mizukoshi Hideaki said, “We are pleased to announce that the Government of Japan has decided to provide additional humanitarian assistance to Sri Lanka in this critical situation. With this latest contribution, the total amount of assistance provided by the Government of Japan, through UNICEF, has exceeded USD 3.8 million since the beginning of the economic crisis last year. Japan continues to stand by and support Sri Lanka.” UNICEF has remained agile in its work to address the needs of children in Sri Lanka and ensuring that the most vulnerable and their families are cushioned from the worst effects of poverty, Covid-19 and now the economic crisis. “The Government of Japan has made a significant contribution to support the efforts of UNICEF collaborating with the Government of Sri Lanka in responding to both the long- and short-term needs of children,” said Christian Skoog, UNICEF Sri Lanka Representative. “UNICEF appreciates and relies on such contributions for its work for children”. This contribution will enable UNICEF and partners to treat 9,000 children with severe acute malnutrition through provision of therapeutic food and support access for children with complications to effective care in 97 hospitals where in-patient treatment is prioritised. Also, it will enable to procure and distribute multiple micronutrient powders for 200,000 children under two years to address deficiencies. The grant will also support  100,000 people, mainly women, through provision of safe and adequate water supply, sanitation, and hygiene facilities in identified Maternal and Child Health clinics. This contribution is in line with the Japanese Government’s commitment that people live in dignity, free from want and fear through the provision of basic social services for the most vulnerable populations, including access to essential lifesaving WASH and nutrition services.

title: Dept of Serjeant-at-Arms celebrates Int’l Women’s Day
author: Author not found
Content: Department of Serjeant-at-Arms of Parliament held a celebratory event this week, in line with International Women’s Day 2023, centred on the theme of ‘innovation and technology for gender equality’. The event was held under the patronage of Serjeant-at-Arms Narendra Fernando, Deputy Serjeant-at-Arms Kushan Jayaratne and Assistant Serjeant-at -Arms Achintha Cooray and members of ‘Suhada Ekamuthuwa’ of the department. The services of 35 women officers attached to the Department of Serjeant-at-Arms were appreciated and the service appreciation awards were given to those women officers. Deputy Serjeant-at-Arms Kushan Jayaratne delivered a speech on the topic work-life balance and Parliamentary Officer Vimansa Vidurangi presented a briefing on embrace equity. The ceremony was colourful with the various items presented by the officials. This is the second time that the Department of Serjeant-at-Arms celebrated such an event in line with International Women’s Day.

With this latest contribution, the total amount of assistance provided by the Government of Japan, through UNICEF, has exceeded USD 3.8 million since the beginning of the economic crisis last year. Japan continues to stand by and support Sri Lanka.” UNICEF has remained agile in its work to address the needs of children in Sri Lanka and ensuring that the most vulnerable and their families are cushioned from the worst effects of poverty, Covid-19 and now the economic crisis. “The Government of Japan has made a significant contribution to support the efforts of UNICEF collaborating with the Government of Sri Lanka in responding to both the long- and short-term needs of children,” said Christian Skoog, UNICEF Sri Lanka Representative. “UNICEF appreciates and relies on such contributions for its work for children”. This contribution will enable UNICEF and partners to treat 9,000 children with severe acute malnutrition through provision of therapeutic food and support access for children with complications to effective care in 97 hospitals where in-patient treatment is prioritised. Also, it will enable to procure and distribute multiple micronutrient powders for 200,000 children under two years to address deficiencies. The grant will also support  100,000 people, mainly women, through provision of safe and adequate water supply, sanitation, and hygiene facilities in identified Maternal and Child Health clinics. This contribution is in line with the Japanese Government’s commitment that people live in dignity, free from want and fear through the provision of basic social services for the most vulnerable populations, including access to essential lifesaving WASH and nutrition services.

title: TU action paralyses many services
author: Author not found
Content: Many sectors including health, education, electricity, banks, water and ports were severely impacted due to the islandwide trade union action organised by the Professionals’ Trade Union Collective (PTUC) yesterday (15). According to the PTUC, over 47 trade unions engaged in the strike mainly against the newly introduced tax scheme and the ‘undemocratic’ conduct of the Government Train services were disrupted and there were only a few office trains running yesterday. However, on 14 March, it was announced that for commuter convenience, 13 office train services would operate at the usual time despite the strike. As a result, trains scheduled to run between 5:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. from Avissawella, Chilaw, Rambukkana, Ganewatte, Mahawa, Kandy, Beliatta, Galle, Aluthgama, and Kalutara-South to Colombo functioned as usual. Meanwhile, clinical treatment and routine operations in hospitals were disrupted. Medical professionals in the State health service comprising medical practitioners from the GMOA, the Association of Medical Specialists (AMS), the Government Dental Surgeons’ Association and Government Ayurvedic doctors joined the strike till late afternoon yesterday (15). Emergency lifesaving surgery, kidney treatment, and one heart surgery unit worked without any interruption. Patients who came for clinics at the Colombo National Hospital were also seen turning away due to the strike action. Meanwhile, it is reported that about 10 per cent of employees of the Government Printing Department had applied for sick leave and did not report to work. Joseph Stalin, General Secretary of the Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) said the strike carried out by teachers was successful. He said most schools in the island did not function. Convener of the National Trade Union Centre, Wasantha Samarasinghe said the strike was successful. He said trade unions in all sectors of the country were involved and more than 200,000 employees participated in the strike.  Thisara Amarananda, President of the Sri Lanka Air Traffic Controllers’ Association (SLATCA), said air traffic controllers had decided to engage in a ‘work to rule’ from 12.00 noon to 2.00 p.m. in support of the ongoing professional struggle yesterday (15), but aircraft overflying Sri Lanka, emergency aircraft, medical aid and patient transport aircraft and rescue were carried out as usual. Meanwhile, BOC General Manager, Russel Fonseka had confirmed that 265 branches including the Head Office and all divisions of the Bank of Ceylon  operated as usual to serve the public, the Presidential Media Division(PMD) said. According to the PMD, People’s Bank Acting CEO, Clive Fonseka also confirmed that 272 out of their 340 branches were fully functional with a staff attendance of over 75 per cent as at 10.30 a.m. The PMD further said the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation and Ceylon Petroleum Storage Terminals LTD Chairman, M.U. Mohamed said over 300 loads of 6,600 litres of Petrol and Diesel have been processed to maintain normal operations, while the Ceylon Electricity Board Shroff and Cashier Union had notified the CEB General Manager that they will not engage in any trade union action and  pledged their support to strengthen the country’s economy. By Thameenah Razeek, Dilanthi Jaymanne and Nabiya Vaffoor

title: China donates material for Police uniforms
author: Author not found
Content: The Chinese Embassy in Sri Lanka donated material for police uniforms to the Government yesterday (15). Ambassador of China to Sri Lanka, Qi Zhenhong, handed over the donation to Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles. The donation was made at the Presidential Secretariat. President Ranil Wickremesinghe was present. Chief of Staff and Senior Adviser to the President on National Security, Sagala Ratnayake and Secretary to the President, Saman Ekanayake, were also present.

title: ‘Harak Kata’, ‘Kudu Salindu’ brought back
author: Author not found
Content: Notorious drug dealers and criminal figures Nadun Chinthaka alias ‘Harak Kata’ and Salindu Malshika Gunaratne alias ‘Kudu Salindu’ were brought to the country last morning (15). The CID dispatched a team to Madagascar earlier this week to repatriate Harak Kata and Kudu Salindu who were arrested in Madagascar. The two were later brought to India’s Mumbai International Airport and was supposed to be repatriated to Sri Lanka on Tuesday (14). The CID team had to defer the repatriation to yesterday (15) due to a flight delay. On 8 March, the defence officials in Madagascar officially informed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the arrest of eight suspects including ‘Harak Kata’ and ‘Kudu Salindu.’ According to foreign media, a Malagasy woman who claims to be his spouse and her father were also among the suspects arrested in Madagascar on 1 March. L’Express, a leading media network in Madagascar, mentioned that the suspects had been taken into custody at the Ivato International Airport in Antananarivo, Madagascar, while trying to fly out of the country. The arrests had been made in a joint operation conducted by the National Central Bureau (NCB) of the INTERPOL, Madagascar’s law enforcement authorities and Customs officials. According to L’Express, five Sri Lankan suspects had landed in Nosy Be on a private jet on 12 February. The group later travelled to Antananarivo on a domestic flight the following day. After staying at two hotels in Ivato and Ambohimangakely, the suspects reached the airport in two luxury cars. The gendarmes (paramilitary police officers in France or French-speaking countries) had recognised and arrested them with the help of the red notices previously issued by the INTERPOL. During his stay in Madagascar, ‘Harak Kata’ had posed as a wealthy businessman while ‘Kudu Salindu’ and the others had pretended to be his bodyguards. The two luxury cars and the mobile phones of the suspects were also seized by the Madagascar law-enforcement authorities. Further, a sum of Malagasy Ariary (MGA) 32 million found on the woman who claimed to be the wife of ‘Harak Kata’ was also confiscated. Earlier, the Defence Ministry of Sri Lanka said necessary measures were taken through the Sri Lankan High Commission in Victoria, Seychelles to extradite the arrestees from Madagascar, as Sri Lanka does not have an embassy or a high commission there. After being officially informed of the arrest of the suspects, a group of local law-enforcement authorities comprising an Assistant Superintendent of Police and an Inspector of Police attached to the CID departed for Madagascar, along with two Special Task Force personnel. ‘Harak Kata’ who operates his drug syndicates in Dubai, Malaysia, Singapore, Seychelles, the Maldives and Madagascar was previously arrested at the Dubai International Airport last August.  However, he had changed his name to Herath Dissanayakage Roshan Isanka in the passport which was found on him at the time of his arrest in Dubai. The Dubai Police had released ‘Harak Kata’ on 3 October, 2022, as they were unable to complete the legal matters pertaining to his deportation. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Zahran’s wife granted bail after nearly four years
author: Author not found
Content: Kalmunai High Court Judge Jeyaraman Trotsky, yesterday (15), granted bail to Abdul Cader Fathima Hadiya, wife of Easter Sunday bomber Zahran Hashim, on strict conditions. She was granted bail on two sureties of Rs 2.5 million each and cash bail of Rs 25,000. She was charged for withholding information related to Katuwapitiya Church bomber Atchi Muhammadu Muhammadu Hasthun and Pulasthini Rajendran alias Sara Jasmine to Police and was in remand custody for nearly four years. The case was taken up to consider the bail application of the suspect and the pre-trial conference of the case was also held yesterday (15). The Judge said the suspect was released on bail considering that she was in remand custody for three years and 10 months on the charge of withholding information about Sara Jasmine. The Attorney General filed the case in the Kalmunai High Court on charges of the suspect not providing information about Sara Jasmine to Police. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: AG requests Court to dismiss Kudu Salindu’s Writ Application
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General yesterday (15) requested the Court of Appeal to dismiss at first instance, the Writ Application filed to ensure the safety of notorious drug trafficker Salindu Malshika Gunaratna alias ‘Kudu Salindu’ who was arrested in Madagascar and repatriated to Sri Lanka. The Writ Application was filed by Gunaratna’s mother on the basis that there is imminent danger to his life and that he should be produced before Court. Deputy Solicitor General Shanil Kularatne said the Writ Application has been filed on a mere ‘assumption’ and requested Court to dismiss it at the first instance. President’s Counsel Nalin Ladduwahetty and Attorney-at-Law Hafeel Farisz, appearing on behalf of the petitioner, observed that the Writ Application was filed based on past conduct whilst emphasising on the death of Makandure Madush. They argued that Madush’s wife wrote to the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL), the Director of the Colombo Crimes Division and the Red Cross, urging immediate intervention to protect the life of her husband. However, despite such pleas, Madush was killed on the 20 October 2020, just prior to his period of administrative detention, under the Prevention of Terrorism Act, was to end after he was illegally moved to the custody of the Colombo Crimes Division from the Criminal Investigations Department where he was held. Further, they observed that there have been similar incidents where drug offenders have been shot after having been taken by Police to recover weapons and thereby that there is an imminent threat to the life of the petitioner. Following submissions made by both parties, Court ordered the Attorney General to obtain instructions from the CID and report its stance to Court on Monday (20), when the case will be taken up next. The Petitioner was repatriated to Sri Lanka last morning (15), together with drug kingpin Nadun Chinthaka alias ‘Harak Kata’ and six others. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Doctors call off strike
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors who comprised a section of professionals who were against the recently introduced tax scheme, temporarily called off the strike as there had been a positive response to their demands from the Government. The Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam yesterday (15) said the Presidential Secretariat had written to the Professionals’ Trade Union Alliance (PTUA) noting that the President and the Government were prepared to consider the proposals submitted by the PTUA in a positive light. The Government also pledged to make room for the PTUA to discuss amendments to the new tax scheme with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), he said. Focusing attention to strengthen the tax administration while taking into consideration submissions and opinions made by trade unions when taking future decisions regarding the economic affairs, he said. Medical professionals in the State health service comprising medical practitioners from the GMOA, the Association of Medical Specialists (AMS), the Government Dental Surgeons’ Association and Government Aurvedic doctors joined the strike till late afternoon yesterday (15). By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Cabinet reshuffle on the cards?
author: Author not found
Content: Discussions are underway for a Cabinet reshuffle soon, Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP S.M. Chandrasena said. In response to a question raised at a Media briefing held yesterday (15), Chandrasena noted that he should rightfully get a ministerial portfolio based on his seniority. “It is unfair that I have not been given a ministerial portfolio based on my seniority and the services I have rendered in the past. I have had a non-problematic political journey while I have even paid for my own fuel during the peak of the fuel crisis,” he said. He added, however that it is better if such issues are rectified and that it should be done as soon as possible. Chandrasena added that he will accept any portfolio offered to him by the President in the event of a reshuffle and that he will not demand for a position. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Health staff who served during strikes to be appraised
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella pledged to appraise staff in the State health service who continued serving the masses without participating in ‘baseless’ strikes.  Rambukwella said many trade unions in the health service were engaged in duty as usual. “Measures should be taken to evaluate their services as they were engaged in their duties with great dedication. I instructed the Ministry Secretary to evaluate their services and recognise their dedication and what could be bestowed on them at professional level,” he said. Senior Spokesman for the Health Ministry said yesterday (15) that facing the serious challenges that had arisen in the recent past, they had opted to work to maintain the health services and bring back normalcy, without participating in baseless trade union action. “At a time like this when the country is moving forward, certain political groups and trade unions have been slandering the Health Ministry and himself showing their destructive politically motivated tendencies,” the spokesman alleged.  Quoting Rambukwella, he said the Minister was ready to face these absurd allegations and respond to them. He said it was necessary for the entire State health employees to remain dedicated to the service at a time when the system was struggling to return to normalcy. It was also important to recognise those who were more dedicated than others to establish normalcy after almost three years of being affected by Covid-19, he added.                                                     (DJ)

title: Renewable Energy Association, CEJ go to SC
author: Author not found
Content: The Electricity and Renewable Energy Association and the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) appealed against the dismissal of the Writ Application seeking an order quashing the Cabinet Decision, on revision of the electricity tariff and against the amended General Policy Guideline for the electricity industry approved by Cabinet. While the initial Writ Application filed at the Court of Appeal was dismissed on 17 February, the petitioners filed a Leave to Appeal application before the Supreme Court yesterday (15). The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), Chairman of CEB, the Cabinet of Ministers, the PUCSL, President Ranil Wickremesinghe, in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies, Minister of Defence, Minister of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment, Minister of Technology and the Attorney General were named as respondents to the Leave to Appeal application. The Court of Appeal dismissing the initial Writ Application held that according to the submissions made by the Additional Solicitor General, on behalf of the respondents, referring to several provisions of law, the relevant Minister has the power to formulate guidelines and the Cabinet has not taken any unlawful decision in reference to the affairs mentioned in the Application. It was thereby held that Cabinet had the authority to amend existing guidelines and that the Petitioners have failed to establish that the impugned decisions illegal. Further, it was also held that there is no viable legal ground presented by the Petitioners, for Court to declare the impugned amendments to the guidelines were ultra vires. The Petitioners in the Leave to Appeal application observed that the amended General Policy Guideline for the electricity industry and the proposed electricity tariffs approved by the Cabinet of Ministers had bypassed the provisions of the Sri Lanka Electricity Act No.20 of 2009 (as amended) and the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka Act No. 35 of 2002 and undermined the functions of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka, the Regulatory Authority and hence the said Cabinet decision  is ultra vires the provisions of the Sri Lanka Electricity Act No.20 of 2009 (as amended) and the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka Act No. 35 of 2002. They thereby sought leave to appeal and an order setting aside the dismissal by the Court of Appeal. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Unhygienic food served in Ratnapura restaurants
author: Author not found
Content: President of the Sabaragamuwa Hetak Organisation (SHO),  Sunil Jayasiri said most restaurants and canteens in Ratnapura town serve unhygienic food to the public including children and those who attend evening tuition classes. He was speaking at a recent meeting of the SHO held at the Buddhist Centre, Ratnapura. He said they had reliable information that leftover food is being served to the public and students attending afternoon tuition classes by a majority of canteens and restaurants in the Ratnapura town. Jayasiri also said certain canteens charge exorbitant amounts for the food they serve. He added that his organisation has already brought the situation to the notice of the PHIs in Ratnapura. BY K. A. S. Piyathileka – Kuruwita

title: Green Village set up at Lippakelle Estate
author: Author not found
Content: Marking the 75th Independence Day of Sri Lanka, distribution of fruit plants to set up a Green Village at Lippakelle Estate in Lindula was held on 7 March by Arivoli Foundation in collaboration with Hatton Plantations PLC. The programme was organised under the guidance of the Agrarian Development Department. Sri Katpaha Vinayagar Temple (SKVT), Walthamstow, London provided financial sponsorship to set up the Green Village and distributed fruit plants (Mango, Orange, Avocado, Guava and Sunhemp (narang) to the community at Lippakelle Estate. The concept behind this project is to overcome the nutritional vulnerability faced by the younger generation in particular and the society in general due to the ongoing economic crisis. The event was graced by Chief Guest Sujiva Godage, Deputy General Manager, Hatton Plantations PLC and K.K. Chandralatha, District Officer at the Agrarian Development Department. The guests of honour were Grama Niladharis, former Grama Niladhari S. Thiyagarajah, Development Officers, teachers, health sector officials, community leaders and beneficiaries. The event was chaired by Ammasae S. Nallusamie, President of Arivoli Foundation. Deputy General Manager of Hatton Plantations PLC, Godage, in his speech, advised the beneficiaries to follow the path of their forefathers who were instrumental in what we enjoy at present and called on the people to be more responsible in setting up the Green Village and safeguard the fruit plants. President of Arivoli Foundation Nallusamie, in his speech, said it was the plantation community and the industry who continuously contributed to foreign exchange inflows even during the pandemic. He urged the Government to pay attention to the plantation industry and the worker community. The programme commenced with the hoisting of the National Flag, marking the 75th Independence Day of Sri Lanka. The Green Village was ceremonially launched with the chief guest, special guests and guests of honour auspiciously planting the fruit tree saplings. (SRM)

title: UK to launch new Developing Country Trading Scheme in SL
author: Author not found
Content: The UK Government held a number of events in Colombo with the goal of creating a new trade preference programme, the Developing Country Trading Scheme (DCTS), which will be introduced this year in Sri Lanka in the backdrop of a steady decline in trade volume between Sri Lanka and the UK in products like textiles, tea, and rubber since 2018. Speaking at an event held on 14 March, British High Commissioner Sarah Hulton said, “The UK’s DCTS provides Sri Lankan and UK businesses with a fresh opportunity to diversify and deepen supply chains and reduce the cost of exporting to the UK. We hope businesses will take advantage of the great opportunities we have highlighted through our events this week.” UK officials showcased high potential value chains and products that can benefit from the new scheme. This was based on research into UK retailers’ and consumers’ buying considerations, as well as insights from Sri Lankan producers, trade programmes and policymakers. The UK said, while Sri Lanka exports numerous high-value products to the UK including textiles, tea and rubber, there has been a steady decline in trade volumes betweenSri Lanka and the UK since 2018. Under UK trade preferences, Sri Lankan exports will benefit from generous tariff cuts and new products will be brought into scope, facilitating access to the UK market for Sri Lankan businesses across a wide range of industries. UK Minister of State at the Department for Business and Trade, Nigel Huddleston said:  “The Developing Country Trading Scheme will support businesses by giving them the tools to export duty-free to the UK, opening up markets and boosting consumer choice. “We want to go bigger and further with our global trade links and the DCTS enables the UK to achieve this with developing countries.” The new scheme has been designed to grow free and fair trade with 65 countries, including Sri Lanka, thereby creating jobs and boosting their economies. The DCTS offers one of the most generous sets of trading preferences in the world and demonstrates the UK’s commitment to building long-term, mutually beneficial relations with countries like Sri Lanka. During the visit to Colombo, DCTS officials also met the Minister of Trade, Commerce, and Food Security, Nalin Fernando. They additionally delivered further information sessions and engagements in partnership with the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce, Department of Commerce, EDB, and BOI, Joint Apparel Association Federation, European Chamber of Commerce Sri Lanka, AmCham Sri Lanka, and Rotary International. The sessions focused on sharing insights including present trends, UK market purchasing criteria, barriers to trade and what can be done to unlock Sri Lanka’s trade and investment potential. Attendees also learnt about other key trade-related information including quality certification and Customs requirements. The main event was attended by State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe, Central Bank Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe, and senior officials from the Department of Commerce, Export Development Board of Sri Lanka (EDB), and the Board of Investment of Sri Lanka (BOI). The event was delivered in partnership with the Council for Business with Britain – the UK-Sri Lanka bilateral trade association. (SRM)

title: Islandwide strike cripples many sectors
author: Author not found
Content: More than 40 trade unions including port, water, electricity, petroleum, health, education, railway, Banks and postal services staged an islandwide strike yesterday (15) based on several issues including amending the newly introduced tax scheme. Some schools were closed as teachers also had joined the strike. Railway stations were deserted while military personnel were deployed. Meanwhile, only emergency treatment was carried out at State Hospitals islandwide.  (PIx Thisara Samal (Anuradhapura), Farhan Nizamdin (Galle) and S. Diyagahage (Galle), Amila Prabhath (Anuradhapura), L. Jawfarkhan (Batticaloa), Nita Pathma Kumari (Norwood) and C.D.H. Hewage (Watawala)

title: Southern hoteliers in dire straits
author: Author not found
Content: Several hoteliers in the Southern Province said they are facing untold hardship owing to the massive hike in interest rates on bank loans. They said the relief period provided to them during the Covid-19 pandemic has not been extended. They claimed interest rates on loans had increased to 22.29 per cent and 30 per cent. “If the banks do not provide them with any relief, they will be forced to mortgage their properties and get onto the street as they have no other means of survival,” they stressed.  By Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: 10,000 more jobs for Sri Lankans in Malaysia
author: Author not found
Content: The Malaysian Government  has allocated an additional quota of 10,000 jobs in the security services for Sri Lanka, Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara said. Nanayakkara was speaking at an awards ceremony for foreign employment agencies held at the BMICH in Colombo on 14 March. The Minister said the new quota was in addition to the existing quota of 10,000 employment opportunities already allocated for Sri Lanka. “The previous Malaysian Government approved a quota of 10,000 jobs for Sri Lankans. In addition to that, we were able to get another job quota approved by the current Malaysian Government. There is possibility to get 100,000 employment opportunities for Sri Lankans in Malaysia,” he said.  “This is a Government-to-Government agreement. We are targeting USD 1 billion of foreign remittance through such agreements,” he said. He said the Foreign Employment Agency Act has been amended to include the welfare of Sri Lankan migrant workers, he said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: SENARO GN 125 MOTORCYCLES DONATED TO PRESIDENT’S OFFICE
author: Author not found
Content: SENARO GN 125 motorcycles were donated to the President’s Office yesterday (15). The assembly of the motorbikes followed the Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) that was introduced by the Ministry of Industries to manufacture, assemble and produce vehicle components in Sri Lanka, a spokesman said. President Ranil Wickremesinghe was given the keys and accompanying documents by Senaro Motor Corporation Managing Director, Roshana Waduge, he added. The newly built assembly factory in the Yakkala area has been producing the SENARO GN 125 motorcycle with 35 per cent value addition through locally produced spare parts through Senaro Motor Company Pvt. Ltd. The company has invested Rs 1.5 billion in this venture, with full financial support of the Bank of Ceylon. The goal is to increase value addition to 50 per cent in the near future and create more than 160 direct job opportunities, the spokesman added and said it was introduced to the Sri Lankan market and was a force in reviving the local economy and adding new energy to local enterprise, the spokesman said. Chairman of the Bank of Ceylon, Ronald C. Perera (PC), General Manager Russell Fonseka, Deputy General Manager Rohana Kumara, Director, Senora Motor Company Mohan Somachandra and other officials were present at the event.

title: Court recalls Wimal’s arrest warrant
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis on 14 March recalled the arrest warrant issued on MP Wimal Weerawansa on 13 March, over the latter’s failure to be present in Court, for a case in which he has been named as a suspect. The Chief Magistrate recalled the arrest warrant after Weerawansa surrendered Court via a motion. The case is based on a complaint filed by the Cinnamon Gardens Police, against the MP and six others, on charges of causing public inconvenience, by obstructing the roads around the UN Compound at Thummulla Junction, Colombo, when the then UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Prince Zeid Al Hussein, arrived in Sri Lanka seven years ago. Seven persons, including Weerawansa, Weerakumara Dissanayake, Piyasiri Wijenayake, Mohomad Muzammil, Jayantha Samaraweera and actor turned politician Roger Seneviratne, have been named as suspects in the case. Further hearing of the case was deferred to 19 June. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: TUs on strike today
author: Author not found
Content: Trade unions representing many sectors, including ports, banks and health, launched a strike from midnight yesterday (14) against the newly introduced tax scheme, increase in electrify tariffs and bank interest rates and to demand that the Government honour the working class people’s freedom to exercise their democratic rights. Employees of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) have announced that they will engage in a work-to-rule campaign from 9.00 a.m. today (15). Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) General Secretary Joseph Stalin said the main protest march will be held in Borella today (15) and they have organised protests at zonal levels as well. The trade unionists have warned that country-wide indefinite strike action will be launched if the government fails to address their demands. Amidst preparation for strikes by trade unions, railway and postal services were gazetted as essential services. Meanwhile, doctors and health staff would stage a countrywide strike today (15) demanding the government either repeal or amend the Inland Revenue Act (amended) after talks held on Monday (13) evening with the government failed.  GMOA Media Committee Member, Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam said yesterday (14) that although trade union representatives had met the Presidential Secretary and officials from the Finance Ministry and the two parties had been able to agree on certain proposals that had been submitted by the Alliance of Professional Trade Unions, regarding new amendments to the Act, they had steadfastly held that the large taxations levied from earnings of professionals could not be amended. All medical trade unions, including the Association of Medical Specialists and Government Dental Surgeons Association (GDSA) would join the countrywide strike today (15). They noted however that emergency services and hospital admissions would be conducted as usual. Services in Women’s’ Children’s Hospitals, Apeksha Hospital for cancer patients, cancer units, Renal Care Hospitals and Units would be maintained. Pic by Dumindu Wanigasekara By Dilanthi Jayamanne and Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Cabinet greenlights new Rights of Persons with Disabilities Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approval has been granted to draft a new Bill on the Protection of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities to repeal the Protection of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act No. 28 of 1996. Accordingly, the Legal Draftsman was instructed to prepare the draft bill. Sri Lanka signed the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) in 2016. In terms of Article 4 of the said convention, “the States undertake to ensure and promote the full realisation of all human rights and fundamental freedoms for all persons with disabilities without discrimination of any kind on the basis of disability.” A committee comprising MPs has been appointed to prepare a preliminary draft Bill. Accordingly, the joint resolution presented by the President as the Minister of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment and the Minister of Justice for the introduction of a new Act by repealing the Protection of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act No. 28 of 1996 was approved. (TR)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Four more arrested for assisting ‘Booru Muna’
author: Author not found
Content: Four more suspects were arrested, by Negombo Divisional Crimes Investigation Unit on Monday (13), for aiding and abetting wanted criminal ‘Booru Muna’ to escape from Police custody at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) on 24 February. The wanted murder suspect is said to have been involved in 13 murders, including that of a shop owner in Hanwella on 12 December 2022. He was arrested by the Airport Police on 24 February, when he arrived at the Airport to board a flight to Dubai, using a forged passport. However, he managed to escape from the Police custody. The four suspects who were arrested on 13 March are accused of aiding and abetting ‘Booru Muna’ by providing transport facilities, sheltering and providing food. The suspects are aged between 38-year-old and 43-year-old residents of Negombo, Minuwangoda and Katuwellegama. Two cars used by ‘Booru Muna’ and other suspects were taken into Police custody. Earlier, a couple who provided accommodation to the criminal was arrested by the STF during a raid in Nuwara Eliya. It was revealed that the arrested couple not only provided accommodation but had also provided money to make a forged passport for him to flee the country. Also, four Police officers, were arrested after the suspect fled from their custody. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: SJB withdraws petitions on LG polls
author: Author not found
Content: Two Petitions filed before the Supreme Court, challenging a letter sent by the Secretary to the Ministry of Public Administration, Neel Hapuhinne, to the District Secretaries (DS), ordering them not to accept deposits from candidates for the Local Government Election 2023, were withdrawn by the Petitioners yesterday (14). The two petitions were filed on behalf of General Secretary of the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), Ranjith Maddumabandara and SJB Colombo Mayoral Candidate Mujibur Rahuman. Whilst Rahuman filed a Fundamental Rights Petition observing that such decision has violated his fundamental rights, Maddumabandara filed a Writ Application seeking a Writ of Certiorari quashing the decision to not accept deposits from local government election candidates. Secretary to the Ministry of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils, and Local Government, Commissioner General of Elections, Chairman of the Election Commission, Attorney General and 81 others including the Cabinet of Ministers were named as respondents to the petitions. Hapuhinne issued a letter, on 10 January, to the District Secretaries, ordering them not to accept deposits from candidates for the upcoming local government election. Hapuhinna said, the directive was issued to the District Secretaries, as per the decision taken by the Cabinet on 9 January. Maddumabandara in his Petition observed that the respondents are bound by Sections 28, 29 and 30 of the Local Authorities Elections Ordinance No.53 of 1946 (as amended) to accept nomination papers and deposits from the local government election candidates which are being duly submitted as per the provisions of the said Ordinance. The petitioner stated that SJB is in the process of depositing the monies in order to be eligible to contest all the local authorities in the country and will be restrained in doing so in the event Divisional Secretaries comply with the directive of Cabinet. President’s Counsel Upul Jayasuriya with Nisala Fernando, instructed by Sampath Wijewardena, appearing on behalf of the petitioners yesterday (14) informed Court that they are withdrawing the relevant petitions. According to Maddumabandara, the reason of withdrawing the two petitions was Hapuhinne withdrew the letter within 24 hours of issuing. Since this particular letter, related to accepting deposits from candidates was withdrawn by Hapuhinne himself and accepting deposits went as planned, they also decided to withdrew the petitions based on that technical fact, Maddumabandara said. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Private medical students to receive clinical training at State hospitals
author: Author not found
Content: An expert committee has been formed by President Ranil Wickremesinghe to identify suitable State hospitals to provide clinical training for medical students of private medical colleges. Medical students enrolled at the General Sir John Kotelawala Defence University (KDU), Dr. Neville Fernando Teaching Hospital, Lyceum Campus and other private universities in Colombo, Kalutara, Gampaha, Kurunegala and Polonnaruwa will be eligible for training, without hampering the training of students in State Universities. State Minister of Health Dr. Seetha Arambepola will be appointed as the Chairperson of the committee, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. Other committee members will include Additional Secretary to the Ministry of Health Dr. R.M. Saman Kusumsiri Ratnayake, Additional Secretary (Medical Services) of the Ministry of Health Dr. A.K.S. de Alwis, Chairman of University Grants Commission Senior Prof. Sampath Amaratunge, Senior Consultant Surgeon Prof. Mohan de Silva, Professor in Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, University of Sri Jayewardenepura Prof. Bawantha Gamage, Senior Consultant Orthopaedics and Trauma Surgeon Dr. Narendra Pinto, Dean of Faculty of Medicine – KDU Prof. Namal Wijesinghe, President of Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC) Prof. Vajira Dissanayake, President of Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) Dr. Darshana Sirisena, Executive Director of University Hospital KDU Prof. J. Balawardane, and Director Nursing (Medical Service) of Ministry of Health R.L.S. Samanmali. The committee will be responsible for studying, reviewing and identifying suitable State hospitals to function as Teaching Hospitals to provide clinical training for medical students of private medical colleges. The committee is also expected to make recommendations for the necessary development to upgrade the hospitals identified to provide clinical training and submit a report within eight weeks.

title: 800 SLTB buses non-operational – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: About 800 buses belonging to the Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB) are non-operational due to driver and conductor vacancies at the SLTB, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said yesterday (14). Gunawardana, who is also the Minister of Transport and Highways, said the Public Service Commission has instructed the ministry to hire 800 drivers and conductors on a contract basis, and interviews are underway. Speaking at the Cabinet media briefing, Gunawardana said it is expected to operate these buses by the Sinhala and Tamil New Year season this year. When queried what steps the Ministry of Transport plans to take to address unruly SLTB drivers, Gunawardana said misconduct occurs among both the private and SLTB bus drivers. “The underlying reason is the competition between private and public sectors. The drivers have been warned if they are involved in fights or any other misconduct, action will be taken against them. Steps will be taken to revoke licences of such private bus drivers as well,” Gunawardana said. “The relevant authorities are taking appropriate action on this matter. However, it will take some time to set up a mechanism to regulate bus drivers,” he added. He said there is unwanted competition between them and private bus drivers are warned that if they are found guilty of being involved in quarrels their licences will be cancelled and this was also brought up in Parliament.   “If the SLTB bus drivers are found guilty, action will be taken against them as well. Competent authorities are taking action to regulate these drivers which will take time,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: MCC on Justice disagrees with Law College decision
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministerial Consultative Committee (MCC) on Justice, Prisons Affairs and Constitutional Reforms has disagreed with the decision, taken by the Council of Legal Education, to make English as the mandatory medium of examination at the Sri Lanka Law College. The disagreement arose when the Ministerial Consultative Committee met in Parliament recently under the chairmanship of Minister of Justice Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe. The MPs present at the committee meeting, questioned Sri Lanka Law College Principal Dr. Athula Pathinayake about the purpose and reason behind making English mandatory for examinations. The MPs were of the view that many excellent professionals in the legal field sat for college examinations in a preferred language. Therefore, the committee was of the view that those who wish to become lawyers by sitting for exams in their mother tongue have never been a hindrance to excellence. Moreover, the committee members were of the view that Primary Courts, mainly use Sinhala and Tamil as the main languages during the proceedings. It is only the Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court that use English. Furthermore, they pointed out that in the Northern Province and where the majority of population are Tamil and Muslim, Court hearings are conducted in Tamil while the Court proceedings are conducted in Sinhala in the areas where the majority is Sinhalese. Furthermore, they pointed out that it is a ground reality that people in many rural areas do not have facilities for education in the English medium. Therefore, making English mandatory for Law College examinations is a violation of fundamental rights.

title: Five-Judge Appeal Court Bench to hear Sirisena’s Writ
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (14) decided to appoint a five-Judge Bench comprising most senior Court of Appeal Judges to hear the Writ Application filed by former President Maithripala Sirisena, challenging the issuance of summons to him by the Fort Magistrate, in relation to the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks. The Court of Appeal two-Judge-Bench comprising Justices Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and M.A.R. Marikkar made this order after considering a motion filed on behalf of Rev. Father Cyril Gamini, seeking a fuller Appellate Court Bench to hear the Petition filed by Sirisena. Further, Court also ordered the Fort Magistrate to stay proceedings in the private plaint filed against Sirisena, until the final determination of the Writ Application. A Private Plaint was filed by Rev. Father Gamini and a victim of the Easter Sunday attack Jesudasan Nadesan, before the Fort Magistrate on 16 September 2022, alleging that Sirisena had failed to order the arrest of Zahran Hashim and his followers, to oversee their arrest, to prevent the murder of those who do not profess the Islamic faith, thus resulting in omissions in terms of the Penal Code. Oral submissions were made on behalf of the complainants and the Fort Magistrate made an order issuing summons on Sirisena, requiring him to be present before the Fort Magistrate’s Court on 14 October 2022. Sirisena, through the Writ Application, observed that the Magistrate has failed to exercise his discretion properly in deciding to issue summons and has erred in law in acting upon hearsay. It was noted that the Magistrate has acted on inadmissible material and that the complainants have willfully misrepresented facts and as such, the Fort Magistrate has misdirected himself on the material facts and that complainants have willfully suppressed material facts, mainly that there was a State Minster of Defence overlooking the Department of the Police and the Armed Forces and Intelligence agencies during the relevant period. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Railway employees’ leave cancelled
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Railways General Manager W.A.D.S. Gunasinghe has instructed all department heads of the Sri Lanka Railways to submit a report to him on all employees who do not report to work today (15). All leave of Railway Department employees has been cancelled with immediate effect following a Gazette Notification declaring the Railway Department as an  essential public service in order to provide an uninterrupted service to commuters. The President has declared the Sri Lanka Railways to be an essential service, according to the Government’s Extraordinary Gazette Notification No. 2321/07 dated 27 February 2023. Accordingly, the General Manager of Railways took steps to cancel the leave of all employees with immediate effect from 14 March 2023. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Cabinet greenlights new Rights of Persons with Disabilities Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approval has been granted to draft a new Bill on the Protection of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities to repeal the Protection of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act No. 28 of 1996. Accordingly, the Legal Draftsman was instructed to prepare the draft bill. Sri Lanka signed the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) in 2016. In terms of Article 4 of the said convention, “the States undertake to ensure and promote the full realisation of all human rights and fundamental freedoms for all persons with disabilities without discrimination of any kind on the basis of disability.” A committee comprising MPs has been appointed to prepare a preliminary draft Bill. Accordingly, the joint resolution presented by the President as the Minister of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment and the Minister of Justice for the introduction of a new Act by repealing the Protection of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act No. 28 of 1996 was approved. (TR)

title: Cardinal urges Parliament to uphold dignity of the Judiciary
author: Author not found
Content: The Catholic Church urged Parliament to uphold the dignity of the Judiciary rather than belittling its authority and undermining the very basis of democracy in the country. Addressing the media, at the Archbishop’s House, Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith on Monday (13) appealed for action to be taken against MPs, who interfere with judiciary for petty political gain, to ensure that freedom of the judiciary Recalling the past, he said that in October 2018 then President Maithripala Sirisena without a legal basis had ousted then PM Ranil Wickremesinghe. “Wickremesinghe sought legal intervention through the Supreme Court, appealing against that decision and by order given on 13 December 2018, after hearing of case SC FR 351/218, the Court ruled the decision of President Sirisena was illegal and he had to reappoint Wickremesinghe and his government.” “However, what is surprising is that the same Ranil Wickremesinghe, who sought refuge in the Supreme Court at that time, was now allowing MPs to belittle and criticise the decision of the Supreme Court with regard to the funds allocated for Local Government Election 2023,” he alleged. No one has the authority to interfere with the decision of the Supreme Court. “It is clear that the judgment given on 3 March 2023, by the Supreme Court, is binding on the President, the Government and Parliament in equal measure, so, they need to follow that decision faithfully, the Archbishop claimed. “It was reported that two MPs have spoken concerning the judgment given by the Supreme Court. The MPs have called this decision, a violation of their parliamentary privileges,” Cardinal Ranjith charged, noting that the matter was to be viewed with great concern. This request by the MPs was not in keeping with the dignity and freedom of Supreme Court and any interference with Courts on the basis of Parliamentary Privileges is unacceptable, he added. Cardinal Ranjith said that according to the Constitution of Sri Lanka it was clear that the Supreme Court was the highest and last decision making body in matters concerning the interpretation and application of the law. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Exam to recruit public service graduates as teachers on 25 March
author: Author not found
Content: An examination will be held to recruit graduates in public service to the teaching service on 25 March 2023 at 341 centres island -wide. The department has made the necessary arrangements to send admission cards to candidates facing the examination. Graduates required for vacant teaching positions, in national and provincial schools, will be calculated based on the results of this examination. Following that, Provincial Councils will recruit graduates on a provincial basis.
