title: Stop being undemocratic – Rahuman
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) Colombo Mayoral Candidate Mujibur Rahuman urged the Government to stop undemocratic actions as the whole world is watching Sri Lanka at the moment. Addressing the media on Monday (13), Rahuman said the world is watching to see whether Sri Lanka has achieved political stability in the present context.  “However, the President shows that there is no political stability in the country. The Government is trying to suppress everything with tear gas and water cannons. These actions of the Government are clearly showing the world that political stability of the country is far from achieved,” he alleged. Rahuman noted that the political stability is important in a country as economic stability depends on it.  By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Cabinet nod for Anti-Corruption Draft Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved publishing the Anti-Corruption Draft Bill in the Government gazette and tabling it in Parliament. The Cabinet Paper with regard to this was presented by Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe. Cabinet approved the Anti-Corruption Draft Bill during the meeting on 18 July 2022. The Bill was prepared by the Legal Draftsman and the Attorney General cleared it. Speaking at the Cabinet media briefing held yesterday (14), Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said although there is extensive discussion regarding combating corruption, legal provisions have not been prepared on the matter thus far. He said after lengthy consultations with all relevant parties, the Minister of Justice took immediate action and obtained Cabinet approval for the quick passage of the Anti-Corruption Bill in Parliament. Speaking further, Gunawardana said this Bill is important for future agreements with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and debt restructuring, as Sri Lanka will have to assure the international community that corruption will be stamped out. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Pera Uni Alumni Association Colombo Chapter AGM
author: Author not found
Content: The 32nd Annual General Meeting of the Alumni Association of the University of Peradeniya, Colombo Chapter, will be held on 31 March from 3 p.m. to 6 p.m. at the Institute of Engineers, No 120/15, Wijerama Mawatha, Colombo 7. For details, please visit the website (www.aaupcc.org) or contact AAUPCC General Secretary Priyath Cabral ([email protected] or 0777560708).

title: GMOA gravely concerned about President’s decision
author: Author not found
Content: The Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) expressed grave concern regarding President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s decision to use State hospitals as teaching hospitals to provide clinical training for medical undergraduates from private medical colleges. Speaking to Ceylon Today, GMOA Media Committee Member Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam said his outfit had an issue with regard to the composition of the committee which has been appointed to select State hospitals for the purpose and the terms of reference. “The GMOA discussed the matter, but did not reach a decision as it should be made by its General Committee,” he said. According to the President’s Media Division (PMD), medical students of the Kotelawala Defence University (KDU), Dr. Neville Fernando Teaching Hospital, Lyceum Campus and other universities in Colombo, Gampaha, Kalutara, Kurunegala and Polonnaruwa, will be given clinical training at selected State hospitals without hampering the training of students in State universities.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: ‘Tuskers in the Skies’ celebrates 30th Anniversary
author: Author not found
Content: No. 6 Helicopter Squadron, SLAF Base Anuradhapura, celebrates its 30th Anniversary today (15). The squadron was formed on 15 March 1993, at SLAF Base Katunayake, with the arrival of Mil Mi-17 helicopters. The squadron then moved to SLAF Base Vavuniya on 29 April 1993 and later to Anuradhapura due to high operational requirements. The No. 6 Helicopter Squadron, home to the Russian-built Mi-17 helicopters, nick-named ‘Tuskers in the Skies’, has extended its wings globally by participating in UN Peacekeeping missions since 2014. The squadron is capable of conducting a wide spectrum of air operations, which include Charter flights, Casualty Evacuation, Medical Evacuation, Humanitarian Assistance and Disaster Relief Operations, Search and Rescue (SAR) Operations, Tactical and Armed Reconnaissance and Close Air Support. Through the valiant efforts of this squadron, countless military and civilian lives have been saved and thus, the No. 6 Helicopter Squadron was bestowed with the colours of the President of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka in 2021. The squadron is currently commanded by Group Captain Tyronne Munasinghe.

title: CNH Director ordered to produce original copy of Schaffter’s bed ticket
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (14) ordered the Director of the Colombo National Hospital (CNH) to promptly submit the original copy of the bed ticket, of the late Director of Janashakthi Insurance PLC, Dinesh Schaffter, who was admitted to the hospital last December, to the five-member-panel of doctors appointed to probe the post-mortem. The Chief Magistrate gave this order when the case pertaining to the mysterious death of the late businessman was heard.  The Court thus ordered the hospital Director, to submit the original copy of Schaffter’s bed ticket, to the five-member panel of doctors, headed by Senior Lecturer at the Department of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Colombo Dr. Asela Mendis. The next hearing of the case was fixed on 22 March. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: SEUSL undergrad drowns while sea bathing
author: Author not found
Content: An undergraduate of South Eastern University of Sri Lanka (SEUSL), Oluvil drowned while swimming in the sea with a group of undergraduates on 13 March. The Police Media Division said residents of the area rushed the victim to the Divisional Hospital Oluvil, but he was pronounced dead on admission. The deceased is a 21-year-old resident of Oluvil. His body was handed over to relatives, following the post-mortem examination. Akkaraipattu Police are conducting investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Sarana indicted, allowed bail
author: Author not found
Content: Indictments were served to former Deputy Minister and former head of the Development Lotteries Board (DLB) Sarana Gunawardena on 13 March, by the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), before Colombo High Court Judge Mahen Weeraman.  He is accused of misusing three official vehicles belonging to the DLB, while serving as its Chairman from 1 August 2006 to 31 July 2007 and thereby causing a loss of revenue to the State via his actions. Later the Judge ordered the accused to be enlarged on bail in two sureties one million rupees each. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: UDA mulls resuming stalled construction projects
author: Author not found
Content: The Urban Development Authority (UDA) is considering the possibilities of taking over the stalled luxury apartments projects in the heart of Colombo and resume construction through a public-private partnership, as hundreds of people have paid for the apartments. During the recent Ministerial Consultative Committee on Urban Development and Housing, Minister of Urban Development and Housing Prasanna Ranatunga instructed the officials to follow a relief programme for the people who paid a colossal sum of money for constructing these luxury apartments. During the meeting, State Minister Arundika Fernando pointed out that in the heart of Colombo, there are abandoned and unfinished buildings such as ‘Krrish’ and ‘Hyatt’ which are causing a lot of inconvenience to the people who have paid money for the luxury apartments.  Therefore, it was emphasised in the committee that immediate action should be taken in this regard. When Ceylon Today, contacted UDA Cahirman Nimesh Herath, he said a report regarding the matter has been prepared following several complaints from the people. There are some projects such as ‘Destiny Mall’ and its foreign contractor is no longer in Sri Lanka. The project had been stalled even though they obtained money from the people, Herath said.  “And now, these unfinished places have become shelters for those involved in minor offences. They are living in the buildings illegally and carrying out their crimes, he pointed out. As a result, a discussion was held with Condominium Management Authority to determine ways to deliver justice to the customers who paid for apartments in these stalled apartment projects. Right now, we are considering resuming these projects under the UDA or finishing them through public-private partnership, the UDA Chairman said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Indian eggs here this week
author: Author not found
Content: The first batch of the eggs from India will arrive this week, Minister of Trade Nalin Fernando said. He revealed this during a meeting held with dried areca nut exporters at the Ministry of Trade. Fernando also said permission was granted to import egg powder and pasteurised liquid eggs in order to meet the industry’s egg requirements. “Sri Lanka sought eggs with highest global standards from egg importing countries. Only three companies in India met those standards we sought,” he said. “Local egg producers went to the Court of Appeal despite the Government’s pledge to control the process. As a result the MRP of eggs increased significantly and it created a shortage in the market. There was a 40 per cent shortfall in egg production in the country. When I, as the responsible Minister, intervened directly to control the situation and requested permission to import eggs, officials from the Department of Animal Production and Health delayed giving approval,” Fernando said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: AG’s appeal against acquittal of Pujith, Hemasiri fixed for 4 July
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme yesterday (13), fixed 4 July to commence the hearing of the appeal, filed by the Attorney General, challenging the acquittal of Former IGP Pujith Jayasundara and former Secretary to the Ministry of Defence Hemasiri Fernando, from cases filed in regard to the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks. Fernando and Jayasundara, both indicted on charges of failure to prevent the Easter Sunday attacks and complicity to murder, were acquitted of all charges when their case was taken up before a Trial-at-Bar of the Colombo High Court on 18 February 2022. When the appeal was taken up, before Supreme Court Justices P. Padman Surasena, Yasantha Kodagoda, Kumudini Wickremasinghe, Mahinda Samayawardhena and Arjuna Obeysekera, yesterday (13), it was fixed to commence on 4 July and to be completed within four days. Accordingly, the appeal was fixed for 4, 5, 11 and 12 July and the Court ordered the Attorney General to file written submissions prior to 31 May following which the respondents were given three weeks, from such date, to file written submissions. The Attorney General filed a total of 855 charges against Fernando and Jayasundara, on criminal dereliction of duty, for failing to take action to prevent the Easter attacks, despite having received intelligence information. The two were acquitted on the basis that the prosecution failed to prove the charges against them. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Govt must resign and hold General Election – Cardinal
author: Author not found
Content: The Government MPs must resign and give an opportunity for the people to elect a new Government, Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith urged yesterday (13). Addressing a media briefing, Cardinal Ranjith said the people voted for a manifesto a few years ago and that manifesto is no longer in action. Therefore, the people should be given the opportunity to vote for a fresh manifesto. Fielding questions, the Archbishop alleged there are different manifestos being followed by the Government at the moment and those manifestos did not receive people’s mandate. “Now, the Government is trying to sell national assets to survive. There should be a referendum if some asset or institution, belonging to the island, was being given to another country or it’s military,” the Cardinal said, adding that the people should at least be asked as to whether they are agree to a project being carried out by a foreign country on their soil.  Citing an example, the Archbishop said the people should be asked if the Trincomalee Harbour was being given to a foreign country for one its projects. He said that Switzerland was one country which held regular referendums to ascertain the will of its people. “Our country should move towards such a democracy,” he observed. Therefore, the Government should refrain from obstructing the Election Commission (EC) conducting the Local Government Election 2023 Cardinal Ranjith said. Having come through the rear door, the incumbent President has been elected by the MPs rather than the citizens of the country. Parliament is now like a den. But democracy should be upheld at all costs, Cardinal Ranjith said.   Condemning the attacks on the recent protests that were held, he said that the citizens should be given the chance to vote as it was their democratic right. He questioned what happened to Rs 10 billion allocated in Budget 2023to hold elections. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: TUs on warpath against tax scheme
author: Author not found
Content: Employees from many sectors, including health, banking and ports, are on the warpath, with strikes being launched from yesterday (13), against the Government’s reluctance to abolish or amend the newly introduced income tax scheme. Members of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) struck work at a number of hospitals in several provinces from yesterday (13) morning in support of the on-going trade union actions of the professional trade union alliance. They struck work in the Western, Central, Southern and Eastern Provinces, the Union’s Media Committee Member, Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe said. The All Ceylon Nurses’ Union (ACNU), All Ceylon General Ports Employees’ Union, Ceylon Bank Employees’ Union Joint Trade Union Alliance of the National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB), Government and Semi-Government Trade Union Collective and the Trade Union Collective of Teachers and Principals have pledged their support to the strike during the next few days. Meanwhile, a discussion had been called between the President and the professionals’ Trade union Collective yesterday (13) night at the Presidential Secretariat.             (DJ) Pic by S. Diyagahage – Ahangama

title: Herath questions US Ambassador’s silence
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) executive committee member MP Vijitha Herath questioned US Ambassador to Sri Lanka Julie Chung’s silence over the Government’s methods to suppress peaceful protests in the country. Addressing a rally in Gampaha, Herath said the Ambassador actively raised her voice on twitter during the ‘Aragalaya’ last year and alleged after Ranil Wickremesinghe became the President, she is maintaining silence on attacks against peaceful protesters. Herath said the rulers of the country do not like when people in distress become strong and get involved in politics actively. “Now, the Government is trying to create chaos between the Legislature and the Judiciary. This attempt should be defeated. They also sabotaged holding the local government election 2023 as scheduled. When a JJB Government is elected we will do everything to ensure the rights of the citizens,” he said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Indian eggs here this week
author: Author not found
Content: The first batch of the eggs from India will arrive this week, Minister of Trade Nalin Fernando said. He revealed this during a meeting held with dried areca nut exporters at the Ministry of Trade. Fernando also said permission was granted to import egg powder and pasteurised liquid eggs in order to meet the industry’s egg requirements. “Sri Lanka sought eggs with highest global standards from egg importing countries. Only three companies in India met those standards we sought,” he said. “Local egg producers went to the Court of Appeal despite the Government’s pledge to control the process. As a result the MRP of eggs increased significantly and it created a shortage in the market. There was a 40 per cent shortfall in egg production in the country. When I, as the responsible Minister, intervened directly to control the situation and requested permission to import eggs, officials from the Department of Animal Production and Health delayed giving approval,” Fernando said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Shelved Indian housing project to resume – Thondaman
author: Author not found
Content: The India-funded housing project in upcountry, which had been temporarily halted, will be restarted as the Indian Government has taken action to provide more funding, Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development Jeevan Thondaman said. Accordingly, an agreement was reached with regard to building the remaining houses at the revised assessment price in order to finish the 4,000 houses project. It is said under the earlier Indian financial scheme, the construction of each house costs Rs 950,000 whereas now the cost has risen to Rs. 2.8 million. Thondaman said resuming the work is very much needed as the economic crisis has impacted the people of the country. At the beginning, the housing project in the upcountry, by India, costs Rs 950, 000 per house whereas now around Rs. 2.8 million is need to build a house there he pointed out. Yesterdays’ signing ceremony was organised at India House on the direction of Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka Gopal Bagle. Thondaman said that when he became a State Minister in 2020, India’s housing project was already in operation. The beneficiaries received the 699 houses after completion. There were around 2,000 houses that lacked essential amenities like power and water which was completed and given to the recipients, he added. The Covid-19 pandemic and subsequent economic crises briefly put a stop to the Indian housing initiative. The cost of a bag of cement has risen to Rs 3,000 thereby increasing the construction costs, the Minister pointed out.                                                      (SRM)

title: Govt to devise a system to care for ‘unwanted’ children
author: Author not found
Content: The Government will devise a system to take care of children if parents encounter situations where they are unable to care for them, State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe asserted. “As the Government, we are responsible for the safety of children. Nowadays, we hear a lot of sensitive news regarding children. We will create a system to take care of children if their parents are unable to raise them,” she said. She also said the concept of ‘single mother’ needs to be recognised by the society as a step to protect the children in the country.  Addressing a media briefing, at Department of Government Information yesterday (13), jointly with the Chairman of National Child Protection Authority (NCPA), Kumarasinghe said a single mother should be able to raise a child and live alone in society without any difficulties.  “A woman should be able to raise her kid alone without any difficulties in the society. Unfortunately, the single mother concept is not recognised in Sri Lanka. In fact, single mothers are often insulted by the society. This situation must be changed and we, as the ministry, are trying our best for that.” Speaking further, Kumarasinghe said the State Ministry is taking steps to establish safe houses for such mothers and she expects to seek assistance from NGOs for that. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Election Commission seeks Rs 60M to pay OT
author: Author not found
Content: To cover overtime payments alone, the Election Commission has sought recurrent expenditure of Rs 60.5 million from the Treasury, for the past two months. This was confirmed by a document sent for approval by the Ministry of Finance. As per the document seeking recurrent funds, the commission has claimed nearly Rs 92 million (Rs 91.755 million) for the same period to cover expenses, including casual pay (with allowances), payments of pensioners, holiday payments of both Staff Officers and non-Staff Officers and water and electricity bills. A  Finance Ministry official said funds sufficient as required could be provided for these payments as per the liquidity position of the Treasury cash flow of March 2023. The Ministry also said funds would be released as per the Minutes of Cabinet Meeting held on 13 February 2023, for the Cabinet paper titled ‘Managing Essential Public Services in keeping with the expected Government Revenue’.

title: Gammanpila goes to SC against CBSL Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Leader of the Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) MP Udaya Gammanpila filed a Special Determination application before the Supreme Court yesterday (13), challenging the constitutionality of certain provisions of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) Bill. It was mentioned in the Petition that clauses 1 to 134, and / or any one or more of them in the Bill are inconsistent with certain provisions of the Constitution. It was stated that cumulative effect of Clauses 5, 6 and 7 prevent the Executive and Legislature in the formulation of economic policy, including the monetary policy of the State. The power to formulate national policy, including economic policy, is vested in the Government. This power to formulate policy is a component of the executive power of the people and the alienation of that power infringes the sovereignty of the people. The Petitioner claimed that the Bill goes beyond protecting the professional independence of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka and its officials and encroaches into directly exercising executive power in the formulation and implementation of policy to the exclusion of the Executive. Further, the Petitioner said clause 6(3) prevents the executive from taking decisions on economic policy other than by legislative action and that the power of the President cannot remove the Governor and members of governing body and the Monetary Policy Board even if the Governor or the members refuse to implement Government policy. He observed that compelling the Minister of Finance to sign a monetary policy framework agreement, fixing an inflation target allowing to only revise the same every three years and in ‘exceptional circumstances’ is arbitrary and violates the sovereignty of the people. It was also stated in the petition that removing the liability of members of the Monetary Board, with regard to pending litigation, including proceedings under Article 126, is an encroachment of the judicial power of the people entrenched in the Supreme Court. He added that giving the power to the Central Bank of Sri Lanka to authorise transactions among residents of Sri Lanka, in currency other than Sri Lankan Rupees, is an attempt to use foreign currency in domestic transactions and may result in the Sri Lanka rupee going into disuse in the domestic market and to introduce the Indian rupee as suggested by interested parties for some time. Lastly, he observed that the essential link between the Central Bank and the Executive is severed by the omission of the Secretary to the Treasury from the governing Board even though, currently, the Secretary to the Treasury is an Ex-Officio member of the Monetary Board. He thereby prayed the Court to declare that such clauses are inconsistent with the Constitution and therefore require to be passed by two-third majority in Parliament and with the approval of the people at a referendum. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Appellate Court issues notice on IGP, AG et al
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (13) issued notice, returnable on 24 May, to the Inspector General of Police (IGP), the Attorney General and eight others, in connection with the Writ Application filed against large-scale deforestation activities, allegedly taking place at the Bogahapelessa Forest Reserve. This was when the Petition filed by the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) and the Wildlife and Nature Protection Society (WNPS) was taken before Court. The Court further ordered that notice be issued to the Central Environmental Authority (CEA) and its Director General, Conservator General of Forests, Director General of Wildlife Conservation, Commissioner of Buddhist Affairs, Divisional Secretary, Divisional Secretariat, Haldummulla, Acting Divisional Secretary, Divisional Secretariat, Haldummulla and Basnayake Nilame, Kuda Kataragama Devalaya, Soragune. The Petitioners noted that the extents of forest land, including the forest reserve, have been parceled out to influential businessmen and politicians, claiming that these lands belong to the Nindagama of Soragune Kuda Kataragama Devalaya. The Petitioners state that these purported Nindagam lands have been bequeathed by the Trustees of the Soragune Kuda Kataragama Devalaya to various farmers for cultivation, resulting in forest destruction. Furthermore, large areas of land comprising parts of the Bogahapelessa forest reserve have also been cleared and handed out to influential businessmen and politicians, on the basis that these are Nindagama lands and belong to the Soragune Kuda Kataragama Devalaya, due to the lack of proper demarcation of the purported Nindagama land belonging to the adjoining Soragune Devalaya and that of the Bogahapelessa Reserve. The Petitioners observe that the ownership of the purported Nindagam, claimed by the Soragune Kuda Kataragama Devalaya, should be investigated and the boundaries of the Forest Reserves, Proposed Reserves and Other State Forests should be effectively demarcated to prevent the encroachment of the forest reserve, noting that nevertheless, the respondents had failed in their duties to prevent the encroachment of these invaluable forest lands, to monitor and take regulatory actions against the perpetrators and to demarcate the boundaries to effectively conserve the reserves and forest lands. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: SL raises the C’wealth of Nations Flag for Peace
author: Author not found
Content: On the occasion of Commonwealth Day, the Commonwealth of Nations Flag for Peace was raised on 13 March by State Minister of Foreign Affairs Tharaka Balasuriya with the participation of Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Aruni Wijewardane and officials of the Ministry symbolising Sri Lanka’s commitment to the shared values and principles of the Commonwealth. The hoisting of the Commonwealth of Nations Flag for Peace by member States, as a collective commitment to peace, is an initiative launched by the Commonwealth Secretariat in line with this year’s theme ‘Forging a Sustainable and Peaceful Common Future’. This year’s Commonwealth Day marks the 10th anniversary of the signing of the Commonwealth Charter. State Minister Balasuriya, in his speech, stated that Sri Lanka, a founding member of the Commonwealth, welcomes the initiative and expressed his appreciation to the organisation for its efforts in promoting peace and prosperity world-wide. Delivering introductory remarks, Foreign Ministry Secretary Aruni Wijewardane highlighted the relevance of the initiative for Sri Lanka, which had suffered years of conflict and that Sri Lanka has identified the year 2023 as the year of reconciliation, recovery and national unity.

title: Extremist TUs trying to sabotage IMF support
author: Author not found
Content: With the appreciation of Sri Lanka Rupee against US dollar, a bus fare reduction is possible in the future, Chairman of the Lanka Private Bus Owners’ Association (LPBOA) Gemunu Wijeratne said. Addressing the media yesterday (13), he said it would be considered when annual bus fare revision, scheduled for 1 July, comes into effect. He stated that trade unions affiliated to ‘extremist political parties’ are trying to sabotage the process of obtaining assistance from International Monetary Fund (IMF), to revive the collapsed economy of the country. Wijeratne said the trade unions affiliated to such political parties do not want to see the development of the country and only want to drag the country into an abyss, once again. He challenged all the State sector professionals to conduct strikes without getting their salaries paid from public money.  “If they have genuine interests, they will be able to do that without hesitation. Then we too can join hands with them,” he said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: BASL felicitates President Wickremesinghe on completion of 50 years at the Bar
author: Author not found
Content: The Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) organised a felicitation ceremony at the Oak Room, Cinnamon Grand Hotel Colombo, on Sunday evening (12) to honour those who had completed fifty years at the Bar. During the Felicitation Dinner, President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who has also completed fifty years at the Bar, was honoured and presented with a plaque by Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya. The Felicitation Dinner was organised by the Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) to honour 26 individuals who have served at the Bar for 50 or more years. The event coincided with the two-day National Law Conference 2023, also organised by the BASL. Juliana Margaret Coswatte, Walter Leslie de Silva, Ratnasabapathy Arumugam Jegatheson, Upali A. Gooneratne PC, Kanagaratnam Kaneshayogan, M. M Zuhair PC, Vijaya Niranjan Perera PC, Vernon Manilal Fernando, Justice J. Asoka Nihal de Silva, W. D. J. Seneviratne and Justice D. J. De S. Balapatabendi were also felicitated at the ceremony. Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya, Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam, BASL President Saliya Peiris, Chairman of the Felicitation Committee Janaprith Fernando and Convener of the Felicitation Committee Chamath Fernando addressed the guests.

title: Bowala takes PSCCTS chair
author: Author not found
Content: Former Director of the Sri Jayewardenepura Hospital and General Secretary of the Public Sector Health Services Association Sugath P. Bowala assumed duties as the Chairman of the Public Service Co-operative Credit and Thrift Society (PSCCTS) Ltd, at its headquarters in Saunders Place, Colombo. Secretary of Public Service Co-operative Credit and Thrift Society Ltd R.M.P.S. Ratnayake, Vice Chairmen H.R.P. Udayasiri, D.W. Piyal Padma, Tuan Zideen, Cooperative District Development Officer Chandana Fonseka and Treasurer P.P.C. Warnapura Fernando were present. (Pic by Thushara Athapaththu)

title: Woman dies after cat bite
author: Author not found
Content: A mother of three died as a result of complications arising from a wound on a leg caused by a cat bite. The post-mortem was conducted at Karapitiya Teaching Hospital on 12 March. The deceased was a 75-year-old Habaraduwa resident. She was bitten by the pet cat in her home and later developed a fever. The woman was initially admitted to Kalugala Hospital, Habaraduwa and later transferred to the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, where she passed away.It was revealed in the post-mortem that the wound had been infected. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: JJB-led protest in Kumbukkana
author: Author not found
Content: A protest was held in Kumbukkana, Moneragala on 12 March demanding that the Local Government Election 2023 be held and that the increased electricity tariff be reduced immediately. The protest was organised by Nilantha Pushpakumara, Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Maduraketiya organiser and nearly a hundred residents in the area participated. People lit torches, protesting the increased electricity bill, for nearly an hour and dispersed peacefully. BY Nandun Gunathilaka – Bibila

title: IGP orders probe into CI ‘interrogating’ woman
author: Author not found
Content: IGP C.D. Wickramaratne yesterday (12) directed that an investigation be launched into the Bandarawela Chief Inspector’s handling of a case in which a woman was arrested for allegedly abandoning her infant in a train at the Fort Railway Station. The Inspector in question had allegedly violated the IGP’s instructions on interrogating women and children, as stated in a circular, according to the Police Media Division. Therefore, the relevant investigation will look into how the female suspect was arrested and later interrogated by the Inspector in a manner that caused her discomfort. A couple was arrested by the Police on 11 March for abandoning their two-week-old infant on the Meenagaya Intercity Express Train. The child was found by the commuters.  The infant was later admitted to the Lady Ridgeway Hospital for Children (LRH). It is reported that the 26-year-old father of the baby, who was employed in Dehiwala, had brought his partner to his place in Colombo after learning about her pregnancy. Meanwhile, the parents have been remanded until 15 March on orders of the Bandarawela Magistrate’s Court. The order was issued by acting Magistrate Kenneth de Silva. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: EC urges President to release funds for LG Polls
author: Author not found
Content: The Election Commission has written to the Minister of Finance requesting the funds needed to hold the 2023 Local Government (LG) Election be released. Election Commission Chairman Nimal Punchihewa said the letter was sent on 9 March. Punchihewa confirmed that the relevant request was sent to President Ranil Wickremesinghe who is also the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation, and National Policies. This move comes shortly after the Commission was informed by the Finance Secretary that no direct decisions pertaining to the release of funds can be made without the approval of the Minister. The Election Commission (EC) announced on 10 March that the District Returning Officers have issued Gazette Notifications on holding the Local Government Election on 25 April, as per the Local Authorities Elections Ordinance. In a statement, the EC said the relevant authorities have agreed to provide necessary assistance to hold the election. The EC held a meeting with relevant authorities, following the Interim Order issued by the Supreme Court on the Treasury Secretary and the Attorney General, preventing them from withholding funds allocated for the elections from Budget 2023. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Professional TUs threaten islandwide strike on 15 March
author: Author not found
Content: Trade unions attached to Education, Health, Ports and Banking sectors have decided to hold a nationwide strike on 15 March against the Government’s new tax policy, interest rate hike, and repressive measures against them. The Professionals’ Trade Union Collective announced that they will intensify trade union action against the Government’s new tax policy, interest rate hike, and repressive measures against them and protests beginning this week. As a result, the collective has decided to hold a nationwide strike on 15 March, and many trade unions conveyed their support yesterday (12). With the breakdown in negotiations with the Finance Secretary regarding the revision of the new tax policy, the union recently decided to intensify its protest action. Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) Secretary Dr. Haritha Aluthge claimed that the trade union action would begin today (13). He said the strike will begin at 8:00 a.m. today in hospitals in the Western, Southern, Central, and Eastern provinces. He highlighted that if the Government announces a proper solution today, they will not have to carry out the trade union action planned for tomorrow. He also highlighted that if no response is received today, the strike will begin in the other five provinces on Tuesday (14) at 8:00 a.m. “If no solution is found to the looming issues, a trade union strike will be called that will affect the entire island beginning at 8:00 a.m. on 15 February,” he said. All Ceylon Nurses’ Union (ACNU) Secretary H.M. Mediwatte said they have decided to join the strike action called by all State employees on 15 March. President of the Academy of Health Professionals (AHP) Ravi Kumudesh said the Joint Council of Government and Semi-government trade unions have decided to go on strike on 15 March and end it within 24 hours, depending on the Government’s response. All Ceylon Ports General Employees’ Union General Secretary Niroshan Gorakanage said port employees will work to rule from 7:00 a.m. today (13) to 7:00 a.m. on 15 March. If no proper solution is provided, they will ensure that the port is shut from 7:00 a.m. on 15 March to 7:00 a.m. on 16 March. Senior Vice President of the Bank Employees’ Union, Anupa Nandula said bank employees have decided to wear black to work today and that on 14 March, they will demonstrate islandwide during the lunch hour. He also highlighted that if they do not receive a satisfactory solution, they will join the 15 March strike along with the other trade unions. General Secretary of the Ceylon Teachers’ Union, Joseph Stalin, said most unions will join hands and that the strike will not end within 24 hours if solutions are not provided. He also promised more trade union action in the future. By Thameenah Razeek

title: HRCSL backtracks on summons issued to Public Security Minister
author: Author not found
Content: The incident where the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) has issued summons to the Public Security Minister to appear before it on Monday, 13 March, took a new turn yesterday (12), when the HRCSL Chairperson issued a fresh statement to ‘clarify’ the ‘erroneous’ statements in the media, with regard to the summons issued to the Minister. The latest statement, which outlines the powers and mandate of the HRCSL, stated that the Commission, through its Secretary, merely requested the Minister, under whose purview the Sri Lanka Police falls, to attend the HRCSL to provide certain clarifications. In a statement issued on 9 March, the HRCSL said Public Security Minister Tiran Alles has been summoned by the Commission over the crackdown by the Police on protests conducted by university students led by the Inter-University Students Federation (IUSF). It further said the subject Minister was summoned to appear before the HRCSL on 13 March to answer questions about the Police conduct on 7 and 8 March, when dispersing protests held near the University of Colombo and the University of Kelaniya, as part of an inquiry launched by the Commission on the day’s events and explain the procedures followed by the Sri Lanka Police. However, Human Rights Lawyer Dr. Prathiba Mahanamahewa pointed out that the mandate of the Commission is limited to calling for a report from State officials and carrying out an investigation based on such report, when a complaint is made or at an instance where fundamental rights are violated. He also noted that the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka does not enjoy judicial powers. On the other hand, four out of the five HRCSL members insisted that they did not take a decision to summon Minister Alles to appear before the Commission to record a statement on the conduct of the Police during undergraduate protests last week, and said that they were completely unaware of such a decision. Commissioner Dr. Nimal Karunasiri said all five members should be aware of any statement issued by the HRCSL. “This is not about whether the decision to summon the Minister is correct or not. This is about the Commission not taking such a decision at all,” he added. Commission member Dr. Vijitha Nanayakkara said the news reports on summoning Public Security Minister Alles on Monday (13) is in fact wrong and steps will be taken to call an explanation from the media spokesman, on what grounds he issued a media statement to that effect, despite four members of the HRCSL being unaware of it. While emphasising that the Commission has not met after 28 February, he also noted that other Commission members got to know about the decision to summon the Minister only through media reports. The Full Statement issued by the HRCSL Chairperson yesterday reads: “The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) notes that every citizen is entitled to the freedom of Assembly and expression and that this right has been exercised by different groups in the country, including trade unions, professional bodies, students and individuals. It has been alleged in several complaints that in several instances where such rights were exercised, law enforcement officers have resorted to the use of tear gas, water cannon and carrying wooden rods as a crowd control mechanism to disperse protesters. The Commission, as the key oversight body to promote and protect human rights in Sri Lanka, views this situation as one that warrants scrutiny, to ensure that the exercise of the right to protest and the restrictions imposed thereon are fully compatible with the relevant provisions of the Constitution and international human rights obligations of Sri Lanka. The Commission, per the mandate conferred on it under the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka Act No. 21 of 1996 (HRCSL Act), has initiated its inquiries and investigation process. The inquiries will ascertain whether the crowd control procedures adopted by law enforcement officers are in line with the constitutional provisions, international human rights obligations of Sri Lanka and basic principles of respecting human dignity. The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka is inter alia required to “inquire into and investigate complaints regarding infringements or imminent infringements of fundamental Rights… (Section 10) The Commission may, on its own motion or on a complaint made to it by an aggrieved person, or group of persons, or a person acting on behalf of an aggrieved person or a group of persons, investigate an allegation of the infringement or imminent infringement of a fundamental right of such person or group of persons caused by the executive or administrative action. (Section 14) Several complaints have been received by the Commission regarding alleged infringements of fundamental rights by the Police, in the course of attempts to prevent protests from being carried out around the Universities of Colombo and Kelaniya on 7 March and 8 March 2023. Press Notice No: HRC/P/E/i/12/03/23 2 Accordingly, the HRCSL is required by law to inquire into such alleged infringements of fundamental rights. Ordinarily, in the first instance, the investigations are handled by the Inquiries & Investigation Division of the HRCSL, which accordingly commenced an investigation. The HRCSL is vested with the power to inter alia, (a) Investigate any infringement or an imminent infringement of fundamental rights in accordance with the succeeding provisions of the Act. (b) do all such other things as are necessary or conducive to the discharge of its functions. (vide Section 11) In order to conduct such an inquiry, the HRCSL also inter alia, (c) to summon any person residing in Sri Lanka, to attend any meeting of the Commission to give evidence or produce any document or other thing in his possession, and to examine him as a witness or require him to produce any document or other thing in his possession. (vide Section 18) However, while the HRCSL possesses full power and authority to summon any person residing in Sri Lanka to give evidence and produce documents, with regard to the aforesaid incident, at this stage, the HRCSL, through its Secretary, merely requested the Minister, under whose purview the Sri Lanka Police falls, to attend the HRCSL to provide certain clarifications. The HRCSL is optimistic that the discussion with the Minister would help to adopt a mechanism to prevent the violations of fundamental human rights in the future and recommend human rights-compliant guidelines for the crowd control during the protest. The HRCSL also observes that in terms of Article 4(d) of the Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, the fundamental rights, which are by the Constitution declared and recognised shall be respected secured, and advanced by all organs of the government. Thus the HRCSL wishes to clarify that certain reports circulating to the effect that summons had been issued on the said Minister are inaccurate and that no such summons has been issued at this stage. This statement is made to clarify the erroneous statements carried out in the media. As such, the HRCSL is confident that all members of the Executive would act in the spirit of cooperation with the HRCSL in ascertaining factual matters relevant to the events of the7and 8March 2023.

title: CID probing leak of Third Term test papers
author: Author not found
Content: The CID has launched an investigation on a complaint lodged by the Central Province Education Department on the leaking of the Third Term test papers prior to the test, Governor of the Central Province, Lalith U. Gamage said yesterday. He said he received complaints from students about receiving these test papers ahead of the test via WhatsApp groups of certain tuition classes. In addition to making a complaint to the CID, in this regard, steps were also taken to instruct the Central Province Education Department Director to conduct an immediate investigation. The Governor said he has received some positive information regarding the release of the question papers and that once they are revealed, strict legal action will be taken against those responsible. On the Governor’s instructions, Central Province Education Department Director Amarasiri Piyadasa has also launched a special investigation into the leaking of test papers. He said the questions and answer sheets for religion, Sinhala, English, and maths for Grades 10 and 11 had been released prior to the test. Students will be given the Sinhala subject test paper for the third term test today (13). BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Sagala launches beach clean-up initiative
author: Author not found
Content: Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of the Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayake, launched a programme yesterday (12) aimed at reducing the environmental damage caused to the coast of Sri Lanka by the X-Press Pearl vessel, which caught fire off the coast of Colombo in May 2021. The programme also involves using machinery to remove the litter from the affected coastal areas, and the launch took place at Crow Island Beach in Mattakkuliya. The programme is jointly implemented by the Marine Environment Protection Authority, Department of Coast Conservation, Ministry of Provincial Councils and Local Government, Central Environmental Authority, Environmental Police, Sri Lanka Navy, and Tudawe Brothers Private Limited. Speaking at the occasion, Ratnayake said tourists are attracted to Sri Lanka because of its beautiful beaches, environment, and cultural heritage. Therefore, he emphasised that it is everyone’s responsibility to contribute to the tourism industry by protecting the coast as well as protecting the environment for the next generation. Ratnayake added that he plans to continue implementing this coastal conservation programme in a sustainable manner and that he anticipates receiving support from non-governmental organisations and resource persons in doing so. The event was attended by Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, Chairman of the Marine Environment Protection Authority, Asela B. Rekawa, Chairman of the Clean Ocean Force Organisation, Jerome Fernando, and other officials.

title: Ali Sabry to attend 22nd Commonwealth FM meeting in London
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry will participate in the 22nd Commonwealth Foreign Affairs Ministers Meeting (CFAMM) at the Commonwealth Headquarters, Marlborough House, London on 15 March. Prior to the CFAMM, on 13 March the Foreign Minister will attend the Commonwealth Day celebrations, which also marks the 10th anniversary of the signing of the Commonwealth Charter that outlines the values and aspirations uniting the Commonwealth member countries. The member states will also support the ‘Commonwealth Flag for Peace’ initiative in symbolising these values and the celebrations will end with a reception hosted by King Charles III for the visiting Foreign Ministers. This year’s CFAMM will engage the Foreign Ministers in discussing joint responses to shared challenges such as the need to build resilience for peaceful and sustainable societies, climate financing for environmental sustainability and leveraging intra-Commonwealth trade and digital connectivity for economic recovery, food, and energy security. Around the Commonwealth, cities will host inter-faith, multi-cultural observances to mark the Commonwealth Day. One of the largest gatherings will be the traditional service at Westminster Abbey in London, attended by King Charles. “It is a privilege for my country to host so many leaders and representatives,” British Foreign Secretary, James Cleverly said. A statement from the UK’s Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office on Commonwealth Day highlighted that occasions like these afford them the unique opportunity to meet and speak in the extended company of old and valued friends. “But they are much more than that. Commonwealth Day is a chance to address our most pressing issues. To consider new cures for common concerns. For us to fashion a fresh vision for an uncertain future. 2023 is a particularly special year for our Commonwealth. It is the 10th anniversary of the Commonwealth Charter. It sets out the values and aspirations of our close partnership. Values like peace, security, rule of law, good governance and sustainability. These principles must always be our priorities. They are more relevant now than ever before. It is also the Commonwealth Year of Youth. Home to 1.4 billion young people, we should never forget that the destiny of the Commonwealth is dependent on the next generation. Let us think about what we want to bequeath them,” it said. The British Foreign Secretary said he is proud of the Commonwealth membership, and committed to doing what he can to ensure that this formidable fellowship of friendly nations delivers real benefits to the 2.5 billion people living in its 56 members states. “The foundation of our friendship might be based on a complex history, but it is also based on a shared understanding – that we can help one another; that we can meaningfully improve the lives of people around the world, that sovereignty, democracy and freedom should and must be defended no matter the price. We should never forget the incomparable make-up of this progressive organisation. It includes some of the world’s largest and most prosperous economies as well as some of the smallest and most aspirational. Our diversity of scale poses an excellent opportunity to address lingering economic imbalances; to protect our planet and enhance our chances for a sustainable future,” it said.

title: 16 Indian fishers arrested
author: Author not found
Content: The Navy said 16 Indian fishermen were arrested early yesterday (12) while fishing illegally in the sea between Jaffna Vetthalakeni and Analativ Island. While the Indian fishermen were fishing in the Northern waters, a group of officers from the Northern Naval Command spotted them and arrested them. The Navy took steps to transport the Indian fishermen, their two fishing vessels, the catch, and their fishing gear to the Kankesanthurai naval port. The Navy then handed over the 16 suspects to the Myliddy Fisheries Inspectorate for investigation. By Shashi Kumar – Mullaitivu

title: CEB restructuring plan to Cabinet soon – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said the road map and timeline for restructuring the Ceylon Electricity Board will be submitted to Cabinet shortly. He said reforms that can be implemented before the final Act will be initiated next week. He said progress on the restructuring of Ceylon Electricity Board was discussed on 10 March. He said the Asian Development Bank, World Bank, United States Agency for International Development (USAID) and Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) have conveyed their support. Meanwhile, he said in Parliament and later tweeted that collective agreements entered into with trade unions of the Ceylon Electricity Board and Ceylon Petroleum Corporation for a 25 per cent salary increment every three years, annual bonuses, allowances and other benefits will not be continued or renewed. He has instructed the Energy Secretary to begin the process of terminating them.

title: Two cop impersonators arrested over multiple thefts
author: Author not found
Content: Two individuals disguised as Police Officers were arrested recently in Colombo for multiple thefts. The arrests were made on 11 March by the Colombo North Divisional Crimes Investigation Unit based on a tip-off, and Police also found over 10g of heroin in the suspects’ possession. The suspects are 24-year-old and 36-year-old residents of Hambantota and Pallewela. Further, based on information elicited during questioning, Police seized 83 mobile phones, four tablets, and five laptops from the boarding house of the suspects. The suspects were handed over to the Modara Police for investigation. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Amaraweera promises to probe fuel distribution delay
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera has assured an investigation into the delay in providing fuel subsidies to farmers. He said an investigation into certain discrepancies in the fuel subsidy system will be conducted, and that all relevant authorities have been instructed to provide subsidised fuel to all farmers. Amaraweera was speaking at an event in Angunakolapelessa, referring to the recent revelation that farmers in certain areas and provinces had not received the aforementioned subsidy. The Minister said the price of urea fertiliser will be reduced further during the Yala Season. He also said the price of a bag of urea, which was previously sold at Rs 10,000 during the peak season, will be reduced to between Rs 7,500 and Rs 9,000 and given to farmers. Further, the minister informed farmers that Rs 6,500 million had been credited to farmers’ accounts at the rate of Rs 10,000 per hectare, with an additional Rs 1,500 million given to farmers who had not received the money immediately. The minister also said the Government made all of these concessions to farmers to reduce their production costs and to protect both farmers and consumers.

title: EC urges President to release funds for LG Polls
author: Author not found
Content: The Election Commission has written to the Minister of Finance requesting the funds needed to hold the 2023 Local Government (LG) Election be released. Election Commission Chairman Nimal Punchihewa said the letter was sent on 9 March. Punchihewa confirmed that the relevant request was sent to President Ranil Wickremesinghe who is also the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation, and National Policies. This move comes shortly after the Commission was informed by the Finance Secretary that no direct decisions pertaining to the release of funds can be made without the approval of the Minister. The Election Commission (EC) announced on 10 March that the District Returning Officers have issued Gazette Notifications on holding the Local Government Election on 25 April, as per the Local Authorities Elections Ordinance. In a statement, the EC said the relevant authorities have agreed to provide necessary assistance to hold the election. The EC held a meeting with relevant authorities, following the Interim Order issued by the Supreme Court on the Treasury Secretary and the Attorney General, preventing them from withholding funds allocated for the elections from Budget 2023. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Many roads in Bogawantalawa inundated
author: Author not found
Content: Many main roads, side roads, and lowlands in Bogawantalawa were flooded as a result of heavy rainfall on 11 March afternoon. Residents of Bogawantalawa claim that the heavy showers lasted for nearly two hours. Due to the drought experienced in Bogawantalawa in recent months, drinking water has become scarce. The present dry weather has seriously harmed both tea and vegetable cultivations. By Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Five gold smugglers netted at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: Officers from the Customs Narcotics Control Unit arrested five suspects at the BIA departure terminal for attempting to smuggle gold to India. These suspects planned to travel to Mumbai, India, on flight UL 141. The gold was carefully concealed in the suspects’ luggage. The smuggling was also linked to an Indian national who was in the airport immigration area. The Indian national was detained for questioning. Based on information elicited, Customs Officers were able to seize 10.5 kg of gold pieces, gold gel, and gold jewellery. The stock of gold is worth approximately Rs 160 million. Officers from the Customs Narcotics Control Unit are conducting investigations.

title: Mosquito control assistants in dire straits – Edirisinghe
author: Author not found
Content: All Ceylon Association of Mosquito Control Assistants Chairman, Chamara Edirisinghe, said 1,125 members of the Association are now in dire straits because they are unable to earn a living by serving for six years on a stipend ofRs 733 per day. He was speaking at a media briefing held recently in Colombo to inform his members about the predicament they are in as a result of the country’s economic situation. Edirisinghe added that Rajitha Senaratne, the Minister of Health at the time, hired them as dengue control assistants in three stages on 6 March 2017. “We were tasked with assisting Medical Officers of Health in dengue control at the time, and it is six years since we were hired. We are paid as little as Rs 733 per day, with a monthly salary of Rs 22,000. According to the country’s present economic situation, that amount is insufficient. Thus, 1,125 of our members working islandwide have faced untold hardship. The daily allowance doesn’t even cover the bus fare, and an additional Rs 1,000 is required for bus fare and food,” he said. He also said they worked tirelessly during Covid-19 and got home at midnight on some days. He said at the very least, they did not receive overtime pay. “We requested a living allowance, but did not receive it, nor did we receive personal protective equipment. However, we also assisted in life-threatening activities such as home quarantine, vaccination, and disinfection,” he added. By Hashan Puspika – Pannipitiya

title: Eight prominent women share their insights
author: Author not found
Content: The third chapter of iLead – an International Women’s Day event jointly organised by NextGenSL and the Friedrich Naumann Foundation for Freedom – was held in Colombo, on Friday (10). The event was organised for the third consecutive year and it featured eight prominent women from diverse industries and sectors. They were given the opportunity to speak for eight minutes on “what they would do differently if they were given the opportunity to lead the country.” The eight women featured at the panel event were Sabrina Esufally, Managing Director, Hemas Consumer Brands, Suhani Kariyawasam Pathirana, Vice President of the Sri Lanka Central Federation of the Deaf, Oshadhi Ranasinghe, Vice Captain of the Sri Lanka Women’s Cricket team, Bhoomi Harendran from the National Transgender Network Trust, Dr. Shemoon Marleen, Consultant Obstetrician and Gynaecologist, Chani Imbulgoda, Deputy Registrar of the University of Visual and Performing Arts, Dinusha Jayamanne, General Manager Human Resources at Brandix and Niranjani Shanmugaraja, Actress and media personality. Sabrina Esufally, opening the forum, stressed the need for better budgetary allocations for education, increasing female labour participation, government expenditure reduction and policy reforms for State Owned Enterprises (SOEs). Suhani Kariyawasam Pathirana, who shared her views representing the differently-abled population, highlighted the need for equal access to education for her community, which would, in return, give them ample opportunities to contribute to the economic growth of the country. Oshadhi Ranasinghe, one of the prominent sports personalities in Sri Lanka, stressed the importance of enhancing the sports sector through enhanced female participation. In her speech, she focused on the importance of implementing social security measures for sportswomen as it would encourage more women to pursue their prospects in the sports arena. The highlight of Bhoomi Harendran’s speech was the need to create an inclusive society where differences and diversity are embraced. She said one’s sexual orientation should not be a measure to determine how that person is treated in society. She spoke of standing for humanity which will usher in a better and safer future for all. Dr. Marleen spoke for fair reproductive health and creating a culture of family planning in Sri Lanka while Imbulgoda expressed her views on addressing critical issues such as process and system development in the country, how technocrats, experts and professionals should be brought in to manage Sri Lanka. Jayamanne, a veteran in Human Resource Management, talked about digital education for all and ensuring financial stability for women – a key component of Sri Lanka’s apparel sector. Niranjani Shanmugaraja, an award-winning actress, talked about measures to create an empowered nation. “Reconciliation cannot be achieved by mere words or pledges. It can only be achieved through action. Action speaks louder than words. I would like to ask this audience if they truly want to elect a person like me – a Tamil woman hailing from a normal family – as the President of Sri Lanka,” she queried. Wolfgang Heinze, the Country Head of Friedrich Naumann Foundation for Freedom in Sri Lanka, said the main objective of the event was to demonstrate the manner in which women will lead if given access to decision-making platforms and adequate opportunities in governance. Delivering the closing remarks, NextGenSL core team member Lihini Fernando said the event would convince the key decision-makers as to why there should be measures to meaningfully address the underrepresentation of women in politics. A number of young political figures from the main political parties are presently working with NextGenSL in various capacities and its main objective is to drive positive youth engagement in politics and work towards addressing challenges that prevent young people — both men and women — from actively engaging in politics. It also seeks to facilitate a healthy political culture and an inclusive platform where diverse political views could be discussed in an amicable manner.

title: Rishikumar Nadarajah appointed country rep
author: Author not found
Content: Rishikumar Nadarajah has been appointed as the country representative by the State Ministry of Investment Promotion for the State of Qatar. He recently received his appointment letter from Investment Promotion Minister Dilum Amunugama. His authority shall extend to the promotion and securing of all types of investment in all sectors of the Sri Lankan economy consisting of Agriculture, Power generation, Industries, City development, Infrastructure development, Mining, Mineral related industrial projects and all other types of investment. Nadarajah was born in Colombo. He completed a Master’s Degree in Business Management at the University of Cambridge and also possesses a BSc in Business Management awarded by the London School of Economics (LSE) and completed a course in Pharmacology at the Harvard Medical School.

title: Arrested with counterfeit notes worth Rs 3.5M
author: Author not found
Content: An individual was arrested for possessing counterfeit cash worth Rs 3.5 million. The Police Media Division said, a total of 700 counterfeit Rs 5,000 notes were found on the suspect at the time of the arrest. The arrest was made in Devipuram, Puthukkudiyiruppu during a raid conducted based on a tip-off received by the Police. The counterfeit money was seized along with a printing machine. The suspect is a 40-year-old resident of Trincomalee. Pix By Shashi Kumar – Mullaitivu By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Police permitted to obtain bank records
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Pasan Amarasena yesterday (9) granted approval to the Narahenpita Police, to obtain records from a private bank concerning the withdrawal of a sum of USD 288(Rs 105,000), from the misplaced credit card of Rohitha Rajapaksa, the youngest son of former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa. The Additional Magistrate instructed the Manager of the private bank to hand over the relevant bank records to the Police. Narahenpita Police told Magistrate Amarasena that they have initiated a probe into a complaint lodged by Rohitha Rajapaksa. The Police stated that in the complaint lodged by Rohitha Rajapaksa, it was mentioned that he had been temporarily residing in Beddagana, Kotte. The plaintiff had stated that he received an SMS on 5 March mentioning that the aforementioned amount had been withdrawn online from the credit card connected to his bank account that. The Police added that the plaintiff had further said, in his complaint, that while he was on his way to his residence in Matara on 4 March, he noticed that his credit card had been misplaced. The complainant had further told the Police that he noticed that a sum of USD 167 had been spent at 10.07 a.m. on 5 March, USD 67 at 12.21 p.m. on 6 March and a further USD 54 at 10.58 a.m. on 7 March at a shop in Jawatte. The Police added that according to the complainant, he then promptly cancelled his credit card and that the total amount, spent from his lost credit card, was estimated at Rs 105.000. Police told the Court, that Rohitha Rajapaksa urged them to conduct a probe into the incident and to take action to have the aforementioned sum, that was stolen from his credit card, returned to him. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Catholic Church opposes rumoured IGP appointee
author: Author not found
Content: Recommending the Police officers, whose names are mentioned in the report of the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI), that probed the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks, as the next Inspector General of Police (IGP), would be an insult to the victims of the bombings, Sri Lanka’s Catholic Church charged. Addressing the media at the Colombo Archbishop’s House, Spokesman for the Colombo Archdiocese, Rev. Fr. Cyril Gamini Fernando, quoting Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith, said with rumours of the incumbent IGP C.D. Wickramarathne’s retirement due in April, suspicions have been raised that three Police Officers, whose names are mentioned, in the PCoI report, for disciplinary inquiries to be conducted against, have been nominated for the post of IGP. “It has been four years to 21 April 2023 since Easter Sunday bombings. But until now, we believe that the truth behind the brutal murders have not been fully revealed,” he lamented. Fr. Fernando said, several recommendations had been made, in the final report of the PCoI, appointed to probe the incident. There were a total three reports that had probed the bombings of churches and hotels killing 271 and injuring hundreds, throwing the lives of the victims into misery. “With the information that had been received during the weeks prior to the bombings there had been multiple occasions in which this tragedy could have been averted. Several high ranking State Officials and several Police Officers were mentioned in the PCoI report for alleged dereliction of duty and disciplinary action against them had been recommended ,” he said. Pledging that the Catholic Church would do everything possible to give justice to Easter Sunday Victims, Fr. Fernando said, “His Eminence Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith, in June 2022, filed a case in the Court of Appeal, on behalf of the Catholic Church of Sri Lanka, seeking an order for the IGP to implement the recommendations of the PCoI against those Police Officers. It was a shameful waste of public funds to have spent a colossal Rs 91 million on the operations of the PCoI, as the authorities are not doing anything despite the recommendations of that commission.” By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: O/L exam faces postponement again
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha stressed that if the paper marking of the GCE Advanced Level examination cannot be completed as scheduled, the GCE Ordinary Level examination will also face the risk of being postponed again. He said he met the teacher trade unions to request their participation in the paper marking process. Premajayantha made this remark in response to a question raised by SJB MP Buddhika Pathirana in Parliament yesterday (9). He said, the paper marking should have started on 22 February and due to payment issues and lack of human resources it was postponed. Premajayantha noted that he submitted Cabinet papers to increase the payments allocated for the teachers and university lecturers, who will be evaluating answer scripts and that approval was given to increase the amount. “The Cabinet has given the approval to increase the payments for the teachers and lecturers and they were informed about it,” he said. He added that the ministry has done everything in their power to increase the benefits given to the teachers and university lecturers. Therefore, he requested a positive response from the teachers, as 4,000 more teachers and 1,300 university lecturers are needed for paper marking. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Maddumabandara to file Contempt charges
author: Author not found
Content: SJB MP Ranjith Maddumabandara warned that if the money required for the Local Government Election 2023 is not released as ordered by the Supreme Court, he will go to the Court again to file Contempt of Court charges. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (9), Maddumabandara said the President, who was elected without a people’s mandate, has continuously acted to destroy the country’s democracy misusing the power of security forces. Although, the President claims that the economy of the country is being stabilised due to their hard work, Maddumabandara stressed that the rates of suicide and malnutrition have increased and health and education sectors are collapsing. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi
