title: Action to be taken against cops who entered Uni – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Police and the Ministry of Home Affairs were requested to take action against Police personnel who entered university premises during recently held protests, Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha informed the House yesterday. The Education Minister was responding to a question raised by SJB MP Buddhika Pathirana on the Policemen and members of the Military entering the university premises. MP Pathirana stressed that even students with special needs were attacked, while a security guard of the university was allegedly killed due to tear gas attacks. He said, that academic staff was also attacked. He asked what steps were being taken by the Ministry of Education regarding these issues. Pathirana also urged the Education Minister to act as a mediator and get both, student union leaders and the Security Forces members to engage in smooth discussions and settle the matter before things get out of hands. We do not want to see history where student leaders and Security Forces clash like in the past, he added.  However, Premajayanatha said that the relevant parties have been informed regarding the issues and adequate steps will be taken to address the concerns of parties involved. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Did soldiers use clubs, iron rods at IUSF protest?
author: Author not found
Content: An investigation has been launched to see whether the soldiers, deployed to disperse the Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) protest on Tuesday (7), carried iron rods and clubs, Army Spokesman Brigadier Ravi Herath said. Speaking to Ceylon Today, Brigadier Herath said this investigation was launched following photos going viral, on social media, showing soldiers carrying iron rods and clubs during the protest. The Army Spokesman said, the Sri Lanka Army did not get involved in controlling the protest. The Police, the STF and Riot Squads were at the frontline and soldiers had not deployed there. Speaking further, he said it cannot be sure that the photos on social media are authentic. Also, it has to be determined whether those photos were actually taken during the protest on Tuesday (7). Therefore, it would take many days to conclude the investigation, the Army Spokesman claimed. BY Mithun Jayawardena

title: Police launch probe into 8 March protest
author: Author not found
Content: Cinnamon Gardens Police yesterday (9) informed Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis that they are currently conducting a probe into the protest, staged on Wednesday (8), by the Federation of University Teachers’ Association (FUTA), the Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) and several supporting groups, on the road from the Faculty of Arts to the JOC roundabout. The protest was held against the conduct of the Police during a protest organised by IUSF on the previous day (7) near the university. It was held from morning to about 3.45 p.m. on Wednesday (8). Police mentioned that they are conducting the inquiry, into the demonstration held by the protesters, which severely inconvenienced schoolchildren, ambulances and residents of the area without an official approval to hold such a protest in a public place. Police added that they are presently probing the incident, with regard to possible violation of Provisions contained in Sections 140, 183, 344, 120, 146 and 486 of the Penal Code, Provisions contained in Section 59 (1) and (2) of the National Thoroughfares Act, Provisions contained in Section 81 (2) of the Local Authorities Elections Act and Provisions contained in Sections of 77 (1), (2) and (3), 79 (2), 81 (1) and (2) of the Police Ordinance. Further submissions will be produced in Court at the next hearing, Police said. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: HRCSL can only summon State officials – HR Lawyer
author: Author not found
Content: While noting that the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) does not enjoy judicial powers, Human Rights Lawyer Dr. Prathiba Mahanamahewa pointed out that the mandate of the Commission is limited to calling for a report from State employees and carrying out an investigation based on such report, when a complaint is made or at an instance where fundamental rights are violated. Referring to media reports that HRCSL has summoned Public Security Minister Tiran Alles to record a statement, on the conduct of the Police during undergraduate protests on 7 and 8 March Dr. Mahanamahewa pointed out that Clause 11 of the HRSCL Act, No. 21 of 1996 states: “For the purpose of discharging its functions the Commission may exercise any or all of the following powers:- investigate, any infringement or imminent infringement of fundamental rights, in accordance with the succeeding provisions of this Act  (b) appoint such number of sub-committees at Provincial level, as it considers necessary to exercise such powers of the Commission as may be delegated to them, by the Commission, under this Act The HRCSL is not an institution which can punish any individual and it only mandates to give recommendations when necessary to safeguard human rights.” Dr. Mahanamahewa pointed out that if the HRCSL felt the need to investigate the incidents of human rights violations on both occasions by the Police or Security Forces, it could have called for a report from the respective ministry secretaries and the IGP. “This is also connected to national security. The Commission cannot force anyone to divulge sensitive details pertaining to national security. If the Commission summons one Minister, they will also have to summon the President, who is the Defence Minister and also the members of National Security Council at this rate – which is not possible,” he pointed out. He also pointed out that the Language Commission has more powers than the HRCSL, where in the Language Commission Act it is clearly mentioned what course of legal actions it could take in the event the Commission feels their recommendations were not followed. “If we take the recent incident of the electricity tariff hike, where both CEB and PUCSL officials were summoned by the HRCSL, the mandate is quite evident. There, the CEB officials disregarded the recommendations by the HRCSL and when the Commission went to Superior Courts challenging CEB officials’ act, the Supreme Court didn’t even find grounds to proceed,” he pointed out. Human Rights Lawyer Dr. Pratibha Mahanamaheva said in an incident involving a human rights violation, the Sri Lanka Human Rights Commission should first call and study a report through the officials of the relevant government agency and it is not in their mandate to summon the Minister-in-Charge of the subject.

title: No more Govt jobs for rioters
author: Author not found
Content: In the midst of daily protests by university undergraduates escalating, the Government has decided against offering State sector jobs in future to those who engage in anti-Government protests and riots. A top Government official said the Government has taken steps to identify and maintain records of those, especially undergraduates, who are engaged in ‘unnecessary’ anti-Government protests. “A database will be maintained and when these people apply for Government jobs, they will not be given preference. There is a procedure where Police records and Grama Niladhari certificates are sought when recruiting for employment in the public sector. This is also the case when recruiting employees to the private sector. However, these things were not taken very seriously in the past when recruitments were made through graduate schemes. However, the Government will strictly monitor and disqualify such candidates who are part of anti-Government protests or riots in the future,” the official said. Meanwhile, it was reported that around Rs 500 million in income loss has been incurred by the private bus sector alone, due to the anti-Government protests held in the Western Province since January 2023.  Lanka Private Bus Owners’ Association (LPBOA) Chairman Gemunu Wijeratne claimed they incur a daily loss aroundRs 10 million when there is a protest. Pic by Dumindu Wanigasekara

title: Protest in Mullaitivu over war missing
author: Author not found
Content: The relatives of those who had disappeared during the country’s three-decade-long war, staged a protest demonstration on 8 March in Mullaitivu, to mark International Women’s Day, stating that they have still not received any information with regard to the whereabouts of their relatives and loved ones. The protest was staged opposite the Mullaitivu District Secretary’s Office. The relatives of disappeared persons started a Satyagraha on 8 March 2017 at the same place demanding details about their relatives, who went missing during the war. BY Sashi Kumar – Mullaitivu

title: Police permitted to obtain bank records
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Pasan Amarasena yesterday (9) granted approval to the Narahenpita Police, to obtain records from a private bank concerning the withdrawal of a sum of USD 288(Rs 105,000), from the misplaced credit card of Rohitha Rajapaksa, the youngest son of former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa. The Additional Magistrate instructed the Manager of the private bank to hand over the relevant bank records to the Police. Narahenpita Police told Magistrate Amarasena that they have initiated a probe into a complaint lodged by Rohitha Rajapaksa. The Police stated that in the complaint lodged by Rohitha Rajapaksa, it was mentioned that he had been temporarily residing in Beddagana, Kotte. The plaintiff had stated that he received an SMS on 5 March mentioning that the aforementioned amount had been withdrawn online from the credit card connected to his bank account that. The Police added that the plaintiff had further said, in his complaint, that while he was on his way to his residence in Matara on 4 March, he noticed that his credit card had been misplaced. The complainant had further told the Police that he noticed that a sum of USD 167 had been spent at 10.07 a.m. on 5 March, USD 67 at 12.21 p.m. on 6 March and a further USD 54 at 10.58 a.m. on 7 March at a shop in Jawatte. The Police added that according to the complainant, he then promptly cancelled his credit card and that the total amount, spent from his lost credit card, was estimated at Rs 105.000. Police told the Court, that Rohitha Rajapaksa urged them to conduct a probe into the incident and to take action to have the aforementioned sum, that was stolen from his credit card, returned to him. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Catholic Church opposes rumoured IGP appointee
author: Author not found
Content: Recommending the Police officers, whose names are mentioned in the report of the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI), that probed the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks, as the next Inspector General of Police (IGP), would be an insult to the victims of the bombings, Sri Lanka’s Catholic Church charged. Addressing the media at the Colombo Archbishop’s House, Spokesman for the Colombo Archdiocese, Rev. Fr. Cyril Gamini Fernando, quoting Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith, said with rumours of the incumbent IGP C.D. Wickramarathne’s retirement due in April, suspicions have been raised that three Police Officers, whose names are mentioned, in the PCoI report, for disciplinary inquiries to be conducted against, have been nominated for the post of IGP. “It has been four years to 21 April 2023 since Easter Sunday bombings. But until now, we believe that the truth behind the brutal murders have not been fully revealed,” he lamented. Fr. Fernando said, several recommendations had been made, in the final report of the PCoI, appointed to probe the incident. There were a total three reports that had probed the bombings of churches and hotels killing 271 and injuring hundreds, throwing the lives of the victims into misery. “With the information that had been received during the weeks prior to the bombings there had been multiple occasions in which this tragedy could have been averted. Several high ranking State Officials and several Police Officers were mentioned in the PCoI report for alleged dereliction of duty and disciplinary action against them had been recommended ,” he said. Pledging that the Catholic Church would do everything possible to give justice to Easter Sunday Victims, Fr. Fernando said, “His Eminence Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith, in June 2022, filed a case in the Court of Appeal, on behalf of the Catholic Church of Sri Lanka, seeking an order for the IGP to implement the recommendations of the PCoI against those Police Officers. It was a shameful waste of public funds to have spent a colossal Rs 91 million on the operations of the PCoI, as the authorities are not doing anything despite the recommendations of that commission.” By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Sajith calls for comprehensive programme
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa wore a wristband in the Parliament Chamber on Wednesday (8) in support of International Women’s Day, which is celebrated under the theme ‘Let’s Embrace Fairness.’ MPs Rohini Kaviratne and Harshana Rajakaruna followed suit. Speaking on the occasion, Premadasa said a strong programme is needed to end violence against women.                                                                                (NV)

title: ATTEMPT TO KEEP TREASURY SECY AWAY FROM EC TALKS – GAMMANPILA
author: Author not found
Content: Claiming that the Government is suffering from “election phobia,” Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader,MP Udaya Gammanpila alleged the President deliberately changed the date of the National Security Council (NSC) meeting to prevent the Treasury Secretary from attending the meeting with the Election Commission with regard to holding Local Government Elections.  Gammanpila said normally, NSC meetings are held on Wednesdays. However, the NSC meeting this week was suddenly moved to Tuesday (7) morning, he claimed. Speaking to the media yesterday, Gammanpila said this is the President’s strategy to prevent the Treasury Secretary from attending the meeting with the EC. “The Government is suffering from ‘election phobia’ and therefore, everything possible is being done to postpone the elections. However, this game of hide-and-seek is not always possible, and the Treasury Secretary should explain how the funds will be distributed to the EC,” he said.  By Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 38th Board Meeting of India-Sri Lanka Foundation in Bentota
author: Author not found
Content: The 38th Session of the Board of Directors of the India-Sri Lanka Foundation (ISLF) was held in Bentota on 3 March 2023. The session was Co-Chaired by High Commissioner of India in Sri Lanka Gopal Baglay and High Commissioner of Sri Lanka in India Milinda Moragoda. Board members of the Foundation, Ambassador Gopalaswami Parthasarathy and Ambassador Bernard Goonetilleke were also present. ISLF was established on 28 December 1998 by a Memorandum of Understanding signed between the Governments of India and Sri Lanka, with the objective of fostering Indo-Sri Lanka relations through the enhancement of economic, scientific, educational, technical, and cultural cooperation and the promotion of greater understanding between the peoples of the two countries. The Foundation receives project proposals in the areas of art & culture, education, agriculture, research, science & technology, health, social works, developmental studies and tourism.The Foundation has supported more than 580 projects till date. The projects implemented so far with support of the Foundation compliment the initiatives by the Governments of the two countries in strengthening the bilateral relationship and people – to – people ties.This year, the Foundation received 98 project proposals from applicants in Sri Lanka and India for consideration of the Board of Directors for the support. The proposals approved for support will be implemented in the months to come.

title: SLFUW celebrates International Women’s Day 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Federation of University Women (SLFUW), under its President Colonel Dr. Udula Krishnaratne, celebrated International Women’s Day on Saturday, 4 March, at its Headquarters in Kitulwatte Road, Colombo. The Chief Guest was the illustrious Professor Emeritus Jennifer Perera, famed Microbiologist and former Dean of the Faculty of Medicine, University of Colombo, who addressed the gathering on ‘The importance of Women’s Health in Economic Development’. Professor Emeritus Takshala Serasinghe, the keynote Speaker, spoke on ‘DigitAll: Innovation and Technology for Gender Equality’. In her welcome address, giving an overview of its history, Dr. Krishnaratne said the SLFUW was set up as a non-political, non-governmental charitable body in 1941, even before the University was established. She paid tribute to the dedicated ladies who contributed to its development. Foremost among them was its Founder President Clara Motwani, a young American with a Master’s Degree in Education and her group of friends, which included Hilda Kularatne, Doreen Wikramasinghe, and Susan George Pulimood. Their foresight and commitment led to the expansion of educational opportunities for the ‘girl child’, a primary need of the time. SLFUW Meetings were held in their homes initially, but in 1996, Professor Lorna Devaraja and Manel Abeysekara were able to obtain a block of land in Kitulwatte Road, Colombo, from the UDA. Finally, overcoming many difficulties the SLFUW was able to move into its own premises in 2006. The programme included the felicitation of two Past Presidents who were present, Professor Nayani Melagoda and Seela Ebert, for their leadership and service.  Five scholarships were presented to University students from underprivileged areas. The President also thanked Indra Puvimanasingham, a former SLFUW President, for a donation of educational equipment from a well-wisher in America. It was handed over to Ananda Samarakoon Vidyalaya in Wewala, attended primarily by underprivileged children.   A noteworthy feature of the event was the participation of members of the Visually Impaired Women’s Federation, with its President Violet Yakandawala, who had obtained her University Degree at a time when even Braille facilities were not available. She revealed the startling fact that the first persons to discriminate against the visually impaired were the family members themselves. Visually impaired children were considered an embarrassment to the family, and kept in hiding, out of sight of society. The celebration was well-attended and well-organised, with dance items by the Sri Lanka Army Dance Troupe, and a song movingly rendered by a second-year law student at the University of Colombo. The General Secretary, Anjali Gamage offered her thanks to all those who helped the SLFUW  in many ways including the Sponsors of the event, and the Council Members who did all the behind-the-scenes-preparatory work for the celebrations. The Sri Lanka Federation of University Women is the foremost organisation of educated women in Sri Lanka engaged in community service work. During the past 82 years, it has made an immense contribution to the welfare of women and children in particular and to the community at large. “The people of Sri Lanka are facing extremely difficult times at present, and we wish that, under its aegis, the women of Sri Lanka will be able to help our motherland forge ahead in socio-economic and cultural development.”

title: Hijara Muslim Vid sports fest
author: Author not found
Content: The Annual Inter house Sports Festival of Sammanthurai Hijara Muslim Vidyalaya was held at the School grounds recently. It was presided over by the Principal of the School Y.B. Mohamed Ismail.  GOC of 24 Infantry Division Major General Wipula Chandrasiri who participated as Chief Guest   at the event is seen  here  hoisting the National Flag to inaugurate the meet while the other picture shows the Chief Guest is presenting the awards to the winners. (Picture by MAP Deen- Ampara Correspondent)

title: Teenager drowns
author: Author not found
Content: A 14-year-old boy had drowned in the Katupila Reservoir on 8 March. The Police said that the victim along with his family had been on a trip. Several children had got into the reservoir and were playing in the water when the boy drowned. He was rushed to the Danduma Hospital where he was pronounced dead. The deceased was a resident of Pelmadulla, Kalugammulla. Sewanagala Police are conducting investigations. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Wildlife Ranger released on bail in robbery case
author: Author not found
Content: Tissamaharama Chief Magistrate Tharindu Chameera Silva, on 7 March, enlarged on surety bail in Rs 500,000, a Wildlife Ranger, who was charged with stealing camera equipment worth Rs 2.4 million belonging to a British woman. The Magistrate also ordered the suspect, H. P. W. Sanka Dilshan Weerasinghe, to be present before him on 12 July. The suspect had been attached to the Galge Wildlife Office on the Kataragama-Buttala Road. The Court also ordered the robbed camera equipment be released to the complainant. BY Ariyapala Ratnayake – Kataragama

title: 36,000 MT shipment of TSP due on 17 March
author: Author not found
Content: A 36,000 MT shipment of Triple Super Phosphate (TSP) for paddy cultivation provided by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) is scheduled to arrive at the Port of Colombo on 17 March. According to the Department of Agriculture, this fertiliser contains phosphorus and potassium required for paddy cultivation which is essential for healthy crops. They added that mineral deficiency resulted in the yellowing of crops. “Prior to the 2021 Maha Season, 4.1 MT of paddy was harvested per hectare, but due to the lack of fertiliser containing minerals like phosphorus and potassium, the yield of paddy per hectare dropped to 2-2.5 MT,” they said. Therefore, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera recommended distributing TSP fertiliser to farmers free of charge. He stated that steps have been taken to provide this TSP fertiliser to 1.2 million farmers who have cultivated paddy in the 2022/23 Maha Season, regardless of whether they have cultivated paddy in the Yala Season. Amaraweera said although a 50 kg stock of MOP fertiliser was given for Rs 19,500 in the Maha Season, the Government has decided to reduce the price by a significant amount in the Yala Season.                                                    (FT)

title: SRI LANKA WELCOMES HISTORIC UN AGREEMENT TO PROTECT HIGH SEAS
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka has welcomed the conclusion of negotiations, on a landmark agreement, to enhance the international legal regime concerning the conservation of marine biological diversity in the High Seas, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said yesterday (9). In a statement, the Ministry said, almost two-thirds of the ocean that lies in areas beyond national jurisdiction and provides a framework for establishing marine protected areas (MPAs), Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) and share the marine genetic resources of the high seas. “Sri Lanka welcomed the commitment of developed countries, under the marine biodiversity, in areas beyond national jurisdiction (BBNJ) agreement, to fund capacity-building projects which will assist developing countries to undertake conservation measures. In order to benefit from the agreement in a fair and equitable manner, developing countries such as Sri Lanka need capacity building and transfer of technology, knowledge sharing and cooperation to fulfil rights and responsibilities in a meaningful manner. Sri Lanka’s participation during the negotiations ensured the conference takes into account these outcomes,” the statement said. Given the interaction between marine life in the high seas and marine biodiversity beyond areas of national jurisdiction and economies, the implementation of the BBNJ will also contribute to the sustainable use of marine biodiversity areas beyond Sri Lanka’s national jurisdiction while also mitigating adverse impacts on the ocean through sea level rise, ocean pollution, and over-exploitation of and marine resources. Sri Lanka has demonstrated its commitment to ocean governance by fostering regional dialogue on pertinent issues within the region. Sri Lanka is the Chair of the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA) Working Group on Maritime Safety and Security till 2027, IORA Vice Chair for 2021- 2023 and will take over as the IORA Chair this year. Sri Lanka has already committed to declaring a minimum of 30% of its marine reserves as protected areas at the UNFCCC COP26 in 2021.

title: Arrested for illegally transporting gems
author: Author not found
Content: Two individuals who were illegally transporting gems worth more than Rs 50 million, from Kallady in Batticaloa to Colombo, in a three-wheeler, were arrested by Valaichchenai Police in the night of 8 March. The arrest was made near Kumburumulai Junction, Valaichchenai, with the assistance of the Navy Intelligence Unit. Preliminary Police inquiries revealed that the suspects had planned to transport gem to Colombo by bus, after bringing it to Navaladi Junction in Oddamavadi, in the three-wheeler. Following a tip off, the Police followed the suspects and arrested them. The three-wheeler and the gems were taken into Police custody. The suspects are the residents of Kallady and Trincomalee. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: JJB alleges chemical weapons used against protesters
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake yesterday (9), voiced concern that chemical weapons and hazardous smoke may have been used on peaceful protesters in past few days. Dissanayake, addressing a media briefing, noted that two persons died, one on 26 February and the other on 7 March, after being exposed to tear gas during protests. “One of them, Nimal Amarasiri was JJB candidate for local government election. He was neither shot nor injured in a stampede during the protest. After being exposed to tear gas during the protest on 26 February, he had vomited and was then hospitalised. He died after that. So, it is clear, Amarasiri died after being exposed to tear gas. That is murder,” the JJB Leader said. Also, Priyantha Wanninayake, a security officer at University of Colombo, also died after being exposed to tear gas. He did not die due to an accident or a shooting. His death was a murder too, he stressed. “With these tragic incidents, we have reasonable concerns as to whether the Government uses chemical weapons and hazardous smoke on peaceful protesters. President Ranil Wickremesinghe is trying to rule the country like a dictator. He must stop it immediately and understand he cannot go on like that forever,” he said. Meanwhile, a group of lawyers, affiliated to the JJB, sent Right to Information (RTI) request to the Inspector General of Police (IGP) seeking a full report on details over tear gas and water used to disperse the protests in recent times.

title: Lanka Sathosa reduces prices of seven essentials
author: Author not found
Content: State-owned Lanka Sathosa has reduced the prices of seven essential items. According to Lanka Sathosa, the price reductions came into effect yesterday (9). The revised prices of the seven essential items per kg are:  Dry chillies Rs 1,500, a reduction of Rs 75, Wheat flour Rs 230, reduced by Rs 15. Lentils Rs 339, reduced by Rs 19. White Sugar reduced by Rs 11 and the new price is Rs 218, Local Kekulu (red) reduced by Rs 9 and the new price is Rs 155 Local Nadu (white) is reduced by Rs 7 and new price is Rs 188. Big onions reduced by Rs 6 and new price is Rs 129.

title: Susil promises to make SPC show profit
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Dr Susil Premajayantha has promised to turn the State Printing Corporation (SPC) into a profitable enterprise. He joined the Indian High Commissioner on an observation tour of the State Printing Corporation yesterday to learn about the current status of textbook printing under the Indian Credit Line provided to overcome the significant challenge of printing textbooks for the academic year 2023. The Minister also expressed his gratitude to the Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Gopal Bagle and other officials, as well as Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, for intervening to provide paper and other equipment needed for textbook printing under this loan assistance programme. By obtaining raw materials with Indian Credit Line, the State Printing Corporation prints textbooks to meet 45 per cent of the textbook requirement. Dr. Premajayantha, who recalled the country’s long-standing religious, cultural, and trade relations with neighbouring India, also stated that the country’s assistance during a difficult time will help strengthen bilateral relations.

title: Port City visa to be USD 200 per year
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Immigration and Emigration has designed three types of visas for the Colombo Port City Special Economic Zone, namely, employment, investor, and residence visas but the issuance of visas has not yet been authorised. The visa fee, meanwhile, has already been decided to be USD 200 per year for multiple entries. However, this fee will depend on the investor’s agreement and the registration of the business. Depending on these factors, the visa duration would be decided, spokesperson for the Immigration and Emigration Department, Hansika Kumarasinghe told Ceylon Today. She also reiterated there won’t be any special passport, but the visa would have a special sticker and that it is being discussed now. She said they were waiting for the Port City Commission to hear about the visa segment for Port City users and they have so far not been officially informed about when to start issuing visas. However, they are currently working on designing a new visa sticker for the Port City. The Port City Special Economic Zone is a new development project in Colombo. It is intended to be a hub for business and investment in the region. As part of this project, the Government has introduced a special visa category known as the ‘Port City Visa’. The Port City Visa is a multiple-entry visa that allows foreign investors, businesspeople, and professionals to enter and exit Sri Lanka for business purposes without having to apply for a new visa each time. The visa is valid for up to five years and above and is renewable. Residents who lease apartments in the Port City will also be charged according to the duration of their stay and the number of visa entries they require.   By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Railways Dept short of 458 locomotive engineers
author: Author not found
Content: The Railways Department requires 458 locomotive engineers to run operations smoothly, but at present there are only 279 locomotive engineers at the department, Minister of Transport Bandula Gunawardana said. He said approximately ten locomotive engineers retire each year. Paying special attention to this, the Ministry hopes to take action by gathering everyone’s opinions and suggestions. Following this, a special system that will allow the 390 daily train journeys to continue uninterrupted will be devised, he said. He said it is time to set up a proper system without accusing trade unions and the administration. Gunawardana had called a special meeting with all concerned parties to discuss the problems that have arisen in recent days regarding the Sri Lanka Railways Department and some reports published in the media, as well as the department’s present situation. Thus, it was decided to review existing train timetables and make necessary revisions to train drivers’ driving time in accordance with international procedures. Other topics discussed included looking into the possibility of extending the service of experienced drivers who have reached the age of 60-63 and they will be recruited on a contract basis or a service extension programme. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Travel ban on MR temporarily lifted
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (8) temporarily lifted the foreign travel ban imposed on former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa, thereby allowing to travel overseas between 20 and 30 April 2023. This was in connection with the case pertaining to the brutal assault of peaceful protesters near Galle Face Green on 9 April 2022. The Court also temporarily lifted the overseas travel bans imposed on SLPP MPs C. B. Ratnayake and Milan Jayathilake, in connection with the same incident. Counsel on behalf of the former Premier requested the Fort Magistrate to lift the travel ban as their client has to attend a summit to be held in Seoul, South Korea. Taking the request into consideration, the Court acceded to it. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Fuel QR quota to be topped up every Tuesday – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: Power and Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera said yesterday (8) that the National Fuel Pass QR quota will be topped up at midnight every Tuesday going forward. Earlier, the fuel quota was topped up at midnight every Sunday. All accounts had been topped up by last morning (8), the Minister tweeted. “This decision was taken in an effort to reduce the distribution cost attributed to operating the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) and the Ceylon Petroleum Storage Terminals Limited (CPSTL) on weekends,” he added. “However, the weekly fuel quota will remain unchanged,” the Minister said. The National Fuel Pass QR system was introduced in 2022 to mitigate the severe fuel shortage faced by citizens at the time. By Adnan Ali Cassim

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: Schoolchildren were in acute distress after inhaling tear gas fired by the Police to disperse protestors near the University of Colombo yesterday (8). The protest was organised by university students. The Colombo University Students’ Union held the protest to denounce the Police entering the university premises without obtaining approval of the university administration in an attempt to disperse a protest by the Inter University Students’ Federation on the previous day (7). The Police fired tear gas and water cannons to disperse protestors at Cambridge Place yesterday (8). There are many schools located in the vicinity. Schoolchildren were seen coughing and in severe discomfort due to exposure to tear gas. Pix by Sarath Kumara Popular

title: COPE recommends appointing committee headed by retired Judge
author: Author not found
Content: A committee to probe matters raised by the Special Audit Report on the functioning of the Central Cultural Fund between 2015 and 2019 should be appointed, the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) said yesterday (8). The proposed committee will be headed by a retired Judge. The Internal Inquiry Committee appointed by the Secretary to the Ministry to investigate the matters raised in the said Special Audit Report for the purpose of reporting to COPE was discussed at length. Further, in the last COPE meeting, there was a lengthy discussion about holding the meetings of the Governing Council of the Central Cultural Fund and whether the funds have been properly utilised, and the committee members had agreed to discuss the validity of the 209th meeting of the Governing Council at this meeting. Accordingly, the Auditor General pointed out that only seven of the 11 members have agreed to the decisions of the 209th meeting and four including the former Prime Minister have not signed. Noting that there is a discrepancy between the signatures used by the seven signatories on the signature list of this meeting and the signatures used by them in the previous Governing Board meetings, the Auditor General pointed out that the decisions of the 209th Governing Board meeting have not been adopted in the 210th meeting. The Auditor General also stated that the then Prime Minister’s Secretary and the present President’s Secretary, who were members of the relevant Governing Body, confirmed that he was not a party to such a meeting. The Central Cultural Fund is due to be recalled before COPE to review the progress of the previous recommendations made by the commission. This is the third committee appointed to probe the alleged malpractices at the Central Cultural Fund (CCF). Previously, two committees were appointed by then Prime Ministers Mahinda Rajapaksa in 2020 and Ranil Wickremesinghe in 2019 to investigate alleged misappropriation of funds at the CCF from 2016-2019 when the fund was under the purview of Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, the then Housing, Construction and Cultural Affairs Minister. However, outcomes of these probes have not been disclosed to this date. By Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Only three have obtained ‘Golden Paradise’ Visa since 2021
author: Author not found
Content: Only three individuals have obtained Golden Paradise Visas so far. Meanwhile, the Department of Immigration and Emigration is seeking to attract more investors and visitors to Sri Lanka by offering this visa and the deposit has been revised to make it more attractive to potential applicants. The Golden Paradise Visa scheme was launched in 2021. The Department is offering a ‘Golden Paradise’ Visa for individuals who are interested in obtaining 10-year multiple entry visas for both business and residence. The cost of this visa is USD 200,000, however, after one year, USD 100,000 will be reimbursed to the visa holder. Previously, individuals were required to deposit a minimum of USD 100,000 in a commercial bank recognised by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka and were eligible to withdraw USD 50,000 after the first year.     One  Golden Paradise Visa holder is a Chinese investor involved in a luxury apartment complex project in Rajagiriya By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Anti-Corruption Bill to be tabled in Parliament soon
author: Author not found
Content: Since the International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the Government to reduce corruption, the Government expects to present an Anti-Corruption Bill to Parliament in the coming days. Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said Cabinet had previously discussed it and that the Bill was already being drafted by Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe. In exchange for a USD 2.9 billion loan, the IMF has urged Sri Lanka to reduce corruption vulnerabilities by improving fiscal transparency and public financial management, implementing a stronger anti-corruption legal framework, and conducting in-depth governance diagnostics. The IMF on Tuesday said Sri Lanka has now received financial assurances from all major bilateral creditors, which will pave the way for consideration by the IMF’s Board on March 20 the approval of the Staff Level Agreement reached on September 1, 2022 for financing under an Extended Fund Facility. BY ThameenahRazeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: e-Passport in SL from 2024
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s Department of Immigration has announced plans to launch electronic passports, or e-passports, beginning 2024. The proposal for the e-passport, along with the technical and procurement teams has been approved by Cabinet, Controller General of Immigration and Emigration and Commissioner for Registration of Persons of Indian Origin I. S. H. J. Ilukpitiya said. He told Ceylon Today that the Department will advertise for bids in April and any country that offers the best options and lowest cost will be selected. He added that the bidding process will last for one month and the announcement will be made in the public domain. The current biometric passport has been upgraded, but the need has arisen for an e-passport, which will be slightly more expensive than the current passport. Once a passport expires, individuals will have to apply for an e-passport. The chip in the e-passport is designed to provide enhanced security and protect against identity fraud by using biometric technology. A polycarbonate chip, which provides a secure and durable storage medium for the passport holder’s personal information, is commonly used in e-passports. The chip is embedded within the passport’s main detail cover page and contains a microprocessor to store and process information. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Gammanpila slams President
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya MP Udaya Gammanpila said obtaining additional loans is not a solution and will only lead to an economic crisis worse than the current one. He said President Ranil Wickremesinghe proudly announced in Parliament that the IMF facility would be approved this month, and that the President also invited anyone to show him alternatives if his approach was incorrect. “We are prepared to demonstrate why his approach is incorrect and what the genuine alternative is. Once we are out of bankruptcy, his plan is to obtain loan after loan. USD 2.9 billion from the IMF, USD 1.5 billion from the World Bank, USD 1 billion from the Asian Development Bank, and an additional USD 2 billion from the issuance of government bonds. It means that the Government intends to borrow at least USD 7.4 billion over the next three years,” he explained. He told the media yesterday that it should not be forgotten that they will have to start repaying loans in 2025. He claims that in five years, Sri Lanka will be back in the debt trap, leading to an economic crisis worse than the current one. “If we ended in this crisis because of excessive borrowings, how can further borrowings be the solution? The cause and solution of a problem cannot be the same thing. President Gotabaya faced this crisis as a result of the current President’s excessive borrowings from 2015 to 2019. If he makes the same mistake again, the next President will be in big trouble,” he said. In addition, Gammanpila said in a typical year, earnings total USD 23 billion from exports, USD 7 billion from worker remittances, and USD 4 billion from tourism. “We have to spend USD 22 billion for imports.  It means our inward remittance is sufficient to meet the import bills.  Our problem is we need further USD 5 billion to pay back loans.  If we increase our borrowings, our repayment of loans will also be increased, and our dollar outflow will be further burdened,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Gunmen attack 28-year-old
author: Author not found
Content: A 28-year-old man was injured following a shooting reported from Kotuwila, Wellampitiya on 7 March. According to Police two unidentified gunmen had arrived on a motorcycle and shot at the victim and fled the area. The injured person was admitted to the Colombo National Hospital. The victim was identified as a resident of Wellampitiya. Police said a T-56 firearm had been used for the shooting, while it is suspected that a person overseas had planned the shooting. The Wellampitiya Police is conducting investigations. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: SLMMF panel discussion to mark International Women’s Day 2023
author: Author not found
Content: A panel discussion titled ‘The values of women’s rights in the East and West’ organised by Sri the Lanka Muslim Media Forum (SLMMF) to mark International Women’s Day 2023 chaired by Forum’s President Senior broadcaster Furkhan Bee Ifthikhar at Light House Auditorium of the Lakshman Kadirgamar Institute on 12 March beginning 3.30p.m to 6.30p.m. Among the panelists will be former Head of Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) Dr. Deepika Udagama, Prof. Fareena Ruzaik Senior Lecturer of the University of Colombo, Dr. Zaherah Mirjafari of Tehran IR Iran Phd in women and Family Studies and Swasthika Arulingam (Attorney at Law). The  panel discussion will be moderated by Senior Media personality and Editor in Chief of Saturday Express Hana Ibrahim. (NJ)

title: Education Minister thanks China
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha extended his gratitude to China for their donation of school uniform material required by four million Sri Lankan schoolchildren in 2023. China donated 70 per cent of school uniform materials. The donation was made in phases and the final phase of the donation was completed on 3 March. Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka Qi Zhenhong handed over the remaining stock of uniforms to Premajayantha at the Ministry of Education. Further, Premajayantha said the Government will expedite the distribution. It expects to complete distribution before the start of the next school term. The uniform material is given to students of State schools and State-aided schools as well as to student monks studying in pirivenas. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Govt denies Indian eggs tested on soldiers claim
author: Author not found
Content: While emphasising that no eggs have been imported so far, Trade Minister Nalin Fernando denied allegations which claimed that soldiers were given imported eggs on a test run. Speaking in Parliament, he said legal action will be taken against those who spread false rumours. Responding to SJB MP Thushara Indunil Amarasena, who queried as to whether the ministry was planning to import underweight eggs from India, the Minister said Sri Lanka has requested a world recognised quality certificate in this regard and one Indian company has agreed to supply eggs in keeping with the requirements. The Minister said a false story has been spread that the Army was first given the eggs to check and said he would institute legal action against those who spread false rumours. Minister Fernando also said it was the responsibility of the Ministry of Trade to import not only eggs but also products the people could afford in the event of a shortfall. He told Parliament that eggs produced in Sri Lanka weigh about 50 to 55g whereas eggs that are to be imported from India weigh only 35 to 40g. Amarasena said egg prices have risen due to prices of substitute food such as meat, fish, dried fish and canned fish increasing and added that to reduce the demand for eggs, prices of substitute foods should be reduced. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Aqua culture farms to be set up in Palaitivu Island
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister DouglasDevananda has directed that aquaculture farms be set up on the Palaitivu Island in the Poonakary Divisional Secretariat (DS) Division of the Kilinochchi District as soon as possible. This follows the Minister’s inspection tour of the area to investigate the feasibility of setting up aquaculture farms here. During his tour, Devananda also inspected locations where ponds will be built to promote fish breeding and provide people in the region with access to low-cost aquatic resources. The Government has introduced many livelihood methods to improve the living and economic conditions of thousands of local fishery folk while planning to implement many welfare plans towards them and their families, according to Devananda. The Fisheries Minister also focused attention to start aquaculture projects including seaweed and sea cucumber farms with the participation of private sector investors to raise the economic and livelihood standards of people who are depending on fishery for their survival, a senior official attached to the Fisheries Ministry said yesterday (8). BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Paramour, mother arrested over death of six-year-old
author: Author not found
Content: The Hirana Police launched an investigation into the suspicious death of a six-year-old girl inside a house in Pinkella on 7 March. The Police Media Division said the girl was residing with her mother and the mother’s paramour. It was revealed that the girl had been ill for several days and had not been given medical attention. She was also a speech and hearing impaired. Investigations revealed that the child had been physically assaulted by her mother’s paramour on multiple occasions previously. According to Police, the girl was found with several scars and swellings on her body. The 25-year-old mother and the woman’s 29-year-old paramour were arrested over the death. The magisterial inquiry into the death was conducted, while the body was at the Colombo South Teaching Hospital in Kalubowila for the postmortem examination. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Letter of Intent signed for USD 2.9B IMF bailout package
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe informed Parliament yesterday (7) that he received a financial assurance letter from the Exim Bank of China on Monday (6) night and the Letter of Intent, which he signed with the Governor of the Central Bank, was sent to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to obtain its assistance to overcome the present economic crisis in the country. The assurance of China with regard to debt restructuring had been a major hurdle for Sri Lanka to obtain the USD 2.9 billion IMF bailout package.  “I completed my obligation to the country and I anticipate that the IMF will fulfil its responsibility prior to the end of this month,” the President said, delivering a special statement on Sri Lanka’s present economic situation and the progress made with the IMF. Wickremesinghe warned if the ongoing programme implemented by the Government is disrupted, the country could be pushed to an even more perilous state than it experienced in February and March of 2022. The President also said an election can be held once normalcy is restored. However, he did not mention about holding the Local Government Election 2023 which has been postponed. The President only spoke about the Presidential and General Elections in his speech. The Government had to revert to the same tax policy implemented in 2019. After the emergency tax cuts implemented at the end of 2019, Government revenues fell by as much as 8 per cent of GDP. “To restore it, we had to go for new tax policies,” he said. “Similarly, interest rates had to be raised under the Central Bank’s monetary policies. Raising interest rates was a positive step we had to take to control the rising inflation. By September last year, average inflation had risen to around 70 per cent. Food inflation crossed the 90 per cent mark.” However, at present the rate of inflation has decreased to approximately 50 per cent, and food inflation has also dropped to 54 per cent. In addition, due to a shortage of foreign exchange, exchange regulations were tightened, and imports were limited. “Starting in 2021, the IMF has been issuing constant warnings about Sri Lanka’s economic crisis, specifically regarding the foreign exchange crisis. Since mid-2022, discussions between the IMF and Sri Lanka have been ongoing, with regular delegations visiting the country for extensive talks concerning the balance of payments, fiscal crisis, and foreign exchange crisis. Further, the IMF has emphasised the need to implement long-overdue structural reforms, stating that there is no room for delay.” “We had a staff-level agreement with the IMF by 1 September 2022, but the IMF stated that the agreement couldn’t be presented to the Executive Board until our country achieves debt sustainability. To achieve debt sustainability, the Government continued discussions with creditors and sought the help of international agencies such as Lazard and Clifford Chance. The discussions were lengthy and complex. Accordingly, discussions were held with both Paris Club and non-Paris Club creditors, including India and China, who have provided loans to Sri Lanka, to secure financing assurances. India provided their assurance on 16 January while China extended their assurance on 18 January. The Paris Club agreed to provide financing assurances to Sri Lanka at their meeting held on 25 January. In addition, we had lengthy discussions with India and China as well. Subsequently, I discussed with the Managing Director of the IMF Kristalina Georgieva about an Extended Fund Facility Arrangement on 2 March. On Monday (6) evening, I discussed with the United States Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen as well. The Government had to fulfil the requirements set by the IMF, which included revisions to electricity tariffs and fossil fuel prices, ensuring the independence of the CBSL, and increasing interest rates to control inflation, reforming public enterprises, strengthening the social safety net, working to increase public revenue and controlling public expenditure. Expanding competition in the petroleum and electricity sectors had to be done in advance. Those tasks that Sri Lanka should have done proactively have been completed by now.” The President, who apologised to the public for all the sufferings they have to undergo, said this time, there is no room for failure in completing every task agreed on with the IMF, unlike the previous 16 occasions. “If the existing agreement with the IMF is breached, foreign economic activities will be largely hindered, and we would have to pay loans taken from foreign countries and private banks,” he pointed out. “We accept the people’s right to freedom of speech. But that should be done peacefully. Holding meetings and holding protests is not a problem. But I would like to say that if this programme is disrupted through this agitation, this government will act strongly on it,” the President said. “We can decide on holding an election, be it a Presidential Election or General Election when the country is stabilised. A decision about it will be taken by the country. What I’m asking is whether y’all are ready or not for this (journey of reviving the economy). You can accept or reject my invitation. It is totally up to you,” the President asserted. By Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Electricity bills not issued for four months
author: Author not found
Content: The CEB has failed to issue electricity bills to consumers in Menikwatta, Wanarajawatta in Hatton-Dickoya, for the past four months and owing to that scores of consumers have been severely inconvenienced. Several estates in the Wanarajawatta and Menikwatta are being served by the Hatton Electricity Consumer Service Centre. Residents of these estates said the last occasion they had been issued electricity bills, by the Ginigathhena Regional Electricity Engineer’s Office, was in October 2022. The consumers on these estates mentioned that failure to issue monthly electricity bills could further exacerbate as the final tally to be paid could be exorbitant and they do not have sufficient incomes to do so. When contacted an official from the Ginigathhena Regional Electricity Engineer’s Office agreed that they had not been able to issue electricity bills for the past four months, as they do not have the adequate number of meter readers. But, he assured that the bills will be issued promptly and separately for the consumers for the months concerned while providing them a relief period to pay the bills. By Neeta PathmaKumari – Norwood

title: Police fire tear gas, water cannons at IUSF protesters
author: Author not found
Content: The Police fired tear gas and water cannons at Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) protesters near the University of Colombo yesterday (7). The IUSF protest was scheduled to kick off from Colombo Fort, but later it was decided to launch the protest march from the University of Colombo. The students alleged that the Police followed the protesting students into the university premises and fired tear gas into the lecture halls. (NV)

title: EC suggests 25 April for LG Polls
author: Author not found
Content: The Election Commission (EC) announced yesterday (7) that it recommends 25 April as the ‘most suitable’ date to hold the Local Government Election 2023. In a statement, the EC said it had directed the District Returning Officers to make an announcement with regard to the election date. In a special Gazette Notification, dated 30 January 2023, issued by the respective District Returning Officers for the LG bodies of each district, under Sub-section 38(1)(c) of the Local Authorities Elections Ordinance, it was announced that the LG election would be held on 9 March. The commission later announced that the election could not be held as scheduled due to “unexpected and unavoidable reasons,” mainly the lack of funds. However, the Supreme Court issued an interim order last week preventing the Finance Ministry Secretary and the Attorney General from withholding the funds allocated for election purposes in Budget 2023. Meanwhile, a group of MPs of Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), National People’s Power (NPP), Freedom People’s Alliance, Tamil National Alliance (TNA) and other parties representing the Opposition convened a meeting at the Election Commission this morning to discuss the matters pertaining to the election. Also, discussions were held between the EC, the Government Printer and the Inspector General of Police (IGP) yesterday. Although the Finance Ministry Secretary was supposed to be at the meeting, he did not participate. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Women MPs call for better investigative mechanism
author: Author not found
Content: The Women Parliamentarians’ Caucus (WPC), issuing a special statement coinciding with International Women’s Day 2023, said Sri Lanka needs a more effective and efficient complaint and investigative mechanism to regulate gender-based violence on digital platforms. WPC proposes to develop a more effective and efficient complaint and investigative mechanism to regulate gender-based violence on digital platforms to safeguard the well-being and dignity of women and girls.  WPC also says that it is necessary to increase awareness on digital gender-based violence and safer means of using digital platforms among the public. The statement was issued by Dr. Sudarshani Fernandopulle, Chairperson of the Women Parliamentarians’ Caucus to mark International Women’s Day, which falls today (8). “On 8 March 2023, we commemorate International Women’s Day which is observed with an overall objective of promoting the understanding of issues faced by women striving for greater gender equality and women’s empowerment, while celebrating the progress made so far towards achieving such goals. Whereas an international day dedicated towards women might appear inconsequential, the observance of this day is crucial in creating public awareness on women’s rights and issues faced by women, and above all it is a powerful advocacy tool to mobilise political will and resources to realise gender equality and women’s empowerment.” It was emphasised that in order to cater to the changing world and the problems that come hand in hand with it, the theme for this year’s International Women’s Day is ‘DigitALL: Innovation and technology for gender equality.’ “With the advancement of technology and globalisation, the challenges that women face have changed. However, prejudices and stereotypical beliefs still stand in the way of women realising their full potential, even in the 21st century. In light of the pandemic and the resultant movement restrictions imposed, life on earth drastically changed with many activities, ranging from professional work, education and social activities, being transformed and transferred to the online digital world. Online education and working from home have now become the norm in many post-pandemic societies, including Sri Lanka. Therefore, the use of digital spaces and devices increased drastically, particularly among children, as parents permitted children to access the Internet and use smartphones in order to facilitate online education.” WPC emphasised that while the overall usage of online and digital spaces and devices have increased, a considerable part of the country is prevented from accessing the Internet altogether due to problems ranging from connectivity issues to the inability to purchase digital devices due to economic constraints.  “This is particularly detrimental to children whereas online education has become the new norm. It also appears that in instances where a family could afford just one device, the male child is given preference over the female child to use the device due to prejudicial beliefs. It is reported worldwide that the digital literacy is lower for women than for men due to the limitations faced by women in their access to devices, networks and data.” However, WPC noted that if it is also not used correctly, the Internet could very easily become a medium to propagate violence and harassment. “Complaints made to the Sri Lanka Computer Emergency Readiness Team (SLCERT) and National Child Protection Authority (NCPA) by distressed individuals and parents reached a record-high by a pandemic-hit society. The victims of most such instances were women and girls. Therefore, increasing awareness on digital gender-based violence and safer means of using digital platforms among the public is an imperative,” WPC said. In view of the above, the WPC also said it has strengthened its efforts to initiate discussions to mobilise resources for improved accessibility to the Internet and to improve regulations to prevent digital gender-based violence. While acknowledging there is still a long way to go, the WPC said it is committed to its undertaking to empower women, and create an enabling environment that promotes, protects and supports the digital rights, well-being and dignity of women and girls.

title: Susil apologises to Rohini
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha expressed remorse and apologised to Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Rohini Kaviratne over using unparliamentary language on her in the Parliament Chamber on 24 February. “I deeply regret my remarks on that day. I did not intend to use such words on anyone. I am sorry if I caused any hurt,” he told Kaviratne.  In response Kaviratne raised concerns whether the Speaker and Prime Minister accepted such obscene language in Parliament and if the matter has been removed from the Hansard. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Decision on fuller Bench for Sirisena’s Writ Petition on 14 March
author: Author not found
Content: The decision whether or not a fuller Appeal Court Bench will be appointed to hear the Writ Application, filed by former President Maithripala Sirisena, challenging the issuance of summons to him, by the Fort Magistrate, in relation to the 2019 Easter Sunday attack, will be delivered by the Court of Appeal on 14 March. The Court of Appeal two-Judge-Bench comprising Justices Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and M.A.R. Marikkar made this order after considering a motion, filed on behalf of Rev. Father Cyril Gamini, seeking a fuller Appellate Court Bench to hear the Petition filed by Sirisena. While a motion requesting for the appointment of a fuller Bench should only be filed before a Bench comprising the President of the Court of Appeal, the motion was thereby filed before Justice Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne (President) and the relevant decision will be issued on 14 March. A Private Plaint was filed by Rev. Father Gamini and a victim of the Easter Sunday attack, Jesudasan Nadesan, before the Fort Magistrate on 16 September 2022, alleging that Sirisena had failed to order the arrest of Zahran Hashim and his followers, to oversee their arrest, to prevent the murder of those who do not profess the Islamic faith, thus resulting in omissions in terms of the Penal Code. Oral submissions were made on behalf of the complainants and the Fort Magistrate made an order issuing summons on Sirisena requiring him to be present before the Fort Magistrate’s Court on 14 October 2022. Sirisena, through the Writ Application, observed that the Magistrate has failed to exercise his discretion properly in deciding to issue summons and has erred in law in acting upon hearsay. It was noted that the Magistrate has acted on inadmissible material and that the complainants have wilfully misrepresented facts and as such, the Fort Magistrate has misdirected himself on the material facts and that complainants have wilfully suppressed material facts, mainly that there was a State Minster of Defence overlooking the Department of the Police and the Armed Forces and Intelligence agencies during the relevant period. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Transport of animals and products from North banned due to LSD
author: Author not found
Content: The transportation of animals and animal products from the Northern Province has been temporarily banned, due to the spread of Lumpy Skin Disease (LSD) amongst Cattle in the Mullaitivu District. According to the Livestock Development Division, of the Ministry of Agriculture, LSD is a virus that forms lumps on cattle skin. Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera noted that if the disease spreads, it will primarily affect the production of milk.  Additional Secretary of the ministry Dr. L. W. N. Samaranayake said the condition was first reported in Sri Lanka in 2019, adding that there is however a low mortality rate amongst cattle infected with this virus and that they often heal with treatment.   He added that cattle once infected with the disease have no possibility of contracting the disease again. ’’This disease does not spread by wind like foot and mouth disease. The only way the virus spreads is through direct contact with other animals. Therefore, the sick animals should be kept away from the cowsheds and isolated, ‘’he said. Amaraweera instructed the Livestock Development Division to promptly investigate the situation and take necessary action in consultation with veterinarians. He noted that the Ministry of Agriculture has already taken a number of measures to prevent diseases in districts such as Nuwara Eliya, where animal husbandry is practiced on a large scale.  While stating that there is no need to be afraid of LSD, as the death of infected cows is at a minimum level, he added however that if the disease spreads, it will primarily affect the production of milk, due to which those involved in cattle management should be vigilant. (FT)

title: Sajith accuses Govt of blocking Treasury Secy meeting EC
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa accused the Government of preventing the Finance Ministry (FM) Secretary from participating in the crucial meeting with the Election Commission yesterday (7), to determine a fresh date to hold the delayed Local Government Election 2023. Speaking in Parliament Premadasa alleged the Government prevented the Finance Ministry Secretary from attending the meeting. Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said, in the House, that the Finance Ministry Secretary could not participate in the meetings as there was a meeting of the National Security Council (NSC).   However, Premadasa did not accept the answer and said it was a blatant lie that there was an NSC meeting and questioned how come there was an NSC meeting when the President, Prime Minister and the Defence Minister were present in the House. In response to these allegations PM Gunawardena said, the President came to Parliament after participating in the NSC meeting and as the Prime Minister, he informed the President he would not attend the meeting. He added that an NSC meets every Tuesday and that it is not compulsory for the President to inform about that to the public.  BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Parliament heats up over COPF chairmanship
author: Author not found
Content: A heated situation arose, once again, in the Parliament Chamber yesterday (7) over the chairmanship of the Committee on Public Finance (COPF), after Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena announced that SJB MP Mayantha Dissanayake officially handed over resignation from the post. The Opposition questioned UNP MP Wajira Abeywardena’s being appointed as the Acting Chairperson of the committee. The Speaker announced that after Dissanayake’s resignation, the Parliament Committee of Selection will meet on 4 April to appoint a new Chairperson.  At this juncture, Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella questioned why Abeywardena was appointed as the Acting Chairperson of COPF. Kiriella claimed that Abeywardena has been temporarily given the chairmanship of COPF and that it is against the Standing Orders. He emphasised that according to the Standing Orders, an Opposition member should be made the chairperson to maintain stability. Even if it’s temporary the chairperson should be from the Opposition, he stressed. Meanwhile, State Minister Suren Raghavan said it was clearly stated that Acting Chairperson could be elected and Patali Champika Ranawaka’s name was proposed. However, as MP Ranawaka refused to take the post, MP Abeywardena was made the chairperson temporarily, State Minister Raghavan said. Minister Manusha Nanayakkara, who joined the conversation, said any MP is capable of holding the position of Chairman of the COPF. Nanayakkara also said that Mayantha Dissanayake was forced to resign owing to internal problems of the SJB. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Volunteer task force to combat poaching
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said arrangements have been made to form a volunteer task force, in addition to the Sri Lanka Coast Guard, to combat poaching in Sri Lanka’s territorial waters off the Northern coast. According to Devananda, the poaching of Indian fishermen in Sri Lankan waters is on the rise and the costs to the country’s fisheries industry and economy are too high. A long-term solution to this problem must be found soon. He emphasised this during the recently held Jaffna District Coordinating Committee Meeting, over which he presided, according to a senior official attached to the Fisheries Ministry (7). “Apart from Indian fishermen, locals are also engaged in illegal fishing in the Northern and Eastern regions. If those activities were not stopped the country’s fisheries industry would suffer tremendously very soon,” Devananda said. He said that attention has been focused on including the local fishermen, too, who show more enthusiasm to protect the country’s fisheries industry through a task force. It has been reported that narcotics are sold under the guise of selling peanut and sweets targeting the students near schools in the Northern Province. Expeditious action must be taken to bring the wrongdoers before the law. Steps will be taken to rehabilitate those who are addicted to narcotics in consultation with the Minister of Justice and Prison Reforms, Devananda added. BY Naalir Jamaldeen
