title: Sri Lanka’S FISH PRODUCTION FALLS TO 12-YEAR LOW
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s (SL’s) fish production fell to a 12-year low last year (2022), scarred by the country’s kerosene oil and diesel shortages due to Sri Lanka lacking US dollars to import the same, Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) data from yesterday (7) showed. Sri Lanka’s total fish production, both marine and inland, registered a figure of 397 million kilos (kg) last year, whereas in the Covid-19 impacted years of 2020 and 2021 which restricted movements, however, registered higher fishery catch figures of 429 million and 435 million kg, respectively. Seventy five per cent of Sri Lanka’s fishery catch comprises marine fishery, data showed while only 25 per cent is inland fishery. Meanwhile, a lower figure than last year’s marine catch of 397 million kg took place 12 years ago in 2010 (381 million kg) before gradually ascending to 445 million kg (2011), 486 million kg (2012), 513 million kg (2013), 535 million kg (2014), 520 million kg (2015), 531 million kg (2016 and 2017 respectively), 527 million kg (2018), 506 million kg (2019), 429 million kg (2020), 435 million kg (2021) and 397 million kg (2022). In the immediate aftermath of the 26 December 2004 tsunami, the fish catch in the following year 2005 fell to 163 million kg from 286 million kg in 2005, before picking up from 2006 (251 million kg), 2007 (291 million kg), 2008 (319 million kg) and 2009 (340 million kg), respectively. The above reference years 2004 to 2009 were also scarred by the LTTE war which impacted fishery, particularly off the Northern and Eastern provinces of Sri Lanka. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Five arrested over three-wheeler robbery
author: Author not found
Content: Five suspects were arrested on 6 March over the robbery of a three-wheeler in Boralesgamuwa. Boralesgamuwa Police made the arrest after conducting investigations following a complaint lodged with them regarding a stolen three-wheeler. Accordingly, five suspects were taken into Police custody. Police also seized three stolen three-wheelers based on information elicited during interrogations. The suspects were identified as individuals aged between 23 and 32 years and are residents of Dehiwala, Nawalapitiya, Rosella, Hatton and Kotagala. They were scheduled to be produced before the Nugegoda Magistrate’s Court yesterday (7) and Boralesgamuwa Police are conducting further investigations. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: LG PollS to be held in several stages?
author: Author not found
Content: A crucial discussion, between the Election Commission (EC) and the Finance Ministry Secretary, will take place today (7) on holding of the Local Government Election 2023. A proposal on holding the election in several stages will be forwarded during this discussion, Ceylon Today reliably learns. According to highly placed EC sources, the election will be held in stages according to the Finance Ministry’s ability to release the required funds. Therefore, the election would take place in different districts on different dates. If the election is held in several stages, several dates would have to be announced as election dates. It is reported that this proposal will be taken into consideration during today’s discussion. If both parties are agreeable, then another discussion will be held with all parties and independent groups that have submitted nominations for the election. Apart from the Finance Ministry Secretary, the EC will meet the Inspector General of Police (IGP), the Government Printer, the Postmaster General and several other officials. Furthermore, another discussion will be held with political party secretaries and representatives today (7). BY J.T. de Silva

title: Several train runs cancelled today
author: Author not found
Content: Several daily train journeys will be cancelled in coming days due to current locomotive engineer and driver assistant vacancies, Deputy General Manager of Railways M.J. Indipolage said. He said approximately 24 provincial train journeys were cancelled yesterday (6). He also said a long-distance train, six parcel and cargo trains, and several regional trains to Matale, Kandy, Nawalapitiya, Gal Oya, Trincomalee, and Batticaloa were cancelled. Indipolage highlighted that locomotive engineers and driver assistants should be assigned by the sub-department of Railways to run the trains, but the department has informed him that this is not possible. He said five employees who turned 60 in 2023 have retired, and nine workers retired by 31 December 2022. “Long-distance trains are understaffed and the majority of senior drivers are inexperienced. This situation will mostly affect long distance trains. Office trains will likely be less affected,” he noted. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Bread price expected to drop
author: Author not found
Content: As a result of consumers being reluctant to buy bakery items, due to high prices, a price decrease in bakery products can be expected. The price of a loaf of bread is expected to be reduced to Rs 100, the All Ceylon Bakery Owners’ Association (ACBOA) said. N.K. Jayawardena, the president of the ACBOA, said the bakery industry is paralysed because the products cannot be sold due to high prices. As a result, a price increase of bakery products will not happen in the future, only a price decrease can be expected, he claimed.  Jayawardena pointed out that a loaf of bread is now sold at Rs 150 – 180 and it is expected to reduce the price of a loaf toRs 100. He also said that due to the increase in electricity tariffs, the bakery industry has been greatly affected. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Ban Rs 5,000 currency note to tackle black money – ALDIP
author: Author not found
Content: The Association of Leasing and Debt Instalment Payers (ALDIP) said that if the Government wants to tackle black money in the country, it should ban Rs 5,000 currency notes. Addressing the media, on leasing ‘mafia’, President of the association Asanka Ruwan Pothupitiya said the Inspector General of Police (IGP) has issued an order prohibiting the forcible seizure of vehicles and that several individuals involved in forcibly seizing vehicles have been arrested and are in remand. “We understand that paying off debt is a responsibility. However, there is a mafia in action on vehicle leasing. This is a daylight robbery because some leasing companies are like leeches and they increase the instalments, as they wish, without giving any thought about the customer. We can’t pay money like that. It is unfair by the customers. The Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) should be held accountable for the daylight robberies carried out by these non-banking financial institutions. The customers have been cheated in many ways by these companies. First they charge instalments that the customer can’t bear. Then they came up with moratoriums and trapped customers. Now, those who leased the vehicles can’t pay instalments,” he elaborated. When the customer is in the debt trap created by the companies, the vehicles are forcibly seized using thugs and organised gangs, he said, adding  “We have now filed over 50 lawsuits against those who forcibly seized the vehicles. They have pleaded guilty for that in Court. We will file more lawsuits against individuals and institutions involved in forcible vehicle seizure. We will fight for the people,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Ali Sabry attends India’s Raisina Dialogue
author: Author not found
Content: Foreign Affairs Minister Ali Sabry paid an official visit to New Delhi to attend Raisina Dialogue – 2023, India’s premier conference on geopolitics and geo-economics, jointly hosted by the Observer Research Foundation in partnership with the Ministry of External Affairs of India from 02-04 March. The opening session of the Dialogue was inaugurated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the Prime Minister of Italy Giorgia Meloni.  On the side-lines, Foreign Minister Ali Sabry met the External Affairs Minister of India Dr. S. Jaishankar on 4 March for bilateral talks at the Hyderabad House in New Delhi. Minister Sabry briefed Minister Jaishankar on the current developments in Sri Lanka as well as on the status of the country’s debt restructuring process and the negotiations on the IMF programme. The two Ministers reviewed the present status of on-going economic cooperation and discussed the way forward. Minister Sabry followed up on the invitation that was extended to President Ranil Wickremesinghe by Prime Minister Narendra Modi to undertake a visit to India. Ali Sabry also held bilateral meetings with the Foreign Minister of Türkiye Mevlüt  Çavuşoğlu, Foreign Minister of South Africa Dr. Naledi Pandor, Foreign Minister of Brazil Mauro Vieira and Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign & European Affairs Minister of Slovenia Tanja Fajon with a view to strengthening relations and cooperation with those countries. He also had several interactions with the New Delhi-based media. On 3 March Minister Sabry engaged in ‘Lunch Conversation with Raisina Young Fellows’ under the theme ‘Healing a Divided World’ and the Minister conversed on how democratic societies should respond to polarisation and the role of the leaders in that process. Following this, the Minister was in a one-on-one conversation with the Chairman of the Observer Research Foundation Sunjoy Joshi at ‘Raisina Ideas Pod’ and spoke on the current economic situation in Sri Lanka and country’s path to recovery. Minister Sabry was also a panellist of the Plenary Panel Discussion, ‘Bytes of Promise: How Can Technology Lift Communities’ where he spoke on the infrastructural and financial barriers to the spread of digital technology; importance of skill upgrading; how digitalisation can enhance resilience and the need for sound policies and platforms to leverage technology for the uplift of communities.  Minister Sabry was accompanied by senior officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the High Commission of Sri Lanka in New Delhi.

title: Private bus operators lose Rs 500M due to protests – Gemunu
author: Author not found
Content: Around Rs 500 million in income loss has been incurred by the private bus sector, due to the anti-Government protests held in the Western Province since January 2023, Lanka Private Bus Owners’ Association (LPBOA) Chairman Gemunu Wijeratne claimed. Speaking to Ceylon Today, Wijeratne said when there is a protest, a they lose around Rs 10 million daily.  “Due to protests, we had to reduce the daily bus trips and a large volume of fuel was wasted on the road waiting in traffic. Including this fuel wastage, the total loss is closer to Rs 10 million per day in the Western province due to protests,” Wijeratne said. He added when compared to other provinces, the private bus sector in the Western Province suffered a heavy loss “State sector employees conduct protests while receiving salaries at the end of each month. But we have to make an income daily for our living. These protests do not affect the SLTB employees because they too receive a monthly salary,” he said. Therefore, Wijerathne said they had informed the Police earlier to ease the traffic congestion during protests or direct the protesters to areas where they would not be a hindrance to the traffic flow. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Professionals have a duty to pay tax – Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: Although professionals in the country are facing difficulties due to the newly introduced income tax scheme, as people who benefitted from Free Education in the country, those professionals have a duty and responsibility to uplift the lives of common people, who receive even less than the salaries of professionals after paying tax, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said. Addressing the media after a programme in Bulathkohupitiya, he said the country is gradually recovering from the economic crisis and paying taxes in the correct manner is essential for the economic growth. “One of the main reasons for the current crisis was that we cut taxes a few years ago. The PAYE tax was there and after 2019, we closed about 1.5 million files following the tax cuts. Now we are introducing an income tax scheme again and the amounts in taxes have been slightly increased. According to the new tax scheme, a person who earns Rs 150,000 pays Rs 3,000 as monthly tax. Only 2.6 per cent of the work force of the country earns more than Rs 100,000. A majority of them earn only between Rs 100,000 – Rs 150,000,” the State Minister claimed. BY Asela Wickramanayake – Bulathkohupitiya

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Foreign Ministry in a quandary
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is in a difficult situation as a result of pressure from political bigwigs to appoint their family members and relatives to diplomatic posts, Ceylon Today learns. At the moment, there are 98 vacancies in diplomatic missions to be filled as only 166 vacancies have been filled from the approved Foreign Service cadre of 264 posts. This situation has resulted in several political bigwigs who have strong ties with the Government pressuring the Ministry to give the vacant posts to their family members and relatives.

title: Illegal constructions in Kurunegala town to be removed
author: Author not found
Content: Illegally constructed and unauthorised shops in the Kurunegala town and the main bus stand will be removed today (7), on the instructions of the North Western Province Governor. It was reported that a large number of shops have been constructed illegally and business has been conducted without obtaining a permit from Kurunegala Municipal Council. Due to these unauthorised and illegal constructions, the area of the main bus station has become unsafe for the passengers. Also, ownerships of many of these illegally operating shops have been transferred for large sums of money and political influence. Considering these facts, the Governor has instructed the removal of those shops. BY Ravindu Sooriyabandara – Kurunegala

title: Cowpox kills 67 cattle in two days
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 67 head of cattle have died of cowpox in several areas of Kilinochchi, in the past two days. Most of the deaths have been reported from Pooneryn, Karachi, Palai and Urutirapuram in Kilinochchi. According to veterinary officials, this disease primarily affects young cattle. They develop large blisters all over their body and it begins to fade away after contracting the fever. Cowpox killed 3,347 cows in Kilinochchi in 2000. Cowpox is a viral disease which is carried by flies, and mosquitoes. This time, the number of cattle dying of cowpox in Kilinochchi is on the increase because no cure has been discovered so far. BY Rasadi Chaturangi Gamage – Vavuniya

title: A million pending Court cases in SL
author: Author not found
Content: There were over a million Court cases pending in Sri Lanka as at 30 June 2022, a recently released Justice Ministry publication said. The publication titled ‘Progress Report 2022-January to September’, further said that the number of such pending cases, which totalled 1,064,882 (1.1million), saw  that the highest number of such cases in Magistrate’s Courts (764,536), followed by District Courts (269,378),  High Courts criminal (30,030), Commercial High Courts (8,018),  Civil Appellate High Courts (7,030), Labour Tribunals (5,543),  Supreme Court (5,236), Appeal Court (3,506), Children’s Magistrate’s Courts (1,632) and Special High Courts (three). In this regard, the Ministry said, “Long delays in settling Court cases have discouraged foreign investment in Sri Lanka.”  It also said, “For a considerable period of time, long term delays in Court cases have been witnessed. The backlog of cases in Courts in Sri Lanka, as at 30.06.2022 is 1,094,912. The number of Judges for hearing those huge number of cases is 15 per one million of the population, but with the recent recruitment of judges, this ratio has increased 18 per one million of Sri Lanka’s population. However, this is very low in comparison to the international standard and may have caused to drag down Sri Lanka in international grading.” The report further said that to rectify these shortcomings, “It is expected to review the situation and prepare and implement a revised plan for implementation as soon as the economic situation is of the country is back to normal. As of present there are 24,000 prison inmates. All measures have now been taken to manage prison overcrowding.” BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Medicine procurement manipulated by some MPs – ACMOA
author: Author not found
Content: The All Ceylon Medical Officers’ Association (ACMOA) alleged that at least three to five major medicinal drug companies have tied with some MPs and therefore, the procurement process has been manipulated to ensure those companies are benefitted. Co-Convener of the All Ceylon Medical Officers’ Association (ACMOA) Dr. Jayantha Bandara, who spoke about the current medicinal drug shortage in the country, alleged there is a matter regarding the commissions that politicians and officials received during importation as well. Dr. Bandara said that the Government’s corrupt method of procuring pharmaceuticals has been the main cause of the prevailing crisis. Dr. Bandara when contacted yesterday (06), alleged that at least 70 to 75 per cent of the funds spent on purchasing pharmaceuticals has been pilfered by pharmaceutical companies which acted as intermediaries for the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC).  Leave aside the Government’s excuse of the prevailing economic crisis, it is unable to even utilise the available funds to purchase the necessary medicinal drugs, reagents and consumables to battle the prevailing shortage as a result, he alleged. “The SPC is affiliated to the Health Ministry and is tasked with importing medicinal pharmaceuticals – especially medicinal drugs, consumables and reagents to distribute them to State hospitals and to import raw materials to manufacture medicinal drugs locally.  The SPC has failed in its duty due to the machinations of the vested government interests,” he alleged.   Instead of utilising the SPC to its fullest capacity, the Health Ministry, through the SPC, imports a major portion of the medicinal drugs and reagent, paying a lion’s share to intermediaries, spending four or five times more than the actual cost. Citing an example, Dr. Bandara alleged that when there should only be a maximum difference of about 200% from procurement to retail, there was a 500 to 1000% difference incurred by the SPC when purchasing medicines through Pharmaceutical companies. Dr. Bandara lamented that there was also the issue with regard to the fast depleting human resource of the Health Ministry. Unconfirmed numbers have it that at least 2,000 medical practitioners had left the country for greener pastures. There is large number of medical practitioners currently engaged in study courses in a bid to leave the country, he noted. With the increasing cost of living, the government and Health Ministry have found a way to reduce the wages of all health sector employees. As a result, these doctors do not have much choice but to leave the country, he noted. Dr. Bandara accused the government of not having a proper plan to at least control the current situation. Dr. Bandara warned that his outfit would stage a token strike tomorrow (8) taking into consideration the above grievances. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Mother of three killed by husband
author: Author not found
Content: A mother of three children was killed by her husband following a dispute on Sunday (5) The woman was killed in the couple’s house at Parussagoda, and the suspect was arrested by Uragasmanhandiya Police. According to the Police the wife had taken their three children and gone to her mother’s place on 3 March, after a heated argument with her husband. The husband had later brought them back to their house. However, the wife was killed following another dispute. The victim was identified as a 34-year-old and the suspect as 51 years old. Uragasmanhandiya Police are conducting investigations. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi
